DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: 7 allied Officers Killed in Iraq.
Fighters with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades overwhelmed two cars of armed Spanish inteligence officers on a heavily traveled highway, killing seven of the eight agents aboard in a brief but fierce battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: SIA pilots: Law to be tightened.
The Singapore Government yesterday hardened its stand on Singapore Airlines (SIA) pilots, saying it will tighten the law to remove union members' right to have the final say in any negotiations with management.
The Lianhe Zaobao: To prevent another confrontation between SIA and Alpa-S, Singapre Govt will amend the law.
To prevent another a cycle of acrimony, Ministry of Manpower will amend the Trade Unions Act to ensure that the rules of registered trade unions enable executive committees to negotiate and commit to collective agreements without the need for formal ratification by the general membership or the branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT TO AMEND TRADE UNIONS ACT

TEXT.P: After several warnings by government ministers to the Singapore Airlines (SIA) pilots' union, the Singaporean government has taken the first step to what it says is "preventing another cycle of acrimony between management and the pilots' union."
The government announced Monday in a statement that it will amend the Trade Unions Act, a process which is likely to take several months.

The recent ouster of the leadership of the Airline Pilots Association of Singapore (ALPA-S) led three government ministers to warn the pilots not to embark on "confrontational industrial relations" or "take on the government."
The amendment will allow executive committees of trade unions to negotiate and commit to collective agreements without having to go back to its members for approval.
The ALPA-S is the only trade union in Singapore where members have to approve agreements struck by its executive committee.

The government noted that the ALPA-S and the SIA management have had a troubled relationship, with protracted negotiations often resulting in deadlock. Between 1980 and this year, 25 disputes between the two sides had to go before the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) for conciliation.

This year, SIA management negotiated with the pilots' union as SARS hit the travel industry. The MOM and the Industrial Arbitration Court had to be called in to help settle the wage-cut package. However, after an agreement was reached, 55 percent of the ALPA-S members voted out the negotiating team.

The government emphasized that both SIA management and the pilots must put the past behind them and start anew. It said SIA must improve its human resource management so that the emphasis is not entirely on the pilots and management has to pay competitive wages and incentives to staff.
The government statement stressed that aviation is a key industry, pointing out that SARS, terrorism, low-cost airlines and other developments challenge Singapore's status as a premier air hub.
It added that confrontational industrial relations will add to the problems of SIA and so put jobs at risk.
The statement ended by saying that the government will not allow any group to undermine good industrial relations based on the partnership between unions, management and the government.

A member of the ALPA-S executive committee said he is surprised the government has resorted to amending the Trade Unions Act. Captain P. James, vice president of industrial relations, said ALPA-S members will be unhappy with the move because it will remove one of their rights.

James said he disagrees that the pilots' union has been confrontational by sacking its leadership. pointing out that it was just an internal constitutional process which was followed and initiated to change the leadership.
He said SIA should treat its employees as partners in this process, and not just as something with a price tag that can be replaced.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Two Japanese envoys killed in Iraq; Seven Spainish intelligence agents slain In separate ambush.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REFUSES TO RULE OUT OPTION FOR VOIDING REFERENDUM BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has not yet decided whether to ask the Legislative Yuan to reconsider a referendum bill that the Executive Yuan considers "flawed", Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

Although President Chen Shui-bian said he will call a referendum March 20 whatever the outcome of the present controversy, it will not stop the Executive Yuan from turning the bill back over to the Legislative Yuan, as that is another issue altogether, Yu went on.
The Executive Yuan will not show its hand before being given formal notice by the Legislative Yuan of the passage of the bill.

In a related development that day, an appeal for a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices on the "unconstitutionality" of the bill has already won the endorsement of 81 lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), far more than the number required for such an appeal.

Condemning the opposition of Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) for steam-rolling through the legislature a bill rife with flaws, the ruling party lawmakers are trying to annul the bill through a Council of Grand Justice ruling, which is empowered to strike down "unconstitutional" laws.
Instead of giving people a full right of referendum, they said, the bill restricts the public's right to initiate amendments to Constitution, while giving this right over to the legislature.
However, the appeal was not presented to the council immediately because the bill has not yet been promulgated by the president.

The KMT and PFP lawmakers, boosted by their victory in pushing through the bill, moved on to seek sponsors among their colleagues in the legislature for a proposal to revise the Constitution with the dual aims of writing the newly created referendum legislation into the Constitution and cutting by half the number of legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD SETS TARGET FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH NEXT YEAR AT 5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved Monday an amendment to the national development program for next year, adjusting the annual growth rate from the original planned 4.7 percent to 5 percent.

CEPD officials said that the execution of the government's proposed expansion of public construction projects by NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) in the next five years and the continuous implementation of programs for increasing jobs, which have been in effect since earlier this year, are required to achieve the goal.
The speed of world's economic recovery will also serve as a key factor for Taiwan's economic performance, they noted.
The country's top economic planning agency estimated that consumption and investment by the private sector will increase by 3.5 percent and 9.6 percent next year, respectively.
Meanwhile, public sector consumption, investment and investment from state-run enterprises will grow by 2.4 percent, 16 percent and 0.3 percent, respectively, they added.
At the same time, they predicted, exports and imports of commodities and services will surge by 6.7 percent and 7.6 percent, respectively.

In terms of production, they forecast that the output of the knowledge-intensive manufacturing and service industries will enjoy growth of 8.8 percent and 8.7 percent, respectively, while the non-knowledge-intensive manufacturing industry will grow 2.8 percent.
The CEPD also estimated that the unemployment rate will fall to 4.5 percent by the end of next year, while the consumer price index will rise by 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF DYSENTERY CASES OF TAIWAN TOURISTS REACHES 95

TEXT.P: The number of tourists from Taiwan to be infected with shigellosis while visiting the Indonesian resort island of Bali has increased by three cases to 95, all of whom are tourists who returned to Taiwan before Nov. 24, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Officials from the DOH's Center for Disease Control said that some tourists who returned after Nov. 24 have suffered from fever and diarrhea -- the standard symptoms of the disease -- but all tested negative.
The officials stressed that the shigella bacteria can be transmitted from drinking water and food and that those infected will then contaminate furniture, dinner ware and door knobs through touching.
The officials urged the tourists to be alert to food sanitation and personal hygiene and to seek medical treatment if they develop symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting and severe stomach pain.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE MEN THAN WOMEN INFECTED WITH AIDS IN TAIWAN: DOH

TEXT.P: More men than women are infected with AIDS in Taiwan, with the 20-29 age group the most heavily infected with the incurable disease, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Statistics compiled by the DOH's Center for Disease Control show that from 1983 to October 31 this year, 5,464 people have been infected with AIDS, 5,042 of whom are Taiwanese, or 92.28 of the total, and that 1,560 have developed full-blown symptoms. There are 422 foreigners infected with AIDS, accounting for just 7.72 percent of the total, 35 of whom have full-blown symptoms.
In terms of gender, the number of men infected with AIDS is markedly higher than that of women.

The number of Taiwan men infected with AIDS is 4,694, or 93.1 percent of the total, with 1,437 having developed full-blown symptoms, and 833 deaths. The number of Taiwan women infected with AIDs is 348, with 123 having developed full-blown symptoms and 71 having died.

In terms of age group, those aged between 20 and 29 are the largest group, with 1,841 in this age group, accounting for 33.62 percent of all those infected, followed by those aged between 30 and 39, with 1,695 infected, and 668 in the 40-49 age group.
In terms of infection risk factors, the CDC claimed, the number of heterosexuals infected with AIDS is 2,049, compared with 1,840 AIDs sufferers who are homosexual and 613 who are bisexual.

A hundred drug addicts have contracted AIDS, while 12 were infected by tainted blood transfusions, nine from their mothers, 53 from hemophilia, nine from "unidentified reasons" and one from handling AIDS patients with open wounds.

The 422 foreigners with AIDS come from 39 countries, and 163 Thais account for the largest group, followed by 34 Indonesians, 33 Burmese, 31 Americans, 23 Cambodians, 19 mainland Chinese, 18 Filipinos, 17 Malaysians and 16 Vietnamese.
The CDC's statistics were released in coincidence with a World Health Organization report which said that one person dies of AIDS every minute in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: 46 Iraqis die in fierce fight between rebels and G.I.'s.
American soldiers killed 46 Iraqi guerrilla attackers. The soldiers met multiple ambushes on two convoys rolling separately through the town of Samarra. The clash was described by military officials as the largest battle since the occupation began.
The Wall Street Journal: Railroad logjams threaten boom in the farm belt.
The shortages of railcars and crews of the railway fail to meet the demand for grain-hauling while the Farm Belt is booming after five years of recession. Delays in grain shipments reduce potential profits and may affect overall U.S. economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED SPY FOR MAINLAND CHINA RELEASED ON BAIL

TEXT.P: A local businessman who was detained in August on suspicion of spying for Beijing was released on NT$300,000 (US$8,793) bail Monday.

Yeh Yu-chen was taken into custody by prosecutors Aug. 5 on suspicion of collecting classified military information for Beijing and acquiring night vision goggles from the United States for Beijing by falsely claiming they were for use only in Taiwan.

Investigators said Yeh colluded with a Chinese-American businessman and a technician at the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, which is in charge of the development of weaponry for the armed forces, to gather information about secret arms experiments and pass it to Beijing.
All three were detained and Yeh was the last to be released. No charges have been filed against any of them as yet.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TAKING CARE OF VETERANS, DEPENDENTS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he has advocated a policy of taking care of veteran servicemen and their dependents.
The president made the remarks when he received Evlyn McCune, national president of the Ladies Auxiliary to Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) of the United States.

Chen said that he recently met for the fifth time with the national president of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States and was very pleased to meet with the head of the Ladies Auxiliary to the VFW.

Chen noted that the VFW was established in 1899 and has a membership of 2.5 million. The Ladies Auxiliary of the VFW has 700,000 members, and the Republic of China's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen has maintained close exchanges with the two organizations over the years.

He said that the commission has spared no efforts in the care of veterans and their dependents and that since he assumed the presidency, he has advocated the policy of "safety for servicemen" and care for their dependents and veterans.

McCune said that her organization's major task is to do its utmost to assist veterans and their dependents and to provide them with assistance in times of need, as concern and care for survivors is the best way to honor the fallen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS TAIWAN TRADERS FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised domestic traders Monday for their contributions to the nation's development, particularly in the economic field.

Addressing a ceremony marking the 50th anniversary of the Taiwan Importers and Exporters Chamber of Commerce, Chen said that Taiwan's exports and imports have increased by 770 times over the past five decades, with two-way trade expanding from US$303 million in 1952 to NT$233.2 billion in 2002, thanks to the efforts of the country's traders.
During the same period, Chen went on, Taiwan's per capita income grew by 70 times, from US$180 to more than US$13,000.

Chen said that his administration will continue to provide strong support to Taiwan exporters and importers and he encouraged businessmen to work with the government to create a second round of Taiwan's "economic miracle."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PLANE AIRLIFTS ROCSAT-2 TO U.S. FOR JANUARY LAUNCH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's second satellite -- ROCSAT-2 -- left Taiwan Monday for the United States where it will be launched into orbit early next year.
The 3,000 kg satellite is scheduled to arrive by air in Los Angeles Tuesday, according to the National Space Program Office (NSPO).
"The satellite will then be delivered by truck to Vandenberg Air Force Base in California for liftoff Jan. 17," said Chen Jeng-shing, the ROCSAT-2 project manager.
The satellite was placed in a special container into which nitrogen was injected to ensure stable conditions for the long journey to the United States, Chen said.

China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier experienced in transporting precision machinery, airlifted ROCSAT-2 to Los Angeles. Two French engineers from the NSPO's French contractor Astrium Co., along with an NSPO engineer, accompanied the satellite.

Chen said he will lead a 20-member team to Los Angeles Dec. 2 to begin preparations for the launch. "A lot of work, including assembly, integration and testing, must be done before the launch," he added.
Taiwan launched its first satellite -- ROCSAT-1 -- five years ago. Chen said the launch of ROCSAT-2, which carries a price tag of NT$4.7 billion, will lead Taiwan into a new era of space research.

According to Chen, ROCSAT-2 is different from its predecessor in that it will have practical applications involving remote-sensing technology to help upgrade Taiwan's capability in disaster prevention, land mapping and environmental monitoring.

ROCSAT-2 can take pictures of objects on the ground as small as two meters across, Chen said, adding that the satellite is designed to orbit the Earth 14 times a day, including two passes over Taiwan, at 891 km above the Earth.
In addition to its remote sensing mission, ROCSAT-2 has the scientific mission of investigating various lighting phenomena in the upper atmosphere.

Chen said ROCSAT-2 has a two-year life span. "But it may remain functional longer than its shelf life, judging from the fact that ROCSAT-1 remains operational five years after its launch into the orbit," he added.
The ROC government launched a 15-year space technology development plan in 1991. In its initial stage, the NSPO is concentrating on ROCSAT, which consists of three different satellite ventures.

ROCSAT-1 was built by the U.S. firm TRW and successfully launched in 1999 from Cape Canaveral, Florida, while ROCSAT-3 is an ROC-U.S. joint venture that will be launched in 2005. Some components of these satellites will be manufactured in Taiwan under the auspices of technology transfers from foreign contractors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Arms deal turned sour for Saddam.
It was Saddam Hussein's last weapons deal - and it did not go exactly as he and his generals imagined. For two years before the U.S. invasion of Iraq, Saddam's sons, generals and front companies were engaged in negotiations with North Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER TO VISIT U.S.

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Lin Chong-pin confirmed Monday that he will visit the United States in the near future.

Lin was responding to questions from lawmakers at a Defense Committee meeting where he was asked to comment on a newspaper report that he and Vice Chief of the General Staff Ju Kai-san are scheduled to leave for Washington, D.C. Friday at the head of a high-profile military mission for comprehensive talks on arms deals, Taiwan's security and bilateral military cooperation. The two-week visit would be the largest in scope in Taiwan-U.S. military talks in recent memory, the report said.

Lin said that all Taiwan-U.S. military engagements are conducted under the framework of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) -- the U.S. law that regulates exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

He declined to give details of his upcoming visit, saying only that the visit is part of the routine Taiwan-U.S. military exchanges under the TRA framework. At the moment, Lin went on, it remains uncertain whether he will start his U.S. visit Friday.

According to the newspaper report, Lin's mission will also visit the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii, where a computer war game will be conducted Dec. 15-17. The simulation is necessary for the United States to update its military contingency plans to cope with a possible escalation of tension across the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to Taiwan's next presidential election on March 20, 2004, the newspaper report said.
Commenting on the report, Lin said that even if there were a computer war game scheduled, it would be routine and would have planned long ago.

Asked about his view of President Chen Shui-bian's claim a day earlier that Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan is sufficient reason for a "defensive referendum" to be called on the day of the March 20 presidential election, Lin said the People's Liberation Army's (PLA's) threat to Taiwan has always existed.
As to whether the threat is impending enough to justify the holding of a "defensive referendum, " Lin said only that the PLA has not taken any "evident military action" at the moment.

Article 17 of the referendum law passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan last Thursday empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security in the event of an external military threat aimed at compelling a change in Taiwan's status. The threat that could trigger such an action, dubbed a "defensive referendum, " is tacitly seen as coming from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR NEW 10 MAJOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged legislators across the party spectrum Monday to support his "new 10 major construction projects" idea to create more favorable conditions for Taiwan's progress and prosperity.

The president made the remarks when he and other government officials presided over the inauguration ceremony of a new tunnel, one of the most difficult sections of the Keelung River dredging project. With the inauguration of the tunnel, the construction work to divert floodwater is 52.1 percent complete, a little ahead of schedule.
Chen noted that even though the nearly 2.5-km tunnel passes through three faults and a great number of disused mineshafts, the construction workers completed the tunnel in little over a year.

He also lauded the power and efficiency of his Cabinet with regard to the project, saying that after the project is completed at the end of next year, it will effectively reduce the water level of the lower reaches of the Keelung River and will prevent flooding for up to 200 years.

He noted that when Typhoon Lynn hit Taiwan in 1987, the floodwater inundated houses up to two stories high in Hsichi, Taipei County. However, the Taiwan provincial government did nothing to address the problem. After the streamlining of the provincial government, the project received support from then-Premier Vincent Siew and was further implemented with the continued efforts of his successors, premiers Chang Chun-hsiung and Yu Shyi-kun.
Chen said that if the project, which was delayed for 12 years, could have been started earlier, it would have gone far toward relieving flooding problems in greater Taipei.

He expressed hope that legislators will support the new 10 major construction projects unveiled earlier by the Executive Yuan, including making rail transport faster and more convenient, building mass transit systems in central, northern and southern Taiwan, building a sewage system, constructing the third freeway and intercontinental container center in Kaohsiung Harbor, upgrading universities and research centers, and improving the information and communication network in Taiwan.
Chen claimed that public wants these projects to be implemented as they will upgrade the overall competitive edge of Taiwan and improve the quality of life.
"We have no time to wait for 12 years for every major construction project, " the president said, adding that "if the dredging of the Keelung River had not started, we would pay a hefty price today."
"Similarly, if we do not implement the new 10 major projects today, we will surely regret it tomorrow," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCUFFLE OVER REFERENDUM CONTINUES TO RAGE

TEXT.P: A fierce battle between the ruling and opposition parties continued to rage Monday, with both sides trading barbs and the issue turning from what kind of a referendum law the country needs to whether the president should push for a referendum March 20, the day of the next presidential election.

Although the opposition stole the ruling party Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's thunder Thursday by passing a referendum bill mainly based on their own ideas, with the aim of reining in President Chen Shui-bian's attempts to organize the country's first national referendum on March 20 on issues put forward by his party, it seems there is no holding Chen's determination to do so.

Citing an article successfully tacked on to the bill by the DPP, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung argued Monday that should the country be under threat, the president is authorized to call a referendum after getting the endorsement of the Cabinet and that this right is not subject to the approval of a commission founded for this purpose under the Executive Yuan.

Lin said the country has always been under threat from mainland China, which has targeted the island with almost 500 missiles, not to mention repeated warning from Beijing's leaders that war is inevitable should the island move on the path toward separating itself from the mainland.
The former government of the Kuomintang misled the people by instilling a false sense of safety into their minds, Lin claimed.
Therefore, he said, it is appropriate for the president to call a referendum for March 20.

According to Lin, Article 17 of the referendum bill, which reads "...the president may put to referendum issues related to national security..." is different from Article 16, which provides that the legislature can initiate referendum proposals and refer them to the referendum reviewing commission.

Furthermore, he said, it would be "unreasonable and unnecessary" to have a referendum proposal that is put forward by the president and endorsed by the Cabinet reviewed again by a commission under the Cabinet.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung shared the spokesman's views, arguing that Beijing's military threat against the country is a fact beyond dispute and the president would be exercising his legal power by calling a referendum.

He complained that KMT Chairman Lien Chan "hurt his feelings" by claiming the previous day that it is harder to guard against the president than it is to guard against a thief, adding that he cannot understand why someone would try to block the president from rallying the public behind the government in defense of the country.
Vice President Annette Lu also claimed in Taipei County Monday that the military threat from Beijing justifies the president's calls for a referendum.

At the other end of the political spectrum, both the KMT and its political ally the People First Party (PFP) , which united with the KMT to push through thereferendum bill Thursday, denounced the president for what they described as abuse of power for political gain.
Lawmaker Lee Chia-chin, secretary of the KMT legislative caucus, said the president should follow the terms of the bill while exercising his power.
Lawmaker Chou Hsih-wei, secretary of the PFP caucus, accused Chen of trying to use referendum as a vote-getting trick.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLOW PASSENGERS TO BRING UP TO 6,000 RENMINBI INTO COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Passengers entering Taiwan will be allowed to carry mainland Chinese currency of up to 6,000 renminbi with them, beginning by the end of 2003, Vice Minister of Finance Chang Hsiu-lien said Monday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said inbound passengers, presumably most of them Taiwan citizens returning from trips to mainland China, will be allowed to carry renminbi with them as part of the government's efforts to increase convenience for people amid the rapid rise in cross-strait exchanges.

Currently, mainland Chinese currency is not allowed to be brought into Taiwan by anybody. The opening policy, Chang said, has been adopted by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) in compliance with a Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area amendment which was recently passed by the Legislative Yuan.
Chang said that the limit of 6,000 renminbi was decided upon after the MOF took into consideration Taiwan's overall economic development as well as the practices adopted by other countries.

In addition, Chang said, mainland China's law prohibits mainland citizens from taking more than 6,000 renminbi out of the country with them. "It would be impractical if Taiwan were to allow people to bring more than 6,000 renminbi into the country," she added.
Currently, the maximum amount in foreign currency that people are allowed to carry with them into Taiwan is US$10,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR OPPOSITION PARTIES BEGIN PUSH FOR CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: The caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) said Monday that they have jointly filed a proposal to add referendum clauses to the constitution.

Members of the KMT and PFP caucuses also said at a press conference that they have begun to push for another constitutional amendment, by which the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan will be cut by half.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said at the press conference that he hopes a constitutional amendment committee will be established as soon as possible so that the two proposals can be deliberated as early as Friday.

The two caucuses have begun to invite legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its political allies to endorse the proposal to reduce the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan, hoping that enough signatures will be collected by the end of next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: President To Drop Tariffs On Steel; Bush Seeks to Avoid A Trade War and Its Political Fallout.
The Bush administration has decided to repeal most of its 20-month-old tariffs on imported steel to head off a trade war that would have included foreign retaliation against products exported from politically crucial states, administration and industry sources said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO STRENGTHEN ECONOMIC TIES WITH PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Bing-fan said in Taipei Monday that Taiwan should try its best to improve its trade and economic relations with Paraguay so that it may become a strong base for Taiwan to develop South American markets.

Speaking on the relations between the two countries at the Foreign Relations Committee of the Legislative Yuan, Yen said that to reach the goal, the government should encourage more Taiwan investors to invest in Paraguay, strengthen the agricultural technical cooperation between the two countries, and improve their economic and trade relations.
Yen said Paraguayan news media have recently urged Taiwan investors to look for investment opportunities in Paraguay.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES KMT TO RETURN ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS TO NATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return the property that it had illegally taken from individual persons or national coffers during its nearly 55-year rule of Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at the opening of an exhibition of photos, documents and artifacts featuring Taiwan's human rights development as part of the celebrations of the upcoming Dec. 10 World Human Rights Day.

Chen said he was pleased to see KMT Chairman Lien Chan publicly acknowledge that the KMT had committed many wrongdoings during its rule of Taiwan, including one-party dictatorship, martial law and human rights infringements.
Addressing a Saturday campaign rally, Lien, the presidential candidate of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " said he was willing to apologize for his party's wrongdoings during the martial law era.

Chen said a public apology from Lien is not enough. "The most important thing is action. Deeds speak louder than words. The KMT should take action to redeem its past sins that once caused many family breakups, social tragedies and distortions of human nature."
One thing that the KMT should do to show its genuine repentance is to return all the assets it had stolen from the people and the nation, Chen said.

Touching on World Human Rights Day celebrations, Chen said he hopes the values and regulations of human rights, the rule of law and democracy can take root in Taiwan's political, social and cultural arenas as early as possible.

In his 2000 inaugural speech, Chen said he outlined three key principles regarding his human rights policy -- pushing the legislature to pass and ratify the International Bill of Rights as a domestic law of Taiwan so that it becomes the "Taiwan Bill of Rights"; setting up an independent national human rights commission in line with the United Nations requirements; and bringing Taiwan back into the international human rights system.

Chen urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to support his human rights policy and pass all relevant bills as soon as possible to facilitate Taiwan's development into a "human rights" power in the world.

He lauded Academia Historica and the preparatory office of the National Human Rights Museum for their joint efforts in organizing the Taiwan human rights arts exhibition and establishing a new Taiwan human rights information network.
Chen further said he believes that with dedication and confidence, "human rights seeds" will blossom in Taiwan in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.041 to close at NT$34.167.
A total of US$453 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.286 and was traded between NT$34.147 and NT$34.291.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL INCOMING MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES NOW SUBJECT TO INTERVIEWS

TEXT.P: Immigration officers began to interview all incoming mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens Monday as part of the government's efforts to stem an influx of mainland immigrants through marriages of convenience.

The personal interview system was introduced for the first time Sept. 1 after a spate of bogus marriage cases involving mainland Chinese citizens were uncovered. Initially, only selected mainland spouses were interviewed.

From Oct. 1, the system was expanded to cover all mainland Chinese spouses who were making their first visits to Taiwan and the two ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
Starting Dec. 1, the system was further extended to cover all arriving mainland Chinese spouses, including those who had visited Taiwan before.

Statistics compiled by the Bureau of Immigration (BOI) under the National Police Administration showed that between Sept. 1 and Nov. 27, 3,918 mainland spouses were interviewed upon their arrival and 470 of them, or 12 percent of the total, were determined to be in a bogus marriage with a Taiwan citizen and were repatriated.

During the same period, 1,037 incoming mainland spouses were required to receive a second round of personal interviews after their entry to Taiwan, accounting for 26 percent of all those interviewed upon arrival. As of last Friday, second-round interviews had been conducted on 737 of those people.

After second-round interviews, 51 were determined to be in fake marriages and were thus repatriated immediately; 80 were ordered to leave Taiwan within a specified period of time and 32 of them had left Taiwan.

In the future, BOI officials said they will use administrative discretionary rights to have more people repatriated immediately after second-round interviews to prevent overstays by those in bogus marriages.
Moreover, the officials said they will step up checks and personal interviews on those who have entered Taiwan to deter mainland people from trying to come to Taiwan through bogus marriages.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN URGED TO DONATE BLOOD

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Blood Donation Center said Monday that hospitals in Kaohsiung and Pingtung have almost run out of blood and people in the area are urged to donate blood.

A spokesman for the center said that under normal conditions, there is seven days of blood supply, or 7,700 bags, in the blood bank, but now there is only one-and-a-half days of supply in the blood bank of the Kaohsiung and Pingtung area.

He said there is less than three days of blood supply in Taiwan. Hospitals on the island will not have sufficient blood to use in case of a major accident, unless people can generously donate their blood, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Abramovich Halts Sibneft-Yukos Merger.
Sibneft called a halt to its landmark $35 billion merger with Yukos on Friday, a brash move that stunned the market and all but derailed the creation of Russia's first oil supermajor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Turkish Daily News: Latest Iraq killings fuel heated debate.
The killing of seven Spanish intelligence agents and two Japanese diplomats in ambushes in Iraq sparked fresh debate on Sunday in countries allied to the United States on the risks of joining the Iraq mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO PUSH FOR REFERENDUM ON DIRECT AIR AND SHIPPING LINKS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Monday that he will push for a referendum to allow Kaohsiung residents to decide whether or not their city should open direct air and shipping links with mainland China.

Lien, the presidential candidate of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " said if he is elected, he will see to it that Kaohsiung residents cast their referendum votes for the opening of direct air and shipping links between Kaohsiung and mainland China as part of the effort to rejuvenate the port city's glory and help generate job opportunities.

Lien made the promise during a ceremony marking the establishment of a supporters group of residents living in the Tsoying-Nantsu district for himself and his running mate, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.

The opposition presidential candidate derided President Chen Shui-bian's recent spate of moves seeking to rewrite the ROC Constitution and initiate a "defensive referendum" as electioneering gimmicks contributing nothing to the people's welfare and only serve to provoke Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 200 RUNAWAY FOREIGN LABORERS TURN THEMSELVES IN: CLA

TEXT.P: More than 200 foreign laborers who have absconded from their Taiwan jobs turned themselves in voluntarily over the past three months, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Monday.

About 70 percent of the foreign laborers who surrendered to police between Sept. 1 and Nov. 30 for absconding were Indonesian nationals, CLA officials said upon the conclusion of a three-month assessment to examine why foreign laborers run away from their jobs and whether CLA incentives encouraging these people to turn themselves in voluntarily are working or not.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu said in late October that a freeze on admissions for new Indonesian laborers might be lifted by the end of November if the three-month assessment proves that fewer Indonesian workers already in the country have absconded from their jobs. Chen said that the introduction of Vietnamese laborers might be halted as well if their absconding rate has not dropped in the same three-month period.
To this concern, the CLA authorities have not made any comments as of noon Monday, presumably because pertinent figures for November are not yet available.
According to statistics compiled by the National Police Administration, a total of 890 foreign workers ran away from their jobs in September, 430 of whom are Vietnamese.
As of Oct. 31, nearly 11,200 foreign laborers remain unaccounted for in Taiwan, including 1,953 Filipinos, 4,000 Indonesians, 1,480 Thais and 3,533 Vietnamese, CLA officials said.
Pleased with the preliminary results of the three-month assessment, the CLA will likely extend the period allowing more of the absconded foreign laborers to report themselves, the officials said.

The CLA will also talk with domestic police authorities as well as Taiwan offices of laborer-exporting Southeast Asian countries in convincing them that the repatriation process period be shortened and free air tickets should be provided for expatriation, as incentives to persuade more absconded workers to emerge, the officials added.
About 280,000 legal foreign laborers are working in Taiwan, most of whom work in the manufacturing sector, according to CLA tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 106 points to close at 5,914, with 35,120 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 102 points to finish at 5,912, with 154 contract transactions, while March futures rose 91 points to finish at 5,899, with 20 contracts traded.
June futures moved up 38 points to finish at 5,885, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,808 for December, 5,810 for January, 5,808 for March, 5,847 for June, and 5,847 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 4.6 points to finish at 251.8, with 3,987 contract transactions, while January TE futures gained 3.8 points to finish at 251.5, with 17 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 98.4 points to close at 5,870.17.
The bourse opened at 5,768.69 and fluctuated between 5,878.13 and 5,752.15 during trading.
A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.06 billion (US$2.08 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 2.6 percent, textile issues and foodstuff shares, both at 1.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, electrical shares at 1.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent, and construction stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 653 to 137, with 138 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE PEOPLE ENTITLED TO FREE FLU VACCINATIONS

TEXT.P: More Taiwan residents will be given free flu shots as winter approaches following the first wave of free flu vaccinations provided to senior citizens and health care personnel in September, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Monday.
Health authorities are encouraging citizens aged over 55 to get influenza vaccinations as a precaution against the flu as well as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) this winter.
The elderly, especially those with diabetes, who have a higher risk of getting the flu, are more vulnerable to the disease in the winter.

In addition to seniors, health care personnel, including pharmacists and school nurses, as well as physically- and mentally-challenged people are also encouraged to get a flu shot, DOH officials said.

The DOH officials urged the public to pay more attention to the flu, which has similar early symptoms to those of SARS. Approximately 10 percent to 20 percent of the Taiwan people get the flu each year, with the medical costs for treatment reaching NT$31.2 billion (US$917.65 million) annually.

If the vaccinations can reduce the number of flu cases by 50 percent or 60 percent, this will considerably ease the workload of medical workers who can then concentrate their energies on dealing with real SARS cases if need be, the officials said.
The DOH launched the first round of the flu vaccination campaign Sept. 15, first among health workers, such as doctors and nurses working at hospitals, and then the elderly aged over 65 Sept. 22.
Meanwhile, city-run schools of all levels in Taipei City began a temperature-taking drive Monday. Regular temperature-taking is one of the measures employed to guard against another SARS outbreak.
SARS hit Taiwan hard between early March and late June this year, claiming 84 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS GRACING TAIWAN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Despite a spate of cold fronts in recent days, the number of endangered black-faced spoonbills wintering at a wetlands reserve in the southern county of Tainan has not increased significantly, local conservationists said Monday.
The number of black-faced spoonbills wintering at the Chiku wetlands in Tainan County usually peaks in the second half of November, wild bird conservationists said.
A record high number of 706 of the rare birds spent the winter in the Chiku marshes last year.
As of Sunday, only 617 black-faced spoonbills had arrived at the Chiku wetlands at the estuary of the Tsengwen River, far lower than the figure of 700 birds for the same time last year.

Conservationists said that a worldwide black-faced spoonbill census will be conducted next January and that it remains uncertain at the moment whether the global population of the rare species has declined due to the mass die-off that occurred in Taiwan late last year and early this year as a result of botulism.

Botulism caused the death of 73 of the birds between late last year and early this year. According to wild bird experts, the reproduction rate of the black-faced spoonbill ranges between 8 percent and 12 percent per year. Extrapolating from the deaths and the reproduction rate, the maximum number of arrivals this year has been estimated at around 700, the conservationists said.

Each year, a large number of black-faced spoonbills migrate from the Korean peninsula and northeastern mainland China to the Chiku wetlands to spend the winter. The mass die-off last year was the first such case on record involving the endangered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 1, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS TO EDUCATE MILITARY MEMBERS ON REFERENDUMS: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) currently has no plans to educate members of the armed forces' rank and file on referendums even though the Legislative Yuan has recently passed a referendum bill into law, an MND spokesman said Tuesday.
"Chukuang Day" -- the day regularly reserved for education in the military each week -- has not been used to give lessons about referendums, MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said.
Speaking at a regular news conference, Huang said all the officers and soldiers in the military are certainly well aware of their voting rights as citizens.
Huang said that even if a referendum were held tomorrow, the ROC armed forces would maintain the norms of its combat training and preparedness.

He added that the defense ministry is constantly monitoring the movements of the mainland Chinese People's Liberation Army and that it has found that the PLA has not made any unusual moves despite mainland Chinese officials' saber rattling over the ROC Legislature's passage of the referendum bill last Thursday.
"We have not detected any abnormal movement of mainland Chinese troops in recent weeks, " Huang said, adding that the PLA is only conducting routine training activities at the moment.

On questions of whether President Chen Shui-bian's advocacy recently of a "defensive" referendum has caused any alterations in the military deployments of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Huang only said that it is a political issue and that he is not supposed to comment on political issues of any kind.

On another question about whether the defense ministry will go along with the notion of "barracks voting, " or allowing the men and women in uniform to cast their referendum ballots at the barracks, Huang said this is an issue for the Ministry of the Interior to deliberate, and not for the defense ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOLE IN MILITARY INTELLIGENCE BUREAU UNCOVERED: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: A major working for the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) has been taken into custody by military prosecutors with court approval for allegedly spying for Beijing, according to a statement issued Tuesday by the Ministry of National Defense.

Maj. Pai Chin-yang, who is from Hong Kong, has worked for the MIB since 1983 but was found to have run up heavy debts in 2001 following failed investments in the stock market and was blacklisted by several banks as a bad lending risk.

But Pai's financial status improved significantly after a trip to Thailand in January this year, during which, the ministry quoted the MIB as saying, he came into contact with spies from mainland China. He then began spending generously after a trip to Macau in September.

He also became an enthusiastic worker, seeking opportunities to access as much classified information as possible, apparently motivated by the desire to collect valuable information for Beijing, according to the ministry.

In October, more evidence of his spying was uncovered and the MIB assigned Pai to a job away from headquarters to prevent him from coming into contact with classified information. Meanwhile, they fed him with false information in an attempt to build an ironclad case against him.
The statement described Pai as a low-level MIB clerk with no access to top secrets and in no position to do much damage to the MIB.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIST WORKER QUESTIONED BY PROSECUTOR OVER ALLEGED LEAKAGE OF SECRETS

TEXT.P: A technician from the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) who was taken custody on suspicion of passing classified information about a smart bomb under development was questioned by prosecutors Tuesday.

Two arms dealers who said they knew Huang Cheng-an were also questioned by Investigation Bureau officials Tuesday, but both of them denied any involvement with Huang's alleged passing of secret information.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD UNIVERSITY BASEBALL INVITATIONAL TOURNAMENT OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2003 World University Baseball Invitational Tournament, sponsored by the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation, opened Tuesday at the Hsinchuang Baseball Diamond in Taipei County.

Education Minister Huang Jong-tsun, Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang, National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports Vice Chairman Chu Shou-chien and Panamanian Ambassador Jose Antonio Dominguez threw out the opening pitches and Huang also gave a speech to welcome the players.

A total of six teams -- three from Taiwan, two from South Korea and one from Panama -- are competing in the tournament that will last through Dec. 9, with games taking place at the Hsinchuang Baseball Diamond and at the Tienmu Baseball Diamond in Taipei City.
The games are expected to attract a large number of baseball fans, especially since the Chinese Taipei national team recently managed to earn a place in the 2004 Athens Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADA PRIME MINISTER VOWS TO FURTHER PROMOTE TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: St. George's, Grenada, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Grenada Prime Minister Keith Mitchell pledged recently to further promote relations between his country and the Republic of China, the ROC envoy to the Caribbean nation said Tuesday.
Ambassador Jiang Li-shang said that Mitchell made the pledge Nov. 29 after being sworn in for his third four-year term at a ceremony held at the Governor's Office.
Jiang said that Mitchell told him after the ceremony that he greatly appreciates the assistance the ROC has extended to his country and that he will continue to promote ROC-Grenada relations.
Mitchell's New National Party won eight of the 15 seats in the parliament in legislative elections held Nov. 27, maintaining its ruling position.

DOC.HEADLINE: LODGE FOR MAINLAND CHINESE FISHERY WORKERS OPENS IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: A lodge exclusively for the use of mainland Chinese fishery workers opened Tuesday in Nanliao, a fishing port in Hsinchu County.
Twenty-two mainland fishermen, escorted by officers from the Coast Guard Administration, became the first batch of guests at the lodge, which can accomodate 100 people.
Another 15 mainland fishermen who had applied to stay at the lodge did not move in that day because they were still working at sea.
The lodge is one of four lodges set up by the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture to accommodate mainland fishermen working on Taiwan fishing boats.
Besides the lodge at Nanliao, the other three are in Nanfanau, Ilan County; Patoutzu, Keelung City; and Wuchi, Taichung County. They opened the previous day.

The fishermen used to be forbidden to make landfall on Taiwan unless in an emergency and they had to live on overcrowded and filthy "floating hostels" -- in reality the dilapidated hulks of disused fishing boats -- off the coast between jobs. In order to improve their living conditions, the Executive Yuan decided last year to set up the lodges.

DOC.HEADLINE: 99 TAIWAN TOURISTS CONFIRMED TO HAVE SHIGELLA AFTER VISITING BALI

TEXT.P: A total of 99 Taiwan tourists who visited the Indonesian resort island of Bali last month had been confirmed as having contracted shigella as of Tuesday, according to a government official.

Shih Wen-i, deputy director-general of the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, said four new cases had been confirmed as of a day earlier among tourists who had traveled to Bali between Nov. 7-22 and had returned prior to Nov. 24. The first case was reported Nov. 23.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was reported to be arranging meetings between health officials from Taiwan and Indonesia to discuss the situation, according to a ministry spokesman.

The DOH has refrained so far from issuing a travel advisory for tourists planning trips to Bali, while Lin Yung-lo, Taiwan's representative to Jakarta, flew into Bali last Thursday to assess the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS ISSUES TO BE PUT TO REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who is determined to carry out the country's first national referendum March 20, urged his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) comrades Tuesday to come up with issues that could be put to referendum.

Presiding over a DPP meeting, Chen, who is also the DPP chairman, called on his party comrades to suggest security-related issues for the referendum, which he called a "defensive referendum" because it is supposedly to be used only when the country's safety is threatened by outsiders.
Chen expressed hope that the hard-earned right to referendum will be used to underscore Beijing's military threat to Taiwan and to reflect public opinion.

DPP Legislator Trong Chai suggested opposition to Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula of unifying with Taiwan as an issue for referendum, while others suggested that a referendum be held to "tell Beijing to withdraw missiles aimed at Taiwan." No decision was taken during the meeting.
Chen himself had suggested earlier a referendum on whether to continue with work on the fourth nuclear power plant and whether the country should seek to join the World Health Organization.

He also touted the new 10 major projects brought before the legislature by the Executive Yuan at a budget of NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) over five years as a series of measures designed to turn the country into a first-class world power.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIP BUSINESS REVENUES IN JAN.-OCT. PERIOD JUMP OVER 20 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Business revenues chalked up by the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) , Taiwan's top hi-tech stronghold, in the first 10 months totaled NT$700 billion (US$20.58 billion) , up by 21.3 percent over the year-earlier level, park authorities reported Tuesday.

Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Director James Lee said the figure is nearly on par with the NT$705.5 billion level posted for the whole of last year. He added that the full-year level for 2003 is expected to hit up to NT$900 billion and the level for the whole of 2004 may break the NT$1 trillion mark, fueled by an ongoing economic recovery.
According to Lee, the business climate at the leading industrial park in northern Taiwan has noticeably improved since the third quarter of this year after a recession of more than two years.

Its business turnover during the first eight months also grew by 15 percent year-on-year to reach NT$515.5 billion, while its level posted in the Sep.-Oct. period jumped by 49 percent from a year ago to NT$184.5 billion, administration statistics show.
At the same time, a total of 101,146 workers were employed as of the end of October by companies based at the park, a rise of 3.3 percent as compared to the previous-year level.

In October, the park's exports were valued at NT$43.4 billion, representing a three-year, single-month high and an astounding growth of 53 percent from a year ago. Its outbound shipments during the first 10-month period totaled NT$316.3 billion, up by 9 percent over the year-earlier period.

Also, the park's imports in October were worth NT$24.6 billion, an annual increase of 7 percent, while its combined level for the first 10 months totaled NT$173.9 billion, down by 19 percent year-on-year.

Meanwhile, efforts to attract investment also have paid off, Lee added. A total of 49 companies have set up shop in the compound and channeled capital worth NT$29.821 billion since the beginning of this year until the end of November, up by 12.3 percent in value.

In terms of the output value for the first eight months, the semiconductor industry led five other major sectors with NT$343.3 billion, followed by the computer and peripherals industry with NT$80 billion in second place.

The opto-electronics industry came in third with NT$51.9 billion, while the telecommunications industry ranked fourth with NT$35.8 billion. The precision machinery garnered fifth spot with NT$3.4 billion, ahead of the biotechnology at sixth with NT$110 billion.

Lee attributed the HSIP's growing production value to a larger number of IC design companies opening shops in the park. He forecast that the IC design industry will eventually replace the semiconductor contractors based in the park as the leading contributor to its business revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO HOLD REFERENDUM ON SOVEREIGNTY CHANGE: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's administration will not hold any referendum that would involve a change to Taiwan's sovereign status, a Presidential Office spokesman said Tuesday.

"A referendum that touches on sovereignty issues will not happen so long as mainland China refrains from using force against Taiwan, " said James Huang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.

Huang was responding to U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher's remarks a day earlier that the United States opposes any attempt by either side of the Taiwan Strait to change the present status quo in the region.

Speaking at a regular news briefing, Boucher further said the United States is opposed to Taiwan holding any referendum that could lead to altering Taiwan's current status or to the island moving toward de jure independence. Boucher also urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to exercise self-restraint and not to issue statements or take action that could escalate cross-strait tension or hinder a resumption of bilateral dialogue.

Boucher's statements came after President Chen declared over the weekend that he will initiate a "defensive referendum" against mainland China's military threat on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004.
Huang said Boucher was mainly reaffirmed the stance of the U.S. on cross-strait relations on the eve of mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's visit to the United States.

Stressing that President Chen has on many occasions reaffirmed his commitment to the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech, Huang said the planned "defensive referendum" will not touch on the sensitive "independence vs. unification" issue.

Article 17 of Taiwan's newly passed referendum law empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security issues in the event of an external threat. The threat which could trigger such an action, dubbed a "defensive referendum, " is tacitly seen as coming from mainland China.

Addressing a Sunday rally in southern Taiwan supporting his re-election bid, President Chen said Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan was sufficient reason for a "defensive referendum" to be called on the day of the March 20 presidential election.
Chen's declaration has drawn concerns that the move might provoke Beijing, which has threatened to attack Taiwan should the island declare independence.

Huang said such concerns are unjustified, stressing that planned "defensive referendum" will not breach the "four noes plus one" pledge nor will it has anything to do with the "independence vs. unification" issue. The government is still working on details regarding the proposed "defensive referendum," he added.
Meanwhile, Huang urged mainland China not to "interpret" Taiwan's democratic development or reform plans purely from negative and "independence vs. unification" perspectives.
Huang reiterated that Taiwan's referendum legislation and plans to write a new constitution that fits its present reality are primarily aimed at "deepening and consolidating" its young democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DIETMEN VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two Japanese lawmakers recently visited Taiwan to exchange views with government officials on a wide range of issues, including discussion on the possibility of signing a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two nations, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Lin Sung-huan, MOFA's director-general of the Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks when he spoke at a news briefing sponsored by the MOFA.
Lin said that Takeo Hiranuma, a former Japanese economics minister and currently a house representative, and Norifumi Kato, a house councillor, arrived in Taiwan Nov. 25.

During their stay in Taiwan, the two called on President Chen Shui-bian, former President Lee Teng-hui, the MOFA and the Government Information Office to exchange views on expanding bilateral trade and cultural exchanges and discussed FTA issues.

Lin said that Hiranuma is currently the deputy head of the Dietmen's Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, and he has always been friendly to Taiwan. He has spared no efforts in promoting the signing of an FTA between Taiwan and Japan, has supported Taiwan's past bids to join the World Trade Organization and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, and has helped with the cooperation between Japan's Shinkanshen and Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.
The two lawmakers wound up their Taiwan trip Nov. 27, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, giving up NT$0.019 to close at NT$34.148.
A total of US$366 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.218 and dipped to a low of NT$34.117 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE EXCHANGE TIGHTENING STOCK MARKET LISTING RULES

TEXT.P: The Singapore Exchange is tightening its stock market listing rules to better safeguard investors.

As part of a push towards a disclosure-based regime, regulators have in recent years been little concerned about the profitability of a company making an Initial Public Offering (IPO) so long as investors are adequately informed.
After much consultation, the Singapore Exchange will once again start asking firms applying to list to prove they are in a healthy financial position.
However, things won't be as stringent as in the old days when applicants had to adhere to strict profit track record requirements and their books were meticulously scrutinized by the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIRIBATI PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: Kiribati President Atone Tong will visit Taiwan early next year, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Lin Sung-huan, director-general of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said that the president of Kiribati will lead a delegation to visit Taiwan next February to boost relations.
Lin noted that the Republic of China established diplomatic relations with Kiribati Nov. 7 of this year based on the principles of mutual benefits.

Chen Su-liang, the ROC ambassador to Kiribati, presented his credentials to President Tong Nov. 21, and the ROC embassy in the Pacific island state is in operation, Lin said. Both countries are ready to exchange and cooperate in the areas of agriculture, fishery, culture, education, tourism and technology, he added.

Lin noted that mainland China has tried in vain to salvage its relations with Kiribati, but announced Nov. 29 that it would terminate diplomatic relations, close its embassy, and withdraw its satellite tracking station. The stadium under construction in Kiribati will be suspended and mainland China's ambassador, Ma Shuxue, will leave Dec. 4.
Lin said that severance of diplomatic relations between mainland China and Kiribati has highlighted the solid relations between the ROC and Kiribati.

Taiwan is now actively planning cooperation in the areas of agriculture, fishery and livestock, and that a Taiwan delegation visited Kiribati late last month to assess setting up a technical mission there.
The non-profit Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association will also organize a trade organization to visit Kiribati Dec. 11-20 and another ally, the Marshall Islands, on its way back.

As for the one-third completed stadium, Lin said that Taiwan's delegation will consult with Kiribati on the matter and will respect its wishes on whether to assist with the resumption of construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER INSPECTS INTERVIEW OPERATIONS FOR MAINLAND SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien visited CKS International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan Tuesday to see how procedures were being handled for interviewing all arriving mainland Chinese spouses.

Yu said that since the interview system was put in place Sept. 1, the number of arriving mainland Chinese spouses has dropped 50 percent, which indicates that the word is out on the new policy and has frustrated the efforts of some wishing to enter the country on false pretenses.
"The interviews will protect those who follow the law and targets those who do not," Yu said.

Yu asked immigration officers working in the airport to screen carefully spouses from mainland China and come up with a standard interview technique so that no fraudulent cases will slip through their net.
Along with vigorously screening the entry of mainland Chinese spouses, Yu also said that the interior ministry will do its best to provide assistance to legal foreign and mainland Chinese brides.

Bureau of Immigration (BOI) Commissioner Tseng Wen-chang said Tuesday that starting from Dec. 1, both husbands and wives applying for a mainland spouse to come to Taiwan for a visit, reunion, or residence and settlement will be interviewed.
If a marriage is determined to be bogus, then the entry permit for the mainland spouse will be revoked and the Taiwan resident will also be prosecuted according to relevant criminal law.
When a Taiwan resident applies for his or her mainland spouse's entry, the applicant will be interviewed first and the application will be rejected if there is doubt at that point.

The interviews were first introduced Sept. 1 after a spate of bogus marriage cases involving mainland Chinese people were uncovered. Only selected mainland spouses were interviewed to verify the veracity of their marriage at this stage.

From Oct. 1, the system was expanded to cover all mainland Chinese spouses who were making their first visit to Taiwan and the two ROC-held front line islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
Starting Dec. 1, the system was further extended to cover all arriving mainland Chinese spouses, including those who had visited Taiwan before.

Statistics compiled by the BOI under the National Police Administration showed that between Sept. 1 and Dec. 1, 3,497 mainland spouses were interviewed upon their arrival and 517 of them were immediately repatriated because of their suspected intention to come to Taiwan for prostitution or to work illegally.
As of Monday, second-round interviews had been conducted on 892 individuals. After second-round interviews, 68 were determined to be in fake marriages and were thus repatriated,.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY MEMBERS OFTEN ACCOMPLICES OF PERPETRATORS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Family members are often the accomplices of perpetrators of domestic violence toward foreign wives of Taiwanese men, a study conducted by a non-profit organization showed Tuesday.

The Garden of Hope Foundation made the comment based on its interviews with 12 women from Southeast Asian countries such as mainland China, Vietnam, Cambodian and Indonesia who have been victims of domestic violence.

One woman from mainland China who said that she strongly feels the discrimination against her by her husband's family, said the first incident of domestic violence was triggered by a rumor spread by her mother-in-law, who seemed to enjoy the sight of her being beaten by her husband.
Another mainland Chinese spouse also said that her husband's ex-wife and children join forces to beat her, and treat her as the slave bought from mainland China.

Yet another case is a 17-year-old woman from Cambodia. She said that she wanted to come to Taiwan in the first place because she had seen so many of her compatriots marry Taiwanese men. She was beaten the third day after her arrival in Taiwan because she asked if she could return home to visit family members after living in Taiwan for six months.

Based on the cases studied, foundation officials said that domestic violence is mainly triggered by the lack of a solid foundation between the foreign brides and their Taiwanese husbands, emotionally unstable husbands, unfriendly family members, and poor daughter-in-law and mother-in-law relations, all of which result in the family members often becoming accomplices of the perpetrators of violence.

Chi Huei-jung, executive director of the foundation, said that Taiwan, as a host country of foreign brides, should have formulated a friendly policy to embrace the foreign bribes who are alone in Taiwan.

In addition, the government should implement rigorously its rescue and assistance system, not only providing foreign bribes with language learning opportunities but also courses or brochures about their own rights so that they will know where to seek assistance when in trouble.
Chi urged people in Taiwan to treat foreign bribes with the proper respect so that their children can grow up in a healthy environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HAS NOT YET RETURNED ALL ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS TO NATION: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday refuted the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) claim that it had returned all of its ill-gotten assets to the nation.

Speaking at a news conference, DPP Legislator Chou Ya-shu said KMT Chairman Lien Chan was lying when he claimed a day earlier that his party had returned all of its ill-gotten assets to the nation and has entrusted the party's legal assets to professional trust companies.

"When the KMT was in power, it embezzled vast amounts of national property. Lien should honestly face up to his party's past sins and stop cheating on this issue, " Chou said, adding that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, should support the passage of a bill that would legalizes investigations into assets of major domestic political parties.

Another DPP legislator, Lai Ching-teh, claimed that the KMT's controversial assets could be divided into four categories -- properties taken over from the Japanese colonial government at the end of World War II, such as the building of the Broadcasting Corp. of China; properties snaffled from the government, including 19 theaters, 11 of which were sold secretly by the KMT; 115 pieces of land given by city or county governments; and properties that the government sold to the KMT at unreasonably low prices, such as the KMT's present headquarters.
"Among all these assets, the KMT has only returned about half of the 115 pieces of land presented by local-level governments, " Lai claimed.

Legislator Chen Chi-mai, also a DPP legislative whip, said the KMT should explain why it has so far only returned half of land lots donated by local-level governments and why it has dragged its feet on handling other illegally obtained assets.
Chen also questioned whether the KMT has truly entrusted its assets to professional trust firms. Take the KMT-owned Central Investment Co. as an example, Chen said.

"The KMT said it has entrusted management of the firm to Credit Suisse First Boston Co. But five of the firm's board members were KMT stalwarts. The firm's management remains in KMT hands," Chen claimed.
In response to the DPP legislative caucus' criticism, KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan said his party has truly returned all of its ill-gotten assets in accordance with current laws.

Addressing the opening of an exhibition of artifacts and documents featuring Taiwan's human rights development a day earlier, President Chen Shui-bian also urged the KMT to return the property that it had illegally taken from individual persons or national coffers during its nearly 55-year rule of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SEEKS TO EXEMPT TAXIS FROM FUEL, LICENSE TAXATION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is seeking to exempt the country's taxi drivers from paying fuel and license taxes for their vehicles that they use for making a living, a KMT party whip said Tuesday.

Lee Chia-chin said the KMT will shortly propose an amendment to relevant laws to change taxis into a category of vehicles for non-profit mass transportation, rather than the existing profit-making business category.
Lee said the amendment draft is aimed at being passed within December so that the new policy can be put into force on Jan. 1, 2004.
If the proposal were enacted into law, all taxi drivers of the country, numbering nearly 100,000, will directly benefit, Lee said.
Lee said it is not a scheme for drumming up support for the KMT in the run-up to the upcoming presidential election. Rather, he added, it is a "must-do" policy to seek justice for taxi drivers.

According to Lee, a group of taxi drivers approached the Executive Yuan to present their appeal for the cancellation of taxi fuel and license taxes in November 2001, but were arrested on charges of disturbing public order.

As of Sept. 30, registered taxis islandwide totaled 98,540, paying about NT$1 billion in fuel taxes annually. Lee said the NT$1 billion tax revenues may be an insignificant amount of income for the government, but it is a huge sum that is important in the livelihood of taxi drivers.
