DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINES FARE MUCH WORSE THAN HAN COUNTERPARTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official in charge of aboriginal affairs asked Tuesday that a higher aboriginal affairs budget be legislated as an effective means to help raise the living standards of aboriginal people to prevent "the weak from becoming weaker."

Addressing a national conference on the welfare of aboriginal people and related affairs, Cheng Tian-tsai, deputy director of the Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs, said indigenous people have long been denied access to resources that have been sufficiently provided to the non-aboriginal population due to low budgets and inadequate laws.
Cheng said unless the budgetary provisions are increased and relevant laws revised, indigenous people have little hope of seeing themselves fare any better.

According to Cheng, the per capita income of aboriginal people is 2.3 times lower than that of non-aboriginal people, while indigenous people's unemployment rate is 1.7 times higher than that of non-indigenous people.

The percentage of people having received college or higher education among indigenous people is 15 percent less than that of non-indigenous people, while the percentage of people having received only junior high education or lower among indigenous people is 16 percent higher than that of non-indigenous people, Cheng said.

On average, aboriginal males have a shorter life expectancy than their non-aboriginal counterparts of about 10 years, while the life expectancy of women aborigines is five years shorter than that of non-aboriginal women.

By comparison, the percentage of aboriginal people who own their own house is 8 percent less than that of non-aboriginal people, Cheng said, adding that about one-third of the aboriginal villages and rural townships islandwide have no kindergartens or related facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA INSTRUMENTAL IN TAIWAN-BALI BILATERAL TALKS ON DYSENTERY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been helping health officials from Taiwan and Indonesia engage in bilateral talks in the wake of an outbreak of dysentery among Taiwan tourists who visited the Indonesian resort island of Bali last month.

The number of confirmed dysentery cases among Taiwan tourists returning from the island of Bali increased to 95 Monday, 55 more than the level when the dysentery outbreak among Taiwan tourists was first reported Nov. 23.

The foreign ministry instructed Lin Yung-lo, Taiwan's top representative in Indonesia, to travel to Bali Nov. 27 to gain first-hand information about the situation and talk with Indonesian health officials there about relevant matters, MOFA officials said Tuesday.

The officials said that Lin has been instrumental in helping health officials from Taiwan and Indonesia to conduct direct dialogue on the dysentery outbreak in a bid to facilitate eradication of the diarrhea-like disease in Bali as well as treatment and recovery of the Taiwan tourists.

More than 300 of the tourists have been put under observation in the wake of reports of a rising number of suspected cases of dysentery among Taiwan tourists who visited Bali Nov. 7-22. Many of them have reportedly developed fever, diarrhea and vomiting, with some cases having been confirmed to be Shigella dysentery.
Despite the outbreak, the government decided recently not to issue a travel advisory for Bali, which is a favorite destination for Taiwan tourists, attracting about 400,000 Taiwan visitors per year.
Bali remained popular among Taiwan tourists even during the height of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak early this year.
The owner of a local travel agency expressed concern that the dysentery outbreak might scare some Taiwan tourists away from Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were generally higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 16 points to close at 5,930, with 22,367 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 14 points to finish at 5,926, with 121 contract transactions, while March futures lost 2 points to finish at 5,925, with 9 contracts traded.
June futures moved up 27 points to finish at 5,882, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,914 for December, 5,912 for January, 5,927 for March, 5,855 for June, and 5,953 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
December TE futures moved up 0.9 points to finish at 252.7, with 2,994 contract transactions, while January TE futures gained 1.3 points to finish at 252.8, with 14 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 867.2, with 6,040 contract transactions, while January TF futures rose 0.8 points to close at 867, with 40 contracts traded.
March TF futures increased 17 points to finish at 865, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO RECYCLE KITCHEN LEFTOVERS FROM DEC. 26

TEXT.P: Taipei City will begin recycling kitchen leftovers of regular households from Dec. 26, with a three-month educational campaign to follow, the head of Taipei City Government's Environmental Protection Bureau (EPB) said Tuesday.

Chen Yung-jen, director of the EPB, urged the people to work in tune with the new system and divide their kitchen leftovers into two categories -- namely food scraps, which can be used to feed hogs, and compost material, such as leaves and fruit peels.
The kitchen leftovers will be collected under the same system as the current five-day-per-week garbage collection system, he added.

As the special containers for such garbage have not yet been distributed to all Taipei City residents, the EPB has urged people who have not yet received them to place their moist kitchen leftovers into their own containers or in plastic bags to make the garbage men's job easier.

To familiarize the public with the new system, Taipei City Government will launch a three-month educational campaign, Chen said. After Feb. 26, if people mix their kitchen leftovers with their regular garbage, they will be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000 (US$35.19-US$175.95), he added.
If people have any questions, they can call a kitchen leftover hotline at (02) 2725-2818 between 8 a.m. and 10 p.m. every day, or call the EPB's 24-hour hotline at (02) 2720-6301,

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 41.28 points to close at 5,911.45.
The bourse opened at 5,919.23 and fluctuated between 5,921.11 and 5,884.32 during trading.

A total of 3.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.71 billion (US$2.31 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.04 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$71.06 billion (US$2.08 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with textile issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent. Pulp and paper issues remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. COMMUNICATIONS CHANNELS SMOOTH: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is fully aware of the U.S. stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait, and Taiwan-U.S. communications channels have always been smooth, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Richard Shih said Tuesday.

Shih made the remarks after U.S. Statement Department spokesman Richard Boucher said a day earlier that the United States opposes any attempt by either side of the Taiwan Strait to change the present status quo in the region.

Speaking at a regular news briefing, Boucher further said the United States is opposed to Taiwan holding any referendum that could lead to altering Taiwan's current status or to the island moving toward de jure independence. Boucher also urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to exercise self-restraint and not to issue statements or take action that could escalate cross-strait tension or hinder a resumption of bilateral dialogue.

Boucher's statements came after President Chen Shui-bian declared over the weekend that he will initiate a "defensive referendum" against mainland China's military threat on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004.

Responding to Boucher's comments, Shih said the MOFA is fully aware of the U.S. stance on cross-strait ties. "As a matter of fact, our communication channels at various levels have been smooth, " he added.

Noting that the referendum legislation is aimed at strengthening Taiwan's democratic system, Shih said that President Chen has on many occasions reaffirmed his commitment to the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech and that the planned "defensive referendum" will not touch on the ultra-sensitive "independence vs. unification" issue.

Article 17 of the referendum law passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security in the event of an external military threat aiming to compel a change in Taiwan's status. The threat which could trigger such an action, dubbed a "defensive referendum, " is tacitly seen as coming from mainland China.

Addressing a Sunday rally in southern Taiwan supporting his re-election bid, President Chen said Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan was sufficient reason for a "defensive referendum" to be called on the day of the March 20 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Tuesday, Dec. 2, or the ninth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-SARS DOMESTIC TOURIST TRIPS ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau's efforts to promote domestic leisure trips in the wake of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak earlier this year have paid off, tourist officials said Wednesday.

Quoting official tallies, they said visits to the island's 265 major sightseeing spots have increased steadily since July when the Tourism Bureau began to implement a series of tourist promotional activities in cooperation with travel service operators.

The SARS outbreak between March and June of this year dealt a severe blow to the local travel industry. To revitalize the sector, the Tourism Bureau pooled domestic tourist resources and introduced innovative tour packages.

According to official statistics, the 265 major scenic spots attracted 150,000 visits in July, and the number increased to 190,000-plus in August, 2000,000-plus in September, 223,000 in October and 238,000 in November.
Compared with the year-earlier levels, the number of visits grew by 15 percent for September and by an even more remarkable 35 percent for October.
Nevertheless, the numbers still fell below the average of 250,000 visits per month registered over the first three months of this year.

In a public ceremony held earlier in the day, Tourism Bureau Director Su Cheng-tien drew lots to determine the winners of prizes offered in a tourist promotional program that ran from Aug. 4 to Nov. 24. The prizes are worth a total of NT$80 million, including eight cars, 15 international flight tickets, five notebook computers, as well as specially-designed Giant bicycles, digital cameras and free hotel packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF SPOONBILLS GRACING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The wetlands in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan still boast the world's largest number of black-faced spoonbills as a total of 706 of the rare migratory birds have reportedly arrived here this year to winter as of Wednesday.

According to the private Tainan Black-Faced Spoonbills Conservation Association, a total of 598 black-faced spoonbills have been sighted in the area at the mouth of the Tsengwenchi River and the surrounding Chiku wetlands so far this year, while another 108 have been sighted near the Sitsao wetlands area of Tainan City, bringing the total to 706.

The figure is the highest in Taiwan in three years, greater than the 705 recorded by Dec. 2, 2002, and the 601 posted by the same date in 2001. A total of 1,069 of the rare birds were counted in a global black-faced spoonbill population survey conducted in January this year, wild bird conservationists from the association said.

The conservationists said they had worried that the number of the rare birds' arrivals might decline substantially this year due to the mass die-off that occurred in Taiwan late last year and early this year as a result of botulism.
However, Wednesday's figure has proved that Tainan remains the most popular transit habitat for black-faced spoonbills despite the botulism outbreak, the conservationists said.

Botulism caused the death of 73 of the endangered wild birds between late last year and early this year. According to wild bird experts, the reproduction rate of the black-faced spoonbill ranges between 8 percent and 12 percent per year. Extrapolating from the deaths and the reproduction rate, the maximum number of arrivals this year had been estimated at around 700, the conservationists said.

A total of 17 black-faced spoonbills had contracted botulism but were treated by Tainan vets and then released back into the wild early this year. Of these birds, 15 were found to have returned to Tainan again late this year, while one was spotted in Japan recently, according to the Tainan bird watchers. The other bird remained unaccounted for as of Wednesday, they added.

Black-faced spoonbills migrate from North Asia to the warm wetlands in Taiwan and other Asian lower-latitudinal countries between late September and early December every year to spend the winter and avoid their cold northern breeding grounds. The birds then return north around April or May of the next year.

The Tainan wetlands are technically not just an ideal habitat for black-faced spoonbills alone as currently there are about 100 other kinds of migratory wild birds staying around the Tsengwenchi River, Chiku and Sitsao areas, making the southern wetlands a haven for Asian migratory feathered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POLICY ON TAIWAN HAS NOT CHANGED: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Wednesday that the policy of the United States on Taiwan has not changed, which means that the United States does not support the independence of Taiwan.

Chien made the remarks in response to questions from reporters on whether the United States has changed its Taiwan policy from "not supporting" to "opposing" Taiwan independence after U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Tuesday that the United States would be opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence.

Chien noted that Boucher's remarks was clarified later by Adam Ereli, deputy spokesman of the U.S. Department of State, who said Boucher's remarks cannot be construed as opposition by the United States to Taiwanese independence.
"I would say we choose our words carefully, and our policy is that we don't support Taiwanese independence," Ereli said.

"I think that our policy is clear, and our policy is not to support Taiwanese independence. And that's the position, you know, we have elaborated, that is the position we're going to stick with, " Ereli added.

President Chen Shui-bian recently said he would hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of the March 20, 2004 presidential election, because Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles targeting Taiwan is a sufficient reason for holding such a referendum.
A referendum law passed recently by the Legislative Yuan gives the president the right to initiate a referendum on national security issues in case of an external threat.
Chen's movement has been construed by mainland China as a possible attempt to shift the status quo.
Chien stressed that as Washington and Taipei have maintained good relations, it is natural that the United States would express concern on Taiwan's elections and its democratic development.

The communications between the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the United States have been very smooth, and foreign ministry officials have given the message to the United States that Taiwan's referendum will not touch on the topic of independence or unification, Chien added.
Referring to Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's upcoming visit to the United States, Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has set up a ad-hoc committee to study his trip.
Chien said he thinks the United States government will not do anything that will be harmful to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS TONE FOR PARTY CONGRESS PRIOR TO PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: "Believe in Taiwan, Insist on Reform" will be the keynote for the coming national congress of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) set for Dec. 13 in Taipei, a ranking party official said Wednesday.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said that the ruling party will display its achievements since President Chen Shui-bian came to power on May 20, 2000 as a means of sharing its great confidence in Taiwan's future and its philosophy of rule with the public ahead of the next presidential election on March 20.
It will be a meeting full of expectations, optimism and cheers, Lee said.

DPP delegates attending the gathering will ratify the nomination of President Chen, the party's sole candidate, to compete for a second term in the presidential race along with his running mate after the DPP presidential yet-to-be-formed ticket is nominated first in a Central Executive Committee meeting on Dec. 10, he said.

President Chen will give a speech in the national congress to explain his concepts on various issues of major national concern, such as holding a referendum on election day, writing a new constitution and national security matters, he went on.

In an effort to help foster an enthusiastic atmosphere at the national congress, an election song and a logo to be used during the campaign will be made public a day earlier and presented in the national congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Russia to reject pact on climate, Putin aide says.
A senior Kremlin official said Tuesday that Russia would not ratify the Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty requiring cuts in emissions of gases linked to global warming. A total of 120 countries have ratified the treaty. Russia's rejection could be a fatal blow to the treaty which can take effect only when approved by enough countries to account for 55 percent of 1990 emissions from the industrial world. With the United States and Russia, that threshold cannot be met.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF DENIES REPORT ON OPPOSITION TO TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Douglas Paal denied reports Wednesday that he had suggested that United States President George W. Bush openly announce his opposition to Taiwan independence.
In an interview with Central News Agency (CNA) , Paal said that the reports were "totally groundless."

The Wall Street Journal said in its editorial Dec. 3 that both Paal and James Moriarty, senior director of Asian affairs at the U.S. National Security Council, want Bush to change U.S. policy on Taiwan independence from one of neutral "non-support" to active and presumably public "opposition."
The AIT chief also described reports by Taiwan media that the U.S. State Department has called him home for consultations as "ridiculous."

Referring to another report that Moriarty was recently in Taipei to convey President Bush's concerns to President Chen Shui-bian about the holding of referendums, Paal said that he does not know whether Moriarty had visited Taipei or not and that he would not comment.
Dean Anderson, a spokesman for AIT, echoed Paal's statement by saying that Paal has no plans to return to Washington, D.C. in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE OFFICIAL VISITED TAIPEI: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: James Moriarty, senior director for Asian affairs of the U.S. National Security Council, had indeed made an undisclosed visit to Taipei in the past few days, a U.S. China hand said Tuesday.

John J. Tkacik, a Heritage Foundation research fellow who once worked at the Department of State, said he has received confirmation from reliable sources that Moriarty visited Taipei recently to exchange views with senior Taiwan officials on the latest developments in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Tkacik said Moriarty has already left Taipei but is still in Asia. "Moriarty is scheduled to return to Washington, D.C. Thursday," he added.

Moriarty is likely to be in Beijing at present to negotiate certain details regarding mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's upcoming visit to the United States, particularly those related to cross-strait ties. Wen is scheduled to arrive in New York Sunday and will travel to Washington, D.C. Tuesday to start his first official visit to the United States since taking office.

Tkacik said he thought that Moriarty should have an important agenda to consult with senior Taiwan officials. To the best of his understanding, Tkacik said the Bush administration was originally scheduled to hold a meeting of deputy chiefs of various departments Tuesday to set the tone regarding Wen's upcoming visit.

It was worthy of concern that Moriarty traveled to Taiwan before the Bush administration set its tone on Wen's visit, Tkacik said, adding that this should be related to a seeming escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait.

Commenting on State Department spokesman Richard Boucher's remarks a day earlier that the United States would be opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move toward independence, Tkacik said it seems to him that Boucher's remarks signal a change in U.S. policy toward cross-strait relations, even though relevant State Department officials had reiterated to him that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged.

Meanwhile, Tkacik said he agreed with ROC President Chen Shui-bian's statement that Beijing's deployment of nearly 500 missiles aimed at Taiwan is sufficient reason for a "defensive referendum" to be called March 20, 2004 -- the day of the next presidential election.

Article 17 of Taiwan's newly passed referendum law empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security issues in the event of an external threat. The threat that could trigger a "defensive referendum" is tacitly seen as coming from the mainland.
Chen's declaration aroused concern that the move might provoke Beijing, which has threatened to attack Taiwan should the island declare independence.
In his view, Tkacik said, whenever Beijing equates Taiwan independence to war, Taiwan should retort it with the declaration that an attack from Beijing means Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO DECIDE ON REFERENDUM LAW VETO DEC. 8

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will decide whether to request the Legislative Yuan reconsider the newly passed referendum law next Monday, a senior official said Wednesday.

Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung made the remarks after Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung at a weekly Cabinet meeting to make an overall review of the referendum law passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan last Thursday.

The referendum law was sent to the Presidential Office earlier in the day for promulgation. According to the ROC Constitution, the Cabinet may request the legislature to reconsider a law within 10 days of the promulgation in case it deems the law difficult to execute. If after reconsideration, more than half of the legislators present at the meeting uphold the original bill, the Cabinet must abide by the bill.

Lin said a final decision will be made on whether to ask the legislature to reconsider the referendum bill at a meeting of officials from the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) headquarters next Monday.
"It will also be decided at the meeting whether to ask for reconsideration of all provisions of the bill or just some of its clauses," Lin said.

The Cabinet had requested the Legislative Yuan reconsider various bills on eight previous occasions, including the bill on allocation of government revenues in 2002, the Labor Standard Law in 1995 and the Legislative Yuan Organizational Law in 1993.

The DPP legislative caucus said it will urge the Cabinet to request the legislature reconsider some controversial provisions in the newly passed referendum bill, such as the clause that empowers the Legislative Yuan to initiate a referendum and the provision requiring the formation of a committee to screen referendum proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN ASSESSING SIGNING FTA: BUREAU OF FOREIGN TRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan are currently assessing the possibility of signing a free trade agreement (FTA), but the reality of such an accord remains some way off, an official with the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Wednesday.
According to the BOFT official, the bureau will do its utmost to push for such an agreement with Japan, and relevant authorities in the two countries are conducting an evaluation of the issue.

The official's remarks came after a foreign media report that two major economic groups in Thailand and Japan recently inked a pact on closer economic cooperation -- mainly on cutting customs tariffs and easing regulations to erase trade barriers -- to pave the way for a much-anticipated FTA. It is expected that the two countries will launch FTA talks next week.

Given that Japan is Thailand's largest direct foreign investor, the cooperation pact will help Thailand largely sharpen its international competitiveness against mainland China and countries in the Middle East and South Asia, especially in the car, home appliances and electronics industries, the official commented.
On the other hand, the pact will also help Japan make inroads into the promising Southeast Asian market, which boasts of a population of 570 million people, he said.

Amid Japan's full drive to forge FTAs with countries in the region, which also includes Malaysia and the Philippines, he said the BOFT will do its best to push for such an accord with Taiwan, although it may take some more time to see any results.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST SUPPORT GROUP BY FOREIGN SPOUSES TO BE INAUGURATED SUNDAY

TEXT.P: The first support group set up by foreign spouses in Taiwan will be formally inaugurated Dec. 7, a professor who helped organize the association said Wednesday.

Shih Hsin University professor Hsia Hsiao-juan said she hoped the group will be able to help women coming from such Southeast Asian nations as Cambodia, Indonesia and Thailand to learn Mandarin Chinese and the local customs of Taiwan.
In the future, the group hopes to help foreign women get the protection and working rights in Taiwan they are entitled to, Hsia said.

More than 10 foreign brides attending a language class in Meinung, southern Taiwan, first came up with the idea of forming a group to help others in their situation. They felt that newly arrived foreign women are not fairly treated in Taiwan, and that those who have weathered the storm of unfamiliar customs and language should pool their strength to form a group to engage in positive dialogue with Taiwan society.
Hsia pointed out that immigrant-related regulations are now under review, but Taiwan's legislation has failed to take into account the voices of these new immigrants.
At the inauguration of the association will be various classes to serve and support women from Southeast Asia, she said.

Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung and Yeh I-jin also attended the announcement, saying that they are concerned about the situation of newly arrived immigrants. They also bought paintings by the group's foreign spouses to sell to help get the association off the ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY HAS ROLE IN SENSE OF ACHIEVEMENT: POLL

TEXT.P: Money plays a role in people's sense of achievement, according to the results of a mental health survey released by a private mental health promotion group Wednesday.

The telephone poll of 1,077 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the Mental Health Foundation from Oct. 17-22 found that those who have a monthly income of NT$80,000 or over are most optimistic about the future.
The survey results also show that for the respondents, the higher one's income, the higher one's sense of achievement.
In contrast, those who have received tertiary education do not necessarily feel a strong sense of achievement, according to the poll.
Nearly 58 percent of the respondents said they think the future will be better than the present, while 42 percent said they think otherwise.
A background analysis shows that those with higher income (NT$80,000 or over) and higher education are generally more optimistic about the future.
In comparison, male respondents, elderly people and those who have less education, are divorced, widowed or separated, are generally more pessimistic about their futures.
An interesting finding is that those with less education enjoy a higher degree of sense of achievement than those with tertiary education.

Compared with the findings of a similar survey conducted last year, the mental health of this year's respondents was slightly better than that of those surveyed last year, even though their average score in the foundation's zero-to-100-point scale was still two points short of a passing grade of 80 points.

A foundation spokesman attributed the progress to a combination of factors, including the steady economic recovery, social stability and a relatively improved public health environment in the wake of the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak of earlier this year.
According to the poll, one out of every three respondents said they suffer from sleep disorders, fatigue and susceptibility to despair or depression.
Dr. Hu Hai-kuo, director of National Taiwan University Hospital's mental health department, said an ordered life, regular workouts and rest are key elements to mental health.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE 7,000 TONS OF RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has decided to offer 7,000 tons of rice to help the poor in Mongolia, who have been suffering a food shortage due to a severe winter, a COA official said Wednesday.
With the help of the charity organization World Vision Taiwan, the rice will be shipped within the next few days to Mongolia, where it will be distributed to some 250,000 Mongolians in need.
The COA has offered to donate 100,000 tons of rice annually to local charity organizations for delivery to other troublespots around the world as necessary.

To date this year, the COA has donated 24,000 tons of rice to countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan, and has offered 50,000 tons of rice to local charity organizations, including the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps, for overseas relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PROPOSES NAME CHANGE FOR TAIWAN IN PLANNED REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) proposed Wednesday that the government put the issue of a name change for Taiwan's official designation on its planned referendum slated for March 20 along with the next presidential election.

TSU Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia urged President Chen Shui-bian to include the issue in the planned referendum "in order to underscore Taiwan's sovereignty and national dignity" to mainland China and the rest of the world.
Taiwan can only make its sovereignty and national dignity clear to the world and win its respect by changing its official title of the Republic of China, Lin claimed.

The TSU's proposal came on the heels of comments made recently by Washington officials on the U.S. stance on Taiwan that reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan independence and would be opposed to a referendum that would change Taiwan's status quo.

Lin claimed that the officials made the comments to placate Beijing prior to a visit by mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and to serve as a warning to Beijing's threat of the use of force against Taiwan.

According to Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, Chen is expected to come up soon with issues to be contained in what he calls a defensive referendum, which could be held when the nation's security is threatened by outside forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CANADA TIES GROWING STEADILY: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Substantive relations between the Republic of China and Canada are growing steadily despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, ROC Representative to Canada Chen Tong-pi said Wednesday.
Addressing a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, Chen said the Canadian government's previous pro-Beijing policy once hampered growth in bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Nevertheless, he went on, Taiwan-Canadian ties have managed to make progress through the concerted efforts of diplomatic staff over the years.

Chen said the Canadian parliament's passage of a resolution earlier this year supporting Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly -- the governing body of the World Health Organization -- marked a breakthrough in bilateral relations.

Under its "one China" policy, Chen said, the Canadian government only supports Taiwan's participation in international trade and economic organizations, such as the World Trade Organization and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. As for organizations that require statehood, he added, Canada has adopted a cautious "no support, no opposition or conditional support" attitude.
Meanwhile, Chen touted the achievements in promoting parliamentary exchanges in recent years, noting that more than 110 of the 300 Canadian parliamentarians have visited Taiwan.

Moreover, Chen said, Canadian parliamentarians have formed an amity association to promote exchanges and cooperation with Taiwan's Legislative Yuan. "The association now has 110 members, making it the largest of its kind in the Canadian parliament," he added.
With the establishment of a parallel friendship association by Taiwan legislators Oct. 31, Chen said he is convinced that Taiwan-Canada parliamentary exchanges will become even closer in the future.

In the face of mainland China's intensified campaign to sway the allegiance of ROC expatriates, Chen said he has spared no efforts to strengthen contacts with the overseas Chinese community in Canada since assuming office.

The ROC representative office in Canada has forged strong ties with all associations of Taiwan expatriates there, regardless of their party affiliation, Chen said, adding that branches of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace have been set up in six Canadian cities, including Vancouver, Toronto, Ottawa and Montreal.

As incoming Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin has long been active in international affairs, Chen said the ROC government should step up efforts to promote engagements with Canada for mutual benefit.
"We should endeavor to lobby the Canadian government to play a stronger pro-Taiwan role in the international arena," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS ASSOCIATIONS MUST PLAY GREATER ROLE IN AGRICULTURAL PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Farmers' associations should diversify their roles to help local farmers widen their business scope and explore the domestic and foreign markets, experts said Wednesday at a seminar aimed at seeking new horizons for farmers' organizations.

Speaking at the seminar, which was jointly sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Lin Chin-hung, chairman of the National Training Institute for Farmers' Organizations, said farmers' associations should adjust their structure to better serve farmers in rural and urban areas.

Farmers' associations in the countryside are often troubled by lack of budget for conducting promotional activities, while those in urban areas are healthier financially but lack customers to serve, Lin said, pointing out that their operational earnings are not sufficient to aid the farmers they represent.

According to Lin, farmers' associations nationwide register a total business turnover of nearly NT$30 billion (US$870 million) each year from a wide range of operations, but their profits are limited. A majority of 243 are slightly profitable, five are in the red and five are breaking even, he added.
The Taipei County Farmers' Association is the most profitable, with annual earnings of just over NT$21 million, he noted.
Stressing the need for in-depth agro-financial reform, Lin urged farmers' associations to sharpen their competitiveness in distribution, processing, warehousing and exports.

Day Sheng-tong, chairman of the Republic of China Small and Medium Business Association, said Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) has had a great impact on the agricultural industry and he urged the sector to make bold adjustments to embrace the coming challenges by setting up distribution networks in the international market.

Farmers' associations should play an institutionalized role of product distributor and marketing organization, as well as information researchers and training centers for farmers, to help them create brand names that can win a greater presence in the international market, he said.
Agricultural reform, mainly focusing on the financial divisions of the farmers' associations, has been one of the major topics on the government's agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE ABORIGINAL STUDENTS TO BE TRAINED AS ATHLETES

TEXT.P: More aboriginal students will be selected to receive government-funded athletic training when the second phase of a Ministry of Education (MOE) training plan begins shortly, an MOE official said Wednesday.

In the second phase of the plan, the MOE will open four more categories -- gymnastics, taekwando, weightlifting and judo -- to allow indigenous students who have shown talent in athletic ability to receive professional training, said Wang Fu-lin, director of the MOE's Department of Physical Education.
According to Wang, during the first phase of the plan, which began in 1989, some 300 aboriginal students were selected to receive professional athletic training focusing on track-and-field.

The 1989 figure has been weeded down to 48 as of this year, said Wang, adding that the 48, after years of training, have become high-caliber athletes who have won 72 gold medals, 65 silvers and 42 bronzes in numerous competitions at home and abroad.

Pan Ming-chang, a track-and-field coach at the Taitung Athletics Experimental School in eastern Taiwan who has been involved in the MOE training program for many years, gave a thumbs-up to the program, saying that the athletic training has not only helped heighten the aboriginal youths' self-esteem, it has helped nurture athletic talent among the aboriginal people.

The program has also helped improve relations between aboriginal parents and their children who took part in the program, as the youths have become more confident in and comfortable with themselves, Pan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO BUILT ANTI-MISSILE SYSTEM, INCREASE COMBAT CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will build an anti-missile system while bolstering its retaliatory capabilities in the face of the increasing missile threat from mainland China, Vice Minister of Defense Chen Ti-tuan said at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.

Chen made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang from Taipei City, who wanted confirmation of news reports that President Chen Shui-bian told the United States recently that Taiwan will put the purchase of Patriot missiles at the top of a list of weaponry systems procurement items.

Chen confirmed the truth of the reports, saying that the purchase of six Patriot PAC-3 batteries -- among the priorities of a 10-year weaponry system procurement plan -- is scheduled to be fulfilled by the end of next year.
The deputy defense minister said that mainland China's submarine and guided-missile attacks are the two greatest threats to Taiwan's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSING REFERENDUM NOT EQUIVALENT TO OPPOSING INDEPENDENCE: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Department deputy spokesman J. Adam Ereli said Tuesday that the U.S. policy of "no support for Taiwan independence" remains unchanged.

Ereli was responding to questions as to whether State Department spokesman Richard Boucher's remarks a day earlier regarding Taiwan's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" imply that the United States is opposed to Taiwan independence.
Boucher said at a regular news briefing that the United States would be opposed to any referendum that would "change Taiwan's status quo or move toward independence."
Asked whether Boucher's remarks were equivalent to opposition to Taiwan independence, Ereli said Boucher's statements should not be interpreted as U.S. opposition to Taiwan independence.

"We choose our words very carefully and I'm not going to change those words. What Ambassador Boucher said yesterday I think dealt with the question fairly explicitly. On the question of Taiwanese independence, our policy has not changed. We do not support Taiwanese independence," Ereli said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 22 points to close at 5,908, with 19,160 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January fell 31 points to finish at 5,895, with 221 contract transactions, while March futures lost 25 points to finish at 5,900, with 7 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 26.48 points to close at 5,884.97.
The bourse opened at 5,921.58 and fluctuated between 5,927.56 and 5,882.08 during trading.

A total of 2.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.74 billion (US$2.01 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.22 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$78.71 billion (US$2.31 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at 1.1 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent.
Only electrical shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 456 to 270, with 197 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLDING REFERENDUM ON ELECTION DAY WOULD SAVE COSTS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said Wednesday that it would be more cost efficient if the "defensive" referendum were held in sync with the next presidential election as recommended by President Chen Shui-bian.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Home and Nations Committee, Yu said that holding a referendum would cost between NT$400 million (US$11.76 million) and NT$500 million (US$14.7 million) and that money could be saved if it were held simultaneously with the presidential election which is slated for March 20, 2004.

Yu made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition People First Party Legislator Tsao Yuan-chang from the outlying island of Matsu who asked Yu where he thinks the extra money to finance the "defensive" referendum will come from if such a national plebiscite indeed is held early next year.

Yu said that as far as he knows, neither the Ministry of the Interior nor the Central Election Committee have budgeted funds for the holding of any referendums. If a referendum is held, the government's Second Reserve Fund may have to be used, he said, adding that holding the referendum on the day of the presidential election would save a lot in costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times:Putin Slams Brussels on WTO Bid.
Russia will not throw away its "natural advantages" to join the World Trade Organization, President Vladimir Putin told a group of visiting European business leaders in the Kremlin on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Allows Lawyer For Citizen Held as 'Enemy Combatant'; Reversal Comes on Eve of Court Filing.
The Bush administration reversed course last night in one of the most closely watched cases in the war on terrorism, saying a U.S. citizen jailed after being captured with Taliban soldiers in Afghanistan would be allowed access to a lawyer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 26.48 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving down 26.48 points to close at 5,884.97.
Market turnover amounted to NT$68.74 billion (US$2.01 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: House OKs P864.8-B nat'l budget.
The House of Representatives finally approved on second reading yesterday the proposed P864.8-billion national budget for 2004.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Palace: No political deal in power hike.
MALACANANG on Tuesday would seek the recall of an order granting Manila Electric Co. (Meralco) a rate increase starting next month as it denied allegations that the increase was part of a deal with the Lopezes to draft Senator Noli de Castro as President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's running mate.
The Philippine Star: Tsinoys to Arroyo: Call in FBI to stop kidnaps.
Anti-crime groups called on President Arroyo yesterday to seek help from the US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and other foreign law enforcement agencies to stamp out the problem of kidnapping.
The Manila Times: All-out war on kidnap.
Conceding that the kidnappers have grown bolder, Angelo Reyes, the chief of the government's main antikidnapping force, on Tuesday laid out the strategy for an all-out war against kidnap gangs, including the setting up of checkpoints and roadblocks in Metro Manila and the outlying provinces.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 3, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: US gets tough on weapons material.
The United States and its allies are ready to use 'robust techniques' to stop rogue nations from getting the materials they need to make weapons of mass destruction - including interdicting and seizing such 'illicit goods' on the high seas or in the air.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Sentosa residential tender draws 'strong' 130 bids.
About 130 bids poured in for the first batch of 22 residential land parcels released for tender on Sentosa, surprising property consultants and even the project's master developer, Sentosa Cove Pte Ltd.

Revving up the populist rthetoric that has become his trademark, Gov. Arnold schwarzenegger left legislators behind in Sacramento to kick off a four-day statewide campaign aimed at persuading wavering Democratic lawmakers to support his budget plan.
