DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUE INTRUDING UPON UPCOMING BUSH-WEN SUMMIT: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan issue is intruding upon the forthcoming Sino-U.S. summit between mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and U.S. President George W. Bush, the Asian Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.

The report, headlined "Taipei Changes Wen's Trip, " said that the Taiwan issue is intruding upon next week's summit, upsetting an agenda heavily focused on critical trade disputes and disrupting recently cooperative U.S.-Chinese relations.
It said that events in Taiwan in recent weeks have forced Beijing and Washington to confront their sharp differences over the island.
"The rising tensions over a perennial point of friction come just before mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jia-bao meets President George W. Bush in Washington Tuesday," it said.

According to the report, their talks are supposed to concentrate on the United States' ballooning trade deficit with mainland China, perceived barriers to mainland Chinese markets and other economic disagreements that have roiled relations but whose fallout both governments have tried to contain.

"Circumstances, however, are putting Mr. Wen and the Communist leadership in a bind, pinning them between China's two foremost strategic goals: nourishing a vital economy that's buoyed by smooth U.S. relations and absorbing Taiwan without angering Washington, which by law is committed to assisting Taiwan's defense," it said.
These dynamics are pushing Wen into a tightrope act during his upcoming four-day visit to the United States, it said, adding that he is expected to lay down mainland China's position on Taiwan.
The report said that the Taiwan issue is also constraining Washington's room to maneuver as well as further complicating its relations with mainland China.
"Bush is trying to balance stronger support for Taiwan with the need for Chinese help on trade and North Korea while mollifying his conservative Republican base," the report said. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON TUNGSHA TO BE STAGED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A seminar on the ecosystem of the Tungsha islands, a group of islands 240 nautical miles southeast of Taiwan's southern port of Kaohsiung, will open in Kaohsiung Dec. 8.
The seminar, jointly sponsored by the Kaohsiung City Government and the National Sun Yat-sen University, is aimed at protecting the ecosystem of the mainly uninhabited islands.
The Tungsha islands, also known as the Pratas islands, are claimed by various countries in the region, including the Republic of China, which has given the administration mandate to Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADS WORLD IN MOBILE PHONE USERS AS PERCENTAGE OF POPULATION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan leads the world in mobile phone users as a percentage of the population, according to the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) under the United Nations.

In its ITU World Telecommunication Development Report 2003, the union said there are 106.15 subscribers per 100 inhabitants in Taiwan, or 106.15 percent of its population, which ranks the island the first among the 182 economies covered in the report.
Luxemburg follows closely behind in second place, with only 0.1 percentage points less.
However, the two countries reversed their order when fixed-line telephones were calculated in, with Luxemburg leading far ahead of Taiwan, 185.74 percent to 164.31 percent.
With a population of 23 million, Taiwan boasts 37 million telephones, including 22.8 million mobile phones, or 65 percent of the total number of phones, according to the ITU report.

Luxemburg is predicted to catch up with Taiwan in 2005, by which time 118.09 percent of its population is expected to have a mobile phone, compared to 114.29 percent in Taiwan, according to the report.
As to the percentage of population that use computers, Taiwan, with 39.46 percent, lags far behind the 70.87 percent recorded by the leader, Switzerland.
However, if measured by the number of households, Taiwan boasts a record of 72 percent, second in the world next only to the 75 percent of Switzerland.
Taiwan comes in 18th place in Internet users as a percentage of its population, with 8.59 million people, or 38.14 percent of its population, having access to the Internet.
Iceland leads the world with 64.79 percent.

The report, released before the World Summit on the Information Society in Geneva, is designed to fathom out the depth of the digital gap between the developed and less-developed countries, according to its author.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUP IN U.S. URGES BEIJING TO EMBRACE DEMOCRACY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese in the United States urged Beijing Thursday to follow Taiwan's lead in embracing democracy.

In an open letter issued prior to People's Republic of China Premier Wen Jiabao's arrival, the Taiwanese Association of America said the PRC should take lessons in democracy from Taiwan rather than threaten the island's burgeoning democracy with force.

Noting that Wen warned in an interview with the Washington Post last week that his country will not sit on its hands if Taiwan tries to separate from China, the letter said the PRC's attempts to bluff will not work as Taiwan is an independent country whose people will never give up their hard-earned freedom.
Instead of trying to frighten Taiwan away from developing democracy, the letter says, Beijing should rein in its corrupt officials and get them off the backs of the mainland poor.
In a related story that day, Huang Chin-san, a deputy chairman of the association, said his group will orchestrate protests wherever Wen goes in the United States.

The protests will begin Dec. 7 in New York, which will be the first leg of Wen's visit, followed by protests outside the Chinese embassy and Wen's hotel in Washington, D.C., on Dec. 9. Another protest will be held in Boston Dec. 11, where Wen is scheduled to deliver a speech at Harvard University, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNLA CERTIFICATE LAB FOR OPTICAL PRODUCTS TO BE ESTABLISHED IN 2005

TEXT.P: The government is planning to establish a Chinese National Laboratory Accreditation (CNLA) certificate lab for optical products in 2005 in Taichung, central Taiwan, an official said Thursday.

Wang Pi-chang, an assistant researcher of the Precision Instrument Development Center under the Cabinet-level National Science Council, said that the lab, which will be qualified as an ISO17025 laboratory, will be constructed in the Taichung Science-based Industrial Park which is home to many optical products manufacturers.
The establishment of the CNLA certificate lab will boost the development of the promising value-added optical industry in Taiwan, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Early flood of political ads saturates airwaves in Iowa.
Iowans have never before been bombarded with so many advertisements from so many candidates so early in presidential campaign season. The four major Democratic candidates competing in Iowa -- Dr. Dean, Mr. Kerry, Senator John Edwards and Mr. Gephardt -- have run at least 4,450 spots in Des Moines alone since January.
The competition over the airwaves is most ferocious in Iowa but is by no means limited to this state. In the nation's top 75 media markets, the Democratic candidates have bought at least 12,700 spots.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES U.S. EISENHOWER EXCHANGE FELLOWSHIPS DELEGATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received visiting delegates of the United States Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships (EEF) Thursday at the Presidential Office and praised the organization for its contributions to the promotion of mutual understanding and peace around the world.

Chen told his guests, who were headed by EEF President Adrian Basora, that Taiwan Eisenhower fellows have invited their counterparts in other countries to tour the country every year since 1974, the year after the formation of the Eisenhower Fellows Association in the Republic of China, with the aim of promoting mutual understanding and friendship.

The association has so far invited 54 Eisenhower fellows from different countries to visit Taiwan, Chen said, adding that it especially invited delegates from its parent group to tour Taiwan this year in celebration of its 30th anniversary.
Chen wished his guests a pleasant visit.
In response, Basora told Chen that the EEF has granted more than 1,600 fellowships to prominent figures around the world since its foundation in 1953, some of whom have become world-level leaders.
The fellowship recipients have made great contributions to the promotion of progress, peace and mutual understanding around the world through their exchanges, he added.
Basora also praised Eisenhower fellows in Taiwan for their efforts to organize exchange activities with their counterparts in other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA WARNS OF POTENTIAL INVESTMENT CRISIS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) warned Taiwan businessmen Thursday of a potential investment crisis in mainland China, especially on the financial front.
The MOEA issued the warning in a report carried out by the Committee of Economic Research and Development under its auspices.

Although the mainland economy will continue to grow fast in 2004, the report claimed that some signals of systematic financial and economic problems have emerged and it urged Taiwan businessmen to be extremely cautious when weighing investment there.

According to the report, the mainland still managed to attract a great deal of foreign investment this year, some US$40.238 billion of which was already capitalized during the first three quarters. It estimated that the mainland's exports and imports in the first nine months might will amount to US$606.3 billion in value.
Citing forecasts by relevant mainland authorities, the report said the mainland economy will expand by more than 8 percent in 2004.

However, the report warned that risks, such as a speculation for renminbi's strong appreciation, inadequate investment in infrastructure and mounting financial loans and money supplies, will accompany the ongoing influx of international hot money taking advantage of the mainland's booming economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMISES TO KEEP FIGHTING FOR DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reconfirmed his commitment to democracy and the protection of human rights Thursday.

In his personal on-line weekly, Chen recalled his bitter fight for democracy and human rights and the contributions he has made to the cause in his political career, not least the long way the country has come in these two fields since he took office in 2000.

His efforts were acknowledged in October when the International League for Human Rights honored him with an award in New York, Chen said, describing the award as an acknowledgement of the country's democratization and an honor for all the people of the country.

The president said his fight for democracy and human rights has taken a heavy toll on his family life, but he added that he takes pride in the difference he has made when he sees that the people can choose their leaders and express their political opinions freely.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES TO RECRUIT SOME 300 FOREIGN PILOTS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, will recruit 200 to 300 foreign pilots in the coming year to meet its operational demands, a company spokesman said in Vancouver Wednesday.

Liu Fang-you, a senior executive of CAL's flight affairs department who arrived in Vancouver earlier this week to preside over interviews of Canadian pilots hoping to work for CAL, said more than 40 Air Canada pilots have registered for the first round of interviews to be held Thursday and Friday. Those who pass the first-round interviews will then travel to Taipei for physical checkups and second-round interviews.

Liu said CAL has plans to open new routes and will gradually take delivery of 18 new passenger and cargo planes ordered from Airbus Co. and Boeing Co. in the coming years. In the meantime, about 50 of its current pilots will retire in the next two years.
Against this backdrop, Liu said, the carrier badly needs experienced foreign pilots and co-pilots. "We need to recruit 200 to 300 new pilots," he added.
CAL presently has 941 pilots, 204 of whom are foreigners from 30 countries. Australians form the bulk of CAL's foreign pilot force, followed by Canadians.

In addition to recruiting Canadian pilots, Liu said 30 to 40 Singapore Airlines pilots will begin working for CAL next year, while the airline will also launch manpower drives in major European countries next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAUNCHES LETTER CAMPAIGN CALLING FOR U.S. SUPPORT FOR REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) issued an open letter to U.S. President George W. Bush Thursday urging him to support Taiwan's holding of a referendum to resolve its sovereignty and status issues.

The pro-independence TSU, an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , also launched a campaign encouraging the people of Taiwan to send letters to Bush pushing him to support the "sovereignty referendum" proposal.

According to the TSU letter, holding a referendum on Taiwan's sovereignty and independent status is a move to demonstrate to the United States and the international community what the party claims is Taiwan's "mainstream public opinion and values."
The move is not only correct but also complies with the prevailing world trend, the letter claims.

It also urges Bush and his administration not to regard Taiwan as a troublemaker. Bush should respect and support the Taiwan people's right to "be the masters of Taiwan's destiny" and "let Taiwan be Taiwan of the world, not of China."
TSU legislative whip Lo Chih-ming said that because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan has been unable to join the United Nations and many other international organizations.

"The embargo seems to deprive Taiwan of its sovereign status," Lo said, adding that the TSU letter is aimed at letting Bush understand the Taiwan people's strong desire to be "masters of Taiwan's destiny."
The TSU noted that Bush's official e-mail address is "president@whitehouse.gov" and urged local citizens to support its "one person, one letter to Bush" campaign.

TSU Legislator Ho Min-hao said he hopes a "sovereignty plebiscite" can be held on the day of the March 20 presidential election next year to remind mainland China that its saber-rattling against Taiwan will be to no avail.
Noting that the United States is a beacon of democracy, Ho said the Bush administration should support Taiwan's holding of a "sovereignty plebiscite."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: 3 convicted of genocide in Rwanda.
In the first verdict of its kind since the Nuremberg trials, an international court Wednesday convicted three Rwandan news media executives of genocide for inciting gangs who slaughtered about 800,000 Tutsi in neighboring Rwanda in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION TO PROPOSE RESOLUTIONS ON STATUS QUO AND MAINLAND THREAT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the opposition camp said on Thursday that they would propose that the Legislative Yuan pass two resolutions concerning Taiwan's status quo and the military threat of mainland China.
The Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) made the announcement in an apparent attempt to block President Chen Shui-bian initiating a planned "defensive referendum."

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's central policy department, said that the resolutions -- that the status quo will be maintained of an independent, sovereign Republic of China, and that mainland China should gradually withdraw its missiles targeting Taiwan, will represent the common will of the people on the island.
"They will represent a statement and declaration of Taiwan people to the United States, mainland China and the Asia and Pacific countries," Tseng said.
He said that if the resolutions pass unanimously in the Legislative Yuan, then President Chen will have no need to initiate a "defensive referendum."
But if the Legislative Yuan fails to pass the resolutions, then the KMT and PFP will not rule out the possibility of the legislature initiating a referendum.

Chou Hsi-wei, the PFP's party whip in the legislature, said that the legislature is the highest representative institution of the people's will and every political party should support the resolutions to be proposed by the KMT and the PFP, which he said will "resolve the threat that the missile crisis poses to Taiwan's political scene."

Chou stressed that resolutions of the Legislative Yuan have the same effect of galvanizing the will of the people in the same way as a referendum, and mainland China's "response to the resolutions is another matter."
Chou also criticized the president's plan to initiate a referendum to protect the nation's sovereignty and to urge Beijing to withdraw its missiles targeting Taiwan as time and money consuming.

Lee Chia-chin, KMT party whip in the legislature, said that the resolutions are a way to express the voice of Taiwan people and a way to protest against Beijing and ask it to address the missile problem squarely, which he said is also helpful to restart the stalled cross-strait dialogue.

The legislature passed a referendum bill last Thursday that was largely based on the version of the opposition camp to set strict restrictions on initiating a referendum, despite the fact that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party had first advocated the legislation.

But article 17 of the referendum bill empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security issues in the event of external threat. The threat which could trigger a defensive referendum is tacitly seen as coming from the mainland.

President Chen, addressing a rally in southern Taiwan last Sunday, said Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan is sufficient reason for a "defensive referendum" to be called on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004.
Chen's declaration has aroused serious concern that the move might provoke Beijing, which has threatened to attack Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO HOLD MULTILATERAL TRADE TALKS SURROUNDING FTA

TEXT.P: The government should not overlook the importance of holding multilateral trade talks with other countries at a time when it is actively seeking to forge two-way free trade agreements (FTA), an economist said Thursday.
Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the call at a seminar on the economic cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region in post-Cancun talks era.

Although countries around the world have shifted their attention to create two-way FTAs following the collapse of the multilateral trade talks held by the World Trade Organization (WTO) in mid-September in Cancun, Mexico, Wu said Taiwan should still try to work out a model under which it can conduct multilateral trade negotiations and ink such trade pacts with friendly countries.

According to Wu, forging a two-way trade accord is usually more costly than signing a multilateral trade pact, and is particularly unfair to poorer countries. At a time when anti-terrorism topics are on the minds of the international community, a multilateral trade accord will also help provide greater security for signing member nations, he added.

The Cancun meeting, a follow-up called by the WTO to discuss a pact reached in the 2001 WTO conference in Doha, Qatar, broke up due to sharp differences between rich and poor countries over the Singapore issue -- market opening, regulatory affairs, improvement in transparency in government procurement and simplified procedures for cross-boarder transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSAL TO AMEND CONSTITUTION TO BE REFERRED TO COMMITTEE FOR REVIEW

TEXT.P: A plenary session of the Legislative Yuan decided Thursday to refer a proposal to amend the ROC Constitution to a committee for review.

The proposal, jointly presented by lawmakers of the two major opposition parties, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , is aimed at substituting a national referendum for a vote of the National Assembly in approving any amendment to the Constitution.

This is the first step in following through with a promise made by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in mid-November when he pledged to give the country a new constitution through a referendum in 2006, two years earlier than promised by President Chen Shui-bian.
The legislature has now to form a committee to review the proposal sponsored by all of the 102 lawmakers of the KMT and PFP.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said he will call in leaders of various parties to work out details in forming the committee. Unless they agree otherwise, a committee on constitutional amendment should have members numbering one more than a half of the total number of lawmakers, or 113.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUIDE DOG ASSOCIATION TO INVITE PEOPLE TO TAKE PART IN TRAINING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan Guide Dog Association is inviting people to take part in a three-year training program in the United States, hoping to nurture more professionals for the long-term development of the Seeing Eye dog program.
Association officials noted that no institutions in Taiwan have the ability to accredit a guide dog trainer, and they have to rely on schools of other countries for training and accreditation.

To speed up the training, the association will cooperate with Leader Dog School in Detroit, Michigan, the officials said, adding that this is the first time that the school has accepted overseas students in nearly seven decades since the inception of the school.

The officials noted that Taiwan currently has a very limited number of professional trainers, and that the training period is a long one. It is hoped that through the assistance of overseas schools, more trainers will be available in Taiwan.

The program will choose three among all aspirants, with two of the students funded by the program, while the third will have to pay his or her own expenses. Those who are college graduates and are under 35 years old can register for the program. More information is available at the Web site: www.guidedog.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ASKED TO WATCH FOR IPR INFRINGEMENT VIA THE INTERNET

TEXT.P: Law enforcement must not only work to protect intellectual property rights by foiling pirates of software, music and movies, but should turn their attention to the issue of copyright infringement via the Internet, an anti-piracy group said Thursday.

Members of the Taiwan Anti-Piracy Coalition, which is composed of various groups around the island dedicated to protecting intellectual property rights, made the appeal during a visit to the offices of the police unit tasked with investigating IPR infringement cases.
Coalition members were appreciative of the unit's overall results but said that more needed to be done to stop illegal exchanges and sales on the Internet.

According to the National Police Administration, the police unit mainly deals with major IPR infringement cases, especially upstream manufacturers of pirated material and wholesale warehouses. The focus of their work has been pirated audio and video discs. The coalition said that the number of pirated discs available has declined over the past year.

However, they said that selling pirated material on the Net is on the rise and cited a recent case where the coalition, working with the police unit, uncovered Internet users who had been using P2P technology to file share copyrighted software.

The coalition members stressed that piracy not only involves business interests, but creates social and economic problems. One example, they pointed out, is that of the local film industry, which has slumped due to the proliferation of pirated movies. Moreover, gangsters have been turning to IPR crimes to fund their other illegal activities, they said.
The IPR protection police unit was established on Jan. 1 this year, and currently has 220 officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING TO FORGE NEW TIES WITH GEORGIA: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has stepped up efforts to forge a new relationship with Georgia following a bloodless revolution in the Central Asian country late last month, a senior official said Thursday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Victor C. Y. Tseng, director-general of MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department, said Taiwan hopes to develop new ties with Georgia in the wake of a transition of power in the former Soviet republic.

Former Georgia President Eduard Shevardnadze was forced to resign Nov. 24 after weeks of opposition protests over a disputed parliamentary election on Nov. 2. Shevardnadze, a former Soviet foreign minister and a hero in the West when he helped oversee the end of the Cold War -- handed power to Nino Burjanadze, speaker of the Georgian parliament and one of the opposition leaders who organized the protests.

Noting that Georgia occupies an important strategic location in the Kavkaz region, Tseng said MOFA will make every possible effort to cultivate friendship and cooperative ties with the new Georgian government.
Meanwhile, Tseng urged local people to cut non-essential visits to the Middle East in view of frequent reports of terrorist attacks in the region.
A spate of suicide blasts were reported in the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh and the largest Turkish city of Istanbul in recent weeks, causing heavy casualties and property damage.

Quoting information provided by the U.S. Embassy in Riyadh, Tseng said the terrorist threat to residents and tourists in Saudi Arabia still exists. Tseng said his department has cooperated with MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs and the Government Information Office in advising local citizens to reduce non-essential trips to Middle East countries, particularly Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: DYSENTERY OUTBREAKS FROM BALI VISITS HURT TAIWAN TRAVEL AGENCIES

TEXT.P: The breakout of dysentery cases among Taiwan tourists who visited Bali in November has had a noticeable impact on outbound travel to the Indonesian resort island, a tourism industry source said Thursday.

Wu Yen-hui, an official of the Taipei Association of Travel Agents, said the outbreak of the disease last month among Taiwan tourists has largely affected the business of domestic travel agencies, prompting airplane ticket prices on regular flights from Taipei to Bali to drop by more than 30 percent from the high season level for the July-October period, which costed NT$12,000 (US$355) for two persons on a round trip.

Charter plane services arranged by travel agencies in southern Taiwan have been more affected, with nearly 50 percent of the customers booking for group package tours slated to depart for Bali in December canceling their reservations, Wu said, adding that travel agencies have not yet canceled the tours out of grave concern that it will deal a further blow to the market.
Wu predicted that the low ticket prices will remain until the middle of January and that the price may rise for the following winter and spring holiday seasons.
A total of 99 Taiwan tourists who had traveled to Bali between Nov. 7-22 have been confirmed as having contracted dysentery as of Tuesday after returning home. The first case was reported Nov. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN TO DISCUSS LABOR IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Mongolian Minister for Social Welfare and Labor Shi Batbayar will visit Taiwan next week to attend an international meeting and discuss issues regarding Taiwan's plan to import Mongolian workers, an official said Thursday.

Victor C. Y. Tseng, director-general of the West Asian Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , said Batbayar is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Monday to attend the 30th Asia-Pacific regional conference of the International Council of Social Welfare.
Batbayar will deliver a speech on Mongolia's social welfare and youth service programs at the Dec. 8-12 conference, Tseng said.

During his stay in Taipei, Tseng said, Batbayar is also expected to meet with Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu to exchange views on Taiwan's plan to import Mongolian workers. The ROC government has decided to open its labor market to Mongolian citizens in the near future.
Officials from Taiwan's Department of Health recently inspected the hospitals in Mongolia designated for giving health exams to Mongolian laborers hoping to work in Taiwan.

In addition, Tseng said, Batbayar will pay a visit to the Eden Social Welfare Foundation which will donate seven notebook computers to the Mongolian Ministry for Social Welfare and Labor in support of the Mongolian government's computerization program.

Meanwhile, Tseng went on, MOFA has invited four Mongolian politicians -- M. Enkhsaikhan, Mongolian Democratic Party chairman; former Finance Minister P. Tsagaan; J. Narantsatsralt, a member of the parliament; and T. Sukhbaatar, director of the Democratic Party's international affairs department -- to visit Taiwan Dec. 15-19 as part of its efforts to boost substantiative relations between the two countries.
Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Tseng said, Taiwan-Mongolian exchanges and cooperation have been growing steadily in recent years.

On Wednesday, Taiwan donated 7,000 tons of rice to poor families in Mongolia. The rice was donated by the Council of Agriculture while the World Vision Taiwan -- a non-profit private organization dedicated to helping the underprivileged -- handled the costly task of delivering the rice to Mongolia, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 7,000 TONS OF RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated 7,000 tons of rice to Mongolia to help the impoverished people of the country, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Victor C.Y. Tseng, MOFA's director-general of the Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said that World Vision in Taiwan on Wednesday delivered the rice, which was provided by the Council of Agriculture.
Tseng said that because of bad weather and the lack of needed necessities in Mongolia, World Vision in Taiwan wanted to give timely assistance.
The delivery of rice is an expensive task since it must first be shipped from Taipei to Tianjin, mainland China, and then to Ulaan Baatar by rail.
The shipment will be made in 4,000 new containers, or those that have not delivered chemicals or pesticides before, and will be made in 20 trips by train.

Dagva Batmunkh, director of the Ulaan Baatar Trade and Economic Representative Office in Taipei, said that the poor in Mongolia account for one-third of the population and the rice is the best Christmas present that the country could hope for.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOPS OTHER COUNTRIES IN DEPENDENCE ON MAINLAND CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan tops other countries in dependence on mainland Chinese market in the first nine months of this year, with 24.3 percent of the island's total exports for the period heading to the mainland, according to the latest tallies from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

DGBAS officials said that the figure has increased over those of the previous two years. Last year, 22.2 percent of Taiwan's total exports for the same period went to the mainland, and the figure was 19.6 percent in 2001.

The figure for the Jan.-Sep. period this year was the highest in the world, followed by that for South Korea, whose exports to mainland China made up 17.7 percent of its total exports, and those for Japan at 12 percent, Russia at 7.7 percent and Thailand at 6.9 percent.

The statistics also showed that Japan was mainland China's main source of imports, accounting for 18 percent of the mainland's total imports, followed by Taiwan at 11.7 percent and South Korea at 10.2 percent.
Following South Korea were the United States, Germany, Malaysia, Singapore, Russia and Thailand, in that order.

TAIEX Index futures for January gained 39 points to finish at 5,934, with 193 contract transactions, while March futures remained unchanged at 5,925, with 4 contracts traded.
June futures moved down 7 points to finish at 5,889, with one contract changing hands, while September futures rose 3 points to close at 5,900, also with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,908 for December, 5,895 for January, 5,925 for March, 5,896 for June, and 5,897 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
December TE futures moved up 1.1 points to finish at 253.9, with 2,902 contract transactions, while January TE futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 253.45, with 15 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.49 points to close at 5,920.46.
The bourse opened at 5,895.28 and fluctuated between 5,927.37 and 5,888.23 during trading.

A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.92 billion (US$1.9 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.95 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$68.74 billion (US$2.01 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares moving down 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 1 percent, electrical shares at 0.6 percent, bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 416 to 292, with 225 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG GOVERNMENT EXPECTED TO BEGIN ISSUING BONDS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government is near a final decision to issue bonds for the first time in a decade, the Asian Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.
Burdened by a widening fiscal deficit,the Hong Kong government is near a final decision to issue bonds, the report said.
The report quoted Financial Secretary Henry Tang as saying that this would create a "deep and liquid" debt market in a city where most people trade only stocks.
"It's in a very advanced stage of consideration," Tang said in an interview with the paper.
"The community is starting to have a stronger and stronger consensus towards it. It's a more modern way of managing finance," he added.

Tang said bonds would be used to finance some of the HK$120 billion (US$15.46 billion) the government plans to spend on infrastructure, such as bridges and highways linking Hong Kong to mainland China, over the next five years.
However, he added that bonds would not be used to overcome chronic shortfalls in the government's recurring expenditures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY DONATES 5,000 EUROS TO URBANI ASSOCIATION
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China first lady Wu Shu-chen has donated 5,000 euros to an association in honor of the late Dr. Carlo Urbani in Italy to provide medical assistance in backwards areas around the world.

Urbani, who was an expert on communicable diseases with the World Health Organization (WHO) , was the first doctor in the world to identify severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) . He later died of the new disease in March this year.
Urbani's wife, eight months after her husband's death, set up the association in his honor to provide medical assistance to backward regions.

ROC first lady Wu, during her nine-day visit to Europe in July, which included a stop in the Vatican, met with Mrs. Urbani in Rome. Wu gladly accepted Mrs. Urbani's invitation at the time to serve as an honorary member of the planned association.

Wu told Mrs. Urbani at the time that although Taiwan has been unable to enter the WHO due to mainland China's obstruction, the island would continue to contribute to international medical care, adding that she is more than willing to donate money to sponsor medical service and research in backward regions.

The first lady recently sent a message to the association through the ROC's representative office in Rome in which she lauded Dr. Urbani for his selfless dedication to world medical care and asked the office to donate 5, 000 euros on her behalf to the association to help in its cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 4, or the 11th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES MONEY AND DEWORMING DRUGS TO PARAGUAYAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan donated NT$5 million (US$146,718) and two million tablets of deworming drugs Friday to be used by Paraguayan students.

In a ceremony witnessed by Vice President Annette Lu at the Presidential Office, Francisco Hwang, vice minister of foreign affairs, presented the funds on behalf of the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the foreign ministry to the visiting Paraguay Minister of Education and Culture Blanca Ovelar de Duarte.
On the same occasion, Vice Minister of Health Lee Lung-teng presented the tablets designed to cure students of round worms to Ovelar.

The donation is part of Lu's efforts to help students in Paraguay. Lu vowed to launch a campaign to encourage local university students to help finance the education of Paraguayan students with regular donations.
The vice president also promised to raise another NT$5 million to finance the education cost of 500 Paraguayan students for two years.

Noting that Paraguay is the country's only ally in South America, Lu said Taiwan should strengthen its ties with the country and make it the country's bridgehead to venture into the South American market.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES PARAGUAYAN EDUCATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu received Paraguayan Minister of Education and Culture Blanca Ovelar de Duarte Friday at the Presidential Office and exchanged views on matters of mutual concern.

Lu told her guest that Taiwan can provide assistance to Paraguay in the educational field five ways, including helping Paraguayan needy children attend school by patronage, encouraging college students of the two countries to write each other, promoting donations of used computers for Paraguayan universities, promoting academic exchanges of the two countries' researchers and helping train Paraguayan skilled individuals.
Lu also extended a warm welcome to Ovelar and asked her to convey her regards to Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte and Vice President Luis Castiglioni.

DOC.HEADLINE: 43 PERCENT OF PEOPLE FAVOR REFERENDUM ON MARCH 20: POLL

TEXT.P: Forty-three percent of the people responding to an Executive Yuan-sponsored poll support the president's call for a "preventive referendum" to be held concurrently with the presidential election on March 20, 2004.

The survey was carried out by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan and was issued Friday. It showed that 43 percent of the respondents favor the creation of a new constitution via referendum by 2006.

Thirty-nine percent said that several articles in the referendum bill just passed by the legislature have unreasonably restricted people's civil rights and the Executive Yuan should try to annul the bill by asking the Legislative Yuan to reconsider it.

Meanwhile, 58 percent believed that the Executive Yuan's new 10 major construction projects, which will cost the government NT$500 billion over five years, will accelerate the country's economic development.
Thirty-six percent of the respondents said "yes" when asked whether it is reasonable for the referendum bill to forbid the executive branch from initiating referendums, while 26 percent disagreed.

Thirty-one percent said it was reasonable for the referendum bill to forbid the executive branch from organizing a referendum that would have no binding force, known as an "advisory referendum," while 33 percent disapproved.

Forty-five percent of those surveyed said it is reasonable to have at least five percent of voters registered in the previous presidential election, or about 770,000 signatures, for a referendum to be held as provided in the bill, while 27 percent said this was an unreasonably large figure.
The survey, conducted by phone between Dec. 1 and Dec. 2 among adults across Taiwan, collected 1,078 valid samples, with a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FALLS FOR NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) stood at 99.75 for November, down by 0.44 percent from the October level and a 0.45 percent fall as compared to the year-earlier level, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.

The average CPI for the first 11 months of this year declined by 0.29 percent from the level posted for the same period of last year, and the CPI for the whole of 2003 is forecast to drop by 0.28 percent as compared to the 2002 level, according to DGBAS tallies.
The fall in the November CPI was a result of noticeable drops in the prices of large production of winter vegetables, a DGBAS official explained.

The wholesale price index (WPI) for November reached 102.32, up by 0.68 percent from the October level and up by 1.06 percent year-on-year. The average for the period from January to November increased by 2.52 percent as compared with the same period a year ago.
The DGBAS official attributed the growth in WPI to rising prices of crude oil, and farm and steel products.

The import price index last month rose by 4.19 percent as compared to the previous-year level, if the prices are denominated in local currency. The index would rise by 6.19 percent if the prices were denominated in U. S. dollars. The New Taiwan dollar appreciated by 1.91 percent against the greenback in November over its year-earlier value.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO BE HONORED BY ALMA MATER IN UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will be honored as a distinguished alumna Monday by her U.S. alma mater, the University of Illinois at Urban-Champaign (UIUC) , according to Lu's office Friday.
Lu, who earned a master's degree in comparative law from UIUC in 1971, will be awarded a medal by Heidi Hurd, the dean of the university's law school, who is in Taiwan for a visit.
In a citation to Lu, the university said the vice president glorifies her alma mater and sets an excellent example for other students with her achievements.

One of the highlights of the NEWater visitor's center is the interactive station which visitors can use to find out how NEWater is made. Visitors can also expect a tour of the plant, slide shows, and of course, a free sample of NEWater. Entry to the center is free of charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FROM VARIOUS COUNTRIES TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from various countries will visit Taiwan next week to learn more of the country and promote mutual understanding and friendship, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.
U.S. Congressman Dan Burton (R-IN) will arrive in Taiwan Dec. 7 for a six-day visit, the officials said.

During his stay, Burton will meet President Chen Shui-bian and other government officials and attend the International Symposium on Aviation and Maritime Security held in Taipei Dec. 7-10, they added.
He will also meet business leaders and visit economic and cultural establishments before departing Dec. 12, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Also, MOFA said that an eight-member parliamentary delegation from Greece, including lawmakers Georgios Orfanos, Constantinos Kiltidis, Petros Madouvalos and Hariklia Makris, will arrive in Taipei Dec. 7 for a five-day visit.
A nine-member parliamentary delegation from Venezuela will arrive in Taipei Dec. 8 for a five-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPANESE PARLIAMENTARIAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received visiting Japanese parliamentarian Tokuichiro Tamazawa Friday at the Presidential Office and thanked him for his long-term support for Taiwan.

During the meeting, Chen also asked his guest to convey his congratulations and regards to Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi for the victory the ruling Liberal Democratic Party won recently in parliamentary elections.
At the same time, Chen asked Tamazawa to help him arrange another meeting with former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori.
Under the arrangement by Tamazawa, Chen met with Mori for the first time in June, 1999 when both of them were not yet in power.
Chen expressed the hope that Mori will visit Taiwan as soon as possible.
On hand at the meeting were also Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chiou Yi-jen, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang and Fang Jen-hui, an advisor to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF QUESTIONED BY PROSECUTOR OVER ALLEGED EMBEZZLEMENT

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong was questioned by prosecutors Friday in connection with his alleged embezzlement.

The questioning, which began early in the morning at the Prosecutors Office of the Taipei District Court, lasted until early afternoon. Afterward, Soong left the Prosecutors Office and made no comment other than to say he asked to argue before a prosecutor against former President Lee Teng-hui, who offered damaging testimony against him in the case. The prosecutor was non-committal to Soong's request.

Soong appeared at a news conference later in the day, claiming he was set up by Lee, who Soong says asked him between 1990 and 1993 to keep funds to finance the Kuomintang's (KMT) secret political work when Lee's grip on power was not yet firm, and that Lee later denied everything.
He reiterated his argument that not a penny of the funds came from the government, and not a penny of it was used to line his own pockets.

He claimed the case only strengthens his determination to cooperate with KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the 2004 presidential election to win power and push democratic and judicial reforms to ensure that the judiciary will never again be used as a political tool.

The case stems from Soong's days as secretary-general of the KMT from 1989 to 1993. He is accused of siphoning off NT$360 million (US$10.55 million) from the party's coffers. The case did not come to light until 1999, when Soong ran against KMT candidate Lien in a three-way race for the presidency.
The KMT filed a complaint with prosecutors against Soong Feb. 16, 2000 -- about one month before the presidential election day.

Soong argued that the funds were entrusted to him by former president and KMT chairman Lee for secret political missions, a claim that has been denied by Lee, who served as party chairman from 1988 to 2000 and was Soong's political mentor until 1999, when the two fell out over a political dispute.
However, a prosecutor ruled against indicting Soong Feb. 20, 2001, when both Soong and Lien were defeated in the presidential election by President Chen Shui-bian.

The KMT, led by Lien, decided not to pursue the case any longer but a lawyer who was retained by the KMT to press charges against Soong filed a motion on his own, forcing the prosecutor to reopen the investigation.

Lee, who fell out with the KMT in 2001, was displeased with the KMT's attempts to close the book on the case and to reach out to Soong, and was especially angry with Lien's decision to unite with Soong against Chen in the March 20 presidential election next year.
Lee gave testimony against Soong Oct. 22 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PROPOSES RESOLUTION PUSHING BEIJING TO REMOVE MISSILES

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposed a resolution Friday demanding mainland China dismantle all of its guided missiles aimed at Taiwan as soon as possible.
The DPP-proposed resolution also urged mainland China to gradually remove its other military installations in its southeastern coast provinces that lie opposite Taiwan.

The DPP legislative caucus initiated the draft resolution after its counterparts of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) proposed a similar resolution a day earlier.
DPP legislative whip Chen Chi-mai said mainland China's missile deployment poses a great threat to peace in the Taiwan Strait and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region.
As the nation's highest popular representative institution, Chen said, the Legislative Yuan should condemn Beijing's military threat on behalf of the 23 million Taiwan people.

Chen said he hopes lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance" which controls a majority in the Legislature can support the passage of the DPP-initiated resolution which he said makes a far stronger push on Beijing than the pan-blue alliance proposed one.

DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Powell asks NATO to play larger role.
Secretary of State Colin Powell on Thursday urged NATO to consider expanding its activities in Iraq, in the Bush administration's most pointed appeal for international help since it went to war last spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONFIDENT OF SUCCESS IN CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT PLAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday he is confident that the plan for cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday can be implemented without problems.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Chen said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has completed all necessary preparations that Taiwan can do unilaterally for the special holiday cross-strait charter flight plan.

"We are now waiting for mainland China to take coordinated action regarding its part of the plan, " Chen said, adding that he believes the mainland will act in time to facilitate the return of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China and their dependents for Chinese New Year.

In an unprecedented move, six Taiwan carriers were allowed to operate charter flights between Shanghai and Taiwan via either Hong Kong or Macau during the last Chinese New Year holiday early this year.

Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said in Beijing Nov. 26 that the mainland is not opposed to allowing a repeat of the charter flights, so long as the services are offered in a "direct, two-way" mode on a reciprocal basis. Zhang further said air carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are welcome to start talks on technical details of the charter flights.
Chen said the MAC has decided to exercise more flexibility and further expand the charter flight plan for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.
According to the MAC's blueprint, the flights can be operated from Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, 2004. Chinese New Year's Day falls on Jan. 22.

The midpoints where the flights have to make a stopover will include other designated third locations in addition to Hong Kong and Macau. The departure and arrival points on the Taiwan side will remain unchanged at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport, while Beijing's Capital Airport will be added to the mainland's departure and arrival points list. Previously, only Shanghai's Pudong Airport was on the mainland list.

Acting on the MAC's request, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a message to its mainland Chinese counterpart Nov. 27 calling for consultations on the charter flight plan. The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) has so far not made any concrete response to the SEF's appeal.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

The SEF said in its message to ARATS that Taiwan is willing to allow mainland carriers to offer the charter flight services, but as two-way services involve the exercise of public authority, including security checks, the SEF said the two sides must meet to hammer out mutually acceptable operational terms.
At Friday's news conference, Chen said he hopes Beijing can take active steps to begin negotiations to materialize the charter flight plan as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES SUPPORT FOR 5-YEAR CONSTRUCTION PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged legislators Friday to put their weight behind his Cabinet's five-year, NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) 10 new major public construction projects for the benefit of future generations.
The premier made the remarks after the conclusion of the general interpellation in the Legislative Yuan that started Sept. 23.

Yu said that he appreciated the views of the legislators during the general interpellation and he added that in the case of those questions that he had not already answered in detail, he will follow up with written reports.

He noted that confined by the rigid expenditure structure, the government's investment in public construction has continued to decline, resulting in a slow pace of growth and a loss of steam in the push to build up momentum for the upgrading of the nation's competitive edge.

For this reason, he said, the Executive Yuan has unveiled its 10 new major public construction projects, which include the building of a third freeway in central Taiwan, the nurturing of the top-notched universities and research centers, and the expansion of Kaohsiung Harbor to turn it into an intercontinental container center, to invest in the nation's future.

Despite criticism from some legislators, he claimed that the nation "has no time for procrastination" and he urged the legislators to look further ahead than the March presidential election and think about the welfare of the nation so that the project can be put into practice as soon as possible.

TEXT.P: Singapore's Police Coast Guard held joint maritime security exercises with its Japanese counterpart Thursday.
The joint exercise involved some 120 officers and 10 patrol craft from the Singapore and Japanese coast guards. It was Singapore's first counter terrorism and piracy exercise with Japan.

Although Singapore's coast guard has regularly held joint exercises with countries in the region, such as Indonesia, the half-day training exercise with Japan was the largest Singapore has ever had with another country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PRODUCES RADIO PROGRAM TO HELP MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: A weekly radio program catering to the needs of mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens will be launched on the Taipei Broadcasting Station from Saturday, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said it has commissioned a private cultural and educational foundation to produce the one-hour program aimed at helping mainland spouses adapt to Taiwan's lifestyle and social customs.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said 190,000 Taiwan citizens have married mainland people, making mainland spouses the largest group of new immigrants to Taiwan.
Chen said the ROC government will continue its policy of "easing restrictions on mainland spouses' daily lives while tightening restrictions on their citizenship applications."

"And the new radio program is part of our efforts to help mainland Chinese spouses understand the government's stance and relevant regulations," Chen said. "We hope the program will help them assimilate into Taiwan society, adapt to local lifestyle and enhance their identification with Taiwan."

Noting that tragedies involving cross-Taiwan Strait marriages have been reported from time to time in recent years, Chen said the government will play an active role in helping resolve problems faced by those couples or families, including parenting and legal counseling.

The new radio program will be aired on FM 93.1 and AM 1134 from 3 p.m. to 4 p.m. every Saturday. Government officials will be invited onto the program to explain official stances and relevant regulations, particularly those related to cross-strait marriages outlined in the newly passed amendments to the statute governing cross-strait exchanges.

In the future, Chen went on, the program will offer a "call-in" section to facilitate two-way communication and if the program receives a good response, he said, similar programs will be produced for broadcast in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH RESULTING FROM FLU VACCINE TO BE COMPENSATED: DOH

TEXT.P: The families of people who suffer a fatal reaction to influenza vaccination can demand compensation of up to NT$2 million (US$58,823), a Department of Health (DOH) official said Friday.

Yen Jer-chieh, a section chief in charge of inoculation at the DOH Center for Disease Control, made the remarks after several sudden deaths were reported after flu inoculation, with the latest case involving Lin Cheng-kuo, president of the fishermen's association in Yunlin, southern Taiwan, the previous day.
Yen noted that the DOH has set up a victim screening team, which will review the application for compensation as well as the verification of the cause of death.
Those who want to apply for compensation should submit their applications within three years of the inoculation, he said.

According to DOH regulations, those who die as a result of flu inoculation can demand up to NT$2 million in compensation, while those who are disabled because of the shots can claim up to NT$1.5 million, and those who are made seriously ill because of the shots will be provided with medical expenses up to NT$600,000.
In addition, the families of victims who are given an autopsy will be given a funeral subsidy of NT$200,000.

The CDC charges one new Taiwan dollar to manufacturers or importers for each dose of the vaccine, which has been funneled into the relief fund for the victims, although few people have applied for compensation in recent years.
He stressed that the flu vaccine is safe and that with the exception for two sudden deaths reported in Yunlin and Changhua, respectively, there have been no other fatalities.
With the possible outbreak of a flu epidemic in Taiwan, many people have rushed to hospitals and clinics to be inoculated as a precautionary measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNAFFECTED BY U.S. REMOVAL OF STEEL IMPORT TARIFFS: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's steel industry remains unaffected by Washington's decision to remove its steel import tariffs as its steel exports to the United States are limited compared to its total outbound shipments, a spokesman for an assets management company said Friday.

Tsai Wan-ta, general manager of ABN-AMRO Assets Management Taiwan, said Taiwan's steel exports to the United States only account for 5 percent, or some 300,000 tons, of the country's overall outbound shipments and that the U.S. decision will have only limited benefits for the domestic industry.
According to Tsai, the China Steel Corporation -- Taiwan's largest steel mill -- produces between 10 million tons and 12 million tons each year.

Tsai said that Taiwan's steel stocks are worthy of investment in the long term because U.S. steel output might fall amid stronger international competition. However, he added that this "indirect" positive effect will not become apparent in the short term.

He said Taiwan's steel stocks are good targets worthy of investment for the time being, as operations and profits in the domestic steel industry are forecast to continue growing next year as a result of robust demand from mainland China. The earnings per share of domestic steel stocks are relatively low at present.

U. S. President George W. Bush scrapped the controversial steel import tariffs, imposed in March 2002, to avert a possible trade war. Mainland China, Brazil, the European Union, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Switzerland and Norway filed a compliant against the U.S. with the World Trade Organization in June the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCOTTISH MISSIONARY COMMEMORATED

TEXT.P: Scottish missionary James Maxwell, who is revered as the original practitioner of Western medicine in Taiwan, was commemorated again Friday with the publication of his biography by a Tainan pastor.

"The Life of Dr. James L. Maxwell, " a 400-page book with more than 400 valuable photos and illustrations, was written by Rev. Joshua Pan, an administrative officer in charge of pastoral care at Sin Lau Hospital, established by Maxwell in 1865.

According to Pan, Maxwell's travels took him all over southern Taiwan during his nearly eight years in Taiwan until 1871, bringing Western medicine to the local people as well as disseminating the gospel.
In addition to preaching and healing, Maxwell also taught in "Pingpu" villages where aboriginal people lived, Pan said.
Maxwell was also the first person to introduce print technology to Taiwan, bringing in the country's first printing machine from Edinburgh in 1880 to facilitate his teaching and preaching, Pan said.

Maxwell's two sons -- John and James II -- both medical doctors, stayed in the region far longer than their father. While John spent more than four decades in mainland China, James junior spent 23 years in Taiwan between 1900 and 1923 as president of Sin Lau Hospital, according to Pan.
A regional teaching hospital, Sin Lau now has 1,500 staff members on its payroll and operates 800 beds in two major facilities in Tainan City and Matou Township in Tainan County.

Dr. Steen, an oncologist from the University of London and a great-grandson of Maxwell, visited Tainan several months ago, bringing with him a lock of his great-grandfather's hair which he donated to Sin Lau as a token for the Tainan people, said Pan.

Addressing the book launch, Deputy Tainan Mayor Hsu Yang-ming lauded Maxwell as a great Western missionary whose significance to southern Taiwan is fully as important as that of Canadian missionary Dr. George Leslie Mackay to northern Taiwan.
Noting that there have been inadequate reports in Taiwan about Maxwell and his sons, Hsu said Pan's new book is an invaluable contribution to Taiwan's historical records.

To commemorate the 138th founding anniversary of the hospital, the Sin Lau authorities have had a statue of Maxwell built and they have invited President Chen Shui-bian to officiate at an inaugural ceremony slated for Dec. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FOC SHIPS TARGETED BY POLICE FOR SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan law enforcement forces are targeting ships plying between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under flags of convenience (FOC) in a sweeping effort to crack down on the smuggling of bootleg tobacco and drugs, sources from the Directorate General of Customs (DGC) said Friday.

Officials from the DGC Kaohsiung Customs Bureau said their information has indicated that counterfeit cigarettes, mostly originating from Tongxiao, Fujian Province, are likely to be shipped via the cross-strait FOC ships to the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung, either for transshipment or for sale in Taiwan as the New Year holiday season approaches.

Since the Kaohsiung Offshore Transportation Center was established in 1997, many FOC vessels plying the Taiwan Strait have been found to be a convenient channel for smugglers bringing in drugs and counterfeit goods via Kaohsiung's transshipment facilities, customs bureau officials said.

Between 1998 and 2000, the "golden" years for smugglers, it was not uncommon for customs officials to discover several different smuggling cases aboard the same ship when making transshipment anchorage at Kaohsiung, the officials said.
Transshipment business has accounted for 60 percent of Kaohsiung Harbor's overall operational business over the past 10 years.
Kaohsiung Harbor is currently the sixth-largest container port in the world in terms of the number of containers that it handles.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNCILORS FILE LAWSUIT AGAINST COA OVER CATTLE BAN

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Council Speaker Chuang Liang-shih and other councilors filed a lawsuit Friday against a Council of Agriculture (COA) official over a ban on the movement of cattle from the island county to Taiwan proper that has been in place for more than four years.

The COA banned Kinmen cattle from Taiwan in June 1999 following an outbreak of foot and mouth disease (FMD) on the outlying island that is suspected of having been introduced by cattle smuggled from mainland China.

After the slaughter of the cattle and vaccination of the remaining stock, the FMD on Kinmen was contained, but the ban on cattle exports to Taiwan proper has yet to lifted, resulting in widespread complaints from cattle raisers.

More than 30 people, including Chuang, Kinmen Farmers' Association President Tsai Shui-yu, who is also a councilor, several of his colleagues and cattle farmers, filed the suit against Chiang Yi-nan, head of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Inspection and Quarantine, for dereliction of duty by banning cattle movements, which they said has undermined the development of Kinmen and has affected the lives of the farmers.
The plaintiffs unfurled banners that read "We want to ship cattle to Taiwan, " and "We want to live" in front of the Kinmen Prosecutors' Office.

Tsai said cattle farmers have worked with the government over the past years to inoculate their herds, but because of the ban, have been unable to sell more than 3,500 head. As the government has failed to provide reimbursement, the farmers have no choice but to file suit so that justice will be done.
The farmers complained that the local market cannot accommodate so many cattle without the Taiwan channel, which they said has resulted in the price of cattle falling by 30 percent.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, who was on hand to give moral support, also asked the central government to heed the voice of the farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 30 points to close at 5,904, with 20,587 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January fell 34 points to finish at 5,900, with 420 contract transactions, while March futures lost 25 points to finish at 5,900, with 4 contracts traded.
June futures moved down 24 points to finish at 5,921, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,934 for December, 5,934 for January, 5,925 for March, 5,945 for June, and 5,923 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
December TE futures moved down 1.85 points to finish at 252.05, with 2,516 contract transactions, while January TE futures lost 1.5 points to finish at 252, with 26 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures fell 2.2 points to finish at 861, with 2,532 contract transactions, while January TF futures lost 2.2 points to close at 861, with 36 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 20.41 points to close at 5,900.05.
The bourse opened at 5,937.41 and fluctuated between 5,945.53 and 5,900.05 during trading.

A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.21 billion (US$1.91 billion) , compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.89 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$64.92 billion (US$1.9 billion).

Half of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.4 percent, and bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 379 to 333, with 218 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW MECHANISM DESIGNED TO PROTECT CROSS-STRAIT MARRIAGES: MAC

TEXT.P: The mechanism of interviewing mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens upon their entry is designed to protect legal marriages across the Taiwan Strait, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday.
Chen said the interview system, which kicked off at the start of September, is designed to protect those who follow the law and to target those who attempt to enter Taiwan under false pretenses.

The interview system is dealing a blow to those entering Taiwan under the pretense of marriage to engage in the sex trade, as well as helping clear the name of legitimate, decent mainland Chinese spouses, Chen said.

According to the Bureau of Immigration (BOI) under the Ministry of the Interior, the number of arriving mainland Chinese spouses has dropped 50 percent since the interview system was put in place Sept. 1.

The interview system was introduced after a spate of bogus marriage cases involving mainland Chinese citizens were uncovered. Between Sept. 1-30, only selected mainland spouses were interviewed to verify the legitimacy of their marriages.

From Oct. 1, the system was expanded to cover all mainland Chinese spouses making their first visit to Taiwan or to one of the two ROC-held front line islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
Starting Dec. 1, the system was further extended to cover all arriving mainland Chinese spouses, including those who had visited Taiwan before.

BOI statistics showed that between Sept. 1 and Nov. 27, 3,918 mainland spouses were interviewed upon their arrival and that 470 of them, or 12 percent, were immediately repatriated because it was determined that they were in bogus marriages.
