DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SET UP AGENCY TO PROMOTE TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the government will establish an agency specifically aimed at helping promote Taiwan's agricultural exports.

The president made the remarks when he attended an agricultural products exhibition held at the Taipei World Trade Center square. The exhibition was held by the China External Trade Development Council at the commission of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture. Purchase officers from Japan also attended the exhibition.

The president said that faced with pressure from international trade liberalization and greater competition since Taiwan's entrance into the World Trade Organization, Taiwan's agriculture sector not only has to stand firm in Taiwan, it also has to take the initiative to actively make inroads in overseas market.
The government will form the agency to help promote Taiwan's agriculture products to make Taiwan's agricultural exports No. 1 in the world like the island's notebook computer exports, Chen said.
Noting that Friday's exhibition is only the beginning, he said similar exhibitions will be held in Kaohsiung Dec. 20, in Tainan Dec. 27, and in Hsinchu in January next year.

The president said earlier in the day while receiving winners of agricultural awards at the Presidential Office that "if Taiwan's agriculture is to be viable, it will have to act like the island's manufacturing industry by actively transforming and upgrading without relying on government protection."

He also said that an agriculture sector that enjoys a competitive edge cannot rely on cheap prices alone but must also offer quality products. He cited the example of imported Japanese rice which enjoys brisk sales in Taiwan despite being several times more expensive than locally-produced rice.

The president stressed that "we don't have to be afraid of or reject liberalization. After joining the World Trade Organization, we have to open up the domestic market, but the world will also open up to Taiwan."
In the future, the government will promote agricultural products with the same zest as it now shows in sponsoring information and computer exhibitions, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND STRAIGHTENS BROKERAGE FEE SYSTEM FOR TAIWAN-BOUND WORKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Authorities from the Thai Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare have begun to straighten out the job brokerage charge system which has been used for Taiwan-bound Thai laborers, sources from the ministry said Friday.

The officials said that the ministry wants the labor brokerage firms to redo applications for licenses and that it has ruled that the brokerage fee for each Thai worker heading to Taiwan should be no higher than 5,600 baht (US$1,435) . Violators risk having their licenses revoked, they added.
Labor and Social Welfare Minister Uraiwan Thienthong said the move is aimed at curbing the trend of overcharging that has been practiced by Thai brokers on workers heading to Taiwan.

Nakhon Silpa-Archa, chief of the ministry's employment bureau, said unregistered job brokerage companies or job brokerage firms that charge brokerage fees higher than the allowed level will be forced to shut down.

Prasit Chaithongphan, chairman of the Association of Overseas Employment Brokerage in Thailand, said that currently, Taiwan-bound Thai workers are charged up to 180,000 baht in brokerage fees, or three times higher than the allowed amount.

The new stricter policy will help ease the Thai workers' financial burden, Prasit said, adding that brokerage firms will still be able to earn between 10,000 baht and 15,000 baht for each worker they send to Taiwan based on the new brokerage fee level.
The Thai officials said that currently, there are about 120,000 Thai people working as laborers in Taiwan, Malaysia and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 5, or the 12th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary-general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: Travellers to temperate countries urged to take influenza vaccines

TEXT.P: The Singapore Health Ministry (MOH) is advising such travellers, young and old, to undergo vaccination to protect themselves against increased influenza activity reported in countries like the US, UK, Spain, France and Belgium.
If you have plans to go to temperate countries in the Northern hemisphere in the current school holidays, please take note, MOH said.
Health authorities have so far not found the Fujian strain in Singapore, although the situation will continue to be monitored closely.
Travellers can get their vaccinations at the various hospitals, polyclinics and General Practitioners in Singapore.
The vaccination should be taken at least 1 to 2 weeks prior to departure as it takes time to take effect.

But despite getting treatment, travellers must exercise caution as the current influenza vaccine composition, which is effective against the Moscow strain, gives limited protection against the Fujian variant.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TELLS NY TIMES REFERENDUM NOT INVOLVING INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Friday told reporters of the New York Times that he planned a referendum next March calling on China to withdraw ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and demanding that China renounce the use of force against the island, and the planned referendum would not involve independence.

The president gave an interview to New York Times reporters Keith Bradsher and Joseph Kahn at the Presidential Office in Taipei Friday morning. The interview and a report were carried on the newspaper's Web site Friday.
Following is a transcript of the interview.
Q1. We appreciate your taking the time for this interview. We are especially interested in whether you are committed to holding a referendum on March 20. If so, what will be the subject?
A: Before I answer the questions that you have just proposed, let
me make some explanations beforehand. While the international
community is highly affirmative of Taiwan's democratic
achievements, I notice the international community only
understands the democratic achievements that Taiwan currently
enjoys but lacks a thorough understanding of the efforts that
Taiwan has made and the difficulties that it faces today in
its pursuit of democracy. Most people only see the lifting of
martial law, the ban on political parties, restrictions on the
publication of newspapers, and how Taiwan has proceeded along
the road to democracy with the complete re-election of the
legislature and the direct election of the president. However,
most people do not understand the very difficult journey we
had undertaken to have martial law lifted, to enjoy true
multi-party politics, and to have one hundred percent freedom
of the press and freedom of speech, to be able to hold regular
legislative elections, and to have the head of state directly
elected by the people. During the pursuit of democracy, the
then-ruling party and administration opposed and resisted all
kinds of demands for further reforms. Their main excuse and
reason was that if we lifted martial law, if we lifted the ban
on political parties or restrictions on newspaper publication,
if we allowed complete re-election of the legislature, or if
we allowed for direct presidential election, then China would
attack us.

In other words, in the old days, when the then-opposition or the pioneers of democracy demanded democratic reforms, the administration rejected their demands on the excuse or logic that the Chinese communists would attack Taiwan. They used this counter-reform and counter-democratic rhetoric, mainly based on the excuse that China might attack us.

The government or the governing party in the past saw democratic reform as equivalent to Taiwan independence or as equivalent to the insurgence of war. They saw the demands for democratization as equal to the call for independence and that would cause China to attack Taiwan.

In the same light, today's opposition, which consists mainly of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) , which used to be the ruling party of Taiwan, still put fear in the people by equating referendums with Taiwan independence, and with war initiated by China against Taiwan.

To put it even more clearly, in the process of democratization, the ruling regime of the past stand in the same line with the People's Republic of China (PRC) in suppressing Taiwan's democratic reforms.

The PRC has over the long-term perceived Taiwan's internal pursuit of further democratization as Taiwan independence, or something that will lead to Taiwan independence. Therefore, they would not renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Faced with such adversities, however, Taiwan's 23 million people and the democratic movement have never been intimidated by the military threat from the PRC. Nor have we been intimidated and held back by the former ruling party's playing the China card and their rhetoric that if we engaged in further democratization, that it would hinder the stability of our society.

Today, martial law has been lifted and there are no more restrictions on political parties or the publication of newspapers. We also have experienced the complete re-election of our legislature and held direct presidential elections. However, those who had resisted such changes, such trends, were the Kuomintang and the People's Republic of China. Now the KMT has become the opposition, while the PRC still exists and their military intimidation of Taiwan has not decreased, nor have they changed their stance. We have, however, completed our own internal democratic reforms.

Over the last 50 years, the road to democracy cost the lives of many people, freedoms were compromised, and families sacrificed their happiness and well-being. This pursuit is ongoing, however, and we have finally succeeded. Now the next stage for further democratization lies in holding a referendum as well as the introduction of a new constitution of Taiwan. We have confidence that we will succeed eventually.

The holding of a referendum is a milestone in our democratic consolidation and the deepening of Taiwan's democracy. It has no bearing on the so-called unification or independence issues. Nor will holding of a referendum violate the pledges. We cannot accept equating referendum with Taiwan independence. Referendum is a universal basic human right. Equating it with Taiwan independence is a serious distortion and insult to such a precious universal human right. If referendum is equated with war, it would be a negation of Taiwan's democratic achievements and a connivance with China's military intimidation. Referendum, for me, is a strong belief that I have held for more than 20 years and a long-standing goal and ideal that we have worked hard to achieve.

Many countries around the world are very familiar with the exercise of referendums. Several countries have had referendums for over a hundred years. Some have had it for several decades and some have just recently held a referendum. Whether they be in communist countries, less developed countries, or even less democratic countries, the people have been able to enjoy the universal right or birthright of referendum. Why should the 23 million people of Taiwan be deprived of this fundamental right?

In the past, when Taiwan was under authoritarian rule, the issue of referendum was perceived as a political taboo or even an absolute taboo. Yet in this democratic era, some groups and individuals create innumerable obstacles and threats against referendums.

Not long ago, the opposition still rejected the idea of holding referendums. Now they have followed the position advocated by the DPP and endorsed by me, to pass a Referendum Law, which marks a very important historical moment in our process of democratization.

To put it very candidly, however, the Referendum Law passed recently is not entirely satisfactory, in fact, in our opinion, several parts of it are unacceptable because they are somewhat absurd and contradictory. Some parts are even against the Constitution.

Fortunately, the Referendum Law includes one very important article, that is Article 17, which concerns "defensive referendums." "Defensive referendums" exist to allow the deepening of Taiwan's democracy as well as the safeguarding and defending of Taiwan's peace and security. In order to deepen our democracy and in order to ensure peace, we see it necessary to push forward with a "defensive referendum." We intend to hold the first referendum in Taiwan's history, a "defensive referendum, " on the same day as the election for presidency, which is on the 20th of March next year.

The reasons for this are several. Firstly, we must consolidate the people's mental fortitude, build a nationwide defense network and unite our people. Among Taiwan's 23 million people, there is a great internal crisis. Quite a few people, however, obviously lack a clear sense of crisis, and lack a clear sense of friend-and-foe. Taiwan faces a serious threat from China. They have deployed 496 ballistic missiles along the coastal areas with in 600km of Taiwan, and which target Taiwan. Faced with such a crisis, such an imminent threat, how can some people totally lack a sense of crisis and a sense of hostility from the other side of the Strait.

Secondly, I'd like to say that China's deployment of ballistic missiles and military intimidation against Taiwan does not just endanger Taiwan, but it also poses a serious threat to peace and security for the whole Asia-Pacific region. I would, therefore, like to take this opportunity to call for nations around the world, in particular nations in the Asia-Pacific region, to seriously examine the threat posed by China against Taiwan.

Our actions are not only taken for the deepening and defense of Taiwan's hard-won democracy. Furthermore, we engage in such actions in pursuit of the peace and security of the Asia-Pacific region as well as for the world.

Thirdly, the Beijing government has refused to sit down and engage in a real dialogue with Taiwan's government, and they have claimed again and again that they want to lay their hope in the people of Taiwan. By holding a defensive referendum, Taiwan will show to China the true voice of its people.

We want to make Taiwan people's voice heard by the Beijing authority and make them listen to the concerted outcry of 23 million people that what we want is democracy, what we want is peace; we do not want ballistic missiles and we do not want war.
On March 20th next year, therefore, we will hold our first historical referendum, and decide on what the issues listed on the first referendum will be.

The 23 million people of Taiwan will firmly demand that the Peoples Republic of China immediately withdraw all the ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and also openly and publicly announce and promise that they will not use force against Taiwan. If the Beijing authority and leadership in China can respond with goodwill and agree to immediately withdraw all the Ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan, and openly announce that they will not use force against Taiwan, then we will not be holding a defensive referendum.

Q2: Given the recent rhetoric from Beijing, are we already in the tensest period of cross-strait relations since 1996, and, if so, do you think that this action on your part will increase those tensions in a way that might upset the United States and other foreign countries?

A: The people of Taiwan want democracy and peace. They oppose missiles and reject war. That this stance would cause some countries to engage in military intimidation and belligerent rhetoric is unimaginable.

The Chinese government can oppose democracy and reforms. However, they have absolutely no right to turn against the will and the determination of the 23 million people of Taiwan in pursuit of democracy and reforms. The United States is a great and democratic country that respects the will of the people, loves democracy, upholds freedom, and shows concern for human rights. I am confident that the people and government of the United States will not oppose the efforts of the 23 million people of Taiwan to enhance democracy and ensure peace.

Q3: Mr. President, you just mentioned that under certain conditions you would consider not holding a defensive referendum. If China did not respond with goodwill, what would be the actual wording and content of a referendum should Taiwan hold one?
A: The topic of the referendum as mentioned could be for the 23
million people of Taiwan to demand that China immediately
withdraw the missiles targeting Taiwan and openly renounce
the use of force against Taiwan. Thus the topic of this kind
of defensive referendum does not involve the issue of
independence or unification, nor would it go against my "five
noes" pledge. It represents the deepening of Taiwan's
democracy and a guarantee of peace.

Q4: When such referendums are held in the United States from time to time, at the state level, rarely at the national level, we as reporters often suspect that the politicians who are behind the referendum really have their own reelection in mind, they're thinking about their own longevity in office. Is there any reason we should believe that this referendum is not connected with your own strategy for the elections, that is, perhaps to increase voter turnout at the election, to mobilize your own supporters in what looks to be a very tight election coming up in March?
A: First of all, I'd like to say that I'm already a president
and it doesn't make a big difference to me whether I serve
for one term or two terms. Secondly, a referendum represents
a concept and belief that I have pursued throughout my
more-than-20-year political career. It is a universal value
and a basic human right. Moreover, I believe that it is also
a dream long pursued by the 23 million people of Taiwan. As
the leader of this country, it is my responsibility, my mission
and duty to shoulder.

As this referendum is called a defensive referendum, our primary goal and purpose is to avoid war. Some argue that holding such a defensive referendum might send our children to the front line. In fact, the opposite is. By holding such a referendum, we will avoid sending our children to war. We must prepare our defense in advance to avoid war. This is also why we demand that the PRC (People's Republic of China) immediately withdraw its missiles and openly renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Q5: Have you received a letter or messenger in the last few days from the National Security Council asking that you not take actions that might disrupt the stability of the Taiwan Strait, in which the United States has repeatedly expressed a strategic interest even while saying democracy within the island is your affair?
A: To safeguard peace across the Taiwan Strait and to ensure the
security and stability of the Asia-Pacific region is Taiwan's
responsibility. I also see it as my duty and responsibility.
When I proposed the "five noes" pledge during my inaugural
speech in the year 2000, I had a precondition: As long as the
Chinese communist regime has no intention to use military
force against Taiwan, I guarantee that I will uphold the
"five noes" pledge during my term as president. Almost four
years have passed, and I have kept my word. However, Beijing
has continued to expand its military capabilities and
increase its military budget. It has also heightened the
threat of missiles deployed against Taiwan. Furthermore, the
leaders in China have openly stated many times that they do
not renounce the use of force against Taiwan. In 1962, the US
faced the 13 alarming days of the Cuba Missile Crisis. With
496 ballistic missiles aimed at the 23 million people of
Taiwan, every day for us is an alarming day.

We are promoting a referendum and pushing for a new constitution. There is nothing unusual about the United States government, as a very good friend of Taiwan, expressing its concern. This is understandable, and we appreciate it. Some people who oppose a defensive referendum have made up stories or distorted the significance of defensive referendum. They equate it to a referendum on the issue of unification and independence. This is inconsistent with reality, and does not represent our original intention. It is not fair to us for it to be labeled a referendum on unification and independence.

I've already made it very clear that next year's March 20 defensive referendum should demand that the PRC withdraw all missiles and openly renounce the use of force against Taiwan. I think that the United States government understands very well that it would not be a referendum on independence, nor would it go against the "five noes." It is about the deepening of our democracy and the safeguarding of peace. The US government should have no reason to oppose.

Q6: Do you feel that you have the support and full understanding of the White House on what you told us today about the purposes of this referendum? Do you believe that the Bush administration officials will understand and support what you're doing in the March 20 elections or do you fear that there are some in Washington who are critical of doing anything that would upset cross-strait relations at this time?
A: Taiwan supports and would be happy to see the improved
relations between the United States and China, as well as
their cooperation on anti-terrorist actions and the problem
of North Korea. However, we do not wish to see Taiwan's
democracy sacrificed over these issues.

We hope that the Chinese premier, Wen Jiabao, will not use his upcoming visit to the United States to ask that Taiwan be suppressed and sacrificed. As for China's intentions and the motivations of the Beijing leadership, we would not be surprised, because they have always done such things. However, the US government should be clear that it cannot sacrifice Taiwan's democracy, or the further consolidation and deepening of its democracy, in exchange for the favor of Wen Jiabao or Beijing's leaders.

The efforts of the people of Taiwan in deepening and consolidating our democracy and ensuring peace should be lauded and encouraged by both the people and government of the United States. This deepening of democracy and safeguarding of peace are assets to the United States, certainly not liabilities. The 23 million people of Taiwan have a historic opportunity next March 20 to hold their first referendum, a defensive referendum to avoid war by opposing the deployment of missiles by the PRC and its intention to use force against Taiwan. This should be a source of pride for the United States.
Therefore, some have even referred to the defensive referendum in Article 17 of the Referendum Law as Taiwan's political TMD (theater missile defense).

Q7: I have a slightly sensitive question. Do you have a long term plan in pursuing independence? Beijing seems to have assumed that you'll attempt to declare independence while Beijing holds the 2008 Olympic Games.

A: That's not how we would think about it. They have a great imagination. Beijing will be holding the 2008 Olympic Games, and we're very happy for them. We will be holding the Taiwan Expo in the same year and have our own goals to which we are committed. We want to maintain our competitive economic edge and ensure our niche in economic development. We have seen that the PRC previously had four constitutions. In other words, its constitution has been rewritten four times. The 23 million people of Taiwan also want to have one constitution that really belongs to them, one fundamental law of the country. The current constitution, which was promulgated in 1947, is definitely not suitable for or tailored to today's 23 million people. It has too many problems, with more than two-thirds of it in need of revision. We cannot repeat the same mistakes. We must make it more suitable and viable. Therefore, we hope to do it through a national referendum and the formulation of a new constitution. National referendum is itself the spirit of making a constitution. We do not want to play the meaningless word game of "constitutional amendment" and "formulation of the constitution." I do not wish to go through the parliament. From past experiences of going through the parliament previously the National Assembly and now the Legislative Yuan, the "high threshold" requiring the approval of three-fourths of the members makes it impossible for revisions to be made for a good constitution. We want Taiwan to become a truly complete, normal, and great country. We want a constitution that I do not wish to be custom-made for myself, for I will not be able to implement it while in office. I hope that, after I am re-elected, I will succeed in promoting a referendum on the formulation of a new constitution. This new constitution will be born in 2006, and on May 20, 2008, when I step down upon completion of my second term in office, the new constitution will be implemented by the twelfth-term president. It will not serve my own selfish interests or those of any political party. It will be geared to the long-term governance and permanent stability of the whole of Taiwan. Only then will it serve the genuine consolidation and deepening of Taiwan's democracy. Therefore, the year 2008 is just a coincidence of timing. It has never occurred to us that when they hold the Olympic Games in 2008, we will hold the Taiwan Expo. As to why the new constitution will be implemented in 2008, that just happens to be when I will complete my second term in office. It is merely a coincidence.
Q8: What's your opinion of the PRC leadership?
A: We only have one wish, that on March 20th next year, when the
people of Taiwan make their due decision and select me as the
eleventh-term president of Taiwan, Hu Jintao and the leaders
of China will respect and accept the decision made by the
people of Taiwan.
Q9: Do you consider this to be Taiwan's biggest crisis since 1996?

A: I do not really think so. Much of it is being fanned up, and I think that the root cause of the seemingly great tension across the Strait actually comes from the reluctance of the Chinese leadership in not wanting to see me re-elected.

I think in the past the Beijing authorities said they would be even-handed and not interfere with Taiwan's elections, so why are they now making loud protests and creating such an issue? I think the reason is very simple: that they now judge that I will be reelected as the next president of Taiwan. I am certainly not their favorite candidate for the presidency, just as former president Lee Teng-hui was not in 1996. This is a case of history repeating itself. I want to say very clearly to the Beijing authorities that the candidate you dislike will, however, be re-elected as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES LOCAL PEOPLE TO TAKE PART IN VOLUNTEER SERVICES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged local people Saturday to dedicate themselves to volunteer services to help push for Taiwan's progress in various aspects.
Chen made the appeal while attending a national rally and athletic contest in the central county of Changhua to mark the Dec. 5 International Volunteer Day.
At the invitation of the ROC Volunteers Association, Chen said he was in a TV commercial earlier this week calling on local citizens to join volunteer services.

"I believe that it will become a precious manpower resource and an important force driving Taiwan's national upgrading if each citizen devotes some of their leisure time to volunteer service, " Chen said.

Whenever he sees volunteers work selflessly, Chen went on, he is moved. "Therefore, I follow in their footsteps. In the past three years, I have volunteered my services at social welfare organizations on my inaugural day on May 20, " Chen said, adding that he hopes May 20 will become Taiwan's Volunteer Day in the future.
More than 3,000 volunteers from around the island took part in the rally to pledge their commitment to lifelong volunteer services.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPE JOHN PAUL II RECEIVES SPECIAL GIFT FROM TAIWAN ARTIST

TEXT.P: Pope John Paul II received a special gift from Taiwan early this month -- a collection of paintings by noted Taiwan artist Liang Dan-feng that portray the magnificence and glory of Catholic churches and monasteries in Italy.

"The volume that contains 30 watercolor paintings and seven pencil drawings was presented to the Pope by outgoing ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Raymond Tai earlier this week," the 70-year-old Taiwan painter said Saturday. "I want to express my tribute to the Pope by presenting the collection."
Liang said Tai, who will retire at the end of this year, invited her to create the special Catholic church volume this summer.
Tai was quoted as having told Liang that after many years of service in the Vatican, he deeply feels that Oriental people lack a deep understanding of the Catholic world.
"He urged me to paint my feelings about Catholic churches as a gift to the Pope who has been concerned about world peace," Liang recalled.
Braving scorching sun, Liang traveled around Italy this past August to paint famous Catholic churches and monasteries in rural areas. "It was an energy consuming task for me," Liang said.

She visited 19 Catholic churches located in major Italian cities. In addition to churches, her paintings also feature images of Pope John Paul II receiving Catholic followers as well as the Pope's security guards.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM AIMED AT URGING BEJING TO WITHDRAW MISSILES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in an interview with the New York Times Friday that his administration's plan to hold a referendum next March is aimed at urging mainland China to withdraw its ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and to renounce the use of force against the island.
Chen stressed that a referendum represents a concept and belief that he has pursued throughout his more-than-20-year political career.

"It is a universal value and a basic human right," Chen said, adding that personal ambition is not a factor in his decision to hold a referendum on the day of Taiwan's next presidential election on March 20, 2004.
"I'm already a president and it doesn't make a big difference to me whether I serve for one term or two terms," he said.

Taiwan's newly passed referendum law empowers the president to initiate a referendum on national security issues in case of an external threat. Chen said last Sunday Beijing's deployment of nearly 500 missiles aimed at Taiwan is sufficient reason for a "preventive referendum" to be called on the day of the March 20 presidential election. His declaration aroused concern that the move might provoke Beijing, which has threatened to attack Taiwan should the island declare independence.

Chen said in the New York Times interview that the planned referendum will focus on Beijing's missile deployment, not independence. The referendum will help Taiwan people and other countries around the world understand mainland China's ever growing military threat, Chen said, adding that awareness of the threat will contribute to alleviating risks of conflict.
Chen further said his administration has informed the United States of its referendum plan. Taiwan needs strong U.S. support for its democratic development, he added.
Reiterating that the planned referendum, the first of its kind in Taiwan's history, Chen said it will mark a milestone in strengthening and consolidating Taiwan's young democracy.

Chen said Taiwan once suffered from martial law rule. During that era, he recalled, Taiwan's pro-democracy efforts always encountered opposition from mainland China and the then-Kuomintang administration.

In related news development, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Saturday President Chen will formally announce guidelines for the referendum agenda at a Hakka people rally Sunday in support of his re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE DANGER OF CHANGE IN STATUS QUO: LIEN CHAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's presidential candidate Lien Chan said in a New York Times interview that Beijing's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan has posed a serious threat to Taiwan's people, but he saw no immediate danger that Taiwan's status will be changed right now.

In the interview published Saturday, Lien stressed that the nation's leader should have the wisdom and capability to deal with the delicate cross-Taiwan Strait relations, as national defense involves not just military power but also many other factors.
Noting that the creation of peaceful and stable ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is urgently important, Lien said their "pan-blue alliance" has the ability to deal with the issue.

Lien was responding to recent declaration by President Chen Shui-bian that he would hold a "preventive referendum" on the day of the March 20, 2004 presidential election, because Beijing's deployment of 496 missiles targeting Taiwan already represents an external threat allowing for such a referendum.
A referendum law passed recently by the Legislative Yuan gives the president the right to initiate a referendum on national security issues in case of an external threat.
Chen's movement has been construed by mainland China as a initial step to move toward the independence, and has caused much concern from the United States.

Lien noted that U.S. policy on Taiwan is quite clear, that is it will help defend Taiwan if the island does not provoke mainland China. However, if cross-strait tension heightens due to the provocation by Taiwan, the United States has no obligation to defend the island, according to Lien. Lien said he agrees that the Bush administration should further clarify the U.S. stance.

With respect to the "pan-blue" camp's mainland policy, Lien stressed that they will give priority in maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, protect Taiwan's interests, and focus on economic development.

Lien said if he and his running mate, James Soong from the opposition People First Party, win the 2004 presidential election, they will try their best to resume the long-stalled cross-strait talks, while keeping a military balance between both sides.
If elected, Lien went on, they will continue purchasing arms from the U.S., hoping that the American government will sell the weapons that the island really needs.

On economic issues, Lien said his "pan-blue" camp will present immediately a four-year, NT$2 trillion (US$58.8 billion) public construction budget plan which forms part of their medium and long-term public construction program, once they are elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS POLICY TO BE CORNERSTONE OF NEW CONSTITUTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday his administration's human rights policy initiatives are part of Taiwan's preparations for writing a new constitution that fits the country's realities and needs.

Chen made the remarks in a written congratulatory message delivered at the opening of a two-day international conference on the theories and history of human rights. Academia Historica President Chang Yen-hsien read the message on Chen's behalf.
In his message, Chen said, human rights protection prescribed in Taiwan's existing Constitution is inadequate and incomplete in terms of modern constitutional standards.

Since assuming office, Chen said he has come up with many human rights policy initiatives, including the establishment of a human rights commission, the issuing of a national rights report annually, and assessing the possible impact on human rights while formulating a bill or policy.
Chen said all these steps can be enshrined in the nation's new constitution to upgrade human rights protection to the modern world standards.

In his 2000 inaugural speech, Chen recalled that he outlined three key principles regarding his human rights policy -- pushing the legislature to pass and ratify the International Bill of Rights as a domestic law of Taiwan so that it becomes the "Taiwan Bill of Rights"; setting up an independent national human rights commission in line with the United Nations requirements; and bringing Taiwan back into the international human rights system.

On Dec. 10, 1948, Chen said, the United Nations passed the World Human Rights Declaration and designated Dec. 10 as World Human Rights Day. The Kaohsiung Incident -- a landmark event in Taiwan people's pursuit of freedom and democracy -- happened on World Human Rights Day in 1979.

Taiwan took part in the formulation of an international human right mechanism in the early stage and signed nearly 20 international human rights conventions. However, Chen said, the previous ROC government failed to substantiate human rights protection. After Taiwan was forced out of the United Nations, it lost direct links with world human rights development.
Chen said Taiwan's historic transition of power between different political parties in May 2000 marked a new start in the nation's human rights development.

Over the past three years, Chen said his administration has initiated a lot of measures and policies aimed at connecting the nation's human rights protection with the international mechanism. As his party fails to control a majority in the Legislative Yuan, Chen said his administration has encountered setbacks and obstructions in institutionalizing a world-class human rights protection system.

Chen said the presentation to him of the 2003 Human Rights Award by the International League for Human Rights marked the world recognition of Taiwan people's efforts to boost human rights development.
For human rights protection, Chen went on, enhancing the public's awareness of human rights concepts is as important as formulation of policies and legal frameworks.

"This is why I proposed the establishment of a national human rights museum on the 2001 World Human Rights Day to facilitate public human rights education and preservation of historical records of Taiwan's human rights development, " Chen said, adding that he hopes the opposition-controlled legislature can pass the organizational bill for the planned museum as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED FOWL, HORSES TO BE QUARANTINED AGAINST WEST NILE VIRUS

TEXT.P: Cases of West Nile virus have been reported in various countries, so fowl and horses that are imported from virus-affected areas must undergo a 14-day quarantine before they are allowed entry into Taiwan, an official of the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Saturday.

Hsiao Chung-yao, a section chief of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that the mosquito-transmitted disease will affect fowl, horses and human beings and that the fatality rate for humans is between 3 percent and 15 percent, while birds and horses could also die after infection.

Hsiao noted that West Nile virus cases have been reported in America, the Middle East, West Asia, Central Asia and North America. There were mass deaths of crows in New York in 1999 for unidentified reasons, and it was later determined to be the West Nile virus. The virus has reached 45 states in the United States so far. A total of 8,219 human cases have been reported so far, and 182 have died. There have been 15,067 cases of the virus affecting birds and horses.

He said that imported horses have to come from stables that have had no West Nile virus cases for over six months, and that they have to undergo a 14-day quarantine and test negative before they come to Taiwan.
COA officials also urged the public to guard against mosquito bites when going to the United States or Canada to avoid being affected.

To stem the West Nile virus from landing on Taiwan, the COA bureau has since June 2002 commissioned the Veterinarian Department of National Taiwan University to monitor imported fowl for the virus, and so far have found none in 1,315 tested specimens.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES RUNNING NECK AND NECK: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: The results of a large presidential election opinion poll shows that President Chen Shui-bian is running neck and neck with his challenger from the opposition "pan-blue alliance," the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.

The DPP's public opinion survey center said it divided the island into six areas for the poll and began to conduct telephone interviews on randomly chosen adult citizens in one region per week starting Oct. 22. A total of 16,804 valid replies were collected. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 0.77 percent.
Poll results show that Chen's support rating stood at 34.1 percent, while his key challenger, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan had a support rate of 33.6 percent.
Chen has yet to announce his choice of running mate while Lien has decided to team up with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to challenge Chen in the upcoming presidential election.
"Chen's 0.5 percent lead fell within the margin of error, indicating that the two sides are running at a dead heat, " said Chen Chun-lin, director of the DPP's opinion survey center.

According to the poll, 41.3 percent of the respondents said they prefer to see President Chen win a second term, compared to 38.9 percent who said they look forward to a transition of power in the March 20 election.

Meanwhile, 30.9 percent of those interviewed said their close relatives and friends will support President Chen in the coming vote while 29.3 percent said their next of kin and friends will vote for the Lien-Soong ticket.

The survey found that President Chen enjoyed a comfortable lead in the southern Taiwan counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung as well as Kaohsiung City, while lagging in other cities and counties.

Chen Chun-lin said President Chen faces a tough, uphill battle in the northern counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli which have a large Hakka population. Nevertheless, he said, Chen's support rate among Hakka people around the island has risen significantly.
Quoting the latest survey findings, Chen Chun-lin said President Chen's support rating among Hakka voters was about 32 percent, 8 percent behind Lien-Soong's 40 percent.
"Compared with the vote President Chen garnered in the Hakka-dominate areas in the 2000 presidential election, his popularity in the Hakka community has increased substantially, " he added.

By areas, the Chen-Lien support rate ratios were 30.7 percent vs. 45.5 percent in the Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Miaoli region; 32.4 percent vs. 31.1 percent in the Taichung-Changhua-Nantou constituency; 39.1 percent vs. 24.9 percent in the Yunlin-Chiayi-Tainan region; 39 percent vs. 30.3 percent in the Kaohsiung City-Kaohsiung County-Pingtung area; 28.1 percent vs. 39.9 percent in the Keelung-Ilan-Hualien-Taitung-Penghu area.
In terms of age, Chen was less popular than Lien only in the 30-39 voter group, while leading or even in all other age groups.

Chen Chun-lin further pointed out that President Chen's support rating among independent or swing voters lagged Lien-Soong by 3.1 percent in a similar DPP survey in July, but the trend reversed in the latest survey.
"The latest poll found that President Chen led the Lien-Soong ticket in popularity among swing voters by 6 percent, " Chen Chun-lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU COOPERATING WITH KOREAN LG GROUP IN LURING TOURISTS

TEXT.P: A series of activities have been launched by many sectors in Taiwan to attract tourists around the world since the government designated the year 2004 as the "Taiwan Tourism Year," and such programs have included a strategic alliance with South Korea's LG Group and Hana Tour.

Wang Jen-teh, representative of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau in South Korea, said Saturday that under the strategic alliance with the LG Group, the group's online shopping Web site www.lgeshop.com has from Dec. 1 presented commercials to promote Taiwan tourism. The promotion will run for 25 days.
According to Wang, nearly 7,000 people visited the Web site in the first day to seek more information about Taiwan.
Under the cooperation program, Hana Tour will offer logistic services to the online visitors interested in touring Taiwan.

A lucky draw will be held next January via the Web site to pick 30 winners who will be offered three-day free tour packages to Taiwan, which will include visits to the National Palace Museum, the world's tallest building, "Taipei 101, " Yangmingshan hot springs and a chance to sample various Chinese gourmet foods.

Taiwan tourism was hard hit by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year on the island, with the number of travelers to Taiwan standing at 963,882 for the first half of this year, a decrease of 31.87 percent over the same period of last year.

To help bring back visitors, the island has presented numerous promotional activities and a program to redouble the annual number of foreign visits to Taiwan to five million by the year 2008 is also high on the agenda of an ambitious national development plan presented by the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL SETS HIGH THRESHOLD FOR PEOPLE TO INITIATE REFERENDUM: EX-DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Lin Yi-hsiung on Saturday continued to criticize the referendum bill for setting too high a threshold for the people to initiate a referendum.

Lin made the remarks in Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, where he and Ilan Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng, DPP legislators Chen Chin-teh and Chang Chuan-tien and party officials distributed leaflets to propagate their idea to scrap the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant through referendum.

Lin, who has long advocated holding a referendum on the fate of the half-finished nuclear plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, said that according to the referendum bill that cleared the Legislative Yuan Nov. 27, the people will have to collect the signatures of 5 percent, or more than 700,000 if based on the previous presidential election, of the electorates in the latest presidential election, to initiate a referendum.

But he pointed out that compared with a presidential aspirant who only needs the signatures of 200,000 to enter into a presidential race, the referendum bill is "absurd" to place such a high restriction on people's ability to initiation a referendum.
The high threshold has ignored the "people's right to take part in the formulation of public policy," he said.

For this reason, Lin said that he will call on Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Dec. 12. The KMT orchestrated the passage of the referendum based largely on its own version. Lin said he hopes Lien will orchestrate a correction of the flaws in the bill.

Under the referendum bill, the people, the Legislative Yuan and the president all have the power to initiate a referendum, although it only empowers the president to initiate a referendum when the nation is under external threat. The external threat is tacitly seen as referring to attacks from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 6, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo will send only convicted kidnappers to the lethal injection chamber and recommend the reprieve of other death row convicts starting January next year, Malacanang made clear yesterday.

ONLY convicted kidnappers, and not all death row convicts such as rapists or drug dealers, are subject to public execution, Malacanang clarified Saturday.

Dirty Bomb Rockets Vanish; Arms Made in Caucasus Feared Sold to Terrorists.
In the ethnic conflicts that surrounded the collapse of the Soviet Union, fighters in several countries seized upon an unlikely new weapon: a small, thin rocket known as the Alazan. Originally built for weather experiments, the Alazan was transformed into a terror weapon, packed with explosives and lobbed into cities. Military records show that at least 38 Alazan warheads were modified to carry radioactive material, effectively creating the world's first surface-to-surface dirty bomb.

A rush for the flu vaccine has spawned shortages worldwide, including Singapore. Up to 300 patients subsequently inundated some of Raffles Medical Group's clinics, causing five of its 60 clinics to run short.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET VALUE INCREASES TO TOP NT$12.4 TRILLION

TEXT.P: The value of the domestic stock market increased to NT$12.43 trillion (US$365.85 billion) at the end of last week, an increase of NT$292.3 billion or 2.41 percent over the week-earlier level, according to a report compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
The weighted index -- the benchmark indicator of the domestic bourse -- rose by 128.28 points for the whole week to finish at 5,900.05 June 13.
Share prices of 16 of the 20 categories moved up, with plastics posting the largest growth of 6.12 percent.

As of last Friday, shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. -- Taiwan's largest chipmaker -- exceeded those of other companies listed on the stock market with a total value of NT$1.317 trillion, or 10.59 percent of the entire market value, followed by United Microelectronics Corp. with NT$493.9 billion and Chunghwa Telecom with NT$474.6 billion.

Among the top ten companies in terms of stock value were also Cathay Holding with NT$423.6 billion, Hon Hai with NT$346.3 billion, Nan Ya Plastics with NT$315.5 billion, Fubon Financial with NT$262.4 billion, Formosa Plastics with NT$259.5 billion, China Steel Corp. with NT$258 billion and Formosa Chemical and Fiber with 248.3 billion, TAIEX statistics show.
Since the beginning of this year, a total of NT$19.42 trillion-worth of stocks changed hands, equivalent to a daily transaction average of NT$84.07 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MORE HEARTFELT CARE FOR AIDS PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Sunday called for the relevant government agencies and the general public to extend more heartfelt care and concern to AIDS patients to allow them to enjoy a life with dignity and equality.
Lu made the appeal at an exhibition on the results of government agencies' efforts and programs towards caring for AIDS patients held at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.

The government should not only actively promote the prevention and control of AIDS but also provide more care and assistance to AIDS patients, such as by offering them better medical treatment and protection of their interests and by setting up a special village for them, she said.

More men than women are infected with AIDS in Taiwan, with the 20-29 age group being the hardest hit by the disease, according to statistics compiled by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health.
A total of 5,464 people in Taiwan have been infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, among whom 1,560 have developed full-blown AIDS and 904 have died, the statisitics show.

Broken down by gender, the statistics show that the number of Taiwan men infected with HIV is 4,694, or 93.1 percent of the total cases, with 1,437 full-blown AIDS cases and 833 deaths. The number of Taiwan women infected with HIV is 348, with 123 full-blown AIDS cases and 71 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SOONG CAMPAIGN HEADQUARTERS OPENS

TEXT.P: The presidential campaign headquarters of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong formally opened in Taipei Sunday.

The two issued what they called their "Wellbeing Declaration" in which they vowed to fight for a better life for the people. They promised to raise the people's income, narrow the gap between the rich and the poor, speed up the opening of direct transportation links with the mainland, and make the island a more inhabitable place.

Lien and Soong vied against each other in a three-way race for the presidency in 2000, decided to team up to run against President Chen Shui-bian this time, with Lien running for president and Soong for vice president.

They have tapped Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, to lead their campaign staff, and Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to take charge of their day-to-day campaign business. They have made "Fight for the economy, save Taiwan" as the theme of their campaign.

In a celebration marking the opening held in front of their new headquarters, Lien and Soong handed a flag to Ma to symbolize their offer of the task to him, and Ma waved it in front of the thousands of supporters gathered from around the island to indicate his acceptance of the mission.
A campaign rally is slated for Sunday night at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall. Organizers of the rally have estimated that some 100,000 supporters of Lien and Soong could attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO LET PEOPLE EXPRESS SENTIMENT AGAINST WAR THRU REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed to let the Taiwan people's sentiment against Beijing's military threat and its missiles directed at the island be expressed through a referendum on the day of the presidential election next March 20.

Speaking at the launch of a national association of his Hakka supporters in Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan, Chen said it is his mission and his duty to show the world that the people of Taiwan are opposed to missiles and war.

He said the referendum bill passed by the Legislature Nov. 27 gives the president the right to hold what he called a "preventive referendum" to protect the country and the people, adding that this is why a referendum next March 20 is necessary.

A self-proclaimed Hakka person, the president touted his many measures designed to enhance the Hakka people's status, including the establishment of the Council for Hakka Affairs and the All-Hakka Television Channel, as well as the launch of the first ever Hakka Cultural Festival in the country.
The launch of the Association of the pro-Chen Hakkas brought together more than 60,000 of Chen's Hakka followers from around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN BEGINS SARS-PREVENTION MEASURES

TEXT.P: Health authorities on the frontline island of Kinmen on Sunday began to check the temperature of visitors by using infra-red thermal imaging machines as part of efforts to prevent a reemergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

From Sunday, the temperature of each passenger leaving Kinmen for the Chinese mainland or entering Kinmen from the mainland will be checked by the two infra-red thermal imaging machines installed at Kinmen's Shuitou Port, the major gateway of the "mini three links, " officials of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) Kinmen office said.

The "mini three links, " initiated by Taiwan in January 2001, refers to direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province.

CDC officials said that if an out-bound passenger is discovered to have a temperature higher than 38 degrees Celsius, the health authorities will advise the passenger not to board a vessel to the mainland. If an in-bound passenger from Fujian is found to have a temperature higher than 38 degrees Celsius, the passenger will be given several surgical masks, as well as be required to take their own temperature daily and report it by telephone to authorities for at least 10 days.

According to Chang Kuo-tu, director of the Kinmen Port Department, the number of people using the "mini three links" channel to travel across the Taiwan Strait is expected to pick up to the tune of between 1,000 and 2,000 passengers per day leading up to and during the Chinese New Year holiday period between Jan. 9 and Feb. 2, 2004.
Neither Kinmen nor Xiamen had reported any SARS cases during the outbreaks earlier this year. SARS hit Taiwan hard between early March and late June this year, claiming 84 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIGLETS STOLEN IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: One hundred and seventy piglets were stolen from two pig farms early Sunday morning in the village of Hsinkang in Chiayi County, a source from the Chiayi Hog Raisers Association said.
The stolen piglets are only a few weeks old, and each weighs only about 18 pounds, according to the source.

He said that because hog raisers in the county have on many occasions in recent months reported piglets being stolen, the association has offered N$100,000 (US$2,900) in reward money for clues leading to the arrest of the thieves.
It was reported on Nov. 20 that more than 100 piglets had been stolen from a farm in the same village.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO PROMOTE TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will try to promote Taiwan agricultural products in Japan, the head of the council said Sunday.

CETRA chairman Hsu Chih-jen said he is optimistic because the quality of Taiwan's agricultural products is high and the prices are competitive, adding that Japanese consumers like to buy Taiwan's agricultural products.
Hsu said the CETRA will continue to hold exhibitions of agricultural products in Japanese cities, as well as establish agricultural product promotion centers in Tokyo and Osaka.
He added that certain Japanese vegetable importers and shopping centers have shown a keen interest in Taiwan vegetables and fruits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CLAIMS HIS RE-ELECTION WILL PAVE WAY FOR MA IN 2008

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that his re-election next year will pave the way for Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to run on the Kuomintang's (KMT's) ticket for the presidential election in 2008.

Speaking at the opening of the rebuilt Pingchiang Market in Taipei City, the president reached out to supporters of Ma who were also present at the ceremony, claiming that if he succeeds in winning a second term in the March 2004 presidential election, then Ma will almost certainly be the KMT's standard bearer in the 2008 presidential election.

The KMT, in cooperation with the People First Party (PFP) , has fielded a joint ticket for next year's election, with KMT Chairman Lien Chan running for president and PFP Chairman James Soong running for vice president. Ma has been tapped to be their campaign manager.
It has been said that if Lien and Soong are elected in 2004, they will likely bid for a second term in 2008 and therefore rob Ma of the chance to run for the KMT that year.
Chen , who lost to Ma in his bid for a second term as Taipei mayor in 1998, thanked Ma tongue in cheek, saying that the defeat forced him to run for the presidency in 2000.
The president also pitched his calls for writing a new constitution from scratch before 2008, using the rebuilding of Pingchiang Market as a metaphor.

He noted that the market was dilapidated and was listed as a dangerous public building in 1994 when he was mayor despite it having been reinforced several times by his predecessors. Chen pointed out he decided to tear it down and rebuild it from scratch at a cost of NT$3 billion (US$ 88.6 million), saying that thanks to his decision, apossible disaster was avoided there when the island was struck by a magnitude 7.3 earthquake Sept. 21, 1999.

Likening the country's Constitution to a dilapidated building, Chen said the Constitution is not suitable for Taiwan's rapid democratization despite it being revised six times in the last decade. "We need a brand new constitution, designed for Taiwan, " he said.

Ma didn't contradict the president during the ceremony, but he told journalists afterward that he was surprised Chen had turned a celebration for the opening of a new market into an activity for his presidential campaign.
Ma said he doesn't see any logic in the president's claim that Chen's successful re-election bid will increase his own chances of running for the presidency in 2008.

He disagreed with Chen's view that the Constitution needs to be replaced altogether, saying that altering the unfit sections of the Constitution is more practical and cheaper in terms of the political cost than creating a brand new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE TO SPEAK IN TAIWAN ON HUMAN GENOME

TEXT.P: Sir John E. Sulston, co-winner of the 2002 Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine, is scheduled to come to Taiwan this week for a lecture and book launching tour, sources from the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said Sunday.

Sulston, former director of the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, who led the British team on the international Human Genome Project, is scheduled to deliver a speech titled "Society and the Human Genome" on Dec. 13 at National Taiwan University, BTCO officials said.
Sulston's speech is part of the activities organized by the BTCO to mark the 50th anniversary of the discovery of DNA.

The Nobel laureate will also be present at a ceremony marking the launch of the Chinese version of the book "The Common Thread: A Story of Science, Politics, Ethics and the Human Genome" that Sulston and writer Georgina Ferry co-authored.
The human genome was successfully sequenced in one of the largest international scientific projects ever undertaken. Now, societies have to decide how that information will be used.

In "The Common Thread, " Sulston and Ferry argue that the desire for commercial profit must not be allowed to hamper future research or to restrict the medical benefits of genetic discoveries to the wealthy.

The Nobel Assembly awarded the 2002 Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine jointly to Sydney Brenner, Robert Horvitz and John Sulston for their discoveries concerning "genetic regulation of organ development and programmed cell death."

The Nobel Assembly panel of judges said that by using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans as a model system, the scientists had identified key genes regulating these processes, and had also shown that corresponding genes exist in higher species, including humans.

Sir John, 60, graduated from Cambridge University in 1963. After completing his doctorate on the chemical synthesis of DNA, he moved to the United States to study probiotic chemistry (the origins of life on earth). In 1969, he joined Sydney Brenner's group at the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology and studied the biology and genetics of the nematode worm C. elegans. He and his team collaborated with Bob Waterston at Washington University to sequence the genome of this model organism.

In 1992, Sulston was appointed as the first director of the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute in Cambridgeshire which made the United Kingdom's contribution to the international Human Genome Project. He was listed among Great Britain's 100 most powerful people by the Observer newspaper. Sir John was knighted in 2001 for his contributions in the field of genome research.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 7, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIMED IRAQI BOY FITTED WITH PROSTHETIC FOOT, HAND

TEXT.P: An Iraqi boy maimed in the U.S.-led war in Iraq was successfully fitted with a prosthetic foot and hand Monday at a Taipei hospital.
Hhaldon kh-Thiab jubilantly expressed his gratitude to the people of Taiwan at a press conference for the assistance and medical treatment he received.

The 12-year-old boy, better known in his local community as Aldon, lost his right hand and left foot as a result of a cluster bomb explosion in the front courtyard of his family's home in April this year.

Under the arrangement of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, a Taiwan charity group dedicated to the care of the handicapped, Thiab arrived in Taipei Oct. 27 and was admitted to the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital to receive treatment.
He is scheduled to leave Taipei for home Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES SWISS DECISION TO ASSIST IN PROBING FRIGATE DEAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice welcomed Monday a decision by the Swiss authorities to extend legal assistance for Taiwan's probe into the dealing surrounding the purchase of six frigates by Taiwan from France in 1991.
Vice Justice Minister Hsieh Wen-ting said he was encouraged by the decision that is all the more valuable because of the absence of a legal assistance pact between Taipei and Bern.

In a ruling on Taiwan's request for assistance, as well as similar requests from France and Liechtenstein, a Swiss investigating magistrate determined that Switzerland will hand over files it has collected in connection with the arms deal.

Both the Taipei and Paris authorities suspect that huge illegal commissions were involved in the US$2.5 billion deal and believe at least some of the money was stashed in an arms broker's bank accounts in Switzerland and Liechtenstein.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HONORED BY U.S. ALMA MATER

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was honored Monday as a "distinguished alumna" by her U.S. alma mater, the University of Illinois at Urban-Champaign (UIUC).
Lu, who earned a master's degree in comparative law from UIUC in 1971, was awarded a medal by Heidi Hurd, the dean of the university's law school, who is visiting Taiwan.
In a citation for Lu, the university said the vice president glorifies her alma mater and sets an excellent example for other students with her achievements.
President Chen Shui-bian was present at the ceremony held at the Presidential Office, and extended his congratulations to Lu, praising her as an important promoter of human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PARTICIPATES IN WSIS ACTIVITIES IN GENEVA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A 60-member delegation from Taiwan participated in a global electronic commerce forum held at the headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva Monday on the sidelines of the upcoming World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS).

Addressing the meeting, which was organized by the Asia-Pacific Council for Trade Facilitation and Electronic Business (AFACT) , delegation head Tsai Ching-yen, who is a minister without portfolio, introduced the development of "e-commerce" in Taiwan and the government's efforts to build Taiwan into a world information industry center and an Asia-Pacific operations hub.
To achieve the goal, Tsai said, the government has listed an "e-Taiwan" program in the "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan it unveiled in 2002.

The WSIS, sponsored by the International Telecommunication Union, will take place Dec. 10-12. It will address a broad range of themes concerning the information society and will adopt a Declaration of Principles and Plan of Action.

Members of the Taiwan delegation include Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming, Cabinet-level National Youth Commission Chairwoman Lin Fang-mei, Academia Sinica Vice President Tseng Chih-lang, Information Industry Institute Chairman Lin Feng-chin and representatives of the public, industrial and academic sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO ASK LEGISLATURE TO RECONSIDER REFERENDUM BILL

TEXT.P: A political struggle between the executive and legislative branches loomed Monday when the Executive Yuan decided to ask the Legislative Yuan to reconsider part of the referendum bill passed Nov. 27.

Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said that a Cabinet meeting earlier in the day determined that 12 of the 64 articles in the bill were unacceptable and would need to be returned to the Legislative Yuan, probably on Friday, for reconsideration.

Although the bill is a step forward in terms of the development of democracy, Lin said, the Executive Yuan will do its part to fix the flaws in the bill by annulling the 12 articles that unduly expand the power of the Legislative Yuan by giving it the right to initiate referendums on major government policy.
At the same time, Lin went on, the bill runs against the general practice of most democracies by stripping the executive branch of the right to propose a referendum.

Furthermore, the formation of a referendum reviewing committee called for in the bill is coincident with the existing Central Election Commission in function, so there is no need for the government set up another agency for the same purpose, Lin said.

Once the request is submitted, the parts requiring reconsideration will automatically be annulled unless the Legislative Yuan rejects the request within 15 days with a majority vote of 113 in the 225-seat legislature.
If that scenario takes place, the premier will have to either accept the Legislative Yuan's decision or step down.
Since the two main opposition parties control a narrow legislative majority of 113 seats between them, every vote will count in case of a showdown.
