DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS RECALL DARK DAYS OF TAIWAN MARTIAL LAW

TEXT.P: A group of foreigners who helped bring democracy to Taiwan gathered in Taipei Monday to recall the days when the island was ruled by an authoritarian government.

In a conference organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, the foreigners cited their own experiences in Taiwan prior to the 1987 lifting of the Emergency Decree and the end of martial law, which allowed democracy to take root.

Rev. Rowland Van Es, who was once deported by the Taipei authorities as persona non grata, said he first arrived in Taiwan in 1960 and found that the people lacked trust in one another because of the rule of martial law. This challenged his work as a clergyman trained to listen to peoples' words from deep in their hearts.
In order to avoid the attention of the omnipresent secret police, Van Es said many private gatherings had to be held late at night amidst a prevailing atmosphere of repression.

Dr. Mark Thelin of the United States said he felt the pinch of martial law when he first arrived in Taiwan in 1945 and the customs authorities confiscated a book about communism. Although the book was later returned to him, he said, this showed him that Taiwan was not a free society.
Thelin, who worked as a teacher at Tunghai University in Taichung for many years before returning to the United States, said he was glad to find democracy has now taken root in the country.

Dr. Richard Kagan, also from America, said he was astounded by the country's persecution of political criminals when he arrived in Taiwan in 1960. His concerns over the government's treatment of these people led him to visit the notorious prison on Green Island, where the country's political prisoners were confined.

Among the foreign visitors at the seminar are five Japanese who expressed their long-time concern over Taiwan's human rights situation during the conference. However, they made no comment when Legislator Feng Ting-kuo urged them to help Taiwan's "comfort women," who were forced to serve as sex slaves for the Japanese military during the Second World War, to get an apology from the Japanese government.

Michael Ying-mao Kau, vice minister of foreign affairs and executive director of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, expressed his thanks to the some 30 foreign visitors to the two-day conference, saying that they helped push the country toward democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE WILL DROP TO 4 PERCENT IN 2005: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Monday that the domestic jobless rate will drop to 4 percent by 2005.
The president made the remarks when he spoke to more than 300 representatives of Chinese and herbal medicine manufacturers in the Yungkang Industrial Zone in Tainan County.
Chen also stressed the importance of his "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan and the recently unveiled five-year, NT$500 billion "10 new public construction projects" plan.

He said the government had originally envisioned that the budget for research and development should account for 3 percent of the gross national product by 2008, but added that it is now hoping to achieve the goal by 2006 so as to strengthen the nation's competitive edge.

In view of the fact that the 2008 Olympic Games will be held in Beijing, Chen also said that Taiwan will hold a science expo in that year. He promised that although the venue has yet to be decided, the Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park will definitely play host to part of the expo.

Chen earlier attended the unveiling of a statue of Scottish missionary James Maxwell, who is described as the first practitioner of Western medicine in southern Taiwan. He established the Sin Lau Hospital in Tainan City in 1865.
Chen said during the unveiling ceremony that as long as a person is concerned about Taiwan, he will be remembered after more than 100 years by local people whether he comes from Scotland or Taiwan.

According to Chen, anyone who contributes to Taiwan is a part of Taiwan society, irrespective of race. He further claimed that Taiwan is open and receptive to many different cultures, which has also enriched Taiwan's own culture.
"Multiculturalism is Taiwan's most valuable asset and is not a liability," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEWS ON MAINLAND SPOUSES EFFECTIVELY CHECK ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: (photos available)

Kinmen, Dec. 8 (CNA) Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said Monday that the interviews conducted on mainland Chinese upon their arrival in Taiwan since Sept. 1 have effectively checked those mainlanders who want to use a "marriage of convenience" to come to Taiwan for illegal activities.
Yu made the remarks when he visited Shuitou Wharf on the frontline island of Kinmen to see the interview operations conducted there on mainland Chinese spouses.

Statistics released by the Bureau of Immigration show that as of Dec. 4, a total of 3,945 mainland Chinese spouses were interviewed at two international airports in northern and southern Taiwan. Out of them, 543 were immediately repatriated because of their intention to come to Taiwan for prostitution or other illegal activities. Among 1,182 who were asked for second-round interviews, 80 were repatriated.
During the same period, 205 mainland spouses were interviewed at Shuitou Wharf in Kinmen and 24 were repatriated.

Yu noted that since the start of the new system, 18 percent of mainland Chinese spouses arriving at CKS and Hsiaokang international airports were repatriated, and 10 percent were repatriated in Kinmen.

The number of mainland Chinese spouses applying to come to Taiwan has also dropped, Yu said, showing that the new system has effectively checked mainlanders who want to come to Taiwan for illegal activities under the cover of a bogus marriage.
He also said that the crackdown on illegal mainland immigrants aims to protect legal foreign and mainland Chinese spouses in Taiwan.
On a different note, Yu said that the policy regarding women police officers will be reviewed regarding their numbers and their working hours and duties.
Yu said that more than 90 percent of those in Taiwan's detention centers for mainland Chinese illegal immigrants are women, resulting in a serious deficiency of women policemen.

He noted that women policemen account for only 3.4 percent of the police force and said that this is low when compared with the figure of 4.3 percent in Japan and over 10 percent in Hong Kong. Most of them work in the office, he noted, instead of going out in the field.
Yu was accompanied by Bureau of Immigration Commissioner Tseng Wen-chang to Kinmen. He also inspected a market where a great multitude of mainland Chinese agricultural products are sold.
Yu said that the agricultural products are indeed cheap, but they are not quarantined and could be a health risk, and they could also seriously affect the livelihood of the farmers in Kinmen.
Yu said that he would take back what he saw on the island to Taiwan for related government agencies to take action based on the information.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM WILL NOT CHANGE CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: MAC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan wants to push for a referendum, but has no intention to use it to change the status quo in relations across the Taiwan Strait, the Republic of China's top mainland China policy planner said.
Tsai Ing-wen, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks in an interview with Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a major Japanese daily, which published the interview Monday.
On President Chen's plan to hold a referendum on March 20, 2004, Tsai stressed that the referendum has "no intention to change the status quo that exists between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

She elaborated that the U.S. is now preoccupied with sensitive regions in the Middle East and North Korea, and Taiwan knows perfectly clear that the U.S. does not want anything untoward to happen in the Taiwan Strait.

On whether Taiwan has solicited the views of others on the issue of a referendum, Tsai said that it is possible to take stock of the views of others, but the nation will have to make own judgment and decision in the end.

She said that interpretations on what constitutes major sensitive issues vary, so Taiwan's referendum will need "correct understanding" by related countries, implying the mainland and the U.S. In addition, she said that Beijing does not want to resolve the Taiwan issue through the U.S. and is hoping to do this by resuming cross-strait negotiations.

Asked whether one of the reasons for Taiwan authorities to advocate holding a referendum also include the increasing aversion of Taiwan people toward the mainland, Tsai said frankly that the people's aversion about Beijing has been rising unabated.
She said further that affected by Taiwan businessmen's investment in the mainland, joblessness has worsened in Taiwan, and the public also worries about Taiwan's increased investment in the mainland.
She said that though Taiwan has handled cross-strait relations with caution, it will be unable to stop the voice of the public in a democratic society.

On the principle role on cross-strait talks, Tsai said that the Chinese Communist Party is the only government representative in mainland China, while Taiwan has several political parties to represent the will of the people, and will not be represented by only one party.

Tsai said that Taiwan has a semi-official organization to serve as the principal negotiator with the mainland, but it will not rule out the possibility of non-profit groups in the private sector representing Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE COMMUNITIES IN U.S. SEND CHINESE PREMIER PROTEST LETTER
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Twenty-nine Taiwanese communities in the United States jointly sent an open letter to mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Sunday to urge the Chinese Communist regime to respect the basic human rights of the people of Taiwan to pursue democracy and freedom.

The open letter, carried in all Chinese-language newspapers in America, called for the mainland Chinese authorities to immediately stop bullying Taiwan by threatening to use force for the purpose of an eventual unification of the two sides, and immediately cease their efforts to contain Taiwan in the international community.

The letter told Wen that history is waiting to see if he makes the right choice -- becoming China's Mikhail Gorbachev or China's Saddam Hussein. "We wish you the ability to make a wise decision, " the letter said.
Wen arrived in New York Sunday for an official visit to the United States. Tensions over Taiwan and U.S-mainland China bilateral trade disputes are expected to top the agenda.

The letter said that the "one country, two systems" unification scheme is absolutely unacceptable to the Taiwan people since Taiwan has democratic sovereignty. "The people of Taiwan enjoy democracy, freedom and economic prosperity, which have been earned by the Taiwan people with their own sweat and blood over the past 50 years, " it said.

It stressed that the people of Taiwan did not derive the sovereignty of the nation from any other country and that Taiwan will never "lower its status" voluntarily to become a "special district" of any other country.
It also refuted Wen's public remarks several days ago accusing Taiwan's leadership of attempting to use a democratic practice such as a referendum as a cover to split from mainland China.

Holding a referendum in Taiwan is a move that will put popular democracy into practice, and Taiwan's success in this regard will in turn serve as an inspiration for mainland China to emulate, the letter said.

Referendums in Taiwan are an internal affair to which no other country should interfere, it said, adding that Taiwan is a peace-loving country and China's military threats are the core reason behind the tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Members of the 29 Taiwanese groups that signed the open letter to Wen included the Formosan Association of Public Affairs, the Taiwanese Association of America, The Taiwanese Human Rights Association of America, the L.A. Chapter of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace and several other Taiwanese volunteers organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TAKEN PART IN INTERNATIONAL ANTI-TERRORISM EFFORTS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Monday that Taiwan has participated in international anti-terrorism efforts.
Lin made the remarks when he addressed the opening of the two-day International Symposium on Aviation and Maritime Security in Taipei, which is sponsored by National Chiao Tung University.

Lin said that in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks against the United States, no countries or people can ignore the threat of terrorism and the trend of the world to be aware of anti-terrorism efforts.
Every government has the responsibility to take substantial measures to protect transport security and prevent terrorist activities from taking place, he said.
As a member of the international community, Taiwan adamantly support all forms of international anti-terrorism cooperation, Lin stressed.

"Taiwan had engaged in anti-terrorism cooperation through bilateral channels, and has actively responded and is ready to fight terrorism, " he said, citing the container security initiative promoted by the U.S. government as an example.

Lin said that Taiwan is a key transport center in southeast Asia and northeast Asia, with over 1,000 flights of civilian airplanes passing over the Taipei flight information region and 500 ships from various countries navigating the Taiwan Strait every day. Therefore, security is a big issue not to be ignored, he added.

But Lin also said that he regretted that Taiwan is not able to participate in the International Civil Aviation Organization and the International Maritime Organization. This creates a missing link in the global sea and aviation security system.
The organizations are under the United Nations, which precludes Taiwan's participation.

Lin also cited evidence to show that Taiwan supports efforts on anti-terrorism to protect shipping security, saying that his ministry has adopted the International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS Code) to monitor all port authorities working out security plans for port facilities, while shipping companies have also acted according to the law to handle commercial shipping and international business port facility security.
Meanwhile, U.S. Representative Dan Burton (R-IN), speaking at the same forum, said that he supports Taiwan's fight against the threat of a missile attack from mainland China.
Burton said that the threat of terrorism is without borders and a problem that the world has to face. He said that all countries have to cooperate to fight against terrorism.

Burton also mentioned Taiwan's planned referendum under the missile threat from the mainland, believing that when freedom is threatened, Taiwan people have to say loudly to the mainland that Taiwan needs freedom, security and peace.
As an international friend of Taiwan, Burton said that he supported Taiwan's people to fight against the threat of the missiles on the mainland.
The symposium brought together 200 figures from government, academia, and industry in Taiwan as well as scholars and experts from 16 countries to deliver papers and take part in seminars.
This was Taiwan's first major conference on transportation safety in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVENTEC CO-FOUNDER DIES AT 55

TEXT.P: By Deborah Kuo CNA reporter

Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) Sayling Wen, one of Taiwan's first calculator makers who went on to become a pioneer of the island's information technology industry, died of cerebral hemorrhage Dec. 7. He was 55.
Wen, who became president of calculator manufacturer Santron at the age of 24, went into coma three days ago due to a hemorrhagic stroke and was rushed to hospital. He never awoke from the coma.
His sudden passing left his old pals from Santron and the thousands of staff members of Inventec Group, one of the major notebook and IT device manufacturers in Taiwan, caught unprepared.

Wen and his National Taiwan University classmate Barry Lam, now chairman of Quanta Computer, and Chiang Ying-tsun, former chairman of GVC Electronics, co-founded Santron Electronics in 1972 to churn out electronic devices and Taiwan's first-generation electronic calculators.
In 1973, at the age of 25, he and Lam and some other IT enthusiasts jointly established Kinpo Electronics to expand manufacturing of calculators as well as to research and develop simple computers.

In 1975, Wen and classmate Yeh Kuo-yi co-founded Inventec Group to make computer peripherals and related products. The founding of these companies paved the way for Taiwan's transition into a global hardware manufacturing powerhouse.

By the age of 26, Wen had traveled to 43 countries, most of the time traveling with a suitcase containing calculators and other innovative electronic devices. By the age of 40, he had traveled to 70 countries around the world, with about 300 days out of every year being spent in either hotels or aboard airplanes.
At 50, Wen retired from the electronics business, as he had planned, and became a writer and a philanthropist.

In 2000, he found himself in the rural township of Huangyangchuan in Gansu Province, one of the poorest areas in mainland China. He said at the time that viewing the local residents there living in grinding poverty brought him to the verge of tears.
He spent the entire year of 2002 traveling around 12 provinces in western, southern and northern China, trying to figure out the best ways to help the poor Chinese people.

In 2002, he set up the Qian-Xiang-Wan-Cai Co. in Huangyangchuan, aimed at establishing a computerized network, at a cost of US$50 million, in western China as a fast track on which the locals' livelihood could be improved.

Meanwhile, he invested US$5 million to build a five-star, 150-room hotel-like conference center in Huangyangchuan, claiming that the hotel would serve as a home away from home for business people. "Only by attracting the rich to the poor area will it be freed from poverty," he said at the time.
Wen was also planning to establish a software development company in Huangyangchuan, aimed at turning the backwater into a high-tech hub in western China.
By early 2003, Wen was the talk of the town in western China.
A philanthropist, Wen himself led the simplest life that he possibly could. Being a little bit plump, Wen stopped eating anything after 3 p.m. every day and only drank diet cola after that hour.
Despite the wealth he accumulated over the past three decades, Wen once said that only the richness of life derived from his experiences over the years was his real fortune.

Wen had his first book published at the age of 49 when he and his friends, including renowned cartoonist Tsai Chih-chung, co-founded the Studio for Tomorrow. In the following six years, he authored 20 books on business management and philosophy, English learning, the development potential of western China, and others.

In fact, according to Tsai, Wen's greatest ambition was to become a novelist writing exclusively Chinese kung fu novels. Wen began to write kung fu novels as a ghost writer in high school to earn money to help his mother make ends meet, Tsai said.

Tsai used the Chinese word "kuan, " which can mean either "wide" or "magnanimous, " to describe Wen. He said Wen had a wide body and was a "wide-minded" man who always demonstrated magnanimity toward his family and friends.

Wen was impartial politically, giving support to any party that he considered was doing a good thing for the people and the country. He once gave the Democratic Progressive Party NT$500,000 in cash to help out the then opposition party during its most difficult years.

More recently, he was scheduled to attend a ceremony marking the establishment of the national presidential campaign headquarters of the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Lien Chan and James Soong slated for Dec. 7 to drum up support for the major opposition camp. He never made it.

Since his psychological retirement at the age of 50, Wen spent a lot of his time chatting with the younger generations online via his Studio for Tomorrow, besides traveling to mainland China to carry out his philanthropic work.
He once said that the one thing that made him feel most comfortable was that he had a good wife and a filial son.
He left numerous "quotable quotes" in his online chats, such as: "The computer is my office, " "Working is a duty as well as a joy, " and "Flying is a time for writing and sleeping."

He also wrote during one of his online chats that: "Busy is staying for only one day at one hotel and not having time to have your clothes washed." "Leisure is staying at the same hotel for three days or more."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 8, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARAB SECURITY PROFESSIONALS RECEIVING FORENSICS TRAINING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of Arab security professionals began to receive forensics training in Taiwan Tuesday under a cooperation program between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia, sources from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MOJIB) said.

Eight trainees from the Riyadh-based Naif Arab Academy for Security Sciences will be receiving intensive training on DNA forensics over the next two weeks at the MOJIB headquarters in Taipei, said Pu Chang-en, a section chief of the MOJIB Sixth Department.

According to Pu, the Naif Arab Academy for Security Sciences was established to fulfill the needs expressed by Arab law enforcement agencies for an academic institution that would promote research on security issues, offer postgraduate programs, and conduct short-term training courses that could contribute to the prevention and control of crime in the 22 Arab countries, most of which are located in the Middle East.

The Naif Arab Academy for Security Sciences has been engaged in academic cooperation with Taiwan's MOJIB since 1995, regularly sending its trainees, most of them police and intelligence personnel, to Taiwan to receive professional training and inviting MOJIB experts to Riyadh to give lectures to the Arab trainees, Pu said.
More than 100 Naif trainees have received training in chemical forensics in previous sessions held at the MOJIB, according to Pu.
The eight Naif trainees who are attending this current training session are mainly police and intelligence professionals from Bahrain and Saudi Arabia, Pu said.

He added that as it has become increasingly difficult for Taiwan to expand its diplomacy worldwide due to the difficult international situation, the MOJIB'S cooperation with foreign academic institutions has opened up another door for Taiwan's diplomatic development.

In addition to cooperating with the Arab world, the MOJIB has also cooperated with Japan and the United States, collaborating in chemical analysis of amphetamines, heroin and other illicit drugs, and in tracing the sources of these illicit drugs, Pu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

Bangkok Post: war on drugs / only 1,600 deaths tied to drugs.
Only 1,600 deaths of the estimtated 2,500 people killed during the government's Febraury-April war on drugs were related, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said yesterday. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Banks' credit card hard-sell curbed.
The days of being hassled on the street to sign up for credit cards could soon be over. Banking regulators have clamped down on hard-sell tactics in public areas used by financial institutions to promote credit cards and other types of unsecured loans.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Eastward Ho! China considers shifting 100 million farmers from its undeveloped western regions to the prosperous east coast.
China is mulling over a massive 'west-to-east' campaign to migrate 100 million farmers in the undeveloped western regions to the booming eastern coast, state media reported yesterday.

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Putin's party, allies triumph in poll As liberals shut out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED 17TH IN GLOBAL NETWORKED READINESS INDEX
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked 17th globally in terms of networked readiness index (NRI) by the Switzerland-based World Economic Forum, according to the global information technology report 2003-2004 posted on its Web site Tuesday.

Covering a total of 102 economies around the world, the report said that the NRI is composed of three component indices that asses the environment for information and communication technology (ICT) offered by a given country or community, the readiness of the community's key stakeholders (individuals, businesses and governments) and the usage of ICT among these stakeholders.
The report uses the NRI to measure the degree of preparation of a nation or a community to participate in and benefit from ICT developments.

The United States heads the rankings, replacing Finland, which ranked first in the 2002-2003 report and fell to third, while Singapore maintains second place. Sweden and Denmark were ranked fourth and fifth, respectively.
Among the other Asian nations, Japan was ranked 12th, Hong Kong 18th and South Korea 20th.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STICKS TO REFERENDUM DESPITE U.S. DISAPPROVAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his determination Tuesday to hold an unprecedented national referendum on March 20, despite news from Washington that the United States disapproves of such a move.
Speaking at a concert to mark International Human Rights Day, the president said his plan for a "preventive referendum" on Beijing's missile threat to Taiwan will not be changed.

Although Chen did not mentioned the United States by name, his remarks were considered a response to an anonymous U.S. official's warning in Washington earlier in the day that the United States sees no logical purpose in the referendum except that it could anger Beijing and destabilize the situation across the Taiwan Strait.

One of Chen's aides turned down journalists' requests to comment on the U.S. official's remarks earlier in the day, saying that his office would not comment on stories attributed to anonymous sources.

However, the aide said there is no difference in the position of Taipei and Washington over the referendum issue. Washington opposes any referendum that would push the envelope and Chen has said he will not contradict his inaugural promise not to toy with the idea of Taiwan independence during his term via referendum, the aide said, adding that these positions have not changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW PASSED TO CHARGE TAIPOWER FOR NUCLEAR PLANT EMERGENCIES

TEXT.P: A bill that authorizes the government to charge a fee to Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) for its nuclear power plants passed the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.

Under the law, the Atomic Energy Council is empowered to levy a charge on Taipower, which runs the country's three nuclear plants and is building a fourth. The fee will be used as a fund for reaction in case of any nuclear emergencies that arise from the plants.
The fund has already been in operation for several years, but the Executive Yuan decided to give it a legal basis by drawing up legislation covering its establishment and operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CONFIRMS AVIAN FLU CASE

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government confirmed Tuesday that a five-year-old boy had contracted the H9N2 strain of avian influenza, but doctors from the Health Department said that the risk of the flu spreading from person to person is not high.
The department also announced that there had been five outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease on Cheung Chau, one of Hong Kong's outlying islands.
A total of 37 children came down with the illness at two child care centers, one kindergarten and two primary schools. Most of the children have recovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST MASTER CHENG YEN DECORATED FOR DEVOTED SERVICES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian traveled to the eastern county of Hualien Tuesday to decorate Buddhist Master Cheng Yen for her outstanding contributions to charity and humanitarian relief at home and abroad over the past 37 years.

Chen conferred upon Cheng Yen the Order of Brilliant Star at a ceremony held at the Tzu Chi Meditation Center in Hualien, with Vice President Annette Lu, several other government officials and some Tzu Chi volunteers witnessing.
Chen lauded Cheng Yen for founding the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation to carry out four major missions -- charity, medicine, education and culture at home and abroad.
Under Cheng Yen's leadership, Chen said, Tzu Chi has become an "empire of charity" and has achieved "brilliant accomplishments" that few other organizations can emulate.

"Tzu Chi has conveyed Taiwan's vitality and love to the world through its selfless, dedicated charitable and humanitarian services over the years, " Chen said at the ceremony. "I admire Cheng Yen as she has entered society to help people."
Cheng Yen was nominated in 1996 for the Nobel Peace Prize for her selfless dedication to helping others and for bringing to a troubled world a renewed vision of compassion in action.

In the July 2000 issue of the U.S. magazine BusinessWeek, Cheng Yen was named as one of the 50 "Stars of Asia" -- leaders at the forefront of change. After more than 30 years of total devotion to disaster relief and charitable works in Taiwan and dozens of other countries, the magazine says, Cheng Yen has gained international prominence as the "Mother Teresa of the Buddhist World."

Tzu Chi now boasts 4 million members in Taiwan alone -- about one-fifth of the country's population -- and takes in a large amount of donations annually to finance disaster relief operations throughout the world, as well as building hospitals, colleges and research centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Putin calls voting fair; observers disagree.
International observers on Monday criticized parliamentary elections here as a step backward in Russia's democratic transition, but President Vladimir Putin described the voting as "free, honest, open and democratic."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN URGE BUSH TO SUPPORT DEMOCRATIC TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Eleven members of the U.S. House of Representatives sent a joint letter to President George W. Bush Monday urging him to reaffirm U.S. support for Taiwan's democratic development and the right of the Taiwan people to decide on their nation's future.

The letter was sent to the White House on the eve of Bush's meeting with mainland Chinese Premiere Wen Jiabao, who arrived in New York Sunday on his first official visit to the United States since taking office.

The congressmen said in the letter that the United States should not compromise with any other country on democratic activities in Taiwan or other parts of the world while American soldiers are fighting for freedom and democracy in Iraq and Afghanistan.

They expressed their common hope that Bush will reaffirm the long term U.S. support for Taiwan's democratic development during his talks with Wen. Support for democracy, human rights and rule of law has been U.S. policy, which also epitomizes America's core values, the lawmakers said.

They also urged Bush to reaffirm to Wen U.S. support for free and fair elections in Taiwan and its stance that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve the issue of Taiwan's status through peaceful and democratic means.
The congressmen included David Wu (D-Oregon) , Steve Chabor (R-Ohio) and Robert Menendez (D-New Jersey).

Meanwhile, the four co-chairmen of the U.S. Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the House, also sent a joint letter to Secretary of State Colin Powell urging him and Bush not to declare U.S. opposition to Taiwan independence during their talks with Wen.
The four co-chairmen are Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), Rep. Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) and Rep. Robert Wexler (D-Fla.).
They reminded Powell in their joint letter that it would mark an actual change to long-term U.S. policy toward Taiwan if Bush publicly announces U.S. opposition to Taiwan independence.

One of the Six Assurances the United States pledged to Taiwan in 1982 was that the United States will not change its stance on Taiwan's sovereignty issue, the four co-chairmen said, adding that they hope Powell and Bush will reaffirm U.S. security commitments to Taiwan during their meetings with Wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL INCREASES FLIGHTS ON TAIPEI-HANOI ROUTE

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, announced Tuesday a plan to increase the number of its weekly flights on the Taipei-Hanoi route from three to four late this month to meet growing demand, a spokesman for the company said.

Starting from Dec. 26, CAL will operate four flights from Taipei to Hanoi per week, adding one Friday morning flight to its existing Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday morning flights, the spokesman said. He added that the decision was made to satisfy robust demand on the popular route, which was opened in July this year.
Taiwan is Vietnam's second-largest importer and foreign investor. Close trade and economic exchanges have fueled an increased demand for convenient travel between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO HONG KONG, MAINLAND CHINA IN NOVEMBER SET NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports to Hong Kong and mainland China hit a new high of US$5.072 billion in November, accounting for 36.69 percent of the country's overall outbound shipments, according to the latest statistics compiled by the Ministry of Finance.

The record high figure made the Greater China area Taiwan's No. 1 export outlet, with the United States and the European Union ranking in second and third spots, absorbing 16 percent and 15.5 percent of Taiwan's exports valued at US$2.21 billion and US$2.14 billion, respectively, last month.

Greater China began to replace the United States as Taiwan's top export market in 2000, with the ratio as a percentage of Taiwan's overall outbound shipments rising from 23.97 percent in 2000 to 25.81 percent in 2001 and 31.23 percent in 2002, ministry statistics show.

At the same time, Taiwan exported US$1.365 billion-worth of goods and services, or about 10 percent of the total, to various member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in November, while its exports to Japan dropped to 8.34 percent of the total.

Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$3.74 billion and US$700 million with the Greater China area and the United States in November, up by US$810 million and down by US$260 million compared to the year-earlier levels, respectively. The country also posted a trade gap of US$720 million in its favor with the European Union, up by US$130 million.
However, Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$2.34 billion with Japan, an increase of US$1.08 billion year-on-year.

Meanwhile, Taiwan exports set a record single-month high of US$13.8 billion for November, customs tallies show. The figure represents a 16.2 percent growth rate year-on-year, which is also the eighth monthly rise in a row.

Taiwan outbound shipments are expected to register another high for December with a double-digit increase, which is forecast to give an export increase rate of 9.8 precent for the whole of 2003, a ministry official said.
November imports were worth a total of US$12.39 billion, the third-highest monthly level in history, according to the same statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWS REVISED TO SHELTER BROADCAST STATIONS FROM POLITICAL INFLUENCE

TEXT.P: A set of three revised laws aimed at sheltering the broadcast media from political influence passed a third reading at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday after years of fierce bickering among the lawmakers.

Under the revised rules of the Broadcast & Television Law, Cable Television Law and the Satellite Television Law, the government and political parties are forbidden to invest in or run radio and television stations.
The government and political parties which owned stakes in these stations before the laws were revised must divest themselves within two years of the revised rules taking force.
The revised laws also forbid elected public officials, officials of government and political party officials from serving as directors, supervisors or managers of broadcast stations.
Those who already served in these posts before the laws were revised will have to quit within six months of the revisions taking effect.

As a consequence, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will have to divest itself of its stakes in the Broadcast Company of China (BCC) and the China Television Company (CTV) within two years, while the Executive Yuan will have to sell its stakes in the Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd. (TTV) and the China Television System (CTS).

The Executive Yuan will have to come up a plan within six months to dispose of its stakes in the two television companies. There has been speculation that the government intends to turn CTS into a foundation while selling its TTV shares to private investors.

In order to prevent the government and political parties from getting around the ban via front organizations, the prohibition will also apply to foundations set up with donations from government or political parties or their attorneys.
The revised rules also prohibit candidates for public office from appearing in television and radio programs, commercials or short films made with government funds.

Lawmaker Hong Hsiu-chu of the KMT, who initiated the ban, calls this article "President Chen's clause" since it was crafted to stop President Chen Shui-bian from airing his weekly televised talk at the cost of the taxpayers once he attains his candidacy in the March presidential election.
In order to prevent exterior forces from "skewing broadcasts, " the revised laws also prohibit foreigners from acting as directors, supervisors, stock owners or founders of broadcast stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ WELCOMES SWISS JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE IN LAFAYETTE SCANDAL PROBE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Tuesday that it welcomes a decision by the Swiss authorities to offer judicial assistance to Taiwan in its probe into a snowballing warship procurement scandal.

The Swiss Ministry of Justice announced a day earlier that a federal court has ruled that Taiwan, France and the Principality of Liechtenstein should be given access to Swiss legal files, particularly documents regarding the Andrew Wang family's bank accounts in Switzerland, to facilitate investigations into an alleged kickback scandal in connection with Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette frigates from France in 1991.
MOJ officials said they welcome the Swiss court's ruling, which they said will be helpful in tracking the flow of Wang's slush funds and shedding light on the alleged kickback scandal.
Swiss judicial authorities have frozen Wang's Swiss bank accounts, which contain some US$600 million in slush funds suspected of being kickbacks from the Lafayette frigate deal.

Wang, an arms broker, fled Taiwan in 1993 and has been wanted since September 2000 for suspected involvement in the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal and the subsequent murder of an ROC navy captain in 1993.

Wang and his son, Wang Chia-hsing, might also have bank accounts with deposits totaling US$100 million in Liechtenstein and the British-administered Cayman Islands in the Caribbean Sea, according to previous press reports.

Since Aug. 1, 2000, a special investigative team headed by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa, has been probing arms procurement scandals allegedly connected with the death of naval captain Yin Ching-feng under suspicious circumstances in 1993.

MOJ sources said two prosecutors from the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court are now handling the case. According to the sources, the two prosecutors have made several visits to Switzerland in the past few years and have forged a smooth, informal working relationship with the Swiss federal court.

Meanwhile, an MOJ official said the ministry is striving to sign judicial assistance agreements with major countries around the world to facilitate crime solving. "European countries, Switzerland in particular, are priority targets for signing such accords at the moment," the official said.
In the past, he went on, most countries have been reluctant to negotiate judicial assistance pacts with Taiwan because of the absence of diplomatic ties.

"Now that the United States has already signed a judicial assistance accord with Taiwan, we think it will benefit our bid to negotiate similar pacts with other countries, " the official said, adding that the MOJ is lobbying for the bid through various channels.

According to reports from Geneva, it remains uncertain whether the Taiwan authorities will be able to take possession of the slush funds in the Wang family's Swiss bank accounts. Taiwan must produce solid evidence proving that the money came from its payment for the Lafayette deal, the reports say, with the final result dependent on a Swiss court ruling.

The ROC Navy purchased six Lafayette frigates built by French defense contractor Thomson-CSF for US$2.8 billion in 1991. Allegations of kickbacks over the deal emerged after the death of Yin, head of the navy's arms acquisition office, whose body was found floating in the sea off the east coast of Taiwan in late 1993.
It has been alleged that Yin was murdered to prevent him from blowing the whistle on rampant corruption in the military -- including the Lafayette deal.

The investigation team has so far indicted six middle-ranking naval officers on charges of inflating the Lafayette price tag for the benefit of the French contractor. Three other naval officers have also been indicted for irregularities in the procurement of an order of minesweepers.

As for the murder case, no major breakthrough has been achieved because key suspect Wang, who is believed to be deeply involved in the Lafayette kickback scandal, remains at large, reportedly residing in London.
The investigation team has not yet discovered any hard evidence of alleged Lafayette kickbacks paid to Taiwan officials.
To speed up the investigations, the team has recently recruited several prosecutors versed in financial and banking affairs to assist in tracking the money trail.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HIS RE-ELECTION WILL HELP END CHAOS IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that if he wins re-election next March, Taiwan's political ecology will undergo a dramatic change, and he is sure current chaotic situations in the Legislative Yuan will end.
The president made the remarks when he paid a visit to Huang Sheng-hsiung, superintendent of the Mennonite Christian Hospital in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

The president said that he would very much like to put the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant to a referendum, but according to the referendum bill passed Nov. 27, there is not enough time to hold a referendum on the issue on March 20, or the presidential election day, because of a series of procedural problems regarding initiating a referendum.

The president, using Article 17 of the referendum bill, has said that he would call for a "preventive referendum, " on that day to demand Beijing to dismantle the missiles targeting Taiwan and renounce its threat of military force against Taiwan.

The president said that the Executive Yuan has decided to ask the Legislative Yuan to reconsider some parts of the recently passed referendum bill, which could result in the unreasonable provisions being eliminated.

But if the Executive Yuan fails to have the legislation reworked, and Chen wins re-election, the president said he feels that the political ecology in Taiwan will change dramatically, meaning that though his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is presently a minority in the legislature, it will become a majority after his election victory.

He said that if the DPP wins legislative elections at the end of next year, then it will mean that the opposition camp will have "gone against the will of the majority of the people, " and the legislators from the opposition camp would have to make adjustment or face being phased out, which he said will provide the best chance for the DPP.
"The significance of my re-election bid will definitely terminate the chaotic situation in politics and in the Legislative Yuan, " he added.
He said, "In 2000, Taiwan people used a political transfer to change Taiwan history, but the historical mission in 2004 will be to promote the holding of a referendum. "

He asked why some backward and former communist countries can hold referendums and Taiwan cannot. He said that 21 countries in the world sponsored national referendums in 2003, and wondered why "so many in Taiwan are still seeing referendum as something ominous to be shunned."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORK UNDERWAY FOR KINMEN TO LAUNCH OUTBOUND CHARTER PLANE SERVICE

TEXT.P: Preparations for Shangyi Airport on the frontline Kinmen Island to launch international charter plane services are underway and operations can start as soon as the Executive Yuan grants its approval, according to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The MOTC made the reply Monday in a written report in response to a question raised by opposition New Party Legislator Wu Cheng-dian from Kinmen, who suggested that the central government upgrade the functions and facilities of the island's sea and airports to help bolster its economic development.

The MOTC said it will do its best to help accomplish this aim and to help promote Kinmen tourism in line with the government's goal of doubling tourist arrivals to the country by 2008, working in conjunction with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Officials from the MAC, MND and the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the MOTC conducted an on-site inspection of the airport Oct. 22 and reached agreement to jointly cooperate in the plan, the MOTC said, noting that the CAA has begun relevant programming, including asking the Chinese Petroleum Corp. to install an oil bunker and fueling facilities on Kinmen specifically for civilian airplanes.

Regarding Wu's proposal that Kinmen's harbor should also be upgraded for international use, the MOTC said its Liaolo, Shuitou and Jeoukung wharfs were designated in 2000 for commercial transportation purposes between the offshore island and Taiwan proper, as well as to serve the direct shipping links initiated in Jan. 2001 with ports in mainland China's Fujian Province.
However, making the harbor into an international port in line with the country's overall development projects will require further study and assessment, the MOTC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEN JIABAO URGED TO FACE REALITY BETWEEN BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A federation of Taiwanese groups in New York on Monday urged visiting mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao to recognize the reality that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait.

In a declaration published in Chinese language news media, the federation composed of Taiwanese residents in the greater New York area urged mainland Chinese leaders to abandon their "one China" policy and stop intimidating Taiwan, hoping that leaders of both sides of the Taiwan Strait can sit down together one day to work for the welfare of all human beings.

The Taiwanese groups, led by Hsu Po-cheng, president of the Taiwanese Association of New York, launched a protest on Dec. 7 outside the hotel where Wen was staying, expressing anger on behalf of all Taiwanese people at Wen's remarks in his recent interview with the Washington Post that "Chinese people will safeguard the country's unification by any means."
The Taiwanese groups will continue their protests along with Wen's next stops in Washington, D.C. and Boston.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, giving up NT$0.045 to close at NT$34.015.

The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.060 and dipped to a low of NT$34.009.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HAVE A SILK WEAVING INDUSTRIAL ZONE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the construction of Taiwan's first silk weaving industrial zone will be completed in June, 2004 at Touliou in central Taiwan.

Speaking at a founding anniversary of the Taiwan Silk and Filament Weaving Industrial Association, Chen said Taiwan's silk weaving industry is powerful and competitive in the world market with exports amounting to NT$102 billion (US$3 billion) each year.

Occupying an area of 270 hectares, the new industrial zone will become an export processing zone, Chen said, adding that it will be included in a "Free Trade Harbor Area" to sharpen its competitive edge in world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWING DEMAND FOR INFANT CARE SERVICES IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Expense and expertise seem to be the two biggest stumbling blocks to providing professional baby care services for working parents in Singapore, child care operators who've branched out into infant care told Channel NewsAsia Sunday.

Despite the growing demand for such services, there are currently only 19 child care operators licensed in Singapore to also provide infant care for toddlers between the ages of two and 18 months. At present, there are some 650 child care operators in the city-state.
Pauline Gan, principal of Precious Care, told Channel NewsAsia that "there's a growing need" for infant care services.
With the cost of such care being a major issue for parents in Singapore, the government is looking at possible financial schemes to make it more affordable and available.
The Community Development and Sports Ministry has said details on such plans will be announced at a later date.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCLUSIVE ZONE TO HELP UPGRADE SILK AND FILAMENT WEAVING SECTOR

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said Tuesday that the silk and filament weaving exclusive zone will help a great deal to upgrade the competitive edge of the silk sector.
Yu made the remarks when he attended the 50th anniversary of the Taiwan Silk and Filament Weaving Association.

Yu noted that annual exports of the silk and filament weaving sector has surpassed NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), making it the major export of Taiwan's textile industry, and that a majority of businesses have produced high quality and high-value-added silk and filament weaving products through high-technology and automated production methods.

To keep the roots of the companies in Taiwan, businesses established a silk and filament weaving exclusive zone seven years ago, which he said will contribute tremendously to the increase of production value, the creations of jobs, and the upgrading of the competitive edge.
Meanwhile, Lin Wen-chung, president of the Taiwan Silk and Filament Weaving Association, said on the same occasion that the textile industry currently faces three difficulties.

The three are the shortened working hours of employees, the shrinking of number of foreign laborers in the textile industry, and the difficulty in soliciting more capital because of slumping textile share prices, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE TO LOOK INTO EXPORT CONTROVERSY OF BANANAS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday that it will soon hold a coordination meeting with banana growers to settle disputes over a 30-year-old marketing mechanism.

Presently, exports of Taiwan bananas have to go through the Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Cooperative, and big banana growers have been complaining saying that they are capable of exporting their produce themselves.
The big growers earlier sponsored public hearings with the help of legislators on ending the domination of the marketing cooperative.
But small banana growers ran ads in the media to oppose the idea of scrapping the existing marketing mechanism for the sake of their own existence.
The big growers asked for free exports mainly because they themselves have the marketing capability. The decline of banana exports over the recent years has increased their sentiment.

They protested against the marketing cooperative for what they said was "exploitation," because the cooperative buys from contracted banana growers for NT$12 (US$0.35) or NT$13 per kilogram, which they say is close to their production costs, but the cooperative offers bananas at more than NT$60 per kilo to Japan.

COA officials said that bananas used to be exported freely overseas. But because of cutthroat competition and small banana growers' inability to market on the scale of larger growers, the government has since 1973 had a single export channel, with Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Cooperative coordinating for exports.

There are around 10,000 banana growers in Taiwan, and more than 60 percent of them are contracted growers. The planting areas of bananas is 10,353 hectares, and the production volume is around 226,000 tons, with 89 percent of them going to the domestic market. The production areas are located mainly in the counties of Pingtung, Nantou and Kaohsiung, which accounted for 82 percent of all production.
But with the production cost of bananas rising, and the steep competition from low-priced bananas from the Philippines and Ecuador, exports of Taiwan bananas has dropped over the years.
COA officials said that with the government's policy to promote fruits due to the banner crop year, banana exports so far this year have increased by 36 percent from the same period last year.

The officials said that banana exports last year were 24,757 tons, accounting for 11 percent of the total production. Exports so far this year have amounted to 31,981 tons, up 36 percent from the same period last year, mainly going to Japan.

As for demands that the government open bananas for free export, the officials said that they have commissioned National Chung Hsing University and National Chengchi University to conduct surveys on banana growers to solicit their views about the 30-year-old marketing system.

After the completion of the surveys, the COA will invite members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Cooperative and banana grower representatives for an overall review of the banana marketing system.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MILITARY EXPERTS VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Two U.S. military strategists -- John Caldwell and Eric A. McVadon -- traveled to the ROC-held frontline island of Kinmen Tuesday for a visit.

Caldwell, a research fellow at the Institute for Defense Analysis, and McVadon, a retired rear admiral, paid a courtesy call on Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng to get first-hand information about Kinmen's developments in recent years.

Lee told his guests that the opening of direct trade, mail and shipping links between Kinmen and Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links, " has contributed to bilateral commercial and civilian exchanges.

Since the opening of the "mini three links" in January 2001, Lee said, Kinmen residents have made 80,000 visits to mainland China through this new channel. Mainland authorities have decided to allow Fujian people to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen via the "mini three links" in the near future, Lee added.

Caldwell said the opening of the "mini three links" has set a good model for the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations. During his recent trip to Xiamen, Caldwell said residents there have told him that they hold positive views on the functions of the "mini three links."
McVadon, who worked at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing between 1990 and 1992, said he once took a distant look at Kinmen from Xiamen. "I'm excited to set feet on Kinmen for a visit," he told Lee.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE MISSILES POSE BIGGEST THREAT TO SITUATION IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The nearly 500 ballistic missiles deployed by mainland China targeting Taiwan pose the biggest threat to stability in the Taiwan Strait, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

Huang Chih-fang made the remarks after Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao toned down his earlier harsh tone against Taiwan in New York Sunday by paraphrasing a line by famous Taiwan poet Yu Kung-chung to say that Taiwan, with one narrow strait separating it from mainland China, is the heartache of China and steeped in nostalgia.
Wen, who is said to love Chinese poetry, earlier said that Beijing will not tolerate separatist forces attempting to use democratic practices like a referendum as "a cover" to achieve independence.

Huang noted that since the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian in May 20, 2000, the ROC president has done his best to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait. In fact, the 496 missiles deployed by Beijing in its southeast coastal provinces pose the biggest threat to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
"Citing a poem will not help improving cross-strait relations, " he said, adding that, "Mainland Chinese leaders should know clearly what Taiwan people want."
He reiterated that President Chen's "preventive referendum" will not touch on his promises made in the inaugural address in 2000, which included no referendum on the nation's future status.

Huang stressed that the exchanges between Taiwan and the United States are good, and the U.S. government has made its stance clear, which is that the U.S. will not support any referendum that will lead to the change of Taiwan's status quo, on which both sides agree and there is no gap between them.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED VOLUNTEER, CONSCRIPTION MILITARY STILL A DEFENSE MINISTRY GOAL

TEXT.P: Transforming Taiwan's miliary from a conscripted force to an all-volunteer one is an aim of the Ministry of National Defense, but the task will almost certainly not be completed before 2012, a military spokesman said Tuesday.

In the initial stage, the defense ministry plans to shift the ratio of the conscription-only military so that 60 percent of servicemen and women would be volunteers. This will better serve changing combat demands before 2012, defense ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a news conference.

Legislators from both the "pan-green" camp, led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the Kuomintang, have recently advocated an all-volunteer military. Some analysts have said, however, that the subject has more to do with posturing during the run-up to the March 20, 2004 presidential election than streamlining the military.
Huang said that unless an all-volunteer military plan is enacted into law and integrated into government policy, the defense ministry will not comment on any "electioneering language or statement."

Huang also made public the results of a volunteer recruiting program that began several months ago, disclosing that the three military units responsible for recruiting volunteers have managed to recruit only 367 individuals as of the end of November, against the original target of 647 volunteers.
The defense ministry will continue to recruit volunteers using similar programs in March and September next year to further assess the feasibility of the experimental plan, Huang said.

Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said recently at the Legislative Yuan that an all-volunteer military will be feasible only when smaller numbers of servicemen and women are required, when the defense budget reaches a certain level and when all necessary advanced weaponry systems are acquired -- all of which have been forecast to be achieved by 2012 or later.
Tang said it is an irreversible trend that the military is becoming "lean and mean," with the number of men and women in uniform gradually decreasing and the forces increasingly becoming high-tech.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOROUGH CHIEF SALARY ISSUE REQUIRES REVIEW: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: A prudent and comprehensive review is needed before deciding whether to change the posts of village chief and ward chief into paying jobs, Vice Minister of the Interior Hsu Ying-shen said Tuesday.

Hsu made the remarks after a group of independent lawmakers came up with a proposal calling for amendments to the existing Law on Local Government Systems to offer salaries to village and borough chiefs on the grounds that they all work as public functionaries.

If the proposal is enacted, the government's annual expenditure will increase by an estimated NT$7 billion. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not support the proposal, but the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party (PFP), and even the DPP's ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- have tentatively shown support for the idea.

Noting that Taiwan now has more than 7,800 village and borough chiefs, Hsu said that giving them a salary would involve a wide range of issues that would require a thorough review from a macro and forward-looking perspective.

"If they are given the status of civil servants, problems regarding examinations, classification and pensions must be addressed, " Hsu said, adding that these issues as well as relevant fiscal and budgetary issues require inter-departmental efforts to resolve.

Commenting on opposition PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei's call that the Ministry of the Interior should propose a feasible solution to this longstanding issue, Hsu said the ministry alone cannot solve it.

Villages and boroughs are grassroots administrative units. Each of them has an office headed by a chief elected by popular vote for a four-year term. Village and borough chiefs only receive subsidies for office overhead and are not salaried.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BUSH URGED TO REITERATE U.S. SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An American expert said in a commentary in Monday's Los Angeles Times that President George W. Bush should quote to visiting Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao the words of the Taiwan Relations Act and urge Beijing to talk directly with Taipei.

Harvey Feldman, senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation's Asia Studies Center, said in the commentary, entitled "U. S. Is Caught Between Two Governments Glaring Across a One-China Policy," that Premier Wen comes to Washington this week to tell the United States to rein in Taiwan's democracy and keep Taiwan from replacing its constitution.

Feldman, who is a retired ambassador and one of the authors of the Taiwan Relations Act, said Washington's "One China policy" says "we have diplomatic relations only with Beijing, though we maintain all other relations with Taipei, and we 'acknowledge' China's claim to the island, but we make no statement about Taiwan's status."
"There is one stipulation: We insist that any change in that status must be accomplished peacefully, and with the consent of Taiwan's people," he added.

Feldman said President Bush should quote to Wen the words of the Taiwan Relations Act: The United States will 'consider any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, including by boycotts or embargoes, a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States."
President Bush might replay his April 2000 statement about doing whatever it takes to help Taiwan defend itself if attacked, Feldman said.

But in any case, Feldman said, the president should add: "It really is time, even past time, for your government to sit down and talk directly to the government in Taiwan-- without preconditions, without treats. And without expecting the United States to carry your water for you." by L. Chu and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUPS CALL FOR CLEAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: With the presidential election campaign gradually heating up, major private groups met at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to urge presidential candidates to commit themselves to a clean election.

Chai Sung-lin, president of the National Clean Election Promotion Association, said at the "clean election and transparent politics" seminar that his association will join forces with other social groups in pushing the contenders in the upcoming presidential election to stick to clean election principles.
Scholars, experts and representatives of major public-interest groups were invited to attend the seminar to discuss measures for promoting a clean election.

As the major candidates for the March 20, 2004 presidential election are running neck and neck, Chai said, they have increasingly resorted to improper rhetoric and divisive tactics aimed at stirring up ethnic sentiments.

"Their moves set a bad example of behavior for society and are detrimental to Taiwan's fledgling democratic system, " Chai said, adding that he is hopeful of integrating social forces to press presidential candidates to conduct a clean election in order to create a clean and transparent political environment and provide the people with a "government of integrity."

Chai outlined seven key principles for clean elections: no vote-buying; no violence; no involvement of criminal gangs; no mud-slinging; no environmental pollution and damage; no corruption; and no extravagance in campaigning.
The upcoming election will mainly be a race between President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan who is running under the banner of the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION SHOULD DEAL WITH WARD CHIEF SALARY ISSUE: PFP

TEXT.P: The administration should squarely face the issue of whether village and borough chiefs should receive a salary, and not just leave the issue to lawmakers and consider it solved, an opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmaker said Tuesday.

Chou Hsi-wei, a PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, urged legislators from across the political spectrum to stop bickering among themselves on the salary issue and called for the Ministry of the Interior to face the problem and work out a solution.

The legislative Independents Alliance recently proposed an amendment to Article 61st of the Rural Administration Act, suggesting that the position of village or borough chief should be changed into a paid position since those holding such posts work as public functionaries.
The proposal, if enacted into law, would cost the government some NT$7 billion (US$205.88 million) a year.
The borough is the lowest government administrative level in Taiwan. Each borough has an office headed by a ward chief who is elected by popular vote for a four-year term.
Chou said the Ministry of the Interior, regardless of whether from the financial point of view or the point of view of the local chiefs' status, should make efforts to tackle the issue.

He said the Ministry of the Interior should first come up with a clear plan on the issue so that the Legislature can deliberate on it, adding that the longstanding issue can then be resolved once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TO BECOME DELICACY CAPITAL IN ASIA: MAYOR

TEXT.P: In addition to its artistic and cultural aura, Taichung also offers an array of local delicacies, and the city will actively promote them to make the city into the delicacy capital of Asia, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Tuesday.
Hu made the remarks while attending a food carnival in Taichung's central district aimed at boosting the area's development.

Hu said that Taichung has long been cited as a cultural city with various kinds of cultural activities happening throughout the year. In addition to the cultural aspect, he said, the city also boasts such delicacies as Taiyang (sun) cakes and pineapple cakes as well as many unique delicacies not found anywhere else.
The city government will work with local communities and local delicacy operators to try to attract tourists from around Taiwan to Taichung to taste its delicacies.
Hu said that he would work toward making Taichung into a delicacy capital in Asia on par with Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 9, or the 16th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: 6.6-MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKE JOLTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake, measuring 6.6 on the oepn-ended Richter scale, jolted the eastern Taiwan county of Taitung Wednesday, causing landslides and damage to some bridges. No casualties have so far been reported.
The quake took place at 12:38 p.m., with its epicenter located near the southeast coastal region of Taitung, said Kuo Kai-wen, a seismologist at the Central Weather Bureau.
Tremors frequent rattle the island but most cause little or no damage. But a massive earthquake in 1999 killed about 2,400 people.
Wednesday's quake was strong enough to sway buildings in Taipei, some 300 kilometers north of Taitung, for about a minute.
