DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON EDUCATION OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An international conference on education opened in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Wednesday with more than 300 educators from 24 countries participating.

The main topic of the Asia-Pacific Regional Conference of the Education International, organized by the National Teachers' Association of the Republic of China, is education under a globalized society and challenges faced by educators.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Minister of Education Huang Jong-tsun said that the topics of the meeting are in line with the trend of education development in the 21st century and praised the participants for their dedication to their careers.
Education reforms that the ROC government has been pushing ahead with will meet the needs of national development and those of the world as well, he said.
He wished the three-day meeting much success.

DOC.HEADLINE: THERE IS MUCH SPACE FOR TAIWAN FOR IT CONTRIBUTION: ICT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Jose Maria Figueres, chief of a United Nation's panel on Information and Communication Technology (ICT) , hailed Taiwan's achievement Wednesday in the information technology development, saying that there is much room for the island to contribute in this sphere.

Figueres, a former Costa Rican president, who is now U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan's special representative on ICT, noted that Taiwan is not a UN member, thus is limited in its participation in global high-tech cooperation programs.

"It's a pity for the island and for the U.N., " Figueres told a Taiwanese delegation who was to participate in the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) to be held at U.N. headquarters Dec. 10-12.

However, Figueres stressed that there is still much space for Taiwan to contribute to global ICT development, for example, in the sub-groups under the ICT panel of the U.N. which allows for the participation of private enterprises, non-governmental organizations and government officials.

Figueres said he knew the complex reasons for Taiwan not being a U.N. member. However, he stressed that the island's high-tech development is a world model, and urged the island to share with the world community its successful experiences, or even failed ones.
Noting that Taiwan's exclusion from the U.N. is a loss to the world organization, Figueres said he is willing to promote Taiwan's further participation in the sphere of high technology in the future.

Members of the Taiwan delegation include Minister Without Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming, Cabinet-level National Youth Commission Chairwoman Lin Fang-mei, Academia Sinica Vice President Tseng Chih-lang, Information Industry Institute Chairman Lin Feng-chin and representatives of the public, industrial and academic sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOPES FOR FTA WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he strongly hopes that a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and Japan can one day be forged for mutual benefits.
Chen made the call during a meeting with a delegation led by Japan Business Federation Vice President Akio Kosai at the Presidential Office.
Expressing his keen hope for such an accord between the two countries, Chen said he believes that setting up such a cooperative venture will help strengthen and enhance two-way economic exchanges.

According to the president, incumbent Japanese Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Shoichi Nakagawa and an ex-minister Takeo Hiranuma both are very supportive of such a pact between Taiwan and Japan.

For his part, Kosai said he was very impressed by Taiwan's remarkable economic development in recent years amid a global economic recession, pointing to the Taipei 101 as an example, which is the world's tallest building.
Kosai added that issues related to a Taiwan-Japan FTA will be topics for discussion at an East Asian Economic Conference slated to open Thursday in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM IS TO MAINTAIN PEACE IN TAIWAN STRAIT: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that his plan to call a "defensive referendum" on the day of the presidential election next March 20 is to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait area.
Chen made the remarks in his speech delivered after accepting the nomination by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as the party's candidate in the upcoming presidential race.
Holding the referendum has nothing to do with the independence-unification issue, but to practice democracy and to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait, Chen stressed.

"No one can force the people of Taiwan to see Beijing's deployment of missiles directed at the island as a normal development and no one could construe the 23 million people's intention to pursue democracy and to maintain peace as provocative," Chen emphasized.

Noting that holding a referendum is a normal practice in a democratic nation and a basic right of the people, Chen said that the people of Taiwan can loudly vow to the world that "They are opposed to missiles and want democracy; they are opposed to the war and want peace."
It is to show the international community, particularly Beijing, that the use of military force can never serve as a means or a option to solve the so-called Taiwan issue, Chen said.

The president announced earlier this month that the topics to be voted on in Taiwan were whether or not the people would wish to have mainland China withdraw the nearly 500 ballistic missiles currently targeting Taiwan soil and whether the mainland should renounce any use of force against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL TRUST KEY TO BETTERING CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: NOBEL LAUREATE
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Vernon Smith, winner of the Nobel Prize for economics in 2002, said Wednesday that mutual trust is the key to promote trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and he urged the people on both sides to work toward this direction.
Smith made the remarks in a speech on globalization and Taiwan's economic development after receiving an honorary doctoral degree from National Sun Yat-sen University.

Smith won the Nobel Prize for economics for his pioneering work in experimental economics, a discipline that maintains that informal rules and social norms can influence people's choices, and the testing for these effects is much more productive in a laboratory than in real time.

The Nobel laureate noted that experimental economics aims at observing and predicting economies, as well as simulating various kinds of economic behaviors to allow people to better understand economic structures. However, he added that all economic problems have the nature of unpredictability.

On how to elevate Taiwan's competitiveness and production, Smith said that only offering subsidies cannot resolve problems, and he suggested that the government offer more training in addition to protecting or increasing workers' minimum salaries.
Only through more training programs can people earn satisfactory income, thus elevating in the same time the corporate competitiveness, Smith went on.

The 76-year-old Smith, now a professor of economics and law at George Mason University, has authored or co-authored over 200 articles and books on capital theory, finance, natural resource economics and experimental economics.

DOC.HEADLINE: BASIC TONE OF U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED: MOFA

TEXT.P: The basic tone of the U.S. policy toward the Taiwan Strait issue has remained unchanged after a meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Wednesday.

Judging from Bush's reaffirmation at a news conference after his talks with Wen in Washington, D.C. Tuesday that the United States opposes any unilateral decision by either China or Taiwan to change the status quo, Chien said the basic tone of the U.S. policy toward the cross-strait issue has not changed.

Chien said Bush has reiterated Washington's one-China policy based on its three joint communiques with Beijing and its Taiwan Relations Act. The gist of the U.S. one-China policy requires a peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes, opposes China using force against Taiwan and offers no support for Taiwan independence.
"Bush's remarks after his meeting with Wen signal no fundamental changes to the basic U.S. policy toward the cross-strait issue," Chien noted.

As to Bush's statement that he opposes "comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan" that indicate that President Chen Shui-bian "may be willing to make decisions unilaterally, to change the status quo," Chien said Washington apparently still doesn't fully understand Taiwan's "defensive referendum" plan.
Chien said the planned referendum on missile threat from China is for strengthening Taiwan's young democracy, avoiding war, maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait and preserving the status quo.

"President Chen himself has on many occasions declared that the referendum plan has nothing to do with the subject of independence and will not breach his 'four noes plus one pledge,'" Chien said, adding that the plan doesn't violate the U.S. strategic goal of maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will strengthen communications with the United States and will continue to make the United States understand the basic spirit of Taiwan's defensive referendum plan and that mainland China's military build-up and missile deployment against Taiwan are the real source of cross-strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO-SMOKING CAMPAIGN PAYS OFF IN RESTAURANTS: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday its efforts to promote no-smoking restaurants have achieved encouraging results, with 770 establishments around the island being smoke free.

The DOH launched the no-smoking restaurants campaign a year ago. Thanks to support from restaurant operators and public health promotion groups, a DOH official said 770 restaurants around the island have joined the campaign by banning smoking on their premises.

Chao Kun-yu, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, said his bureau commissioned Taipei Medical University to conduct surveys in February and November to explore public opinions about the smoking-free restaurant campaign.

In the February survey, 70 percent of the respondents said they endured second-hand smoke in restaurants. But only 57 percent of those interviewed in the November survey said they had encountered second-hand smoke while eating out.

The latest survey found that 90 percent want the government to continue with the campaign. Moreover, 92 percent said they will continue supporting smoke-free restaurants by patronizing them and 88 percent of non-smoking respondents said they hope the government will encourage more restaurants to ban smoking on their premises.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SETS CONTINUED REFORMS AS PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION THEME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian described his campaign theme and major political and economic agendas Wednesday after he was formally nominated by the Democratic Progressive Party to represent the ruling party in the March 20, 2004 presidential election.
The president delivered an acceptance speech on the theme of "believing in Taiwan, insisting on reforms" at the Central Executive Committee of the DPP after his nomination.

For the DPP and he himself, Chen said, the significance of the presidential election is not about a ruling position nor is it about defeating other candidates or political parties, but about the need to solidify democracy and continue with reforms.

He noted that during the process of democratization in Taiwan, there has always been a tug-of-war between pro-reform and anti-reform forces and that although the party has to "reflect upon itself and accept them, " there should be no regression in democratic reforms.

In retrospect, the democratic development of Taiwan, from the lifting of martial law in 1987 to the popular election of the president, has been a "winding, bumpy road and every democratic reform has been resisted by the conservative regimes, even in the face of the verbal attacks and military intimidation from the other side of the Taiwan Strait," he said.
But he said the Taiwan people have strong convictions of the value of democracy and reforms and can move forward step by step and "make the land vibrant with democratic dynamism."

He noted Taiwan completed the first peaceful political transfer in the Chinese world in 2000 and that as it moves towards democracy and human rights, some opposition parties still dwell on the past authoritarian period.
He also said that the endless haggling between the ruling and rival parties must come to a stop and no matter what the difficulties, all chaos must end after the March 20 presidential election.
"With my strong conviction in democracy and Taiwan's future, " Chen said, the strength of the people must be pooled to complete the normalization of Taiwan's democracy in three stages.

First, he claimed, after March 20, 2004, the confrontation between the ruling and the rival parties and the stalled cross-Taiwan strait relations will be defrosted and will move toward the path of normalization.

Next, the DPP, riding on the coattails of his election victory, will gain a majority in the year-end legislative election in 2004, so that the checks-and-balances mechanism between the executive and legislative arms will be normalized.

In the third stage, a national referendum will be held in 2006 on a new Constitution, with the aim of ending the chaotic constitutional rule so that Taiwan can become a "normal, complete and great" democratic country.

He said that from the long-term view of democratic development, the start of the next presidential term in 2004 to the implementation of a new Constitution in 2008 will be a crucial period to solidify democracy and strengthen reforms.
"This is why the DPP has made believing in Taiwan and insisting on reforms its campaign theme," he added.

For this reason, the presidential election next year will be a "three-verse" competition, he said, meaning his advocacy of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" rather than "one China, " insistence on reforms rather than the restoration of the corrupt "black gold" of the previous administration and belief in Taiwan rather than pessimism.

He accused the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has always being on the side of anti-democracy and anti-reform, citing the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" partner the People First Party for ramming through a referendum bill Nov. 27 as an example of this. He said the ruling party will reconsider, ask for a constitutional interpretation and a revision in order to return a complete referendum bill to the people.

He reaffirmed that the Taiwan people have the right to speak out their opposition to the missile threat posed by the mainland and their desire for democracy, and to declare to the world that "military force is never a means or option for solving the cross-strait issue."
"The pursuit of democracy of the 23 million people of Taiwan and their efforts to maintain peace should not be considered `provocation'" of the mainland, he added.

The president also said that over the past three years, the government has continued to push for reforms and has displayed its power of implementation, which is reflected in recent favorable ratings by international assessment organizations.
If the Cabinet's "10 new major public construction projects" plan takes off next year, it is expected to create 64,000 jobs per year and to increase economic growth by 1.03 percent every year.

Chen stressed that if re-elected, he will say with confidence that he will achieve within three years the "3-4-5" goal -- meaning that the budget for research and development will reach over 3 percent of the gross domestic product, the jobless rate will drop to below 4 percent in two years, and the economic growth will increase to 5 percent in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA TO SET UP BUDGET CARRIER BY MIDDLE OF 2004

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced on Tuesday that it will set up an Asian budget airline called Tiger Airways in a four-party venture.

According to an SIA statement published on the Monetary Authority of Singapore's website, the budget airline's partners will be Ryanair founder Tony Ryan's Irelandia Investments, the Singapore government's investment arm, as well as Temasek Holdings, and U.S. private investors Indigo Partners.

"Singaporeans and travelers in the region will get to fly to destinations in Southeast Asia at really low fares with Tiger Airways when it begins operations from Changi Airport in the second half of 2004," the statement said.

The chief executive of SIA said after studying the successful growth of low fare no frills airlines in the United States and Europe that the airline feels budget carriers can do well in this region as well.
Tiger Airways is Singapore's second local budget airline to be announced after ValuAir, which is being set up by Singapore Press Holdings chairman Lim Chin Beng.
ValuAir earlier announced that it plans to take to the skies by the second quarter of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILL INTERVENE IN CASE OF MAINLAND CHINA ATTACK: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States will stick to its pledge to help Taiwan defend itself should Beijing use force against Taiwan, a senior U.S. official said Tuesday.
The official made the comment after U.S. President George W. Bush met visiting mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao for talks in Washington.

Claiming that the Bush's pledge made in April 2001 to help Taiwan remains valid and that the United States will stop playing ambiguous games on the issue, the official quoted Bush as telling Wen: " Look, you know, if you force us, if you try to use force or coercion against Taiwan, we are going to be there."

Asked whether the United States will also help Taiwan if it provokes mainland China, such as by holding a referendum on the independence-unification issue, the official made it clear that Washington will give clear messages to both sides that Beijing should not use military force against Taiwan, while Taiwan should not move toward independence.

It would be very dangerous for Taiwan to change the status quo unilaterally, the official noted, adding that Bush's concern over Taiwan's plan to hold a defensive referendum is aimed at ensuring that the people of Taiwan are aware that the United States will never agree on Taiwan's intention to unilaterally change its current status.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES U.S. TO RECOGNIZE MAINLAND CHINA AS SOURCE OF TENSION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the United States Wednesday to recognize that mainland China is the real source of the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
"Mainland China, rather than Taiwan, is the source of cross-strait tension," Yu said at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Yu made the appeal a day after U.S. President George W. Bush said during a meeting with mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at the White House: "We oppose any unilateral decision by either China or Taiwan to change the status quo, and the comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan indicate that he may be willing to make decisions unilaterally to change the status quo, which we oppose."

Commenting on Bush's statement, Yu said Taiwan's "defensive referendum" plan is primarily aimed at reminding the international community that the mainland's threat to use force against Taiwan and its missile deployment against Taiwan are abnormal and irresponsible.

"The referendum plan is designed to stave off the possibility of mainland China using force to change the Taiwan Strait status quo, " Yu said, adding that the move should not be regarded as an act designed to provoke Beijing.
Stressing that the referendum plan is part of Taiwan's democratic reform efforts, Yu said that Beijing's deliberate distortion of the plan as a move toward independence is "anti-democratic."

Yu said that although the mainland has repeatedly claimed that it will not forsake its hope of resolving cross-strait issues through peaceful means, it has actually stepped up military deployment along its southeastern coast to intimidate Taiwan's government and people.
"Beijing's military build-up vis-a-vis Taiwan has threatened the stability in the Taiwan Strait," he noted.
The premier further said that Taiwan's government and people are concerned and dissatisfied with the mainland's intensified military deployment against Taiwan.

"Moreover, we believe that a continued laissez-faire attitude toward mainland China's missile deployment against Taiwan could mislead Beijing's leaders into making a grave misjudgment that will eventually jeopardize peace in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region," Yu said, adding that he hopes the United States can understand that it is the mainland rather than Taiwan that is the chief cause of tension across the Taiwan Strait.

Yu further said the main cause of the cross-strait disputes lies in mainland China's reluctance to squarely face up to the reality of Taiwan's existence as an independent sovereign state and its refusal to resume bilateral dialogue and consultation on an equal footing.
Noting that Taiwan's policy toward the mainland has remained unchanged, Yu said Taiwan will continue to pursue a peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes.

He also urged the mainland to drop all political premises and resume dialogue with Taiwan as soon as possible. "Only dialogue and consultation can clear up misunderstandings and forge rapprochement and consensus," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE TO COMMUNICATE WITH U.S. OVER REFERENDUM ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States said Tuesday that Taiwan will continue to communicate with the United States on the referendum issue.

Chen Chien-jen made the remarks in the wake of remarks by U.S. President George W. Bush on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation after his meeting with mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at the White House.

Asked to comment on ROC President Chen Shui-bian's proposed plan to hold a referendum on March 20, 2004, Bush said that "we oppose any unilateral decision by either China or Taiwan to change the status quo" and "the comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan indicate that he may be willing to make decisions unilaterally to change the status quo, which we oppose," he added.

In a telephone interview with CNA, Chen would not speculate on Bush's words or their possible effect on Taiwan's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" to demand that Beijing dismantle its missiles aimed at Taiwan and to renounce the use of military force, but he expressed the hope that the government's push for referendum in three aspects be understood.
First, Chen said, Taiwan "cannot accept" mainland China seeing the referendum, which is an exercise in democracy, to be a referendum on independence.

Chen continued that the proposed referendum does not involve issues on either unification or independence and that it will not go beyond the pledges that the president made in his inaugural speech of 2000 in which he promised not to hold a referendum on the status of the nation and not to change the status quo.
Chen said that it is unfair to see Beijing's missile threat against Taiwan as "normal" on the one hand, and Taiwan's worry over this threat as "provocation" on the other.

Chen said that he has yet to explain this to the United States, but he pointed out that this is the attitude of Taipei on the issue, and he added that the government will continue to communicate with Washington.
Chen refused to comment on whether he felt Bush's words were beneficial or detrimental to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT FORMALLY NOMINATED AS DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was formally nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Wednesday as the party's presidential candidate for the March 20, 2004 presidential election.
Following the announcement of his candidacy, Chen then delivered a speech on the theme of "believe in Taiwan and insist on reforms" to DPP Central Executive Committee.

After the nomination, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who has been nominated to represent the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, said that the presidential election is not a battle but a competition.
He expressed the hope that both candidates can compete on a "fair, law-biding and open" basis and added that Chen should not enjoy any advantages as a result of his being the incumbent president.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEISMOLOGISTS WARN OF MAJOR AFTERSHOCKS

TEXT.P: Seismologists warned Wednesday that major aftershocks of an intensity greater than 5 on the open-ended Richter scale could occur at any time in the next month in the wake of the 6.6-magnitude quake that jolted eastern Taiwan earlier in the day.

The 6.6-magnitude jolt, which began at 12:38 p.m., had a violent effect on the eastern county of Taitung, causing landslides and damage to some roads and bridges, with varying levels of intensity felt all over the country.

No casualties had been reported as of press time except for one man reported to have been trapped in an elevator in Fengshan City, southern Taiwan, seismologists from the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
Four major aftershocks with magnitudes between 4 and 5 were detected in the Taitung area within one hour of the quake.

Describing the quake as the result of pressure released from the squeezing action between the Philippine Sea Plate and the Euroasia Plate, Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB Seismology Center, said major quakes of a magnitude larger than 5 can be expected to occur in areas near Taitung at any time within the next month.

Taiwan sits on the Circum-Pacific Belt, which encompasses fault lines stretching from the coast of Chile to California and around through Japan and Taiwan. The belt is, along with the large European Alpida Belt, responsible for 95 out of every 100 earthquakes that occur around the world, Kuo said.

The island experienced its deadliest earthquake in five decades on Sept. 21, 1999, when a 7.6 magnitude temblor struck central Taiwan, killing 2,415 people and injuring more than 10,000. It also caused tremendous damage to property and infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OPTS FOR TALKS AMONG CARRIERS ON CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Beijing has opted to allow private air carriers to negotiate over the operation of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, sources from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) said Wednesday.

ARATS officials said that they had informed their Taipei counterparts -- officials from the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- by telephone that Beijing decided to let the private air carriers from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait discuss the New Year charter flights.
The ARATS officials said that Beijing insists that any such charter flights must be bilateral and that it will allow the carriers themselves to engage in talks over the technical issues.
The officials also said that ARATS has not replied to a message sent by the SEF Nov. 27 calling for consultations on the charter flight plan.

The SEF letter, mailed at the request of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that Taiwan is willing to allow mainland carriers to offer the charter flight services, but as two-way services involve the exercise of public authority, including security checks, the SEF said the two sides must meet to hammer out mutually acceptable operational terms.
As of Wednesday, ARATS had not responded to the SEF appeal.

According to ARATS officials, Pu Zhaozhou, a Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) official in charge of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau affairs, was to meet later that day with representatives from four Taiwan carriers for talks on affairs surrounding the the charter flights. The four carriers are EVA Airways, China Airlines, Far East Air and Trans Asia Airways.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said last week that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has completed all necessary preparations that Taiwan can do unilaterally for the special holiday cross-strait charter flight plan.

"We are now waiting for mainland China to take coordinated action regarding its part of the plan, " Chen said, adding that he believes the mainland will act in time to facilitate the return of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China and their dependents for Chinese New Year.

In an unprecedented move, six Taiwan carriers were allowed to operate charter flights between Shanghai and Taiwan via either Hong Kong or Macau during the last Chinese New Year holiday early this year.
According to the MAC's blueprint, the flights can be operated from Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, 2004. Chinese New Year's Day falls on Jan. 22.

The stopover points will include other designated third locations in addition to Hong Kong and Macau. The departure and arrival points on the Taiwan side will remain unchanged at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport, while Beijing's Capital Airport will be added to the mainland's departure and arrival points list. Previously, only Shanghai's Pudong Airport was on the mainland list.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 10, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng-hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 80 PERCENT OF SINGAPOREANS RECEIVE SPAM: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of Singaporeans have been spammed, according to the results of a survey commissioned by the Internet software developer Symantec.

Spam, or unsolicited email, is the junk mail of the information age. In the survey, 55 percent of the respondents said they receive spam on their home accounts, while nearly 20 percent said they get spam at their work email address. A total of 77 percent of the polled said they spend up to 10 minutes a day getting rid of it.
The Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation has estimated that this translates into some US$28 million in lost productivity.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH RAPPED FOR COMMENT ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. President George Bush was rapped Thursday by an international human rights activist for comments he made about President Chen Shui-bian's intention to hold a referendum.

Scott Horton, president of the International League for Human Rights (ILHR) , said Bush is wrong to express disapproval for Chen's plan to organize a referendum and has contradicted a statement he made several years ago when he said that democracy, human rights and people's right to self-determination are the three pillars of peace.

Bush told a press conference in Washington the previous day that the comments and actions made by Chen indicate that he may be willing to make decisions unilaterally to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
Horton said he admired Chen's decision to press for the right to referendum in Taiwan, describing it as a powerful means of protecting human rights.
Horton, whose ILHR awarded Chen its 2003 Human Rights Award in New York Oct. 31, made the comment while paying Chen a courtesy visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIMED IRAQI BOY LEAVES TAIPEI FOR HOME FOLLOWING SURGERY

TEXT.P: An Iraqi boy maimed in the U.S.-led war in Iraq left Taipei for home Thursday after being successfully fitted with a prosthetic foot and hand at a local hospital.
Hhaldon kh-Thiab said prior to his departure along with his father that he was deeply grateful for the medical treatment and care he received in Taiwan.
"I'll never forget the generous aid and hospitality given to me by the Taiwan people," said the emotional 12-year-old.
The boy, better known in his local community as Aldon, lost his right hand and left foot as a result of a cluster bomb explosion in the front courtyard of his family's home in April this year.

Under the arrangement of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, a Taiwan charity group dedicated to the care of the handicapped, Aldon arrived in Taipei Oct. 27 in the company of his father and was admitted to the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital to receive treatment.

Aldon said he has too many people to thank for his medical treatment. "Many kind-hearted people have taken care of me," he said, adding that after seeing Taiwan children playing in a carefree manner, he would like to live like that.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG PORT MONTHLY CARGO HANDLING DOWN IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Northern Taiwan's port of Keelung handled less cargo and fewer containers in November than it did October, but it performed better than the same month of a year ago, according to the latest statistics released Thursday by the Keelung Harbor Bureau.

The harbor handled 7.95 million tons of cargo in November, down by 6.78 percent from the October level but up by 7.15 percent year-on-year. It loaded and unloaded a total of 174,205 TEUs (twenty-foot-equivalent units) last month, a fall of 2.78 percent from the month-earlier level, but up by 7.99 percent as compared to the figure posted in the same month of last year.

During that period, 746 ships called at the post -- the largest in northern Taiwan -- down by 11.4 percent from the October level, but an increase of 3.04 percent over the previous-year level, the bureau statistics show.

During the first 11 months of this year, the port dealt with 84.57 million tons of products, up by 4.36 percent compared to the volume registered in the same 11-month period of 2002. It handled 18.18 million TEUs from January to November, a rise of 4.11 percent over the year-earlier level. However, ship visits totaled 8,325, down by 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POISED TO BECOME A GLOBAL SOC HUB

TEXT.P: Taiwan is poised to become a global system-on-a-chip (SoC) design and service hub in three to five years, as the government has begun allocating budgets and pooling its efforts and wisdom to promote a national SoC project, an official said Thursday.

Yu Kuei-shin, an advisor at the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , made the remarks at a high-tech symposium on SoC -- the 2003 SoCTEC1st -- which opened that day in Taipei under the joint sponsorship of the department and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).

According to Yu, the MOEA has earmarked more than NT$900 million (US$26.47 million) this year to advocate the national SoC project with the aim of developing Taiwan into an international SoC center in cooperation with the academic and industrial sectors to provide a sound IC design platform that will serve corporate clients around the world.

In addition to SoC technology, Yu said, the government also hopes to promote nanotechnology, optical telecommunications and biotechnology as part of its efforts to make Taiwan an advanced research and development and innovation center in the Asia-Pacific region.

Taiwan must seize this opportunity to edge out mainland China, Singapore, South Korea and India, as the IC design industries in the United States and Europe have been increasingly shifting their attention to Asia since 2000, he said, noting that Taiwan's IC design industry enjoys the second-highest market share internationally.

ITRI President Lee Chung-hsi said Taiwan must consolidate its talent and resources from relevant fields -- such as Internet telecommunications, SRAM and Flash -- to forge new thinking and create innovative products to compete in the SoC arena. The main issue is about how to put all the core technologies and functions into a single chip, he explained.
Scores of Chinese experts from home and abroad will discuss market deployment, industrial trends and technology exchanges in the SoC industry at the two-day gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC INSISTS ON GOVERNMENT ROLE IN CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: Negotiations for mainland Chinese air carriers' participation in cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday should be led by either the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) or the government, a senior official said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks a day after mainland authorities said they would allow mainland carriers to discuss the holiday charter flight issues with Taiwan carriers.

Tsai said Taiwan is willing to allow mainland carriers to offer the holiday charter flight services on a reciprocal basis, but she added that as such two-way services involve the exercise of public authority, the two sides must meet to hammer out mutually acceptable operational terms.
"Such talks must be carried out by the SEF or under the government's oversight," Tsai added.

Acting on the MAC's request, the SEF sent a message to its mainland Chinese counterpart Nov. 27 calling for consultations on the charter flight plan. The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) has so far not made a formal response to the SEF's appeal.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official bodies set up by Taiwan and the mainland, respectively, to handle cross-strait contacts in the absence of official ties between the two sides.
Tsai said she hopes the mainland authorities will respond to the SEF's call as soon as possible to allow the charter flight plan to be fleshed out.

"The exercise of public authority, including security checks, forms the cornerstone of government operations. We cannot compromise on this issue, " Tsai stressed. "We hope the mainland authorities can understand this point."

In an unprecedented move, six Taiwan carriers were allowed to operate charter flights between Shanghai and Taiwan via either Hong Kong or Macau during the last Chinese New Year holiday early this year.

Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said in Beijing Nov. 26 that the mainland is not opposed to allowing a repeat of the charter flights, so long as the services are offered on a reciprocal basis. Zhang further said that any negotiations on technical details of the services must be carried out by the air carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Tsai said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, has decided to exercise more flexibility and further expand the charter flight plan for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.
According to the MAC's blueprint, the flights can be operated from Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, 2004. Chinese New Year's Day falls on Jan. 22.

The midpoints where the flights have to make a stopover will include other designated third locations in addition to Hong Kong and Macau. The departure and arrival points on the Taiwan side will remain unchanged at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport, while Beijing's Capital Airport will be added to the mainland's departure and arrival points list. Previously, only Shanghai's Pudong Airport was on the mainland list.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASKS LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO RECONSIDER REFERENDUM BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan formally asked the Legislative Yuan Thursday to reconsider part of the referendum bill railroaded through the Legislative Yuan by the opposition parties Nov. 27.
Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said that 12 of the 64 articles in the bill were considered unacceptable by the Cabinet and needed to be returned to the Legislative Yuan for reconsideration.

Although the bill is a step forward in terms of the development of democracy, Lin said, part of it is "unconstitutional" because it gives the Legislative Yuan the power to initiate referenda on major policy formulated by the Executive Yuan while denying the Executive Yuan a similar right.

Furthermore, the spokesman said, the setting up of a referendum review committee called for in the bill is unnecessary, as its function would be the same as that of the existing Central Election Commission.

Under the Constitution, the returned bill will be automatically annulled unless the Legislative Yuan rejects the request within 15 days with a majority vote of at least 113 in the 225-seat legislature.
If that scenario takes place, the premier will have to either accept the Legislative Yuan's decision or step down.
Since the two main opposition parties control a narrow legislative majority of 113 seats between them, every vote will count in case of a showdown.
Meanwhile, the opposition parties claimed that the Executive Yuan's move gives the lie to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's claim that it is the driving force for the right to referendum.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said the Executive Yuan's request is unprecedented in that it challenges only part of the bill and in some cases, even only a section of an article.
"Usually, we are called upon to deal with a whole article rather than a section of it, " Wang said, adding that it is up to the lawmakers to determine how to respond to the request.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS SPECIAL LEADERS IN THIS VERY AGE: VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Thursday that in this very special age, Taiwan needs extraordinarily brilliant leaders to assure sustainable development for the island.

Lu made the remarks in a speech after being nominated formally by President Chen Shui-bian as his running mate for the March 20, 2004 presidential election. Chen was officially designated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party the previous day as the party's presidential candidate in the election.

In the press conference, Chen also presented personally five key figures who will be responsible for Chen's campaign activities, ushering in a fierce competition with the "pan-blue" camp composed of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party.

Lu said in her speech that Taiwan is facing many problems in this rapidly changing world, including complicated cross-Taiwan Strait ties, its diplomatic relations with foreign countries, the problem of an aging society, and the ethnic problems resulting from foreign brides.

Although Taiwan is bothered by many problems, it still has created economic and democratic miracles, Lu noted, adding that the peaceful power transition in 2000 has terminated the former authoritarian rule of more than five decades and strengthened human rights on the island.
Because of the existence of Taiwan, there is a force to fight against communism, Lu went on.
The leaders Taiwan needs should have a wide global vision and profound humane interests in order to offer its people a happy and safe life with national dignity, Lu stressed.
Lu said she was honored to have the chance to be Chen's running mate again, and she will do her upmost to better the future of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM PLAN TALLIES WITH U.S. VALUES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the United States should support Taiwan's drive to consolidate its young democracy and should push Beijing to publicly renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

"In line with its founding spirit, the United States should support our pursuit of full democracy and demand that mainland China remove the missiles it has deployed against Taiwan and renounce the use of force against Taiwan, " Chen said during a meeting with Scott Horton, president of the New York-based International League for Human Rights.

Chen has faced intense pressure from Taiwan's most important friend -- the United States -- since he announced late last month that he wants to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004 to demand that Beijing stop pointing hundreds of missiles at Taiwan.

American officials have said the referendum could raise the risk of conflict with the mainland, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan. U.S. President George W. Bush said Tuesday that he opposes any moves that might disrupt the delicate status quo in Taiwan-China relations.

Chen took advantage of his meeting with Horton to defend the referendum plan, stressing that it is in line with America's democratic values, which should allow voters to express opinions about threats.

Since referendum is a universal value and a basic human right, Chen asked why the Taiwan people should be singled out to be denied the right to hold such a vote as part of its drive to be free from a missile threat.

He stressed that the planned referendum on demanding Beijing remove missiles aimed at Taiwan and renounce the use of force against Taiwan is designed to preserve Taiwan's present status as an independent sovereign state.

"We have no intention of changing our status quo. We instead want to maintain the status quo characterized by peace, democracy, freedom and human rights. We'll do whatever we can to prevent it from being changed," Chen said.

In terms of America's founding spirit, Chen said he is convinced that the United States will not accept Beijing's missile deployment against Taiwan as a matter of course, nor will it regard Taiwan's pursuit of full democracy and efforts to maintain peace as "provocative" actions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INTRODUCES KEY MEMBERS OF HIS REELECTION CAMPAIGN TEAM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian introduced five key members of his campaign team Thursday, saying that together they will fight a "fair, clean, and victorious" battle to win the March 20, 2004 presidential election.

The president, one day after he was formally nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to be the standard bearer of the party, nominated Annette Lu, current vice president, to be his running mate again, and also introduced his campaign team members.

Chang Chun-hsiung, DPP secretary-general, will head the team. The other four members are Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang, and Presidential Office Secretary General Chiou I-jen.

The president also elaborated on the "significance of naming Lu and his campaign team" which encompasses four areas -- insistence on democracy, the shouldering of responsibility, the nurturing of talented people, and all-around teamwork.

The president said that looking back over the past quarter century, whether it is the vice president or the campaign team, each one of them has contributed a great deal to this land of Taiwan for a large part of their lives.
"They share the identical beliefs in democracy and they have left their footprints on the path of democracy, and they will now join hands to make history again in 2004," the president said.

The president also said that the DPP is just like a democratic family, and has the tradition of a pluralistic democracy, saying that becoming a ruling party is a shouldering of responsibility, and not the sharing of interests.

He also said that the team is significant in terms of nurturing talented individuals. He said that since the inception of the party in 1986, the DPP has accumulated rich experiences in democracy, and has also nurtured a pool of talented people along the way and the tradition will continue for future generations.

Finally, he said that this is an "all-around" team, encompassing heavyweights from every part of Taiwan who have rich experience in both local and central governments, in the legislative and executive branches, as well as the party and government posts.

Including himself, the president said that the team has one president, one vice president, two party chairmen, two premiers, two vice premiers, and two city majors, magistrates who have served more than one term, and countless legislators and city and government councilmen. He said that this must be the "strongest ever" team.
He stressed that for the sake of the nation's future, the team will work toward fighting a "fair, clean, high-quality and victorious" battle in the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAINLAND FISHERMEN REPATRIATED AFTER FINISHING JAIL TIME IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese fishermen who completed their four-month jail terms for violations of national security law on the frontline island of Kinmen were repatriated Thursday.
Two other men, who attacked coast guard officials with broken glass bottles, are still serving time. The four men came from Xiaodeng via a fishing boat in July 10.
The two convicts returned to Xiaodeng, Fujian province.
Kinmen Red Cross Society Acting President Hsu Chin-lung gave the two returning convicts food and jackets as a humanitarian gesture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Maintains No Political Motivation for Participating in WSIS

TEXT.P: Minister-without-Portfolio Tsay Ching-yen on Wednesday denied a news report that said his participation in aforum on global e-business at the U.N. headquarters in Geneva was aimed at turning the technical forum into a political forum.

According to a Washington Times report, Tsay "slipped into" the U.N.-sponsored conference earlier this week, where he publicly challenged the policy of excluding Taiwan from the United Nations for more than 30 years.

Tsay, commenting on the report, said he attended the forum in his capacity as an advisor to the secretariat of AFACT, an international non-governmental organization, adding that he obtained an entry badge to the U.N. compound through proper procedures.
The Washington Times report also indicated that Tsay "publicly chastised" mainland China for its policy of blocking Taiwanese participation in numerous international organizations.

Tsay strongly refuted the report, emphasizing that in his public speech, he never touched upon political issues. Actually, in his opening remarks to the forum, Tsay focused on Taiwan's information and communication technology achievements and its intentions to further contribute to the global campaign to narrow the digital divide.
He said he regretted the fact that some news reports misinterpreted his speech.

"We want to make it clear that Taiwan wants to be an active player to promote information and communications technology for humanitarian and development purposes and that it has no intention of mixing this up with politics," Tsay said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER AND INTERNET BECOME MORE POPULAR IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The use of computers and the Internet in Hong Kong has become more popular, according to a survey released Thursday.

The survey carried out by the Census and Statistics Department from May to August showed that around 1,479,100 households, or 67.5 percent of all households in Hong Kong, had personal computers at home. Among those households with PCs at home, around 1,312,800 (88.8 percent) had their PC connected to the Internet, representing 60.0 percent of all households in Hong Kong.

This represents a significant increase compared to the situation in 2002 when 62.1 percent of all households in Hong Kong had PCs at home and 52.5 percent of all households had their PCs at home connected to the Internet.
With the increased penetration of PCs and the Internet in households, more persons aged 10 and over have used PCs and Internet services.

Utilization of electronic business services was also high in Hong Kong. A total of 93.6 percent of all persons aged 15 and over had used electronic business services of one form or another for personal matters in the 12 months before the survey, as against 92.6 percent recorded in 2002.

Regarding the usage of online purchasing services, the survey estimated that around 401,600 persons aged 15 and over, or 7.0 percent of all persons in that age group, had used one or more types of online purchasing services for personal matters in the 12 months before the survey. The corresponding figures in 2002 were 274,500 persons and 4.9 percent.

Usage of online government services was also getting more and more common. The survey estimate that around 1,388,700 persons aged 15 and over, or 24.3 percent of all persons in that age group, had used online government services for personal matters in the 12 months before the survey. The corresponding figures in 2002 were 1,015,100 persons and 18.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN THANKS BUSH FOR SECURITY COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thanked U.S. President George W. Bush in an interview with Cable News Network (CNN) Thursday for his support for Taiwan's security.
Bush told mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in their meeting at the White House Tuesday that if China uses force or coercion against Taiwan, then the United States would have to get involved.
Chen said in his interview with CNN Asia correspondent Mike Chinoy that he appreciates Bush's concern and support for Taiwan's security.

Chen also reiterated that his "defensive referendum" plan is by no means aimed at changing Taiwan's status quo. Chen was responding to Bush's remarks made at a news conference following his talks with Wen that he opposes "comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan" that indicate that Chen "may be willing to make decisions unilaterally, to change the status quo."

Chen stressed that the referendum to be held on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004 is to preserve Taiwan's status quo, rather than change it. This stance basically squares with Washington's, he added.

Noting that the planned referendum will ask Beijing to remove its hundreds of missiles pointed at Taiwan and to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, Chen said he will be willing to shelve the plan so long as mainland China makes a goodwill response.

Chen said he has on many occasions explained that the referendum plan is a necessary step to strengthen and consolidate Taiwan's young democracy. "The plan has nothing to do with the subject of independence and will not breach my 'four noes plus one' pledge, " Chen said, adding that the scenario of holding the referendum to change Taiwan's status quo would not happen at all.
In the face of mainland China's missile threat, Chen said, the 23 million Taiwan people should have the right to express their view and feelings.

The referendum aims to express Taiwan people's feelings, Chen said, adding that it's unfair and illogical to regard the move as an act of provocation to Beijing. Chen said the world should not accept Beijing's missile deployment against Taiwan as a matter of course.

Chen denied that the referendum plan is a campaign ploy for his re-election bid. Chen said he feels a strong sense of responsibility to have referendums -- a form of democracy and a universal value -- take root in Taiwan. It would help save social costs to time the referendum with the next presidential election, he added.

Asked whether Beijing regards Taiwan's referendum plan as a step toward independence, Chen said the Republic of China on Taiwan has long been an independent sovereign country and has never been subjugated to the People's Republic of China -- mainland China's official title.

"This is the status quo and a historical fact. As the ROC's top leader, I'm obligated to defend national sovereignty and to prevent it from becoming a local government or administrative region of any other country," he stressed.

In its pursuit of freedom and democracy, Chen said, Taiwan has never intended to provoke a war. If Beijing makes a goodwill response to Taiwan's call for rapprochement and stops pointing missiles at the island, Chen said, it will win Taiwan people's friendship.
If Beijing insists on twisting Taiwan's referendum plan to mean a provocative act, Chen said, it would only further alienate the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU SHYI-KUN PLEDGES TO HELP PRESIDENT CHEN WIN REELECTION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that he will do his best to help President Chen Shui-bian win reelection next year.
Yu made the pledge after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) appointed Chen its candidate for the 2004 Presidential election and Chen named Annette Lu as his running mate on Thursday.

Yu said he is confident that the Chen-Lu ticket will win the election, if the DPP is able to let a great majority of citizens know what it had done for the nation under the able leadership of President Chen in the past three years.
The premier said Chen has always been in touch with the tide of public opinion and able to lead the nation wisely in democratic and other reforms.
Yu also said that, in its presidential election campaign, the DPP shall do its best to let the people know what the ruling party has done and will do for the nation and the people.
He said it would be wise to reelect President Chen because, "You cannot change the chief builder when the house is half-built."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 60 points to close at 5,890, with 19,524 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 55 points to finish at 5,885, with 1,592 contract transactions, while March futures rose 58 points to close at 5,894, with six contracts traded.
September futures moved up 41 points to finish at 5,860, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,830 for December, 5,830 for January, 5,836 for March, 5,812 for June and 5,819 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL SEES NO CHANGE IN U.S. POSITION ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said Wednesday that from the remarks U.S. government leaders made during Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's recent visit to Washington, he sees no change in the basic position of the United States on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Speaking in a TV interview, Chen said the United States has in fact reiterated the position during Wen's visit to Washington that it does not want either side of the Taiwan Strait to change the status quo. It is the "basic policy" of the United States to keep the situation in the Taiwan Strait area peaceful, Chen added.

Chen also said it is clear to see from the recent remarks of State Department officials that U.S. President George W. Bush is strongly opposed to any coercive means that Beijing may use to force Taiwan change the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL TO UNDERGO ASIA DEPT. SHAKE-UP: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Asia team of the U.S. National Security Council (NSC) will undergo a major personnel shake-up, with Michael Green, who reportedly recently orchestrated strong warnings to Taiwan, becoming the new chief.
The news was reported in the latest issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review.

U.S. officials were quoted as saying that Asia chief James Moriarty, a career foreign-service officer and China expert, will step down in January, when he will be nominated to be U.S. ambassador to Nepal.
Moriarty will reportedly be replaced by Michael Green, a Japan specialist who has headed Japan and Korea policy in the NSC.
Green worked in the Department of Defense during the Clinton administration. His slot will be filled by Chuck Jones, a civilian expert on Korea in the Pentagon.

According to the report, Moriarty's confirmation could be challenged by neo-conservatives in Congress who charge that he orchestrated strong warnings to Taiwan, ahead of mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's visit to Washington, not to hold a referendum calling on China to withdraw its ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan.
Neo-conservatives view the warnings to Taipei as an attempt to stifle democracy in Taiwan while currying favor with China, the report noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUAO-HUALIEN FREEWAY CONSTRUCTION PROJECT TO BE POSTPONED: YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that Hualien County Government will be given a three-month grace period to decide whether to construct an expressway linking the eastern county to Suao in the neighboring northeastern county of Ilan.

Yu made the remarks after County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan told him that Hualien County residents have not yet reached a consensus on the Suao-Hualien Freeway construction project. Yu was briefed on Hualien residents' opinions during an inspection tour of the ongoing Hualien Airport expansion project.

Construction on the 86-km freeway was originally scheduled to get underway late this month. As some Hualien residents have publicly opposed the project over environmental concerns, Hsieh asked Yu to give the county government more time to forge a consensus among local residents.
Yu said the central government is sincere about carrying out the project to help boost eastern Taiwan's economic and tourist development.

"All preparatory work has been completed. So long as the county government and residents reach a positive decision, construction can kick off immediately, " Yu said, adding that the central government will respect the county government's decision.

Yu further said that it's up to the county government and the county council whether to hold a county-wide referendum to decide whether to build the new expressway. "A final decision must be made within three months," he added.

The Suao-Hualien Freeway project has been included into the government's "five year, five hundred billion NT dollar" infrastructure construction plan. The planned freeway calls for an outlay of NT$92.6 billion and was originally scheduled for completion in 2011. (B Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 11, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan-chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC OPINION IMPORTANT CONSIDERATION IN FREEWAY DECISION: YU

TEXT.P: Respecting the opinion of Hualien residents is the most important consideration in deciding whether or not to build the Suao-Hualien Freeway, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

Yu confirmed Friday at the Legislative Yuan that development of the Suao-Hualien Freeway -- which would be eastern Taiwan's first -- will be postponed for three months to provide time to gauge public opinion in the region on the issue.

The Suao-Hualien Freeway, which would link Suao in Ilan County with Chian in Hualien County, is one of the "10 New Construction Projects" that the Executive Yuan has set forth for implementation in the following five years.

Yu said that since the freeway system will mainly affect Hualien County, the decision on whether to build it needs to take into account Hualien public opinion, adding that it is up to the county government and county council whether to conduct an opinion poll or hold a county-wide referendum on the issue.

Yu denied that the Executive Yuan decision to postpone the Su Hua Freeway Project is the result of political considerations as claimed by the opposition parties. He called for the opposition camp to refrain from politicizing the issue.

He also said that the decision to postpone the freeway project for three months has nothing to do with a recent meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Hualien-based Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation, during which the latter reportedly asked Chen to call a halt to the project out of environmental considerations.
The opposition camp lambasted the administration Thursday for what it claimed was the administration's manipulation of public construction projects for political gains.

Noting that the administration actively pushed for the Su Hua Freeway Project last year during the run-up to the Hualien county chief by-election which the opposition KMT subsequently won, the opposition camp questioned the motives behind the administration's decision to call a halt to the project in the run-up to the presidential election.
Meanwhile, those in the academic circle as well as environmental protection activists in eastern Taiwan have lauded the administration for what they call a wise decision.

However, members of the business community in Ilan and Hualien have expressed disappointment with the decision, pointing out that transportation is the key to development and that the freeway will generate rural development, improve the local economies and reduce unemployment.

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's request for the Legislative Yuan to reconsider part of the recently passed referendum bill was delivered to the legislature Friday, but talks among political parties at the Legislative Yuan over when to gather to respond went nowhere.
The negotiations will continue Monday before the Rules Committee under the legislature meets Tuesday to decide whether to put the request on the agenda of a plenary session of the legislature Dec 19.
The legislature has to rally a majority vote to reject the Executive Yuan's request for reconsideration with 15 days or the parts requested to be reconsidered will automatically be annulled.
The Executive Yuan has asked the Legislative Yuan to reconsider 12 out of 64 articles in the referendum bill passed on Nov. 27, calling them unacceptable.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMTEC TO HOLD FIRST ASIAN SPA MEETING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The World Federation of Hydrotherapy and Climatotherapy (FEMTEC) -- an organization under the World Health Organization (WHO) affiliated to the United Nations -- will hold its first international meeting of Asian spa organizations and Executive Committee meetings in Taiwan, organizers said Friday.

Despite opposition from mainland China, the FEMTEC -- the most representative association of spa and health organizations in the world -- still decided to hold the string of meetings and celebration activities in Taiwan, in which more than 100 scientists and experts from home and abroad will take part from Dec. 13 to Dec. 19, a spokesman for the Taiwan Hot Spring Association said.

While in Taiwan, the specialists will unveil more than 20 scientific research reports in planned meetings and participate in related activities, including the launch of a series of stamps featuring Taiwan's spa resorts, the spokesman elaborated.
Foreign experts will come from Australia, Hungary, India, Japan, Mongolia, Russia, South Korea, the United States and the Ukraine, he noted.

The recently established Taiwan Spa Association is formed by top experts from the domestic medical, scientific and academic spectrums. It is the only spa "academic" organization based in Taiwan ever accredited by the international community. The FEMTEC recognizes the Taiwan Hot Spring Association as its headquarters in Taiwan, which works in rapport with the WHO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO BE PATIENT IN DEALING WITH BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Turkey, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Time is clearly on Taiwan's side in its tug-of-war with China, the country should be patient in dealing with Beijing by keeping the across-Taiwan Strait status quo, said a well-knowned international columnist Jonathan Power.

In a letter to the editor carried on Friday's Jordan Times which was seen here, the columnist said China is changing so fact that the chances of there being a Chinese Gorbachev is not just wild dreaming- increasingly it looks as if President Hu Jingtao could be preparing to play that role.

A more democratic China will not be the end of all points of controversy between it and Taiwan, but it will surely make Taiwan's life much easier in all sorts of important ways. Taiwan has to give China time. Time is Taiwan's friend, said Power.

The long-lasting U.S. policy of double-deterrence- deterring China from an invasion, on the one hand, and deterring the Taiwanese from moving to declare their country independent suffers from a fundamental flaw; it ignores what may be the democratic wish of a majority inside Taiwan, Power said.

However, it came as no surprise that the Bush administration, which has its hands full with Irag and Afghanistan and needs Beijing to support its efforts to persuade North Korea to nuclear disarm would sent an envoy to Taipei to encourage Chen to stop any attempt to alter unilaterally its ties with the mainland.

He dismissed Taiwan leaders' attempts to draw a parallel between Beijing's missile threat against Taiwan and the Cuba's missile threat against the United States in 1960s, saying that Beijing's 496 missiles which are not tipped with nuclear warheads will do no more harms than what NATO did with 500 missiles on Belgrade four years ago.
Power is a syndicated columnist whose weekly column appears in 41 papers around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE SURPLUS IN NOVEMBER REGISTERS HIGH SINCE LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$2.19 billion in November, the highest since August of last year, according to statistics released Friday by Taiwan's Central Bank of China.

The income Taiwan received from its exports reached US$14.05 billion in November, while it spent US$11.86 billion for imports in the same month, an increase of 16.7 percent and 12.2 percent respectively on a year-to-year basis, which was due largely to the global economy recovering, CBC officials said.

During the January-November period, Taiwan's exports and imports amounted to US$145.49 billion and US$129.78 billion, up 13.3 percent and 18.6 percent respectively over the same period of last year, leaving asurplus of US$15.71 billion for the island, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-PERFORMING LOAN RATIO OF 7 MAJOR DOMESTIC BANKS DROPS TO 4.72%

TEXT.P: The average ratio of non-performing loans (NPL) of seven major domestic banks dropped to 4.72 percent in November, less than the maximum level of 5 percent set by the Ministry of Finance, according to ministry statistics.
Among the banks, the First Commercial Bank sold much of their bad loans worth NT$20 billion (US$588 million), making its NPL ratio drop significantly to 1.87 percent.
The NPLs accumulated by the Bank of Taiwan reached NT$25.2 billion in November, registering a NPL ratio of 2.28 percent.

The NPLs of the Land Bank of Taiwan totaled NT$57 billion, registering a NPL ratio of 4.9 percent, a significant decrease from the 5.13 percent registered in October, due largely to an increase of loans made by the bank and repayments to its NPLs from borrowers.
The NPLs of the Taiwan Cooperative Bank reached NT$57.3 billion, registering a NPL ratio of 4.89 percent.
The NPLs of Hua Nan Commercial Bank and Chang Hwa Bank totaled NT$31.2 billion and NT$44 billion, respectively, registering NPL ratio of 3.75 percent and 5.49 percent, respectively.
By contrast, the NPLs of the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan stood at NT$68.3 billion in November, an increase of NT$300 million over October, registering a NPL ratio of 9.87 percent.
