DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS WRITTEN RESPONSE FROM MAINLAND OVER CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan prefers a written response from the mainland over negotiations about charter flights between Taiwan and Shanghai during the Chinese Lunar New Year, a mainland affairs official said Friday.

With the Chinese Lunar New Year only 40 days away, chances for charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland seem dim. However, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said at a news conference Friday that Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait replied by phone to its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, regarding Taiwan's offer to talk on lining up the charter flights, but Taiwan prefers a formal response in writing.

Taiwan air carriers provided charter flights between Shanghai and Taiwan with a brief stopover in Hong Kong or Macau earlier this year during the previous Chinese Lunar New Year. They would like to continue the flights this time around to serve Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland.
However, Beijing aviation officials said mainland carriers that were excluded from the service last time should join in the operation this time and take a share of the market.

The MAC agreed right away but insisted on negotiating with Beijing over the details, a request at which Beijing balked. Beijing has severed all official contacts with Taiwan since 1999 because of Taiwan's refusal to acknowledge that it is a part of China and will not resume discussions now because of concerns that it might lend a hand to President Chen Shui-bian's presidential campaign.
As a result, the charter flight service plan is still up in the air.

The proposed charter flights would fly the current route between Taiwan and Shanghai with a stopover in either Hong Kong or Macau. The only difference would be that passengers would not have to change planes during the stopover.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications estimated that more than 15,000 Taiwan businessmen in Fujian province, southern China, will return to Taiwan during the Chinese Lunar New Year via Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
That figure will be four times more than that of the last Chinese Lunar New Year when 3,500 persons returned from Kinmen and 65 from Matsu.
They will be ferried by boats from Xiamen or Fuzhou, both in Fujian, to the two islands before taking a 40-minute flight back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE GROUPS PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING PREMIER

TEXT.P: Representatives of various foreign-based Taiwanese groups filed a strong protest Friday against remarks made recently by mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao on Taiwan.

Speaking at a news conference, representatives from Taiwanese academic, women's and medical groups based overseas expressed fierce dissatisfaction with Wen's opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on March 20 next year, which he aired during a meeting Tuesday with U.S. President George W. Bush at the White House.
They accused Beijing's leaders of fueling Chinese nationalism by playing with the Taiwan issue in an attempt to consolidate their power base.

Stating that they firmly support President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold the referendum on the same day as the next president election, they said the president has done the right thing by deciding to hold a referendum to secure Taiwan's status quo.

"The Taiwan people are entitled to demonstrate their desire not to be threatened by mainland missiles, " they said, claiming that Taiwan independence can be achieved one day as long as the United States maintains its stance and does not give way to pressure from Beijing.
Despite what is seen by some analysts to be a rebuke from Bush, Chen has vowed to go ahead with the referendum as planned.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP PROTEST AGAINST REMARKS BY U.S. PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A pro-Taiwan independence group protested Friday against remarks made by U.S. President George W. Bush regarding Taiwan he made during a meeting with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao.

Headed by Wang Hsien-chi, chief executive of the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying The Name of Taiwan, the group went to the American Institute in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. embassy -- to protest against the "improper" remarks made by Bush that they claimed tried to force the Taiwan people to abandon their democratic rights and represented a double standard regarding the implementation of democracy.

In the Bush-Wen meeting, Bush said the United States policy continues to adhere to its "one China" policy and it opposes any unilateral decision by either mainland China or Taiwan to change the status quo.
"The comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan indicate that he may be willing to make decisions unilaterally, to change the status quo, which we oppose, " Bush was quoted as saying.

Bush was responding to President Chen Shui-bian's recent announcement that he will hold a "defensive referendum" on March 20, 2004, the day of the presidential election, asking the people of Taiwan if they want Beijing to dismantle the 496 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan.
A referendum law passed recently by the Legislative Yuan gives the president the right to initiate a referendum on national security issues in case of an external threat.

According to Wang, the passage of the referendum law is considered by "most Taiwan people" as a democratic achievement. However, Bush has tried to push the Taiwan people to abandon this right as a way of kowtowing to mainland China, which considers such a referendum as an initial step toward independence.

The U.S. government wants to implement democracy in Iraq, but opposes Taiwan's conducting a referendum on the country's national security, which represents a double standard, Wang said. He urged other Taiwan associations to also protest against Bush's remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR INVESTMENT EXPECTED TO TOP NT$60 BILLION FOR 2003

TEXT.P: Investment by the private sector into build-operate-transfer (BOT) joint ventures in cooperation with the government is expected to total more than NT$60 billion (US$1.77 billion) for the whole of this year, according to a government official.

Public Construction Commission (PCC) Chairwoman Kuo Yao-chi reported that as of Dec. 9, 26 BOT cases had been approved since the beginning of this year, attracting around NT$59.17 billion. The figure may top NT$60 million for the whole of 2003, an 8.1-fold increase over the year-earlier level, she assessed.
Kuo pointed out, however, that the figure falls well short of the target of NT$100 billion set originally for the year.

According to the PCC head, various important BOT cases are currently being assessed by an investment-promotion panel under the Executive Yuan, including a sporting compound project in Taipei City and a highway toll collection system, as well as several expansion plans at fishing ports and railway stations.
Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, who heads the investment promotion panel, has asked the ad hoc group to accomplish the signing of those cases within the next year, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILINGUAL TAIWAN NGO WEBSITE TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: To promote exchanges between Taiwan's non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the international community, a dual-language Taiwan NGO Website will be formally inaugurated Dec. 20, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
Lee Shu-tung, a section chief of MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, said the Website's inauguration ceremony will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center exhibition hall.

Lee noted that this will be the first time the government has financed an information exchange platform between Taiwan's NGOs and the international community, and the first time the government has set up an online NGO center.

The content of the Website includes an introduction of the development of Taiwan's NGOs, related conference information and links to related issues, providing a channel for Taiwan NGOs to exchange and share information.
The Website, www.taiwanngo.org.tw, also provides a portal to Taiwan's NGOs and allows browsers to gain an understanding of the present situation of Taiwan's NGOs.
Lee said that in tune with the bilingual Website, the ministry will also sponsor an exhibition to display the achievements of the country's NGOs.

The exhibition will be divided into five major categories: democracy, human rights and peace; humanitarian assistance and medical treatment; social welfare for women, children, the disabled and aboriginal people; environmental protection, conservation and voluntarism; and arts, sports and leisure.
The exhibition will show clearly the NGO's results in promoting international affairs, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 SUSPECTS NABBED FOR SMUGGLING DRUGS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Aviation police reported Friday the arrest of five suspects who used the outlying island of Matsu to ship drugs from mainland China.
Police said the suspects first flew to Matsu and boarded a ferry to Xiamen for the drugs, returning to Taiwan via the same route.

Following up on a tip-off, police arrested a woman surnamed Chang, 25, and a man surnamed Chiu, 25, on their arrival at Sungshan Airport in Taipei Thursday from Matsu. They were taken to hospital, where Chang was found to have secreted three heroin balls in her rectum.
Police also arrested a man surnamed Peng, 33, who they said was at Sungshan Airport to pick up Chang and Chiu.

Police also traced another two suspects -- a woman surnamed Tsai, 39 and a man surnamed Gang, 32 -- and found more than NT$200,000 (US$5,882) which the police claimed was money from drug transactions, along with 10 grams of amphetamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.73 points to close at 5,858.32.
The bourse opened at 5,912.93 and fluctuated between 5,922.71 and 5,849.42 during the trading session.

A total of 3.121 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.51 billion (US$2.07 billion), an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 3.12 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$69.53 billion.
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics issues at 0.3 percent.

Five other stock categories lost ground, with financial stocks moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by foodstuff, construction and textile shares both at 0.3 percent, and electrical issues at 0.2 percent.
Only cement shares remained unchanged during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERCHANT SELLING PEARLS TO RAISE FUNDS FOR PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: A Taichung jewelry merchant whose shop had been robbed but who has yet to see justice done, put pearls and other jewelry on sale Friday to raise funds for a bid to run for the presidency of the Republic of China.

Yang Tian-tzu and Huang Chun-shen recently submitted NT$1 million to the Ministry of the Interior as a guarantee deposit, formally registering as the third ticket in the March 20, 2004 presidential election.

Huang, the jewelry merchant, put the jewelry on sale at Taichung railway station as part of his fund-raising. He appealed for public support for Yang and himself, claiming that a victorious Yang-Huang ticket will restore public order and will allow the Taiwan people to lead safe, peaceful and prosper lives.
Neither Huang nor Yang have any experience of politics and neither have any political qualifications.
According to Huang, his jewelry shop was robbed several years ago of more than NT$30 million-worth of jewelry. The case has never been resolved.
Yang and Huang need to collect 240,000 signatures to endorse their bid to run. As of noon Friday, the pair had managed to convince just 38 people to sign.
If they fail to collect the 240,000 signatures, their NT$1 million guarantee deposit will be forfeit, according to government regulations.

If the Yang-Huang ticket somehow manages to get the 240,000 signatures for the endorsement, they will than have to submit NT$16 million as a guarantee deposit to make them officially registered presidential candidates.

The other two presidential tickets consist of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, who will be running for a second term, and the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIRTH RATE CONTINUES TO DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's birth rate has continued to decrease over the past year, with the birth rate falling to 1.01 percent in November this year, another record low, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Friday.
A total of 18,815 babies were born in November this year, representing a birth rate of 1.01 percent and a decline of 0.129 percentage points from November 2002, according to MOI tallies.
Ministry officials said that the birth rate has continued to decline every year since 1997, mainly as a result of a declining marriage rate and a flagging economy.
MOI statistics indicate that about 20,000 babies were born each month in Taiwan last year, which is 6 percent less than the monthly average for 2001.
Taiwan had a record low birth rate of 1.07 percent in 2002.

Official statistics show that between 1993 and 1997, the birth rate averaged 1.5 percent. It dropped to 1.24 percent in 1998 and rose slightly to 1.38 percent in 2000, when a baby boom was anticipated because of the millennium.
Over the past five years, the northern county of Hsinchu has registered the highest birth rate, while the birth rate on the outlying island of Matsu was the lowest, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO UPGRADE IMMIGRATION ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: An immigrants rights promotion alliance urged the government Friday to upgrade the status of a planned immigration administration to better protect the rights of new immigrants and legal foreign contract workers.

The newly formed alliance, which groups major organizations dedicated to helping the underprivileged as well as foreign and mainland Chinese spouses, said the government should upgrade the planned immigration administration to a Cabinet-level agency.

The Cabinet-drafted immigration administration organizational statute, which is pending legislative approval, prescribes an immigration administration under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

However, as immigration affairs involve not only the MOI-administered welfare services but also education, work and economic issues, the alliance said the immigration administration should be put under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet to facilitate inter-departmental coordination and upgrade the new agency's operational efficiency.

The alliance also pointed out several flaws and deficiencies in the draft statute, including the absence of regulations governing the recruitment and cultivation of translators as well as the absence of a supervisory mechanism and channels for immigrants to file complaints and appeals.

According to the draft statute, 75 percent of the new administration's staff members are police officers. "It seems to us that the government regards foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens as potential criminals," said an alliance spokesman.

Foreign and mainland spouses form the bulk of new immigrants to Taiwan. "We are hopeful that the police ratio can be reduced while more professional counselors can be recruited to offer better services to new immigrants and foreign contract workers," the spokesman said.

Meanwhile, the spokesman said, the draft statute fails to lay out a permanent residence (PR) system. "We hope the immigration statute will include PR provisions to protect new immigrants' rights, " he added.

The spokesman also urged the government and the media to do more to help new immigrants adapt to local society and to educate the public to drop its prejudice toward foreign and mainland Chinese spouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2003 AUSTRONESIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL TO BE HELD IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: The 2003 Austronesian Cultural Festival, one of 12 local festivals subsidized by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will be held in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 20-31.

In addition to original and colorful programs to be presented by local aboriginal groups, folklore art performance groups from Canada, Japan, Indonesia, South Korea and Hawaii are also expected to stage performances during the 10-day 2003 Austronesian Cultural Festival, whose theme is "Weaving and Knitting -- The Beauty of Austronesian Handicraft."
The festival, the fifth of its kind, is being co-sponsored by the Taitung County government and the National Museum of Prehistory located in downtown Taitung City.

Local aboriginal groups -- including the Atayal, Amis, Bunun, Saisiat, Tsou, Puyuma, Rukai, Paiwan and Dawu -- will also send their own dancing or artistic troupes to take part in the festival, officials from the Taichung Bureau of Cultural Affairs said.

An Austronesian Night gala party is set to run from the evening of Dec. 31 through to the small hours of Jan. 1, 2004, as a special event different from those held in previous years, the officials said.

Taiwan's indigenous people could either have originally come from the southern part of China or from the vast region called the Austronesian-language area, which spans from Madagascar eastward across the Indian and Pacific oceans to Easter Island, and from Taiwan southward to New Zealand.
In a new theory developed in Australia and New Zealand in recent years, anthropologists believe that Taiwan is the place where the Austronesian-language people originated.

Professor Geoffrey Chambers of Victoria University in Wellington, New Zealand, believes that the Maori people and other Polynesian peoples of the Pacific "island-hopped" from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia. From there, he says, they traveled to the islands of East Polynesia and then southwest, eventually settling in New Zealand.

Taiwan's aboriginal citizens are considered the northernmost Austronesian people. The government currently divides them into 10 major mountain tribes and 10 Pingpu groups. While elements of the languages and culture of the 10 mountainous races have been maintained, most of the native languages of the Pingpu people have died out, with no traces remaining, the officials said.
Among the mountain tribes, the Saisiat and the Atayal are believed to have migrated to Taiwan some 3,000 years ago.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Pingpu groups -- aboriginal people who lived in low-lying areas around the island, many of whom intermarried with Han Chinese -- can be roughly divided into 10 different groups, including the Ketagalan in the Taipei area and the Kavalan in the eastern Ilan area. The remnants of these groups are now working to establish the identity of their respective tribes and refuse to accept the notion that their tribes have died out.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS JUSTICE MINISTRY RESERVED ON SIGNING AGREEMENT WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Swiss Ministry of Justice spokesman maintained a reserved attitude when asked about Taiwan's hopes of signing a judicial assistance agreement with his country, saying Switzerland could not possibly sign such agreements with every single country.
The spokesman, however, stressed that even if there is no judicial assistance agreement between the two countries, Switzerland can still provide sufficient judicial assistance to Taiwan.

His remarks came after the Swiss Ministry of Justice announced earlier this week that a federal court had ruled that Taiwan, France and the Principality of Liechtenstein should be given access to the Swiss legal files, particularly the Andrew Wang family's bank accounts in Switzerland, to facilitate investigations into an alleged kickback scandal in connection with Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette frigates from France in 1991,

Taiwan's Ministry of Justice (MOJ) welcomed the decision by the Swiss authorities, saying it would be helpful in tracking the flow of the alleged slush funds of Wang, an arms dealer, and in shedding more light on the case.
The MOJ further said that in its efforts at signing judicial assistance agreements with other countries, the ministry has listed Switzerland as a priority.

However, the Swiss Ministry of Justice spokesman, when asked about Taiwan's hopes of signing a judicial assistance agreement with Switzerland, did not give a direct answer. He said that in the absence of such an agreement, Switzerland can still extend judicial assistance to Taiwan, such as that given earlier this week, based on an international judicial assistance law.

He also said that Switzerland is currently actively negotiating the signing of judicial assistance agreements with Latin American countries, saying that these countries are the nation's top priority on this issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR LEGISLATIVE SUPPORT FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun delivered a report to the Legislative Yuan Friday on the government's ambitious 10 new major construction projects, which call for an outlay of NT$500 billion over the next five years.

Yu urged the opposition-controlled Legislature to support the Cabinet-drafted bill on expanding public investment in infrastructure construction to allow for the government to borrow money to finance the new major construction projects.

"The planned new construction projects will help sustain Taiwan's economic growth and further upgrade the nation's overall competitiveness in the global market, " Yu said at a legislative plenary session.

In May 2002, Yu recalled, the Cabinet launched a "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan, with "three reforms and four investment directions" as its theme. The plan has so far born fruit, he said.

According to Yu, Taiwan ranks first among all Asian countries and fifth in the world in the 2003 global Growth Competitiveness Index compiled by the Swiss think tank the World Economic Forum. And Taiwan's ranking in the annual World Competitiveness Report compiled by the International Institute for Management and Development (IMD) advanced from seventh in 2002 to sixth in 2003.
"These figures indicate that the "Challenge 2008" plan has contributed to the improvement of Taiwan's global competitiveness, " Yu said.

Noting that the "10 new construction projects" epitomize the essence of the "Challenge 2008" six-year plan, Yu said the new projects aim to accelerate Taiwan's transformation and upgrading in various fields.

The 10 new projects include manpower cultivation, research and development, upgrading of quality of life, environmental protection, sustainable development, and enhancement of global competitiveness, Yu said.

From the viewpoint of cost efficiency, Yu said, now is the best time to launch the 10 new construction projects. "If we do not take action now, we'll regret it in the future. By doing it now, we'll be able to save a large amount of money," he claimed.

If the Legislature passes the special budget plan for the 10 new construction projects, Yu said, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will increase by between 1.0 percent and 1.4 percent in real terms annually over the next five years, while private demand will rise by between 0.6 percent and 0.8 percent. The projects are also expected to create 64,000 job opportunities annually during the five-year period, Yu said.
Meanwhile, Yu added, the government's tax revenues will increase by NT$70 billion to NT$150 billion during the five-year period.

1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.

1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.

1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.

He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL IN U.S. TO GAIN UNDERSTANDING OF BUSH-WEN MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior Taiwan security official is currently in Washington, D.C. to gain a first-hand understanding of the details of the recent meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, sources said Friday.
Ko Cheng-heng, a deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, arrived in the U.S. capital a day after the Bush-Wen meeting at the White House on Tuesday.
According to the sources, Ko's visit was scheduled before the Bush-Wen meeting and is not directly related to Bush's recent criticism of Taiwan's leader.

Bush said at a news conference following his talks with Wen that he opposes "comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan" that indicate that President Chen Shui-bian "may be willing to make decisions unilaterally, to change the status quo."

Despite the U.S. concern that Taiwan's planned "defensive referendum" might disrupt the delicate status quo in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, President Chen has reaffirmed his determination to go ahead with the plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004 that would allow the people of Taiwan to voice their opposition to Beijing's military threat to their country.

In addition to collecting information about the details of the Bush-Wen talks, Ko is also expected to further explain Taipei's stance on the "defensive referendum" issue to relevant U.S. authorities during his visit, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH URGED TO RECONSIDER POSITION ON TAIWAN REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The leaders of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus have urged President Bush to reconsider his opposition to a referendum in Taiwan that would allow its citizens to voice their opposition to mainland China's military threat to their country.

During his public briefing with mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao this week, President Bush warned Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, to resist making any unilateral moves toward independence, including holding a defensive referendum on missiles and other military threats by the People's Republic of China toward Taiwan.

In a letter sent to the president, Reps. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), Dana Rohrbacher (R-Calif.) and Robert Wexler (D-Fla.) wrote that "the mounting threats and hostile actions taken by the PRC toward Taiwan underscore the volatility of the situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait."

"The continued build-up of missiles and military exercises on China's southeast coast remind us that democratic Taiwan and its people face a constant and imminent threat from an authoritarian regime," they wrote.
The members said the administration's action signaled a victory for the People's Republic of China at the expense of Taiwan's democratic reforms.

"The Bush administration's vocal opposition to any referendum in Taiwan would be seen as a great victory for mainland China and a defeat for Taiwan's democratic reforms. It may seem like splitting hairs, but the language is important to our long-term interests in that region, " said Brown, a co-founder of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus.

The Congressional Taiwan Caucus, which includes more than 120 members of Congress, has also led efforts to formalize support for Taiwan's efforts to gain recognition by international bodies, including the World Health Assembly and the United Nations. The text of the letter follows: Dear President Bush:
We urge your administration to cease its opposition to a democratic referendum in Taiwan on the issue of China's ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan.

The defensive referendum as proposed by President Chen Shui-bian does not alter the status quo of cross-strait relations by seeking a declaration on independence. Rather, it is intended to express the immediate and legitimate concerns of the Taiwanese on the peace and security of the region.

The people of Taiwan are particularly worried, and rightfully so, about the increasing missile deployment across the Taiwan Strait by the People's Republic of China (PRC) . Just recently, President Chen indicated that 496 missiles have been placed on China's coast, with the capability of reaching Taiwan in under ten minutes. This number was not disputed by the PRC, and it is estimated to increase by 50 missiles annually.

The mounting threats and hostile actions taken by the PRC toward Taiwan underscore the volatility of the situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. The continued build-up of missiles and military exercises on China's southeast coast remind us that democratic Taiwan and its people face a constant and imminent threat from an authoritarian regime.

Mr. President, in your November 19 "Three Pillars" speech in London, you spoke about America's strong commitment to the global expansion of democracy. We applaud your efforts to promote democracy and freedom and look forward to joining in efforts to garner international support for this important campaign.

However, we are deeply concerned that a vocal opposition to a Taiwanese referendum would send the wrong signal to the international community that the United States is not fully committed to expanding democracy.

Taiwan is a thriving democracy that promotes freedom and the rule of law. It is our hope that your administration will move away from its opposition to a referendum asking that the PRC withdraw the hundreds of ballistic missiles threatening the people of Taiwan. We look forward to working with you to strengthen our friendship with Taiwan and further promote democracy in East Asia. Thank you for your consideration of this important matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH GIVES THUMBS-UP TO FIRST ASEAN+1 SUMMIT HELD IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has given the thumbs-up to the first ASEAN+1 summit to be held outside the ASEAN region.

In a statement read by Goh's press secretary to Singaporean reporters in Tokyo Friday, the prime minister welcomed Japan's decision to accede to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation as a significant development that shows Tokyo's commitment to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations' peace and prosperity.
Underlining that Japan will remain an important partner of ASEAN for many years to come, Goh said Japan will drive the locomotive of integration in the region.

Goh called the just concluded event a success with substantive outcomes. He said the mood was very friendly, positive and constructive, and commended the host Japan for structuring the discussions well.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.S. TO STRENGTHEN HEALTH CARE COOPERATION: DOH MINISTER

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen said Saturday he has reached a consensus with his U.S. counterpart on strengthening health care cooperation between the two countries.
Chen said he met with Tommy Thompson, secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, during his visit to the United States last month.

"We have exchanged views on bilateral cooperation," Chen said, adding that Thompson agreed to strengthen exchanges of epidemic information and cooperation in manpower training and disease control with Taiwan.

Chen said Thompson also agreed to deliver a keynote speech in an international meeting on control of new contagious diseases, health insurance systems and the establishment of a comprehensive health care and medical information system to be held in Taiwan in the near future.
Chen said the DOH is planned to hold such a meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. Both Taiwan and the United States are APEC members.

During his first formal visit to the United States since assuming office, Chen also visited the Agency for Health Research and Quality, the Congressional General Accounting Office and the National Institute of Health to discuss feasible measures to boost bilateral cooperation in health care and medical fields.
Chen said he also discussed with relevant U.S. officials the possibility of the two countries cooperating in offering health care and medical aid to Third World countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PUTS FORTH THREE QUESTIONS TO MAINLAND PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian put forward three questions to mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao Saturday in a speech delivered at a national congress of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

President Chen challenged the top mainland Chinese leader to answer why the term "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" does not apply, why China cannot renounce the use of force against Taiwan and cannot remove its hundreds of missiles pointed at Taiwan, as well as why Taiwan cannot take part in the World Health Organization (WHO).

In his speech, Chen also reaffirmed his determination to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of the next presidential election on March 20, 2004 that would allow the people of Taiwan to voice their opposition to mainland China's missile deployment against their country.

"We'll hold the referendum to express our opposition to missiles and war while highlighting our desires for peace and democracy," Chen said, adding that protecting Taiwan from China's threat is one of his most important missions as the nation's top leader.

Commenting on Beijing's harsh criticism of Taiwan's referendum plan, Chen said he wants to represent the 23 million people of Taiwan in asking mainland Chinese President Hu why his description of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" cannot apply since Taiwan is a democratic country while mainland China is a communist state.
Stressing that the people of Taiwan love peace, Chen asked Hu why Beijing cannot publicly renounce its option of using force against Taiwan and dismantle its missiles deployed against Taiwan.
Chen further asked Hu why Taiwan should be denied access to the WHO even though its people want to play an active role in world health care and medical affairs.
If Beijing authorities cannot make a goodwill response to these questions, Chen said, then he believes the Taiwan people will come up with options in the March 20 referendum.

Chen further said the Taiwan people have the right to voice their opposition to the missile threat posed by the mainland and their desire for democracy, and to declare to the world that "military force is never a means or option for solving the cross-strait issue."

Noting that mainland China's missile deployment has not only threatened peace in the Taiwan Strait but also stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region, Chen said the world should not accept Beijing's military threat to Taiwan as a matter of course.

He reminded the world that mainland China's military build-up, rather than Taiwan's referendum plan, is a threat to Taiwan's status quo and that Taiwan's pursuit of full democracy should not be considered as an act of provocation against China.

Describing his nomination as the DPP candidate for the next presidential election as the beginning of "an enormous duty and a new hope, " Chen said he will lead the DPP and the people of Taiwan in "turning a marvelous page" in the nation's history.

Chen said "believing in Taiwan, insisting on reforms" will be his presidential campaign theme. He reaffirmed his determination to complete the democratic reform "trilogy" -- namely holding Taiwan's first-ever referendum on March 20, 2004, writing a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006, and enacting the new constitution on May 20, 2008, to make Taiwan a "normal, complete and great" democratic country.

"In the first step, the DPP must win the 2004 presidential election, " Chen said. "If we manage to win the election, we have the mandate to push the opposition 'pan-blue alliance' of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to normalize domestic inter-party relations and to force the Chinese Communist Party on the mainland to normalize cross-strait relations," he noted.

In the second stage, Chen said, the DPP must do its utmost to win a majority in the next legislative elections to be held in late 2004. "Once the DPP and its allies manage to gain a majority in the Legislative Yuan, we'll be able to normalize relations between the legislative and executive branches and enhance administrative efficiency," he pointed out.

In the third phase, Chen continued, the DPP will push for the formulation of a new constitution to be put to a referendum in 2006 and for formal implementation from May 20, 2008. "By then, all the constitutional chaos will have become history and Taiwan will have become a genuine and great democracy," he said.

Recalling that Taiwan's democracy, prosperity and peace have never been godsent, but rather hard-won achievements, Chen said his determination to carry out sweeping democratic reform will never be swayed by pressure by Beijing or domestic opposition parties.

Over the past three years, Chen said, his administration has continued to push for reforms and has displayed its capability of implementation, which is reflected in recent favorable ratings by international assessment organizations.

In his 30-minute speech, Chen also outlined his economic platform, saying that the "10 new major public construction projects" unveiled by the Cabinet will further upgrade Taiwan's national competitiveness and enhance the quality of life.
The new projects are expected to create 64,000 jobs per year, Chen said, adding that they will also help raise Taiwan's annual economic growth by 1.03 percent over the next five years.

If re-elected, Chen said, he will achieve within three years the "3-4-5" goal -- meaning that the budget for research and development will reach over 3 percent of the gross domestic product, the jobless rate will drop to below 4 percent in two years, and the economic growth will increase to 5 percent in 2004.

Chen further said the upcoming presidential election will be a "three-versus" competition, meaning his advocacy of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" versus the pan-blue alliance's "one China" notion; insistence on reforms rather than the restoration of the corrupt "black gold" of the previous administration; and faith in Taiwan rather than pessimism.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PLEDGES TO HELP FARMERS AND FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the government has a plan to help Taiwan's farmers and fishermen sharpen their competitiveness in the world market.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of a two-day trade fair in Taipei sponsored by the Council of Agriculture (COA) of the Executive Yuan, Chen said the government will spend NT$2.2 billion over three years to help farmers and fishermen transform their production and marketing methods.
It is the responsibility of the government to take care of farmers and fishermen, he said, adding that the government will help them promote their products in the world market.
The COA opened the trade fair Saturday on the plaza in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei to promote the sale of agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE LOCAL GOVERNMENT CHIEFS MEET IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: More than 10 city mayors and county magistrates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) met in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to drum up support for the alliance's presidential election ticket.

This was the first time that local government chiefs from the opposition camp have met in the southern city to discuss campaign strategies for the pan-blue alliance ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong.
Lien and many other alliance heavyweights, including Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng, also attended the meeting.

During the meeting, local government chiefs from the pan-blue alliance, including Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, pledged to do their utmost in campaigning for the Lien-Soong ticket. They vowed to jointly attract at least 3.33 million votes for the Lien-Soong ticket in the next presidential election on March 20, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ACTIVELY TAKE PART IN U.N. INFORMATION SOCIETY PLAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will actively participate in the U.N.-initiated global information society development plan, a senior Cabinet official said in Geneva Friday.

Tsay Ching-yen, minister-without-portfolio, made the remarks after attending the U.N.-sponsored World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) , whose aim was to spread the Internet and other technologies to the world's poorest regions.

Tsay said he will urge the government to set up a supra-ministerial task force to integrate national resources in order to boost information technology development and actively take part in the U.N.-organized global information society development plan.

Tsay headed a 60-member Taiwan delegation to attend the Dec. 10-12 World Summit on the Information Society. As Taiwan is not a U.N. member, they attended the three-day meeting as International Non-Government Organizations (INGO) delegates.
Tsay said he regrets the fact that mainland China tried hard to obstruct their participation, even though they attended the meeting as INGO delegates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 13, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE FOREIGN SECRETARY PRONOUNCED DEAD AT TAIWAN HOSPITAL
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Yang I-feng, Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Philippine Secretary of Foreign Affairs Blas Fajaredo Ople died of an apparent heart attack on a plane that was diverted to Taipei Saturday night from its original destination of Bangkok.

Ople, 75, fell critically ill aboard a Japan Asia Airways flight from Tokyo to Bangkok late Saturday night. His final destination was to have been Manama, Bahrain, where he was to have been a part of the advance team ahead of Philippine President Gloria Arroyo's official visit.

Ople suffered a fit of dry coughing followed by difficulties in breathing before the situation turned critical. The JAA flight crew attempted to resuscitate Ople while the plane diverted its course and flew to Taipei for an emergency landing after Manila diplomatic officials called their Taipei counterparts for help, according to Richard Shih, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Medical personnel at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport said Sunday morning that doctors at the airport boarded the plane around 11 p.m. Saturday and found that Ople was showing no signs of life. They rushed the Philippine minister to Minsheng Hospital located near the airport.
Minsheng Hospital medical staff pronounced Ople DOA, but said that he was given emergency treatment nonetheless.
Wu Hsin-hsing, Taiwan's representative in Manila, expressed his sympathies over Ople's death. He said it was a major loss for the government and the people of the Philippines.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs helped arrange for Ople's family members to fly to Taipei. They arrived in Taipei at 8: 40 a.m. Sunday after taking the first flight out of Manila, Wu said.

Ople had been foreign affairs secretary of the Philippines since July 30, 2002. He had been a senator for 10 years and chairman of the Senate's Foreign Affairs Committee before becoming foreign secretary.

1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS HURTS TAIWAN TRAVEL AGENCIES

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan has weathered severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), the epidemic has had a serious impact on local travel agencies which said their yearly profit targets will be hard to achieve, an industry source said Sunday.

The massive outbreaks of the potentially deadly SARS in the first half of this year has had a very large impact on local travel agencies, most of them small- and medium-sized businesses, despite a rebound in business from July, the source said.

A vast majority, or some 80 percent of them, which operate outbound travel, said they might post losses for the whole of this year on the grounds that trips to mainland China, the No. 1 overseas destination among Taiwan tourists, have been fewer for the traditional peak season beginning every September, it added.

In the face of the many economic and political uncertainties remaining in the international community, domestic travel or those specially designed high-class tours to newly explored destinations may emerge as better options for many Taiwan people, the source said.

With regard to the mainland Chinese market, local travel agencies should seek to design high-class, in-depth tours featuring special cuisine and landscape to lure Taiwan tourists at a time when a fever for mainland travel is fading because of a lack of new attractions, Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the ROC Federation of Associations of Travel Agents, said.
Destinations in some emerging markets are worth exploring by Taiwan-based travel agencies, Hsu added.

Chang Chin-ming, chairman of the Phoenix Tours International Inc., one of Taiwan's largest travel agencies specializing in outbound tours, said specially designed, high-class and in-depth trips will prevail in the future, given the fact that more than seven million Taiwan tourists go abroad every year.
Russia, Vietnam, Japan and India have the potential to become popular markets for Taiwan tourists seeking extraordinary attractions and new experience, he added.

As to domestic travel, many destinations at home are very competitive with their hot springs, theme parks and fine hotels, a travel agency operator said, adding that there is ample room for the market to grow at a time when the economy has yet to recover fully.
Smart customers are waiting for economical, high quality and finely designed tours, a source noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS TO URGE BEIJING TO DISMANTLE MISSILES TARGETING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of various political parties have introduced resolutions separately to ask Beijing to dismantle its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan, officials of the Legislative Yuan said Sunday.

A resolution introduced by the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) which asks Beijing to dismantle its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan to respect the sovereignty of the Republic of China and to respect the people of Taiwan's rights to pursue democracy and peace, has been put on the agenda of the Legislative Yuan's plenary session for Tuesday, the officials said.
Meanwhile, they added, a similar resolution introduced jointly by legislators of the main opposition Kuomingtang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has also been listed on Tuesday's agenda.

In the resolution, KMT and PFP lawmakers urge Beijing to gradually dismantle the nearly 500 missiles it has deployed against Taiwan, allowing cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and relations to return to normal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT EMPLOYS TEMPERATURE-TAKING TO WARD OFF SARS

TEXT.P: Bracing for a possible resurgence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , the Taipei City government will begin from Monday to take temperatures of persons visiting its offices and medical facilities.
Visitors with a temperature above 38 degrees Celsius will be forbidden to enter and will be advised to visit a doctor.
The measures will be taken on the recommendation of the Center for Disease Control of the Department of Health and in line with similar measures to be carried out by schools in Taipei on Monday.

Fever is the proceeding symptom of the contagious disease, which displays signs at the preliminary stage similar to influenza. Local health officials are on their guard against the disease since winter is the peak season for flu.
City health officials also recommend that people wash their hands frequently and thoroughly as an effectively way to wipe out the virus that causes the disease.
Taipei was hardest hit by SARS between March and July. Two hospitals in the city were forced to close during the hight of the outbreaks because of cross-infection of the disease within the hospitals.
The epidemic claimed the lives of 37 out of 346 cases and took a heavy toll on the country's economy before it disappeared in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO WORK ON ANTI-TERRORISM DRAFT BILL

TEXT.P: The Judiciary Committee of the Legislative Yuan will discuss an anti-terrorism draft bill Monday under which convicted terrorists could face capital punishment.

The draft bill, aimed to underscore the country's determination to wipe out terrorism and to bring itself in line with other civilized nations in terms of cracking down on terrorism, will empower the Executive Yuan to set up an anti-terrorism panel, while the National Security Bureau should coordinate the efforts of different government agencies in collecting information on terrorist organizations and their activities.
Any person convicted of committing a terrorist act will face punishment from 10 years imprisonment to death.
The Executive Yuan drafted the bill in response to the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks in the United States to show, in part, its solidarity with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVEL AGENCIES MUST COPE WITH NEW REGULATIONS TO MONITOR TRAVELERS

TEXT.P: Travel agencies have no choice but to cope with a new government regulation that requires travel agents to report name lists of all Taiwan visitors heading to mainland China, a spokesman for a Taipei-based travel agents association said Sunday.

Taipei media reported Sunday that airlines and travel agencies will be required to report to the Bureau of Exit and Entry the name lists of mainland-bound visitors within 24 hours of their departure as part of the government efforts to better monitor relations of the people across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang Chi-han, chairman of the Chunghua Cross-Strait Travel Agents Association, said he believes that local travel agents have no choice but to follow the rule.

Wang said similar regulations have been promulgated since 1997 after the government opened private visits to the mainland for business purposes or to visit relatives. Nevertheless, the regulations, requiring visitors name lists and itineraries to be reported to the government within two years of the actual visits, remain empty rules and have never been implemented, probably due to technical difficulties, he added.

A number of Taipei citizens, however, have different opinions on the new regulation. They said that it would be a challenging task for the government to have all mainland-bound visitors monitored since Taiwan citizens make at least three million visits to the mainland each year for either travel or business.
In addition, they argued, it is the people's basic human right stipulated by the Constitution to have the freedom to travel, and it is improper for the government to monitor this.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DENIES REPORT THAT MILITARY LEADERS OPPOSE REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense denied Sunday that leaders of the armed forces did not support President Chen Shui-bian's call for a referendum on Beijing's military threat against Taiwan.

In a response to a report in Sunday's United Daily News that said 22 of 24 generals interviewed by two correspondents of the paper had said that they disapproved of the referendum proposal, a defense ministry spokesman said the report was untrue.

Gen. Chen Bang-chih, the chief of the Political Warfare Bureau under the defence ministry, said at a news conference Sunday morning that he personally contacted all active generals except for one who was overseas after the report hit the stands and found they all denied having given any interviews to the media regarding the referendum.
The chief of staff of the general who is out of the country confirmed that no media had approached his boss over the referendum, Gen. Chen said.
The ministry also checked with all lieutenant generals and major generals this morning and was sure none of them has ever talked to any media over the referendum, Gen. Chen added.
Without mentioning any media by name, Gen. Chen said the report was not credible, far from the facts and groundless.
The spokesman said the defense ministry has ordered military personnel to steer clear of politics and remain neutral in the campaigning for the upcoming presidential election.

The United Daily News said Sunday that its correspondents interviewed two generals, 12 lieutenant generals and 10 major generals. Twenty-two of them said that they did not support the referendum called by President Chen. Two opted to keep their own counsel.

The story, bylined by two reporters, also said 20 of the interviewees said "yes" when asked whether the referendum will heighten tensions across the Taiwan Strait, two said "no, " and two refused to comment.

Sixteen of the 24 interviewed said they worried that the longstanding confrontation between Taiwan and the mainland might accelerate into conflict because of the referendum, four said Beijing might up the military ante to a semi-military operation, such as approaching the midline of the Taiwan Strait irregularly with fleets of jet fighters or spying on Taiwan's eastern coastline with its submarines.

The article said the generals covered by the survey come from all three branches of the military and 70 percent of them are commanders of combat units, exercising considerable influence on the ministry's policy-making, although they count for only 6 percent of the 400-odd military generals.
As being ordered to keep out of politics, the newspaper said all of the interviewed generals said that they could give their opinions only if they remained unnamed in the report.

President Chen is calling for a referendum asking the people of Taiwan if Beijing should remove the nearly 500 ballistic missiles targeting the island. The move has been criticized by Chen's political rivals at home as a campaign trick and has raised eyebrows in Beijing, which is concerned that such a vote would be tantamount to taking a step closer to declaring independence for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF TAIWAN PEOPLE DISSATISFIED WITH POLITICS: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan people are not satisfied with either the country's politics or its economic performance and nearly 70 percent of them said that pressure from daily life has become greater than ever, according to the results of a poll released Sunday.
In its annual "state of the nation" survey, the prestigious monthly CommonWealth magazine found that about 60 percent of Taiwan people are dissatisfied with Taiwan's current political environment.

Some 56 percent of the respondents blamed the struggle among political parties as the greatest "crisis" that the Taiwan public is facing, while 30.3 percent said media sensationalization has caused Taiwan's politics to deteriorate, compared with 20.1 percent who attributed lowering and changing social values as the reasons causing the worsening political environment. Only 19 percent of the respondents attributed Taiwan's political situation to a rising mainland China and its military threats to the island, the poll found.
CommonWealth conducted the survey by telephone between Nov. 26 and Dec. 1, obtaining 1,074 valid answers from adults randomly selected islandwide. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

The poll found that 67.8 percent of the respondents felt that the pressures of life are mounting on a daily basis. About 56 percent said the economy was the source of their pressure, while 15.7 percent said chaotic politics was the reason.

Some 57 percent said they are dissatisfied with the injustice of society, while 74.8 percent blamed the gap between the rich and the poor as the greatest social problem. Roughly 33 percent said they were currently out of work, and 68.5 percent said they have been worrying about losing their job, the poll found.

Despite the fact that a majority of Taiwan citizens are dissatisfied with the political and economic environment, nearly 40 percent said they are optimistic about Taiwan's future, compared with 31 percent, who are pessimistic, according to the poll.

In its December 2002 poll, CommonWealth found that 49.9 percent of these responding said that they were pessimistic about 2003, up 25.5 percent from the previous year. The figure was only 15.3 percent when the magazine conducted a similar survey a decade ago.
The percentage of people who want to emigrate also declined in the 2003 poll, with only 18.3 percent responding positively, a figure slightly lower than that of 2002.

The poll also found that 56 percent of the Taiwan public want to see the status quo of the cross-strait relations remain unchanged. Only 9.8 percent favor the notion that Taiwan unify with the mainland. A total of 22 percent favor Taiwan's independence, while 3.9 percent are "extremely inclined toward independence." This figure is the highest in five years.

The poll also found that 43 percent of the respondents are critical of the ability of the administration of President Chen Shui-bian, who has ruled Taiwan for nearly four years, compared with 18 percent who said the Chen administration is capable. These figures, nevertheless, are explicit improvements over those of last year, when half of those polled rated Chen's government's performance as "poor" and only 10 percent rated it as "good."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-VIETNAM SYMPOSIUM ON PROFESSIONAL EDUCATION OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Some 300 educators and experts from Vietnam and Taiwan took part in a symposium on professional education Sunday in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung.

Minister of Education Huang Jong-tsun delivered a speech at the opening ceremony of the symposium on the current situation and policy of professional education in Taiwan in the framework of internationalization.
He said one of the important goals of professional education is to promote the value of life-long learning and education.
Organizers said the symposium is a milestone of friendly cooperation between Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD FRONT BRINGS DRY AND COLD WEATHER TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Seasonal northeast winds has brought dry and cold weather to Taiwan with temperatures in Tamsui and Chiayi dropping to 9.8 degrees Celsius early Sunday morning, a record low so far this year.
A meteorologist from the Central Weather Bureau said temperatures in other parts of the island also dropped to this year's new low.
He said that in early Sunday morning the temperatures dropped to 12.7 degrees Celsius in Taipei, 11.8 degrees in Taichung, 12.3 degrees in Tainan and 14.6 degrees in Kaohsiung.
He said it may warm up to 19 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan and 23 degrees Celsius in central and southern Taiwan on Sunday before turning colder two days afterward.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PREMIER FEARS IMPACT OF TAIWAN REFERENDUM ON MAINLAND: VP LU

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's opposition to Taiwan's referendum plan is because the Beijing regime is afraid that such a democratic event could have a profound impact on its power base, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday.

Lu made the remarks at a campaign rally held in northern Taoyuan County, where she once served as magistrate. The ticket of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) formed by President Chen Shui-bian and Lu was formally ratified by the party congress a day earlier to compete in the next presidential election set for March 20, 2004 for a second term.

Saying that the purpose of Chen's idea of holding a "defensive referendum" on election day is to drum up international support to ask Beijing remove its missiles aimed at Taiwan, Lu added that Wen's opposition to Taiwan's planned referendum, made public during a meeting last week with U. S. President George W. Bush at the White House, is a result of Beijing's inability to prevent Taiwan from holding the vote.

Beijing is afraid of Taiwan's holding a referendum because it fears that such a democratic practice will create leverage and cause a split from mainland China in areas such as Hong Kong, Macau and Xingjiang, the vice president said.

Lu wondered why the U.S. president sent 300,000 troops to destroy the weapons of mass destruction allegedly amassed by Iraq while ignoring Taiwan's desire for peace when the island is targeted by 496 missiles deployed by Beijing.

Bush's rebuke to President Chen's referendum plan has provoked criticism from the U. S. political sector and the general public, Lu stressed, adding that Taiwan will continue to make its stance clear in this regard to have the international community be fully aware of Beijing's intention to use force against Taiwan.
The president has done the right thing in initiating the "defensive referendum" plan to protect Taiwan's status quo, she pointed out.

THE TWO MEN contending to become opposition standard-bearer have finally sat down to a meeting and are apparently working in earnest to settle their differences in time for the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY POLICE CHIEF VISITS MAINLAND CHINA TO BOOST COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Police Bureau Director Chen Jui-tung traveled to Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian Province Monday via the direct "mini three links" route as part of his efforts to promote crime-fighting cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen is among the 13 members of a delegation organized by the Association of Friends of the Kinmen County Police. The mission, headed by Lee Hsi-jung, includes several other senior and middle-ranking Kinmen police officers.
"We hope the visit will contribute to the establishment of a Kinmen-Xiamen crime-fighting cooperative mechanism, " Chen said prior to his departure for Xiamen.

Chen is the second Kinmen police chief to visit Xiamen since Taiwan legalized direct trade, postal and shipping links between its two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's cities of Xiamen and Mawei -- commonly known as "mini three links" -- on Jan. 2, 2001 via the "mini three links" route. It took eight months for Chen to complete the administrative formalities for his current five-day mainland visit.
As Kinmen lies closer to Xiamen than to Taiwan, Chen said he hopes to forge active cooperative ties with Xiamen in fighting against drug trafficking and the smuggling of humans and contraband goods.

One of Taiwan's top 10 most wanted fugitives, Wu Tze-yuan, reportedly resides in Xiamen, and Xiamen law enforcement authorities announced earlier this month that they have uncovered a telephone fraud ring and several human smuggling suspects allegedly connected with Taiwan criminal gangs.

Chen said these issues are not on his agenda for his discussion with Xiamen police authorities during his ongoing visit, but he added that he may try to learn more about Xiamen's crime-fighting operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY OF PHILIPPINE FOREIGN SECRETARY TRANSPORTED BACK TO MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The body of Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary Blas Fajaredo Ople was airlifted back to Manila Sunday night from Taipei where he had been pronounced dead after doctors had tried in vain to save him with emergency treatment.

Under the escort of his wife, daughter and a number of Philippine officials, Ople's body was transported from Taipei to Manila by a Philippine Airlines plane. The aircraft arrived at Manila Airport at around 8:50 p.m.

On hand to meet Ople's coffin at the airport included members of the diplomatic corps in Manila, senior officials from the Philippine Presidential Office, senior officials from the Philippine Foreign Affairs Department, as well as Republic of China liaison officials posted in Manila.
Ople, 75, died of an apparent heart attack on a Japan Asia Airways flight from Tokyo en route to Bahrain late Saturday night.

Ople suffered a fit of dry coughing followed by breathing difficulties before the situation turned critical aboard JAA flight 707. The flight crew attempted to resuscitate Ople while the plane diverted its course and flew to Taiwan's CKS International Airport for an emergency landing.

Doctors at the airport then rushed Ople to Minsheng Hospital in Taoyuan after giving him emergency treatment despite finding that the Philippine minister had been showing no signs of life. The hospital medical staff pronounced Ople dead on arrival at around 11 p.m. Saturday.
The Philippine minister's final destination was to have been Manama, Bahrain, as part of the advance team ahead of Philippine President Gloria Arroyo's official visit.
On behalf of the Republic of China government, Wu Hsin-hsing, Taiwan's representative in Manila, expressed condolences to Ople's family and said that the ROC government has done everything it could.

Officials from the Philippine Foreign Affairs Department, meanwhile, expressed gratitude to Taiwan for its help, particularly to Lin Sung-huan, director-general of the Asia-Pacific Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and his colleagues.

Ople had been a senator for 10 years and chairman of the Senate's Foreign Affairs Committee before becoming foreign affairs secretary July 30, 2002. He had demonstrated his friendship toward Taiwan since he became a senator and supported Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization based on humanitarianism.
