DOC.HEADLINE: ASHES OF FIVE DECEASED BURIED AT SEA UNDER AEGIS OF TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, family members of five diseased individuals fulfilled the wish of their loved ones for a burial at sea under a trial project promoted by the Taipei City Government.
Taipei City Government Bureau of Social Affairs Director Ku Yen-lin apologized to the family members for the red tape involved in the process.
Ku said that the bureau had been too optimistic to think that as long as the procedure was legal, no problem would arise, but the lack of a deep sea port in Taipei caused trouble.

Taipei City officials noted that the city is surrounded by Taipei County, and that the Taipei City Government had originally hoped to have the ship leave from Sanchi, Taipei County, but the application was rejected by the county, mainly because the use of entertainment ships for burials at sea are incompatible with their purpose of seafaring and contradict management regulations.

Although sea burials have been in use for years among the private sector, the Taipei City Government was the first official agency to advocate the environmentally friendly idea. The response was good with one of the five deceased from four households coming from Taipei and the farthest from Kaohsiung County.

However, the scheduled time and venue kept changing Monday, and the ritual was only able to be accomplished in the evening after Taipei City Government officials and media withdrew from the process and the final venue and ship owner were not disclosed.
The Taipei City Government implored the Taipei County Government not to prosecute the ship owners.

Meanwhile, a liner that has cooperated closely with the Taipei City Government took the initiative to call the city government to say that if there is a big demand for sea burials, then the liner is willing to be of service.
The Taipei City Government said that the city government will observe the situation to decide whether to continue with sea burials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MADE PDAS ENJOY GOOD SALES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to manufacture a total of 6.18 million units of PDAs for the whole of this year, representing a 1.5-fold increase year-on-year to account for about 50 percent of the entire world's production, an industry source said Monday.

Pang Shih-chao, deputy director at the Market Intelligence Center under the Institute for Information Industry, estimated that Taiwan-based contractors will put out around 6.18 million PDAs for 2003, thanks to handsome orders placed by top corporate clients such as Palm.

Taiwan's PDA production will continue to increase in the coming four years at a slow pace of 5 percent growth per year, despite a sluggish international demand for the hi-tech device since 2002, Pang predicted.

In an effort to catch up with the newest trends for sustainable survival, Taiwan makers have to focus on diversification and more durable products, Pang suggested. He forecast that advanced wireless PDA modes featuring Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, GPS and GSM/GPRS will prevail in the global market from the second half of next year.

On the other hand, many leading brand names are seeking to lower their production costs and reduce their products' time to market to cope with the market of conventional PDA products which have come of age, he said.

Out of such considerations to attract new customers for low-end PDAs, Taiwan contractors are able to edge out foreign competitors to gain orders from leading companies mainly because of their strong research and development capabilities and high level of manufacturing skills, he explained, noting that Taiwan has now become an international production hub for PDAs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FLIGHTS SET TO FLY TO AND FROM MAINLAND DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: Local carriers have lined up 60 extra flights between Taiwan and Hong Kong, or Taiwan and Macau during the Chinese Lunar New Year to serve Taiwan businessmen in the mainland in light of the fact that the plan for charter flights between Shanghai and Taiwan is still surrounded by uncertainty.
The extra 60 flights will provide an additional 18,000 seats on these route before and after the Chinese Lunar New Year which falls on Jan. 22.

To ease the shortage of flight tickets on these two routes during this traditional family reunion season, China Airlines will provide 40 additional flights, while EVA Airways will put on eight flights on the Taiwan-Hong Kong route and seven flights on its Taiwan-Macau route.
TransAsia Airways, which provides service between Taiwan and Macau, has not yet decided how many flights it will add during the holiday season, probably two to four.

The extra flights will help cope with the heavy traffic during this time of the year between Taiwan and mainland China when Taiwanese businessmen in the mainland flock back to their homeland in Taiwan before the Lunar New Year and return to their mainland businesses afterward.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ZERO-SUM GAME IN U.S. DEALING WITH CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday progress in Washington-Beijing relations doesn't mean a retreat in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Chien made the remarks in a special report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee on Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of a meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Wen Jiabao at the White House Dec. 9.
Chien said Bush called mainland China a "diplomatic partner" in a ceremony welcoming Wen, indicating close Washington-Beijing interaction in the diplomatic arena.
Nevertheless, Chien said, the United States has traditionally adopted a "parallel" approach, rather than a zero-sum game strategy, in dealing with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Against this backdrop, he noted, advancement in U.S.-mainland China ties doesn't necessarily mean a regression in Taipei-Washington relations.

Chien told lawmakers that Bush had unequivocally conveyed several messages during Wen's first official visit to the United States, including that the U.S. "one China" policy based on the Washington-Beijing joint communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act has remained unchanged; the United States does not support Taiwan independence and is opposed to either side of the Taiwan Strait taking unilateral action to change the status quo.
In his view, Chien said, Bush's messages carried two purposes.

"On the one hand, Bush reminded Wen that if Beijing uses force against Taiwan, the United States would have to get involved. On the other, Bush reminded Taiwan that the United States is opposed to Taiwan taking any unilateral action to change the status quo, " Chien explained.
Touching on the U. S. concern about Taiwan's "defensive referendum" plan, Chien said the two sides do not coincide in their considerations.

"While Taiwan considers the referendum issue from the perspective of strengthening its young democracy and opposing mainland China's missile threat, the United States is most concerned about maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and easing cross-strait tensions," Chien said.

Noting that the United States has reaffirmed its security commitment to Taiwan in the Bush-Wen meeting, Chien said the Bush administration would not like to see any escalation of cross-strait tension simply because of Taiwan's referendum, which might force Washington to get involved in a cross-strait conflict.

Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will continue to communicate with U.S. authorities through various channels. "We'll convince U.S. authorities that the planned referendum is meant to reinforce our democratic system and maintain peace and the status quo in the Taiwan Strait."

Chien said MOFA will do its utmost to put forth the point that since the referendum will not touch on the subject of independence or unification nor will it breach President Chen Shui-bian's promise of not to change Taiwan's official name and national flag, it will not violate U.S. strategic interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

MOFA will also seek to have the United States and the international community understand that mainland China's insistence on its "one China" and "one country, two systems" premises, as well as its refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and its continued military build-up against Taiwan are the main obstacles to resumption of peaceful cross-strait dialogue and the alleviation of cross-strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO ADOPT RESOLUTION URGING BEIJING TO DISMANTLE MISSILES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's various political parties have presented proposals to the Legislative Yuan, hoping that it will pass a resolution urging Beijing to dismantle hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party each has their own proposal.

The proposal from the opposition parties said that although the two sides of Taiwan Strait have enjoyed economic and cultural exchanges over the last 15 years, the military confrontation has impeded the two sides from reaching detente. They also said that the Republic of China (ROC) is a country with sovereignty and its status should not be changed by outside force.

Furthermore, mainland China's deployment of nearly 500 missiles targeting Taiwan is not only a threat to the island, but also makes the Taiwan Strait a hot spot in the Asia-Pacific region, the proposal said.

Taiwan people hope mainland authorities do not deploy new missiles targeting the island in the future, and desire that the existing missiles be dismantled in phases to usher in an era of reconciliation, the proposal added.
Meanwhile, the DPP proposal urged Beijing to respect the ROC's sovereignty and Taiwan people's determination to pursue democracy and peace.
The Legislative Yuan will make a final resolution Tuesday based on these proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT MEETS ASIA FOUNDATION HEAD

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu met Asia Foundation President William P. Fuller Monday at the Presidential Office and thanked Fuller for the foundation's assistance and support in Asia's development, including Taiwan.

Lu said she hoped for strengthened and enhanced relations between Taiwan and the foundation and exchanged opinions with Fuller on bilateral cooperation and on issues related to democratization and law and order in Taiwan and the rest of Asia.

The vice president also touched on topics pertaining to Taiwan women's status in society. Citing the results of a recent survey by a magazine, she told Fuller that about 70 percent of the Taiwan people think women perform better than men in the workplace, while some 90 percent of the female respondents are confident that they are more capable then their male peers.

For his part, Fuller said he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's progress in gender equality and thanked Taiwan for its friendship. He promised to further step up cooperation with Taiwan and help train talented individuals for this country.
The United States-based Asia Foundation seeks to promote greater understanding between Asians and Americans in the hope of building a strengthened U.S.-Asia relationship.

The International Herald Tribune: Under questioning, he's 'not remorseful at all'.
The wild gray beard was gone and he sat on a metal army cot, just awake from a nap, in socks and black slippers. He was not handcuffed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Betrayal by clan led to Hussein's capture
The hunt for Saddam Hussein ended late Saturday with information from a member of his tribal clan. At 8:26 p.m. Saturday, less than 11 hours after receiving the decisive tip, 600 American soldiers and Special Operations forces backed by tanks, artillery and Apache helicopter gunships surrounded two farmhouses, and near one of them found Mr. Hussein hiding alone at the bottom of an eight-foot hole. He surrendered without a shot. "He was just caught like a rat, " Maj. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the commander of the Fourth Infantry Division, told reporters at his headquarters in Tikrit on Sunday. "
The Wall Street Journal: Dramatic seizure changes reality from Baghdad To the White House
The capture of Saddam Hussein by U.S. forcess ends a brutal era of Iraqi history and gives a huge boost to the American occupation and Iraqis who support it.
While the capture gives a huge political lift to President Bush, it also injects new volatility into the fight against an increasingly violent anti-American insurgency. Meanwhile, political forces inside the country, ranging from Shiite Muslims in the south to the U.S.-appointed Governing Council in Baghdad, have already stepped up the intensity of their jockeying for power once the U.S. steps aside.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SET UP SYSTEM TO EVALUATE LABOR BROKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) promised Monday to craft a mechanism to evaluate manpower agencies to root out unscrupulous ones and rein in the steady rise in the number of runaway foreign laborers.
CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu made the promise during a Legislative Yuan Budget Committee meeting where many lawmakers demanded the CLA tighten management of labor imports and maintain job market order.

Chen said the phenomenon of foreign workers absconding from their jobs before the expiry of their work contracts can be attributed to a combination of factors, including unfair treatment by employers, exploitation by labor brokerages and personal relationships of individual alien workers.
Chen acknowledged that some unscrupulous manpower agencies have earned illegal profits by recruiting runaway foreign laborers to work as caregivers at local hospitals.
Chen said the CLA is developing a viable system to evaluate manpower agencies to prevent illegal activities by brokers for runaway foreign workers.

Moreover, she went on, the CLA has been carrying out a campaign since September to repatriate runaway foreign workers in cooperation with police authorities. Under the program, the CLA has asked foreign labor supply countries to offer incentives, such as flight tickets and cancellation of runaway records, to encourage absconded foreign workers to surrender themselves.
"The campaign has yielded initial results, " Chen said, adding that the CLA will continue to investigate illegal hiring of foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Saddam captured.
Saddam Hussein was sitting -- unhandcuffed -- in a small, spartan room in a secret location near Baghdad yesterday when four members of the Iraqi Government Council (IGC) arrived to identify him.
Financial Times: 'The tyrant is a prisoner'.
Saddam Hussein was in the custody of US forces last night after the biggest breakthrough for Washington's faltering efforts to rebuild Iraq since it toppled the dictator eight months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIEVES MAKES AWAY WITH NT$27 MILLION FROM BANK VAULT

TEXT.P: Thieves used the cover of an adjacent construction site to make off with NT$27 million (US$793,814) from the vault of a bank in Taipei City over the weekend.

Clerks of the Wanhua Branch in Taipei City of the Hua Nan Commercial Bank returned to work Monday morning to discover a 50 centimeter hole in the bank's vault and NT$27 million cash, an undisclosed amount of U.S. dollars and U.S. travel checks missing.
Police rushed to the scene only to find a knife and hundreds of footprints and palm prints.

They suspected a coordinated group was involved in the theft. Entry appeared to have been made through a firebreak alley separating the bank from an adjacent building which was undergoing construction. The group had broken through three heavy iron grates to get to the wall of the vault.
Jackhammers must has been employed to break the hole since neighbors reported the sound of them being used over the weekend.
The bank's alarm was triggered, but a security guard sent to investigate found nothing out of the ordinary and left the scene.

The case is similar to a burglary that took place on Sept. 9 last year at a branch office of the First Credit Cooperation in Taipei, in which burglars made off with NT$16 million (US$470,408). Another break-in took place on Nov. 3, 2002 at the Luchu Branch in Kaohsiung of the Chang Hwa Bank.

In both cases, the burglars entered the banks from empty adjacent buildings during the weekend and bored a hole in the vault of one bank and opened the safe of another bank with an oxyacetylene torch.
Police believed at least five people are involved in the cases but no arrests have been made.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS SEEMS SLIM FOR CHARTER PLANE SERVICES FOR LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: The charter plane service designed to make it easier for Taiwan businessmen to return home from mainland China for the coming lunar new year might not be profitable, despite better conditions provided by Taiwan and mainland China this year to forge agreement on the issue, business sources said Monday.

It will be very difficult for any carriers planning to offer the service to attract passengers now, as the traditional peak season is fast approaching and tickets on cross-Taiwan Strait flights via Hong Kong or Macau are already nearly fully booked, the sources said.
Pointing out that politics are preventing the two sides from starting negotiations, the sources said the aviation companies are waiting to see whether the political complications can be settled.

Mainland China is willing to allow Taiwan-based carriers to transport Taiwan businessmen from Shanghai, Beijing and elsewhere as necessary during the period between Jan. 9 and Feb. 2, which represents an increase of nine days over the year-earlier period.
However, the political dispute makes it impossible for the necessary negotiations to take place, the sources noted.

Taiwan insists that such talks must be held through government-led channels, while the mainland stands firm on its position that negotiations can be conducted by the private sector and that mainland-based carriers must be allowed to participate in the service.
Last year, the historic charter flight services were not profitable for the six carriers involved, including China Airlines and Far East Air Transport Corp.

With the Chinese new year just around the corner, aviation companies have gone into full gear to offer additional flights on the popular Taiwan-Hong Kong and Taiwan-Macau routes, coupled with flights on the newly established routes through third locations such as Japan's Okinawa and South Korea's Cheju.
As many mainland-based Taiwan businessmen have already booked their homecoming trips, the belated efforts to promote charter plane services might prove unfruitful, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN TAKE PART IN SUBCONTRACTING FOR IRAQI RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not been included on a 63-nation list unveiled by the United States that will be allowed to take part in Iraq's reconstruction, but it will be allowed to take part in subcontracting work, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday.
Chien made the remarks while fielding questions in the Foreign Affairs Committee at the Legislative Yuan.

Hsiao Bi-khim of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked why Taiwan, a staunch supporter of the U.S.-led war on Iraq in March, was not included on the list, while Taiwan's ally Costa Rica is on the list.
Chien said the ministry contacted the nation's representative office in the United States upon learning about the list, and the representative office then contacted the U.S. Defense Department.

The U.S. told the representative office that all 63 countries on the list had joined the U.S. coalition or supported the U.S.-led action in Iraq, while countries like Nicaragua and Honduras also sent peacekeeping forces to Iraq.

According to Chien, although Taiwan is providing humanitarian assistance to Iraq, it is directed toward refugees and the country has not sent troops to take part in the peacekeeping, hygiene or construction works, which is why Taiwan is not on the list.
But Chien said the U.S. stressed that the list is only for major contractors and there will be no problem for Taiwan taking part in subcontracting work.

However, Hsiao noted that Taiwan strongly supported the U.S.-led military operations in Iraq and that the legislative committee had hoped that Taiwan could take part in post-war reconstruction. It is hard to accept that Taiwan has been shut out of Iraq's long-term reconstruction work, a move which also "falls far short of the expectations of the committee," Hsiao said.

She said that the Foreign Ministry should work toward soliciting the right to take part in Iraq's reconstruction and should not allow mainland China to use the referendum issue to mislead the United States and undermine Taiwan's cooperation with the United States.

Legislator Parris Chang of the DPP also said that Taiwan has repeatedly told the United States that its holding of a "defensive referendum" in March to coincide with the presidential election is not an attempt to change the status quo, and he asked why the United States is still "refusing to listen."

Hsiao said that U.S. President George W. Bush's warning on Taiwan's referendum plan shows a different perception of the issue than Taiwan's and asked if this is a communication problem and the result of sending the wrong messages.

Chien said that Taiwan sees referendum as a move toward strengthening its democracy, while the United States is focusing on regional security and stability, which is two different stances. The referendum idea is also a new issue that needs "more communication and understanding," said Chien.

The foreign minister said that after Bush's warning, Taiwan has conveyed to the United States via various channels that President Chen Shui-bian has no intention of changing the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, is not planning to hold a referendum on reunification or independence, and does not want to affect the peace in the Taiwan Strait.

The United States, said Chien, is basically taking a "parallel approach toward handling cross-strait relations, " which he said is not a zero-sum game. Friendly relations between Washington and Beijing do not mean a regression of relations between Taiwan and the United States, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET UNVEILS YOUTH APPRENTICESHIP PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Cabinet unveiled a youth apprenticeship program Monday as part of its efforts to help young high school and college graduates land jobs.

Under the program, the government will offer subsidies for local companies to recruit 2,000 young graduates to work as apprentices. The unprecedented program will call for an outlay of more than NT$100 million.
Each youth hired under the program will be able to receive a monthly subsidy of at least NT$8,000 and will work for up to six months.
The program was jointly organized by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the National Youth Commission and the Council of Labor Affairs.
Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said the program is designed to help young graduates obtain work-based training as inexperience is the biggest obstacle facing fresh graduates looking for work.
"The program will also help narrow the gap between school education and the expertise or skills needed by local enterprises, " Lin said.

Noting that about 66 percent of employees hired under the government's NT$20 billion public service expansion programs were middle-aged or elderly workers, Lin said the new youth apprenticeship program will focus on helping graduates of senior high schools, vocational schools and universities aged between 18 and 29.

The National Youth Commission (NYC) has approved applications by 114 local companies to offer apprenticeship opportunities. Among them are many noted information technology firms, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., as well as large convenience store chains, five-star tourist hotels and banks. They have offered a total of 3,918 apprenticeship vacancies.

NYC officials said they hope that at least 50 percent of those who are recruited under the apprenticeship program will land formal jobs within a year after they finish the work-based training program.

The officials encouraged hopefuls to apply for the apprenticeship opportunities on the Internet (www.career.com.tw/speed/) . Each hopeful can list up to five preferred choices, with successful applicants set to begin work in January.

Meanwhile, Lin said the jobless rate in November was 4.72 percent. "If the unemployment rate can drop to 4.52 percent for December, then this year's jobless rate will fall below the 5 percent mark, " Lin said.
While Taiwan has many jobless people, Lin said, local companies have 80,000 vacancies. "Relevant government agencies must work closely to resolve this contradictory situation," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMOTES COMPUTER RECYCLING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a recycled computers donation ceremony Monday, saying that he hopes Taiwan can become not just an information giant but also "a country with love."

To reduce the digital divide between urban and rural areas and to promote the idea of recycling, a campaign organized by the Office of the President, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, as well as the Institute for Information Industry, has been under way for some time and has received an enthusiastic response from the private sector. A total of 571 recycled computers were collected under the campaign.

Chen expressed gratitude to those who have donated these recycled computers, which will be sent to several underprivileged groups around Taiwan, including nursing homes for the elderly, elementary schools in remote areas and rehabilitation centers.

In the ceremony held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, a group of elementary students played music on recycled musical instruments, wearing Christmas decorations made of recycled plastic juice bottles and paper boxes.

In September, Chen went to an elementary school in a remote area of Taichung County to donate recycled computers and said at the time that he was pleased to see that many students living in remote areas have excelled in computer software design competitions.
On Friday, Chen announced that the campaign results have so far reached their targets and he urged the sponsors to continue the donations as a way of expressing love to the underprivileged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DISMISSES SEF RESHUFFLE SPECULATION AS SHEER NONSENSE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen ruled out the possibility Monday that the government will reshuffle the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and appoint former President Lee Teng-hui as its chairman.

Tsai was responding to a question from opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lee Ching-hua at a Legislative Yuan Interior Affairs Committee meeting about the possibility of Lee replacing Koo Chen-fu as SEF chairman.
"The possibility is nil. The government doesn't have any plans to reshuffle the SEF," Tsai said categorically.

Stressing that the government highly respects Koo and treasures the contributions he has made to the promotion of relations across the Taiwan Strait since he assumed the post, Tsai said any speculation about a shakeup of the SEF leadership is pure nonsense.
"I don't think a senior lawmaker such as yourself should even have bothered to raise the question," Tsai added sarcastically.
The SEF is a semi-official intermediary body authorized by the government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties.
Lee Ching-hua's PFP colleague, Legislator Sun Da-chien, brought up the issue for the first time at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee earlier in the day.

While questioning Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Sun claimed that the U.S. reaction to President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on Beijing's missile threat to Taiwan on the day of the next presidential election was partly prompted by another of Chen's plans -- namely to invite former President Lee, an outspoken critic of Beijing's military threat toward Taiwan and a strong advocate of Taiwan's separate identity, to serve as the new SEF chairman.

In addition, Sun alleged that Chen will urge Beijing to allow its quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue with the SEF under the premise of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait."
Chien declined to respond to Sun's question, on the grounds that mainland affairs are none of his business.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a pro-independence party which names Lee as its "spiritual leader, " dismissed the PFP lawmakers' speculation as a ploy to drive wedges into the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the TSU and other pro-independence groups.

Hsiao Kuan-yu, director of the TSU's social development department, said Lee would be unlikely to take any post in an official or quasi-official agency. "Lee is now focusing on promoting Taiwan's transformation into a full and normal democratic country, " Hsiao said.
Hsiao claimed that the PFP lawmakers deliberately fabricated the SEF reshuffle report in an attempt to undermine Chen's re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 5TH IN OVERALL COMPETITIVENESS: WEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall competitiveness ranks fifth globally in a report released in November by the prestigious World Economic Forum (WEF) , Presidential Office Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said Monday.
The WEF also ranked Taiwan for the second year as the most competitive country in Asia, showing that the world is positive about Taiwan's business environment, Chiou said.

Meanwhile, he said, Britain's Economist Information Unit in its latest quarterly report on global outlook ranked Taiwan's business environment as 17th globally, up four notches from the previous quarter. Taiwan also ranked third in Asia, behind only Singapore and Hong Kong.
On business environment outlook, Taiwan was listed as "very good" among the top 16 countries, especially in the areas of tax and foreign investment policies.

Chiou made the remarks at a signing ceremony to commission five international asset management consultant companies to operate Taiwan's pension funds for civil servants, military personnel and teachers.

Chiou said that Taiwan wants to create the best environment to persuade other countries to come to Taiwan and will reach out to the world, adding that the commissioning of foreign consultancy companies is a step in that direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF VIETNAM-BOUND PASSENGERS ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The number of Vietnam-bound travelers from Taiwan has increased significantly recently, with most airlines making additional flights or using larger aircraft to serve the additional passengers, who include Vietnamese brides and workers living in Taiwan, according to sources within the travel industry.

The number of travelers from Taiwan to Vietnam reached 220,000 last year, which was not considered a high number. However, with the increase of the number of Vietnamese brides and workers in Taiwan, as well as businessmen and Vietnam-bound U.S. tourists making flight transfers here, most of the six major domestic and Vietnamese carriers serving the route have reached full occupancy.

Although the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year in Taiwan badly affected Taiwan's tourism, Vietnam-bound travelers in the first 11 months registered a similar level as in the same period of last year.
China Airlines and EVA Airways have already increased their flights to serve the increasing number of passengers, while Far East Air Transport and UNI Airways plan to follow suit.
It is estimated that the number of Vietnam-bound visits this year may exceed the level of 2002, making it the only profitable route among Taiwan's routes to Indochina and Southeast Asia.
Domestic Vietnam-bound carriers fly mainly to Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City and Danang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL SERVICE MINISTRY OUTSOURCES TO INTERNATIONAL ASSET MANAGERS

TEXT.P: The Public Service Pension Fund (PSPF) run by the Ministry of Civil Service outsourced a total of US$500 million Monday to five international asset management firms for overseas investment.

The Management Board of the PSPF forged contracts with Barclays Global Investors Ltd., State Street Bank & Trust Co., J.P. Morgan Investment Management Inc., UBS Global Asset Management (Singapore) Ltd. and Allianz Dresdner Asset Management of America L.P. in a joint signing ceremony held at the Examination Yuan, becoming the first government fund in Taiwan to undertake overseas discretionary operations.

Under the terms of the contracts, each of the five international asset management companies will be allocated an outsourcing fund of US$100 million for a tenure of two years, while Citibank has been awarded the custodian contract for overseas investment, for a tenure of four years.

In an address at the ceremony, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said the five firms were selected and contracted in accordance with the government's outsourcing policy and in a move to improve asset management expertise, diversify investment risk and implement asset allocation in order to increase investment profit.

According to Minister of Civil Service Wu Rong-ming, an evaluation panel comprising scholars and experts took over two months to verify the management plan proposals, including 12 for international indexed equity mandate, 14 for the international balanced mandate and six for custodian, which were submitted by the candidates from 26 asset management companies and six custodian banks.
Based on a short-list drawn up from the results of oral presentations, the panel completed the selection process a few days ago after implementing the tender and contract negotiations, Wu said.

Through keen competition, the two contracts for international indexed equity mandate were awarded to Barclays Global and State Street, while the three international balanced mandate contracts were awarded to J.P. Morgan, UBS Global and Allianz Dresdner, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 65.92 points to close at 5,924.24.
The bourse opened at 5,910.92 and fluctuated between 5,924.24 and 5,874.06 during trading.

Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with textile issues moving down 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks and electrical shares moving up the most, both at 1.4 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT IMPLEMENTS TEMPERATURE-TAKING POLICY

TEXT.P: Taipei City Government implemented a temperature-taking policy Monday as part of efforts to ward off a possible resurgence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Any person visiting Taipei City Government offices or city government-run medical facilities is now required to have their temperature taken upon entry, Taipei City Department of Health officials said. Those who are discovered to have a temperature of 38 degrees Celsius or higher will be denied entrance and advised to see a doctor, they added.

Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who had his temperature taken upon entering his office Monday, called for all Taipei citizens to develop the habit of taking their temperature on a daily basis and washing their hands frequently to help wipe out the virus that causes the disease.

The temperature-taking policy was implemented on the recommendation of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under Taiwan's Department of Health and in line with similar measures put in place by schools in Taipei from Monday.

The CDC last week advised schools and education institutes of all levels as well as private businesses and organizations to kick off the temperature-taking policy Monday as a nationwide SARS prevention and control campaign restart.
Local health officials are on their guard against SARS, one of whose early symptoms is fever, as winter is the peak season for the flu.

Taipei was the hardest hit area in the SARS outbreak in Taiwan between March and July of this year. Two hospitals in the city were forced to close during the height of the outbreak because of cross-infection of the disease within the hospitals.
SARS claimed the lives of 37 of the 346 people who were infected with the disease in Taipei, and took a heavy toll on the country's economy before it was contained in July.
Meanwhile, a CDC official said at the Legislative Yuan that medical supplies for use in SARS prevention and treatment are in sufficient stock.

CDC Chief Secretary Chen Ying-hui said that as of the end of November, the country's stock of SARS related medical materials included 19.59 million regular surgical masks, 4.81 million N95 masks, 3.51 million anti-SARS medical outfits and more than 2,000 negative-pressure-ward beds, enough to be used by the general public, health care workers and patients for 40-59 days if SARS strikes again.
He added that the CDC has also signed contracts with private companies for extra supplies if the need arises.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 15, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino-American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REITERATES ITS SUPPORT FOR DOHA ROUND TRADE TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 15(CNA) (By Neil Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China trade official in Geneva on Monday reiterated the nation's position in support of the multilateral trading system of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the Doha Round trade negotiations.

Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, expressed clearly Taiwan's position while making an official statement at the WTO General Council Meeting, which is being held in Geneva to discuss issues related to the process of the Doha Round trade negotiations.

In the statement, Yen not only voiced Taiwan's support for an early resumption of the Doha Round trade talks but also suggested that the WTO should reform its mechanism as well as strengthen the function and authority of its secretariat and director-general.

Well-placed sources in Geneva have said that based on the principle of trade liberalization, Taiwan will support getting the Doha Round trade talks back on track but will also stand firm in protecting Taiwan farmers' interests in the sensitive WTO agricultural trade negotiations.

WTO General Council Chairman Carlos Perez del Castillo has actively conducted intensive consultations with different negotiating groups and governments of main WTO members during the past two months in order to re-establish the momentum and confidence in the Doha Round talks after the Cancun Ministerial Conference ended inconclusively in September.

Indicating in a report he made at Monday's General Council meeting, Castillo said that after two rounds of consultations, "there is a strong sense of commitment to the multilateral trading system and the Doha Development Agenda, and also of willingness to move forward.'

However, he also that "we have witnessed little real negotiation, or movement towards accommodation among the different positions, or searching for common ground, with some limited but welcome exceptions."

"Gaps remain wide, not only among the different positions but also between generalized statements of commitment, engagement and flexibility on the one hand, and any concrete manifestation of those statements in negotiating positions on the other," he added.

While pointing out that all the members have a strong willingness to resume the Doha Round trade talks, WTO Director-General Supachai Panitchpakdi also said at the meeting that the most important thing is to turn that willingness into action.

Of the 39 member states that have made statements at the meeting, most of them, including the United States and the European Union, have clearly expressed their position of support for the resumption of the Doha Round trade talks at the beginning of next year.
The goal of the current General Council meeting is to end the deadlock in the Doha Round and to have the negotiations continue.
