DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VIEW OF TAIWAN ISSUE COINCIDES WITH THAT OF U.S.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was quoted as saying at a meeting of his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday that the party's view of the Taiwan issue coincides with that of the United States.

In an attempt to play down the differences between his government and the United States over his call for a referendum, Chen was cited by DPP member Kao Chih-peng as saying that the remarks made by U.S. President George W. Bush after his talks with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao had two points -- that neither side of the Taiwan Strait should change the status quo unilaterally and that Beijing should not try to sort out its differences with Taiwan by force.

Chen reportedly told his DPP comrades that he fully supports Bush's views and that his call for a referendum urging Beijing to stop aiming missiles at Taiwan is designed to send a message to the world that Taiwan is determined to maintain the status quo in terms of its ties with Beijing and to prevent it from being changed unilaterally with coercion.

According to Kao, who was present at the meeting, Chen said that the United States has stood by Taiwan during its democratic development and should not stand in the way of a referendum that will cement the country's democracy.

Concerned that Chen is using the referendum to justify his attempts to separate from China, the United States has warned Taipei in no uncertain terms against pushing the envelope, but Chen has refused to budge. Instead, he has gone to great lengths to assure the United States that his referendum will reinforce the status quo rather than upset it.
Kao said that many of the top-level DPP members at the meeting shared the president's view, but felt that Taiwan should make greater efforts to get the message across.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL PREDICTS RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resume talks after the next March 20 presidential election, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) predicted Tuesday.

In an interview with CNA, SEF Secretary-General Hsi Hwei-yow claimed that the stalemate between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is not due to a lack of communication channels and that the resumption or otherwise of cross-strait talks is a strategy used by Beijing to deal with Taiwan.

Beijing will believe that it is better to hold talks with Taiwan than to allow cross-strait relations to remain idle after the presidential election, according to Hsu, who added that the two sides will drift farther apart without talks.

The SEF, a semi-official organization in charge of dealing with mainland China in the absence of normal relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and its mainland counterpart -- The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- will continue to be the pivotal bodies for cross-strait talks in light of the fact that Beijing continues to transmit its opinions on cross-strait issues to Taiwan via the SEF, he said.

Hsu also suggested that the regulations stipulated in the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area should be flexible because they involve many political factors and considerations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DELEGATION VISITS HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: An industrial delegation from the Japanese city of Kitakyushu visited the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Tuesday to explore the possibility of bilateral cooperation.

The delegation of seven representatives of the Kitakyushu city government and an industrial and academic promotion association in the city, aimed to get a thorough understanding of the development and strategic alliance policy of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the showcase of Taiwan's high-tech sector.

Park administration officials said the park welcomes technical exchanges with Japan as such exchanges would give a major boost to the development of the park, which already maintains strategic alliances with science parks and governments in the United States, Canada, France, Sweden, Spain and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-PERFORMING LOAN RATIO ON CREDIT CARDS HIGH AMONG LOCAL BANKS

TEXT.P: The average ratio of non-performing loans (NPL) on credit cards issued by domestic banks totaled 3.12 percent in October, with six banks of the 53 banks evaluated reaching a credit card NPL rate higher than 20 percent.

According to statistics compiled by the Bureau of Monetary Affairs (BOMA) under the Ministry of Finance, among the 53 domestic credit card issuing banks, four suffered a credit card NPL rate of between 10 and 20 percent; 15 banks registered a NPL rate of between 5 and 10 percent; and 28 banks registered a NPL rate of under 5 percent.
In total, less than half of these banks registered a credit card NPL rate under the average of 3.12 percent, with Chung Hsing Bank registering the highest credit card NPL rate at 42.4 percent.
BOMA deputy director Chang Ming-tao said that those banks that registered a high credit card NPL rate have poor administrative abilities and should press for repayment by borrowers.
The BOMA statistics also show that as of late October, a total of 8.6 million people in Taiwan hold credit cards, with a total of 67.91 million cards issued, 36.63 million of which were being used.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO COOPERATE WITH U.S. IN OFFERING MEDICAL AID

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to form joint medical teams with the United States to offer medical aid to countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen said Tuesday.

Chen said he had discussed the initiative with relevant U.S. officials, including Tommy Thompson, secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, during his recent visit to the United States.
"They all gave positive response to the proposal," Chen said, adding that the two sides will flesh out details for possible cooperative projects in the future.
Chen said Taiwan has assisted its West African ally of Malawi in setting up a central hospital.
"I told American officials that Taiwan is willing to use that hospital to help train medical professionals for other West African countries in AIDS treatment and prevention," Chen said.

For sending personnel to the Malawi hospital for training, Chen said, prospective West African countries can apply for financial aid from the Global Fund, which was initiated by the United States to help Third World countries fight malaria, AIDS and tuberculosis.

"Through this pattern of cooperation, we'll be able to extend our humanitarian concerns and professional medical expertise to countries that do not recognize Taiwan and forge substantive ties with them," Chen said.

During his first formal visit to the United States since assuming office, Chen visited the Agency for Health Research and Quality, the Congressional General Accounting Office and the National Institute of Health and several other U.S. medical institutions to discuss feasible measures to boost bilateral cooperation in health care and medical fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAS FIVE HISTORICAL MISSIONS: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has five historical missions and urged the party members to complete them.

Lu made the remarks at a press conference held at the Presidential Office to mark the reissue of the book "Taiwan: The Past and Future" that she wrote and published 25 years ago. The book was banned by the authorities the year after its original publication.

The DPP's five historical missions are to terminate authoritarian rule, to implement democracy, to achieve the goal of political power transfer between parties, to ensure Taiwanization and to face the challenges brought by globalization.

Apart from the termination of authoritarian rule, Lu said that there still exists room for improvement in the other four aspects in order to create a "normal and perfect country" for the people of Taiwan.

Lu said that she chose Dec. 16 to reissue her book to mark the 25th anniversary of the announcement by former United States President Jimmy Carter that the U.S. government was to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: The New York Times: U.S. troops kill 11 insurgents after ambush.
U.S. troops killed 11 attackers after being ambushed in a town north of Baghdad, the military said Tuesday, and hundreds of Iraqis marched in pro-Saddam Hussein demonstrations in several cities.
The Wall Street Journal: U.N. tackles a changing globe with routines that rarely do.
As the U.N. struggles to redefine itself in a fast-changing world, a central problem is its own ritualized culture and bureaucracy, which seems stuck in another era.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES PLANE MISHAP BLAMED ON PILOT ERROR

TEXT.P: The New Zealand Transport Accident Investigation Commission has concluded that pilot error was the cause of a Singapore Airlines plane mishap in New Zealand earlier this year, the commission announced Monday.
Singapore Airlines has accepted the findings, which pinned the blame on three of its pilots.

The mishap occurred at Auckland Airport on March 12 when an SIA plane's tail caught fire after being damaged and dragged along the runway during takeoff. The plane then made an emergency landing. None of the 369 passengers or crew were hurt.

According to the report, the first officer on Flight SQ286 made a mistake in flight calculations when he keyed into the flight computer a weight figure 100 tons lighter than the plane's actual weight. And the captain of the Boeing 747 did not realize the mistake.
In a statement, SIA added that the emergency procedures followed by the pilots led to the aircraft returning to Auckland safely. It said this was a reflection of the pilots' training and skills.
SIA also apologized for the error and said it will implement the safety recommendations made by the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Bush will let Iraqis decide fate of Saddam.
President George W. Bush said Monday that he had a simple message for the captured Saddam Hussein: "Good riddance, the world is better off without you." He also said he would leave it to the Iraqi people to determine if their former leader should be executed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DEFENSE MINISTRY COMPLEX TO BE ABLE TO WITHSTAND STRONG QUAKE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will have a new home in four years that will be able to withstand a magnitude-7 earthquake, a senior official said Tuesday.

Lt. Gen. Pang Yu-tung, director of the MND's Armament Bureau, told a regular news conference that construction of the ministry's new complex will get underway Thursday on the site of what was originally the Armed Forces University in Taipei's suburban Tachih district.
Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min will preside over a groundbreaking ceremony Thursday, Pang said. Construction is scheduled for completion in 2008.
According to Pang, the new compound will not only accommodate MND units but also the Air Force General Headquarters, which is now located on Jen-Ai Road in downtown Taipei.
Pang said the 19-hectare MND complex, which carries a price tag of NT$13.3 billion, will house three steel buildings plus several other facilities.
The buildings will be designed to withstand blasts and magnetic pulse warfare attacks, as well as a magnitude-7 earthquake, Pang said.

Compared with the Pentagon, home to the U.S. Defense Department, Pang said the new MND complex will occupy a better strategic location as it is located on a hillside. Moreover, he added, the new complex will be in the vicinity of the maximum-security Hengshan military command center. He said the MND might also emulate the Pentagon by installing anti-bombing equipment at the new complex.

For years, Pang said, various MND units have been housed in different areas around Taipei. Noting that the arrangement is inconvenient for peacetime work coordination and could hinder wartime military command and control, Pang said the MND began to plan a new complex back in 1998, with the approval of the Cabinet.

"As the new complex will accommodate both the MND and the Air Force General Headquarters and is close to the Navy General Headquarters, we believe the inauguration of the new complex will help enhance MND operational efficiency and save resources, " Pang said.
In addition to three main buildings and a barracks, the new complex will also have two large squares that can be used as helipads.
Once the complex is completed, a large number of officers and enlisted men will work and live in the region, bringing lucrative business opportunities to the Tachih district, commercial sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVANCE GROUP FROM LIBERAL INTERNATIONAL VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An advance group from Liberal International (LI) visited Kaohsiung City Tuesday to inspect the possible venue for an executive committee meeting slated for March.
The group, led by LI Secretary-General Federica Sabbati, also paid a courtesy call on Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh.
Hsieh claimed credit for convincing LI to hold its executive committee meeting in Kaohsiung when he attended the organization's last annual conference in Senegal in October.
The meeting is slated to begin March 4 and will last for three days.
Founded in 1947, LI is a forum for liberal-minded political parties. It has 84 members from 67 countries.

The organization first came to fame in Taiwan in 2001 when it named President Chen Shui-bian as the winner of its "2001 Prize for Freedom." The prize was accepted on Chen's behalf by his wife, Wu Shu-chen, because Denmark, the country that played host to that year's LI annual conference, refused to issue Chen with a visa to enter the country for fear of offending Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH URGES TAIWANESE TRAVELERS TO ENGAGE IN SAFE SEX

TEXT.P: The Department of the Health (DOH) urged the public Tuesday to practice safe sex to avoid being infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

Lin Tin, deputy director-general of the DOH Center for Disease Control, made the appeal in a press conference at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's gateway to the world, to highlight the safe sex campaign.

Lin said that as of the end of November, 5,125 people in Taiwan were infected with the incurable disease, 16 percent of whom admitted that they had solicited prostitutes. Of this 16 percent, 48.8 percent paid for sex in East Asia or Southeast Asia.

Lin said that the global number of AIDS patients increases by 5 million per year, with Southeast Asia the area of fastest growth. To date, more than 70 million people around the world have AIDS and more than 30 million have died. Every year, there are around 3 million new AIDS fatalities.
The Beijing authorities estimate that in mainland China, the number of AIDS patients is around 850,000 and predict that the figure could reach 10 million by 2010, he said.

He noted that more than 7.319 million Taiwan people traveled overseas last year, 39.2 percent of whom passed through Hong Kong and 20.6 percent of whom passed through Macau. Those passengers often continued on to the mainland.
He urged the public to be on their guard and to wear condoms during sex, warning that up to 10 percent of sex workers in Guangxi Province, southern China, are said to carry the virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH TO REACH 4.12 PERCENT NEXT YEAR: TRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic prospects will improve next year and economic growth is expected to reach 4.12 percent, according to an estimate by the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI).

Wu Tsai-yi, a section chief at the TRI, said Tuesday that if the ten major construction projects planned by the government are approved by the legislature, the public and private investment will represent a major stimulus to the economy.

As the unemployment situation cannot be addressed in short term, the TRI set next year's unemployment rate at approximately 5 percent, but said the growth in domestic consumption is expected to reach 3.04 percent thanks to the economic recovery at home and abroad.

With regard to private investment, which is expected to suffer a negative growth of 3.4 percent this year due to various uncertainties, the country will see an 8.4 percent growth in private investment next year once these uncertainties are cleared up after the March 20 presidential election, according to TRI officials.

As the economy emerges from the shadow of the U.S.-led war on Iraq and the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks, and boosted by global economic recovery, the growth of Taiwan's exports is expected to reach 8.75 percent in 2004.

The TRI also predicted that low interest rates will last for a while until the unemployment situation improves. The Central Bank of China has been keeping interest rates low through market manipulation to ensure sufficient capital supply, according to the officials.

According to the TRI estimate, economic growth this year will reach 3.12 percent and that in the four quarters of next year, they will be 4.02 percent, 4.53 percent, 4.12 percent, and 3.79 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED CINEMA LAW TO GIVE SHOT IN ARM TO SAGGING MOVIE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: A revised cinema law aimed at giving a shot in the arm to the depressed local movie industry passed its final reading in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.

Notable among the changes are incentives to encourage companies to invest in the motion picture industry by crediting their investment against their business income tax. The tax break will be valid for five years after the revision takes effect.

Furthermore, the revised law obliges the government to help the cinema industry when its survival is threatened by imports of foreign movies, such as setting up a fund to offer aid to its workers, marking off theaters for the exclusive screening of domestic movies, or setting a ratio of domestic films to foreign films to be screened at theaters.
Taiwan's domestic movies accounted for 6.73 percent of all movies shown in the country last year and were attended by only 2.21 percent of all moviegoers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABUSED MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES CAN GET WORK PERMIT UNDER NEW RULING

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan residents can apply to work if they have been victims of domestic violence and have obtained a protection order from a court under a new ruling, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said Tuesday.

According to the regulations governing work permits and management of mainland Chinese spouses during their stay in Taiwan, mainland Chinese spouses can stay for six months if they apply to visit Taiwan. If they want to extend their stay, they will have to apply to the Bureau of Immigration.

The regulations also stipulate that mainland Chinese spouses, when apply for work permits, will have to show their papers allowing them to stay and documents that prove that their Taiwan husbands are either low-income, physically or mentally disabled, or afflicted with a major illness.

The Council of Labor said that in addition to the above documents, another document -- which is the protection order from a court -- will also enable abused mainland Chinese spouses to work during their stay in Taiwan.

CLA officials noted that as of the end of October this year, more than 13,000 work permits have been issued to mainland Chinese spouses and they mainly work in the service, wholesale or retail sectors and restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Saddam's last hiding place.
The wooden-framed shaft leading down into the coffin-like hole that was Saddam Hussein's last hiding place is barely wide enough for a man to squeeze through.

DOC.HEADLINE: BONA FIDE VISITORS TO GET VISA FACILITATION: MOFA

TEXT.P: Overseas missions will facilitate the issuance of visas to bona fide visitors and will only target those who intend to work illegally under the cover of students for a more rigorous screening, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Kao An, deputy director-general of MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, said that to encourage international exchanges and foreign students to come to Taiwan to study, MOFA has coordinated related government agencies to adopt a more convenient visa issuing procedure since mid-term this year.

In addition, Kao said that MOFA has since late last year begun to learn related regulations by other countries governing visa issuing to students, such as Canada, the United States, Britain, Japan, Germany, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Singapore and Hong Kong.
Kao said that some countries have been strict in issuing visas, requiring the visitors to be full-time students.

Kao said the issuance of visas by MOFA will not affect those who are bona fide students, and that MOFA is also coordinating with other government agencies to heed the needs of foreign students to create a friendly environment regarding the visa procedure and the duration of their stay.

Larry Wang, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said that he knows 26 students from East Europe have come to Taiwan to learn Chinese under a scholarship program, and eight Polish students and 13 students from the Czech Republic have come to Taiwan to learn Chinese under the scholarship agreement.
Meanwhile, an official of MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs said that rigorous screening of visitors aims to create a favorable study environment.
Kao Kuo-liang, a section chief of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, said that currently foreign students apply to come to Taiwan in two situations.
The first is to apply to Taiwan's overseas missions with an entrance permit issued by a Taiwan university or other necessary documents. The missions will then review whether the visitor is bona fide.
Foreign students will have to get residence cards at their local police stations.

In the second situation, those who have obtained learning certificates from centers or schools can apply to Taiwan's overseas missions for a 60-day visitor visa. When the students enter Taiwan, they will have to go to a police station to have their visas extended, unless they have been marked that their visas are not to be extended. Students can apply to the consular bureau for resident visas after studying for six months.

He said that if foreign laborers, maids and illegal workers extend their stay under the cover of studying Chinese, they will not only waste Taiwan's social resources, but will undermine a favorable studying environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BUILD AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY PARK IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: Taiwan will begin to build an agricultural biotechnology park in Pingtung County early next year, Ting Shan-lung, director of the preparatory office for the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park, said Tuesday.

He said the agricultural park will be composed of two agricultural farms: the Haifung Farm in Changchih village, and the Taiyuan Farm in Fangliao village. The ground-breaking ceremony for Haifung will be held on Feb. 28, 2004.

Occupying an area of 233 hectares, Haifung will be able to accommodate 120 companies upon completion, he said, adding that the government has earmarked NT$12.8 billion for building the agricultural park, the first of its kind in Taiwan.

Five investors have obtained permission to set up production facilities in the park, Ting said, adding that his preparatory office will host receptions soon in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung to introduce the agricultural park to prospective investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITALIZATION LEVEL IN HSINCHU CITY, COUNTY IN TOP FIVE

TEXT.P: The digitalization level of Hsinchu city and county is among the top five in Taiwan cities and counties, the latest figures released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed Tuesday.

The DGBAS has used computers, the Intranet and cellular phones to assess the digitalization level of Taiwan cities and counties. An assessment conducted in 2002 showed that out of 100 households, 66 percent of Hsinchu City has computers, next only to the ratio in Taipei City and Taipei County, and Hsinchu County was in fifth place.

The popularity of the Internet is also a major indicator of digitalization. The figures showed that in every 100 households in Taiwan, 45 percent of the families have the facilities to go to the Internet. The ratio in Taipei is 64 percent, 58 percent in Taipei County, 56 percent in Hsinchu County, and 52 percent in Hsinchu City.

On the popularity of cellular phones, Taipei County and Taoyuan County surpassed 90 percent, while Taipei City ranked third with nearly 90 percent, Hsinchu City was fourth with 88 percent, Hsinchu County was fifth with 86 percent, higher than Keelung, Chiayi, Tainan and Taichung, showing the high level of digitalization of Hsinchu city and county.

DOC.HEADLINE: 55,000 HECTARES OF RICE PADDIES TO LIE FALLOW NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: About 55,000 hectares of rice paddies in the Shihmen and Tsengwen reservoirs irrigation areas will be left fallow next spring to ensure adequate water supplies for household and industrial users, a senior official said Tuesday.

Chen Shen-hsien, director of the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , said the fallow program will help spare the island from water shortages before the onset of the monsoon season next May.
The fallow program was decided upon at a meeting of the MOEA's drought task force, Chen said.

According to Chen, the Shihmen Reservoir in the northern county of Taoyuan has a water storage of about 82 million tons and water storage in the Tsengwen Reservoir in the southern county of Tainan is about 86.4 million tons.

To ensure adequate water supplies for household and industrial use, Chen said some 30,000 hectares of rice paddies in the Shihmen Reservoir irrigation area and 25,000 hectares in the Tsengwen Reservoir area will lie fallow next spring.

The exact scope of affected areas will be announced before the end of this month, Chen said, adding that the government will compensate farmers for their losses. The compensation will range between NT$22,000 and NT$60,000 per hectare depending on the farmland situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF CHEMICAL INDUSTRY TO REACH NT$2.9 TRILLION IN 2008

TEXT.P: The production of Taiwan's chemical industry is expected to reach NT$2.9 trillion (US$85 billion) in 2008, and the percentage of its high value-added products should rise to 40 percent, according to sources from the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).
Cheng Wu-hsiun, chief of ITRI's laboratory on materials and chemical engineering, made the estimation during the inauguration ceremony of the Taiwan Chemical Industry Association.

Cheng noted that the production of the island's chemical and textile industry accounts for 30 percent of the total production of its manufacturing sector, trailing only the electrical and electronics industry.

However, although the production of the chemical industry is quite large, the percentage of its high value-added products only accounts for 20 percent of its total production, compared to the 50 to 60 percent registered by industrially advanced countries.
The chemical industry hopes to increase the percentage of its high value-added products to 40 percent in 2008, Cheng added.
The industry's total production reached NT$1.95 trillion last year, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MARATHON TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI SUNDAY

TEXT.P: More than 7,000 runners will participate in 2003 Hyundai Sanyang Taipei International Marathon on Dec. 21, an official of the Taipei City Government said Tuesday.

He said the marathon will start at 5:30 a.m. from the plaza in front of the Taipei City Government. In addition to the 42.195 kilometer marathon, there will be three shorter races: a 21 kilometer half marathon, a nine kilometer run, and a three kilometer run.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will participate in the 21 kilometer race, the city government official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY SEEN TO GROW 4.26 PERCENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 4.26 percent in 2004, given that the domestic economy has regained momentum since the third quarter of this year, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) reported Tuesday.

The domestic economy gained 4.2 percent in the third quarter of this year after it bottomed out from the economic downturn caused by the U.S.-led war in Iraq and an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year, said CIER President Chen Tian-jy.
CIER researchers believe that the domestic economy will expand at least by 4.26 percent next year judging by all relevant factors, Chen said.

The 2004 growth could even shoot up to 5.06 percent if the global economy continues to grow steadily, Taiwan's politics and cross-Taiwan Strait relations remain stable and no major natural disasters or epidemics occur, Chen added.

According to Chen, CIER researchers forecast that in 2004, consumption in the private sector will grown by 3.06 percent, while investment from the private sector will advance by 6.39 percent, marking the first growth since 2001.
In 2004, the Taiwan currency is expected to maintain a level of around NT$33.80 to US$1, while the unemployment rate will be 4.87 percent, lower than the 2003 average of 5 percent, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE ON CROSS-STRAIT POLITICAL DEVELOPMENTS: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has no timetable on any changes in the political landscape across the Taiwan Strait or the development of cross-strait relations, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday.

Speaking at a news conference for the media from home and abroad, Lien said the "pan-blue alliance, " comprised of the opposition KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , has always maintained that upholding the status quo is the best policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lien, the 2004 presidential candidate of the "pan-blue alliance," said his camp does not support either "extreme unification" of the two sides of the Strait or any rash announcement of Taiwan independence.

The "pan-blue alliance, " however, is resolute in supporting cross-strait dialogue in the hope that the two sides will begin negotiations as early as possible on direct air and shipping links, arms control and other relevant issues, Lien said.

He also said he hoped that the two sides of the Strait will continue to increase business and trade exchanges, while minimizing military threats. Lien said that the "pan-blue alliance" agrees that Beijing should dismantle the missiles targeting Taiwan and has appealed to the leadership across the Strait in this regard several times. Lien said that he does not think it is necessary for Taiwan people to voice their opposition to mainland China's missile deployment in a referendum vote as has been called for by President Chen Shui-bian.
"If the result of a referendum is what everybody already knows, the referendum is simply unnecessary," Lien stressed.
On Taipei-Washington relations, Lien said that all decision-makers in the " pan-blue alliance" believe that U.S.-Taiwan relations are the most important among all of Taiwan's foreign relations.

Lien said if he and his running mate, PFP Chairman James Soong, are elected president and vice president in the March 20, 2004 election, the "pan-blue alliance" will be a government that treasures Taiwan-U.S. relations and will not make any rash moves or flip-flop policy that would undermine the deep relationship that exists.

However, Lien said that as a presidential candidate, he would rather not waste time and energy talking about cross-strait relations, which is an issue that is impossible to solve in the short term. It is also unfair to ask the people to make decisions on the highly thorny political issue in referendums, he added. On the contrary, he said issues pertaining to people's livelihood and welfare, such as unemployment, the domestic economy and social order, are much more important issues for the "pan-blue alliance" to tackle.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also campaign manager for the "pan-blue alliance, " said at the news conference that the cross-strait sovereignty issue is not something for people in Taiwan to solve here and now.
Since the issue should be left for posterity to solve, Wang said that maintaining the status quo of cross-strait relations is the safest and most practical policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.001 to close at NT$34.016.
A total of US$417 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.015 and was traded between NT$34.000 and NT$34.042.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES REGULAR TAIWAN-THAILAND MINISTERIAL TRADE MEETINGS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday met with a Thailand delegation of media and communication specialists and expressed the hope that ministerial-level trade consultations between Taiwan and Thailand can be held regularly.

The president said that he was gratified to learn that a ministerial consultation meeting between Taiwan and Thailand was resumed last year after a hiatus of more than a decade. He also said that he hoping that the meeting could be held like the ones between Taiwan and other Southeast Asian country ministers which is held regularly every year.

The president also said that although Thailand signed an avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of tax evasion agreement with Taiwan in 1999, the agreements have yet to be put into practice, which is a source of concern for many Taiwan businessmen, the president said.
In addition, the president said that Taiwan hopes to sign a temporary admission agreement and fugitive exchange pact with Thailand.

The president cited figures to show how close exchanges between the two countries have been, noting that between 1986 and 2002, Taiwan invested up to US$10.6 billion in Thailand, becoming the third-largest foreign investor in Thailand.
The president also said that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Thailand amounted to US$4.46 billion in 2002, with Thailand enjoying a trade surplus of US$55 million.

He said that Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu visited Thailand late last year to take part in trade consultations with the industry minister in Thailand, which marked a resumption of meetings that were last held in 1991.

The president expressed the hope that the meeting will be held regularly just as the ones between Taiwan and such Southeast Asian nations as Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia.

The president also told his visitors that he was happy to have the Taiwan government take part in a project over the past three decades to help people in northern Thailand plant vegetables, fruits, tea and aid with forestation to replace the original planting of opium poppies and other narcotic plants.

The president also expressed his appreciation for the contribution to Taiwan by Thai workers, noting that they currently stand at more than 110,000, or around 38 percent of all foreign laborers in the country and they have remitted around US$900 million every year back to Thailand. Taiwan appreciates all Thai laborers, whose number has reached 660,000, who have worked in Taiwan, he added.
Taiwan people also made 720,000 visits to Thailand last year, spending US$1 billion there, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 67 points to close at 5,901, with 15,631 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January fell 38 points to finish at 5,914, with 14,190 contract transactions, while March futures lost 42 points to finish at 5,930, with 3 contracts traded.
June futures moved down 57 points to finish at 5,910, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,968 for December, 6,302 for January, 5,972 for March, 5,967 for June, and 5,970 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO CONDUCT FOREIGN SPOUSES CENSUS

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung County Government official urged the central government Tuesday to conduct a nationwide foreign spouse census for reference in formulating social welfare policies.

Wu Li-hsueh, director of the Kaohsiung County Government's Social Affairs Department, said the number of Taiwan men married to foreign women, particularly those from mainland China and Southeast Asian countries, has been increasing steadily.

And many children born to intermarried couples have entered elementary school, Wu pointed out. "We need to learn more about these schoolchildren's adaptability, parental care and study situation, " she said, adding that the government should take an across-the-board census on intermarriage families to serve as reference in formulating welfare policies and measures.
The southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung alone now has more than 16,200 residents who are married to mainland Chinese citizens or foreign nationals. Foreign spouses number nearly 5,000.
"Initial surveys show that many foreign spouses residing in Kaohsiung County are very young, experience language barriers and have limited education," Wu said.

Some foreign women who have married either poor or disabled men or men over the age of 65 tend to run away from their families after they obtain legal working rights, Wu said, adding that the phenomenon has created serious child care and education issues.

Wu said Kaohsiung County Government has organized special study programs to help foreign spouses adapt to local society and lifestyle as soon as possible. "The classes are opened in the Fengshan, Kangshan and Chishan areas where many foreign spouses live, " she added.

Meanwhile, she urged relevant government authorities to rein in manpower agencies specializing in mediating marriages between local men and mainland Chinese or foreign citizens. "Over the years, unscrupulous matchmakers have misled some local people into perceiving intermarriages as business deals, " Wu said, adding that the government should tighten management and supervision of manpower brokerage houses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN FINED FOR ILLEGALLY HIRING MAINLAND CHINESE CITIZEN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court on Tuesday fined a man for illegally hiring a Chinese woman to work in his home.

The court said that the man, surnamed Chu, paid nearly NT$20,000 (US$588.23) monthly between May 13 and July 30 this year to the woman. It fined him NT$30,000, with the option of performing community service for NT$900 a day until the fine is paid off.

The court said that Chu violated Section 4, Article 15 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area which prohibits the hiring or keeping of mainland Chinese citizens to engage in activities that are not previously approved or are incompatible with the purpose of their coming to Taiwan.
The punishment for violators is a prison term of up to two years or a fine of up to NT$300,000, or both.

However, the court, considering the fact that Chu had no prior criminal record, that he hired the mainlander to take care of his elderly mother who was disabled in a car accident and that he cooperated with the police in the case, gave him a lenient sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 37.01 points to close at 5,887.23.
The bourse opened at 5,876.56 and fluctuated between 5,906.77 and 5,871.88 during trading.

A total of 2.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.92 billion (US$1.67 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.62 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$57.49 billion (US$1.69 billion).

Half of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 491 to 258, with 181 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ZEN MASTER TRAVELS TO MIDDLE EAST FOR PEACE

TEXT.P: Zen Buddhist Master Sheng Yen of Taiwan recently traveled to Israel and Palestine in an effort to help put an end to conflict in the area by means of spiritual enlightenment.

Traveling with some 20 world religious leaders, Sheng Yen, a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, hoped to use the power of religion to bridge the differences between the two sides who have been at odds for a long period of time, officials from the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Association (DDMBA) in Taipei said Friday.

During the week-long "spiritual journey" in the Middle East Dec. 9-15, Sheng Yen presented two words -- mercy and wisdom -- to the Israeli and Palistinian people and political leaders as the keys in the pursuit of peace, the officials said.

Sheng Yen called for leadership in both Israel and Palestine to use wisdom to work out solutions to their differences while practicing mercy on all the peoples in the region regardless of their political affiliation or religion so as to not let down the peoples living in the "Holy Land."

Sheng Yen and his party met with Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qureia during a symposium held in Jerusalem Dec. 11. After hearing Sheng Yen's preaching, Qureia reportedly applauded enthusiastically and said to his aides that he looks forward to seeing Master Sheng Yen's suggestions put into practice.

At a colloquium held at the Israeli prime minister's office Dec. 14, Sheng Yen delivered a speech to ranking Israeli officials, including Cabinet officials, parliamentary advisers, and government consultants in news and religious affairs, according to the DDMBA officials.

In his speech, Sheng Yen quoted Islamic doctrine as stipulating that Jihad -- or "Holy War" -- does not mean to strive to defeat others, but instead to defeat one's own evil thoughts. "This is an idea almost the same as the Buddhist concept of conquering the evil in one's mind," Sheng Yen said.
Sheng Yen said he hopes that all the followers of Islam, Judaism or Christianity will reach out their hands to one another so that world peace will prevail.

Master Sheng Yen, author of many Buddhist books, both in Chinese and in English, is respected in Taiwan, mainland China and around the world. As a Zen master, his teachings emphasize that practitioners should in their daily lives be constantly aware of the thoughts circulating in their minds.

Such awareness will allow people to simplify their minds and to clearly perceive the changes in themselves and in their environment, he explained. Wisdom is developed so that people may apply it in their workaday lives to face themselves and to grow, and to dissolve their attachments and enter into a state of "no-self."

Sheng Yen has been actively engaged in inter-faith exchanges that advocate and promote religious understanding. His involvement in such global activities includes being a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders and delivering the keynote address at the 2000 Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders in New York.

In Taiwan, he founded the DDMBA, which now has over one million followers. In the United States, he has been teaching the Buddhadharma since 1975, leading to the founding of two centers, one in New York City and one in Upstate New York.

After concluding the week-long journey in the Middle East, Sheng Yen flew to New York Monday to continue his preaching in North America, which will also take him to Vancouver, Canada, according to the DDMBA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TO ADOPT NEW MEASURES TO ATTRACT FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has worked out a package of measures to attract more foreign citizens to pursue advanced studies in Taiwan, a senior official said Tuesday.

Speaking at a seminar on international educational exchanges and cooperation, Chang Chin-sheng, director of the MOE's Bureau of International Cultural and Education Relations, said the MOE will cooperate with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in setting up a "Taiwan Scholarship" in 2004 to encourage foreign students to pursue advanced studies in Taiwan.
"Our promotional goal is to raise the number of foreign students studying in Taiwan to 15,000 in 2008 from slightly more than 7,300 at present," Chang said.

Some 1,200 foreign students are now pursuing formal academic degrees in Taiwan, Chang said, adding that the government intends to achieve a 15 percent annual growth rate in the number of foreign students pursuing degrees in Taiwan. In terms of this growth rate, the numebr will rise to 3,000 by 2008.

At the moment, 6,048 foreign citizens are studying Chinese language in Taiwan. "We hope to enhance the number by at least 1,000 annually in the coming five years and by 2008, the number of this group of foreign students will rise to 12,000," Chang added.

According to Chang, the "Taiwan Scholarship" will be offered to foreign students studying at local universities or graduate institutes as well as those studying languages in Taiwan. Moreover, he said, the MOFA will offer special purpose scholarships to foreign students.

Chang said the MOE will coordinate with noted local universities in enticing foreign students to pursue advanced studies in certain academic fields in which Taiwan enjoys a competitive edge, such as electronics, electrical engineering, information technology, biomedicine, business management, and the Taiwanese language and culture.

In addition, Chang said, the MOE will encourage local colleges and universities to open English courses, hold Taiwan education fairs in foreign countries, set up Taiwan education centers in selected foreign countries, and offer updated information about Taiwan's education facilities and development.
The MOE will also assist local universities in setting up foreign students service centers and in resolving housing problems for foreign students.

In addition to visiting major Thai tourist attractions, the sources said, the mayor of the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung will also meet with Taiwanese community leaders during his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OWES SUCCESS IN MEETING CHALLENGES TO CIVIL SERVANTS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday his administration owes the country's civil servants for its success in meeting the challenges but at the same time sided with opposition parties in opposing expanding the pension system for career civil servants to cover officials appointed for political reasons.

Speaking at a ceremony to honor distinguished civil servants of 2003, the president touted the achievements that his administration has made amid the challenges of an international economic slowdown and capital flight to mainland China, adding that the civil servants take the lion's share of the credit for this.

Noting that the Civil Service Ministry under the Examination Yuan was trying to extend by one year a 10-year-old law which gives politically-appointed officials a pension for career civil servants, the president said career civil servants are different from politically appointed officials who usually step down with the change of government and should not be eligible for perks reserved for career civil servants.

The ministry in charge with the pension system should not set up the country's politically appointed officials by requesting the legislature to extend the controversial law and giving them undeserved privileges, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INKS BILATERAL PACT WITH SAUDI ARABIA OVER ITS ENTRY INTO WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan inked a bilateral pact with Saudi Arabia in Geneva Wednesday over the latter's access to the World Trade Organization.
Under the pact, Saudi Arabia promises to lower its tariffs on chemicals and advanced technological products in five years after it is admitted into the WTO.

The two countries posted a two-way trade of US$2.74 billion last year, including US$330 million-worth of Taiwan's exports to Saudi Arab and US$2.4 billion-worth of Saudi Arabia's exports to Taiwan, mainly crude oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED SKY MARSHALS TO FLY ON AUSTRALIA-SINGAPORE ROUTES

TEXT.P: Armed sky marshals will guard passengers on some flights between Australia and Singapore as the two countries step up their defenses against terrorism, according to the Australian government.

Australian Customs Minister Chris Ellison, who signed an agreement with Singapore, indicated that the armed officers would be on international flights between the two countries by Christmas this year. Passengers would not be told when air marshals are aboard, he said.

The deal with Singapore is Australia's first international agreement on air marshals. Armed sky marshals have been operating on domestic flights in Australia since shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the United States.

Ellison said the marshals would travel on flights selected after risk assessments. He declined to comment on whether air marshals had stopped any terrorist attacks, only saying that they have worked as a deterrent.
"The deterrent aspect is what it's all about, and you can never gauge what you successfully put off because no one ever tells you what they were going to do anyway," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM FOR NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved the national development program for next year Wednesday, setting the annual economic growth rate at 5 percent.

Reporting on the program at the Cabinet's weekly meeting, Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that the unemployment rate will fall to 4.5 percent by the end of next year, while the consumer price index will rise by 0.7 percent.

Ho said that the execution of the government's proposed 10 major public construction projects by NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) in the next five years and the continuous implementation of programs for increasing jobs -- which have been in effect since earlier this year -- are required to achieve the goal.
The speed of the global economic recovery will also serve as a key factor for Taiwan's economic performance, she added.

The world's economy has been recovering since the second half of this year and the annual growth rate is expected to reach 2.4 percent, while the world trade volume will expanded by 3.6 percent, Ho noted.
The United States will continue to play the locomotive role in the economic development of industrialized nations next year, while East Asia will enjoy the largest growth rate in the world, Ho added.

The Cabinet meeting also approved the budget allocations for the 10 new major public construction projects which include the building of a third freeway in central Taiwan, the nurturing of top-notch universities and research centers, and the expansion of Kaohsiung Harbor to turn it into an intercontinental container center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATCHETS UP GUARD AGAINST SARS AFTER FIRST REPORTED CASE

TEXT.P: Taiwan ratcheted up its guard against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) Wednesday after a researcher of the highly-contagious disease at a military institute was diagnosed with the disease. He had been working on finding a cure.

Aviation officials said both Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan and Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung will ask outbound passengers to fill out a SARS survey sheet beginning Thursday in addition to monitoring their body temperatures via an infrared imaging camera which was set up in April. The survey sheet has been in use for inbound passengers since that time.
Passengers from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau are asked to take their own temperatures twice a day for at least 10 days after their arrival. Offenders face a fine of up to NT$7,500 (US$220).

Passengers on domestic flights were required to take their temperatures before boarding since 5 p.m. Wednesday. Those who display a fever will not be able to board the airplane unless they receive a medical certificate issued within 24 hours to prove they are not suffering from SARS.
Flight crews began to record their temperatures Wednesday afternoon as fever is the proceeding symptom of SARS.
This measures will also apply to drivers of buses, taxis and trains of the mass transit system in Taipei beginning Thursday, but not in other places.

An official from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said they will not ask mass transportation operators to take their passengers' temperatures for the time being but did ask them to provide thermometers at stations and to encourage passengers to take their own temperatures.

Health officials recommended the public to wash their hands thoroughly and frequently, which is an effective way to ward off the SARS virus, and those who have a cough and fever should wear a surgical mask.
However, Su Ih-jen, director-general of the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health said these anti-SARS measures will stop by the end of the month unless new cases are found.
The disease hit the island between March and July, claimed the lives of 37 and wreaking havoc on the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE FINALLY BUST LARGE-SCALE SOFTWARE PIRATING RING

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Wednesday they have foiled a large cross-border counterfeiting ring in cooperation with Microsoft Corp. and law enforcement officers in Hong Kong, mainland China and several other countries.
CIB officials said the cross-border counterfeiting ring was believed to be the largest production and distribution group of pirated Microsoft software products ever uncovered.

CIB investigators raided the ring's Taiwan base in Hsintien on the outskirts of Taipei around Tuesday noon. Six suspects, including the alleged mastermind of the ring's Taiwan operations, were arrested.

A large quantity of pirated Microsoft softwares, including the Windows and Office series of products, as well as counterfeit goods of other world-renowned brands such as EPSON and HP, were found at the ring's warehouses in Hsintien and other places in the greater Taipei area.
Police said the ring was believed to have sold more than NT$50 billion worth of pirated Microsoft products around the world over the past 10 years.

The group's Taiwan mastermind, identified as Chen Tien-en, allegedly had set up a company nominally to sell computer peripherals through the Internet. In fact, the company set up branches in mainland China's Dongguang, Humen, Shenzhen and Shanghai and cooperated with optical disk producers in mainland China and Hong Kong to manufacture pirated software and other related products for sale around the world.

Over the past decade, police said, the ring allegedly sold pirated Microsoft goods via Hong Kong to Thailand, Canada, South Africa, Paraguay, Brazil, India, Kenya, Great Britain, the United States, Germany, Australia, Israel and Dubai.

With information provided by Microsoft, law enforcement officers in Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China, Canada, Brazil and India simultaneously raided a total of 13 locations Tuesday to thwart the ring's operations.
CIB officials said the ring usually received orders, produced pirated products and laundered money in different countries to avoid investigations by law enforcement authorities of a single country.

"For a single order, their operations could span three to five countries, " a CIB officer said, adding that close international cooperation is needed in fighting commercial piracy and protecting intellectual property rights.
Noting that the CIB has spent more than a month probing the case, the officer said the raid signifies the government's determination to wipe out commercial counterfeiting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED FREE STATE BY U.S. FREEDOM HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked as a free country, while mainland China has been ranked as a not-free country, according to the latest assessment of Washington-headquartered Freedom House.

Japan leads the countries of Asia in terms of freedom, with Taiwan tied with South Korea and Israel in second place, followed by India, the Philippines and Thailand, all of which were assessed as free.
At the other end of the scale was North Korea, which brought up the rear in Asia. Mainland China, Vietnam, Cambodia and Uzbekistan tied in second-last place.

Freedom House is a non-profit organization dedicated to the advance of freedom around the world. It began to publish an annual assessment of states of freedom by assigning each country and territory the status of "Free", "Partly Free" or "Not Free" by averaging out their political rights and civil liberties ratings.

Both are measured on a one-to-seven scale, with one representing the highest degree of freedom and seven the lowest. Those whose ratings average 1-2.5 are generally considered "Free," 3-5.5 "Partly Free" and 5.5-7 "Not Free".
Its 2004 rating, to be released Thursday, covers 192 countries and territories around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO DEPLOY MORE MISSILES AGAINST TAIWAN: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The number of missiles deployed by Beijing targeting Taiwan will eventually increase to 880, Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday.

Addressing a gathering of students at the National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences in southern Taiwan, Lu said that Beijing has so far deployed 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan and the number will continue to increase.
She urged the people of Taiwan to keep alert to Beijing's increasing missile threat and to pool together all possible forces around the world to cope with Beijing's bullying attitude toward Taiwan.

The vice president also urged the international community to condemn Beijing for intimidating Taiwan with missiles and military force and ask Beijing to dismantle the missiles targeting Taiwan as soon as possible.

Also, Lu said that President Chen Shui-bian said that a new constitution should be written for Taiwan because the current one was established in mainland China more than five decades ago and is outdated.
She encouraged students to join the nation's efforts to promote the development of Taiwan and to sell Taiwan internationally.

American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis over the course of a day, the military reported Tuesday, in ambushes and violent rallies around the nation's Sunni Muslim heartland, where anger and disbelief at the capture of Saddam Hussein were still boiling.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORIAL CONCERT HELD FOR IT INDUSTRY TYCOON IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A memorial concert was held for Sayling Wen, vice chairman of Inventec Group, who died of a cerebral hemorrhage Dec. 7 after a stroke at the age of 55.
Thousands, including family members, friends and government officials, attended the concert held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.

The hall was decorated with a large scroll that had one of his famous quotes: "There is only one kind of people in the world and they all need to be cared for" to portrait the man who had devoted his life to the care of others and communities.

Wen, born in an impoverished family in Taiwan, made his fortune in his youth as one of Taiwan's first calculator makers and later went on to become a pioneer of the islands's information technology industry.
But the rag-to-riches story did not stop there. He said that he would no longer be a businessman after he turned 50 and he kept his word, devoting more time to writing and education.

His assistance to Huangyangchun, in Gansu province, is becoming legendary. He set up a computerized network in the poor countryside to help farmers sell their agricultural produce through the Net, giving them needed income as well as confidence in bettering their own lives.

He also invested US$5 million to build a five-star, 150-room hotel-like conference center in Huangyangchun, claiming that the hotel would serve as a home away from home for business people. "Only by attracting the rich to the poor area will it be freed from poverty," he said at the time.
Speaking in the memorial concert, Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang said that those who are both entrepreneurs and writers are many, but those who love Taiwan as much as Wen are numbered.

His aid in Huangyangchun, his promotion of information technology to educate the young and help them to get out of poverty, as well as his love for all extended to the other side of the Taiwan Strait, and he will be long remembered, Chiang said.

Chiang said that Hsu Hsin-liang, former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, once said that if a Nobel Peace laureate is to be to a cross-strait figure, then Wen should be the first one to be considered.

Many of his peers, including Wen's National Taiwan University classmate. Barry Lam, chairman of Quanta Computer, were choked with emotion when they delivered their thoughts about how Wen had inspired them during their life.

"He spent his life caring for other people, " Lam said, adding that he has had always harbored big ambitions, big plans and told others to do their best to get the best results, which had become a principle of Wen.

Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, lauded Wen for setting up schools in mainland China and Malaysia to help impoverished children, which is a spirit of Taiwan of "going all over the world and caring for those throughout the world."
Attending the concert were also James Soong, chairman of People First Party, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, and heads of big computer companies.

Meanwhile, mainland Chinese officials, including Chen Yunlin, director of Taiwan Affairs Office of State Council, went to Inventec's Beijing office to pay tribute to Wen for his contributions to cross-strait trade cooperation and assistance to the development of western mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO WILL ISSUE NO TRAVEL WARNING IF SARS CASE IS ISOLATED INCIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) recognized Taiwan's handling of the latest severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) case Wednesday, saying Taiwan has adopted correct measures in dealing with the incident.

WHO spokesman for communicable diseases Iain Simpson made the remarks after receiving a report from Taiwan that a medical researcher has tested positive for SARS, the first case in Taiwan since the flu-like virus was contained in late June this year on the island.
In addition to informing the WHO of the case, Taiwan's medical authorities immediately put the researcher into quarantine and traced all those who had come into contact with him.

The patient is an army lieutenant colonel doing SARS research at a military-run laboratory on the outskirts of Taipei. Taiwan's Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said the officer is believed to have contracted SARS at work, probably when he was destroying SARS samples after using them for experiments and analysis around Dec. 5.

Simpson said if the case is confirmed to be an isolated one that occurred in an enclosed environment, the WHO will neither issue a SARS-related travel advisory against Taiwan nor declare Taiwan as a SARS-affected area.
In September, a Singaporean medical research also contracted SARS at work.

Simpson said these two cases indicated the importance of laboratory security. At a WHO-organized seminar on SARS prevention held in October, the world health regulatory body called for strengthening of security measures in laboratories around the world.
Simpson said the WHO will keep close tabs on the development in the latest SARS case in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM TO BE SCRAPPED IF BEIJING WITHDRAWS MISSILES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in a recent interview with the Financial Times that if mainland China agrees to withdraw missiles aimed at Taiwan and renounces the use of force against Taiwan, a referendum planned for March 20 can be canceled.

But he also stressed that if the mainland test fires missiles in the runup to the presidential election set for March 20, then it will be regarded as "provocation" and Taiwan will not rule out any possibilities, including a change of the content of the referendum. The interview was conducted on Wednesday.

Chen plans to hold a "defensive referendum" March 20 to coincide with the election, to gauge public opinion as to whether the government should demand that Beijing withdraw 496 missiles targeting Taiwan and renounce the use of force against the country.

Asked whether the referendum will go ahead even if the United States is opposed to the idea, Chen described the referendum as a "universal value " and "a basic human right," and he asked why the 23 million people of Taiwan should be deprived of this right.
The president reaffirmed that he does not want the referendum to raise the issue of sovereignty because of the "four noes plus one" that he pledged in his 2000 inaugural speech.

But he said the one precondition of the "four noes plus one" is that Beijing must not use force against Taiwan. If they use force against Taiwan, "then the pledges will no longer be valid. We do not want to see this happen, " Chen said.

Chen's "four noes plus one" pledge is no declaration of independence; no change in the country's national title; no inclusion of the "state-to-state" description in the Constitution; no promotion of referendum to change the status quo; and no abolishment of the National Unification Council.
Asked of Taipei's reaction if Beijing test-fires missiles during the election period, the president said that it will be seen as clearly "an attack" by the mainland.

On the triangular relations between Taipei, Beijing and Washington, he said that after the meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in the United States last week, the White House spokesman said that U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged and went out of his way to say that Bush told Wen during the meeting that if Beijing uses force or coercion against Taiwan, "we'll be there."

Chen noted that Bush said in October 2001 that the United States will do "whatever it takes" to help Taiwan defend itself, and that he said during his meeting with Wen that he does not approve of either side of the Taiwan Strait unilaterally changing the status quo.
Chen reaffirmed that he has no intention of changing Taiwan's status quo, but in fact wants to defend and maintain the status quo, a point upon which both he and Bush are in agreement.

He also said he would like to see improved relations between the United States and the mainland, but does not want to see Taiwan's interests used as leverage or the improved ties coming at Taiwan's expense. He noted that the United States has promised that this will not be the case.

Touching on cross-strait relations, Chen said that polls have shown that "Taiwan consciousness" is rising and that the ratio of those who describe themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese has surpassed 50 percent, while the number of those who support independence has also increased.
Even though cross-strait trade will become even brisker as the the two sides drift further apart politically, the phenomenon will not be contradictory, he said.

Chen stressed that if the mainland continues to increase its missile deployment, it will only drive Taiwan further away and incite antagonism from the Taiwan people who view the mainland as a "hostile country."
He expressed the hope that Beijing's leaders will listen to the 23 million people of Taiwan and not listen only to what they want to hear in Beijing's power center of Zhongnanhai.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR ALISHAN TRAIN WORKERS GET PRISON SENTENCES OVER MARCH CRASH

TEXT.P: Four Alishan mountain train technicians were given prison sentences Wednesday for the crashing of a four-carriage train earlier this year that left 17 dead and 172 others injured.
The Chiayi District Court in southern Taiwan sentenced Wen Fu-ming, a train inspector, to three years in prison for his part in the tragic accident.
The court ruled that Wen was to blame for the accident as a stopcock controlling the airbrake connection between the locomotive and the passenger carriages had been inadvertently left closed.
The train's captain, driver and co-driver -- Su Yin-fu, Tsai Chen-sen and Liu Po-yueh -- were each given two-and-a-half-year prison terms.

Judges said all four men should be blamed for their failure to exercise prudence in performing their duties. According to the court rulings, all four committed offenses of involuntary manslaughter and injury, as well as overturning a public transport vehicle. All of them have been suspended from work since the accident.
The train crash was the worst accident in the 92-year history of the train service at Alishan, one of Taiwan's most famous mountain resorts.

The 72-kilometer alpine railway climbs from the subtropical zone into temperate pine forests, crossing more than 80 bridges and passing through about 50 tunnels. Its route includes a series of dangerous switchbacks.

The ROC government operates the train at an annual loss of about NT$110 million (US$3.2 million), but has preserved the line because of its historic interest and as a draw for tourists -- it is one of only three of its kind left in the world.

The Chiayi branch of the Taiwan Forestry Bureau (TFB) , which administers the historic mountain railway, has so far struck compensation deals with 171 victims and has paid out more than NT$178 million in damages.

TFB officials said they are still negotiating compensation terms with two other victims. Meanwhile, families of seven deceased victims and several injured passengers have commissioned the Consumers Foundation to file a group lawsuit against the TFB over the accident.

The plaintiffs have demanded a total of NT$572.97 million in damages, as well as punitive compensation from the TFB. The suit marks the first time in Taiwan that a consumer protection organization has ever filed a group suit against a government agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY SARS RESEARCH CENTER CLOSES

TEXT.P: The laboratory conducting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) research at the Institute of Preventive Medicine Research (IPMR) of the National Defense Medical College was closed down temporarily Wednesday after one of its researchers was confirmed to have contracted the flu-like disease, military sources said.

With the closure of the lab, all SARS research work in the military has also been halted, said Chang Sheng-yuan, director-general of the Military Medicine Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense.
Also Wednesday, the Cabinet-level Department of Health announced that all public and private laboratories conducting SARS research should also shelve their operations with immediate effect.
Health Minister Chen Chien-jen confirmed Wednesday that the 44-year-old male researcher, an army lt. col., had tested positive for SARS.

The officer -- the first SARS case in Taiwan since the last outbreak was contained in late June -- has been transferred to the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, a SARS-designated institution, for observation and treatment in a negative-pressure ward.

Chen said the officer is believed to have contracted SARS at work, probably when he was destroying SARS samples after using them for experiments and analysis around Dec. 5. According to Chen, the patient flew to Singapore with six laboratory colleagues Dec. 7. He complained of fatigue and muscle pain Dec. 8 while in Singapore but had no fever until the night of Dec. 10 after he returned to Taipei.
Meanwhile, Chang said that six of the patient's IPMR colleagues were ordered to suspend work at the laboratory and start self-health management at home for 21 days.
The four family members of the officer are also starting self-health monitoring at home for 21 days, although they have not displayed fever or any other SARS-like symptoms, Chang added.

According to officials from the Military Medicine Bureau, the IPMR is one of the most outstanding biological research institutions in Taiwan. Since the SARS outbreak that began in March, they said, the institute has successfully discovered, from over 10,000 plants and medications, at least four herbal and other medicine ingredients that have been proved effective in containing SARS.

The IPMR, located in a secluded area of Sanhsia, in Taipei County, is the only top-grade P4 laboratory in Taiwan. P4 refers to polymers, properties and polymerization processes and denotes a laboratory able to work in the fields of chemical engineering and chemical technology, among others.

According to Chang, in addition to finding SARS remedies, the IPMR has had excellent research results in other areas, developing reagents that can identify whether suspicious powder contains lethal anthrax spores in five to 15 minutes. "Both accuracy and sensitivity rates of our reagents exceed 99 percent," Chang said.
The IMPR assisted in anthrax spore testing when the United States was hit by a spate of anthrax scares following the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington Sept. 11, 2001.
Since SARS hit Taiwan, the IPMR has been racing against the clock to analyze the characteristics of the virus, Chang said.
Taipei was the hardest-hit part of the island by SARS between March and July. The outbreaks claimed the lives of 84 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: NO IMPORTS OF MAINLAND CHINESE LABORERS DURING HIS TERM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in central Taiwan Wednesday that he will never allow domestic businessmen to import mainland Chinese laborers and will never recognize diplomas issued by mainland Chinese universities during his term.
The president made the remarks when he attended a campaign rally in support of his re-election bid sponsored by the Nantou County Workers' Union, which had expressed concern about unemployment.

Chen said that he "has 100 percent confidence" about winning the March 20 election, although he added that one should never let one's guard down, as the election will be a crucial battle between the advocacy of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" against "one China, " democratic reform versus the restoration of corrupt "black gold" politics, and faith in Taiwan against pessimism about the island.

Addressing concerns as to when the economy will rebound, Chen stressed that although Taiwan's economic growth of 3.59 percent last year was "not satisfactory," it was "far better" than the 2.2 percent growth in Singapore, 2.3 percent growth in Hong Kong and 0.3 percent growth in Japan.
Chen said that when he assumed office in May 2000, the global economy was sluggish, but he noted that Taiwan has overcome the most difficult times during past three years.
He expressed confidence that economic growth next year will reach 5 percent, while the jobless rate will drop to below 4.5 percent, dropping further to 4 percent in 2005.
He said that to protect domestic laborers, he will not increase the quotas for foreign labor imports and will never allow the import of mainland laborers.
He said he will also not recognize diplomas handed out by mainland schools. "Taiwan will be first in everything," he added.

Chen said that more bills concerning laborers were cleared during his term, including the shortening of weekly working hours and the five-day work-week system, and he claimed that "everything" is improving and that the public should have confidence.
