DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY VOWS TO PUSH FOR STEADY PROGRESS IN PHILIPPINE TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan should consider using the Philippines as a strategic production base for its manufacturing, agricultural and fishery development, the ROC representative to the Philippines said Wednesday.

Addressing a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, Wu Hsin-hsing said Taiwan and the Philippines are close neighbors and have traditionally maintained cordial economic, labor and tourist exchanges.

"In the future, I think our government should consider using the Philippines as a strategic hinterland for our manufacturing, agricultural and fishery industries, " Wu said, adding that by so doing, Taiwan will be able to expand its national development and further boost its relations with the Philippines.

Wu said Taiwan-Philippine relations are not expected to see a major breakthrough on the political front in the foreseeable future due to Manila's "one China" policy which recognizes Beijing as the sole ruler of China.

However, Wu said the Philippines' pro-Beijing policy has not hindered bilateral trade and economic cooperation. "And our communication channels with the Philippines' administration are also operating smoothly," he added.

As to relations with the Philippine Congress, Wu pointed out that the Philippine Senate and House of Representatives passed separate resolutions in May in support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.

"The moves indicate that the Philippine Congress is friendly toward Taiwan," Wu said, adding that the ROC representative office in Manila will continue to forge extensive ties with Philippine lawmakers.
In the future, Wu said, the representative office will also invite as many influential Philippine politicians to visit Taiwan as possible.

Touching on fishery disputes between the two countries, Wu noted that under Philippine law, fishing contracts signed by Philippine local governments or fishery brokerage houses with private Taiwan companies are invalid.

Wu said he has asked domestic fishery administrative agencies to step up a publicity campaign to help local fishermen better understand the Philippine fishery regulations and thus avoid being detained by Philippine authorities while operating in Philippine waters.
Acting on his suggestion, Wu said, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has sent a fishery expert to work at Taiwan's representative office in Manila to assist with handling relevant affairs.

According to Wu, nine Taiwan fishing boats and 23 fishermen have been detained by the Philippine authorities since 2002. Wu said that all those ships have either been released or have escaped and only two crew members are still pending Philippine court rulings.
Taiwan is still negotiating a new fishery cooperation agreement with the Philippines, as a previous accord has already expired.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SARS PREVENTION MECHANISM MOVES UP A GEAR TO LEVEL B

TEXT.P: Taiwan's severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) prevention mechanism has been geared up to Level B upon the confirmation of the first SARS case reported in Taiwan this winter, Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said Wednesday.

Priority missions to be made in the SARS prevention mechanism Level B include making sure that the SARS virus is prevented from being taken abroad, mandatory temperature-taking for people working aboard airplanes, thermal monitoring at airports and travel restrictions on those who have displayed fever or those who have had personal contact with people who have displayed fever, Chen said.
Chen also suggested that officials at public places begin taking the temperature of people upon admission during the Level B period, which will continue until Dec. 31.
From Thursday, he said, passengers who display fever will be prohibited from going abroad without producing proof that they are not infected with SARS.

Those who have had personal contact with confirmed SARS cases, have displayed fever but are determined by the Department of Health as non-SARS should conduct home quarantine for at least three days, Chen added.
The health minister confirmed Wednesday that a 44-year-old male researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine of the National Defense Medical College had tested positive for SARS.

The patient -- the first SARS case in Taiwan since the outbreak was contained in late June -- was transferred to the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, a SARS designated institution, for observation and treatment in a negative-pressure ward.
Chen said the researcher is believed to have contracted SARS at work, probably when he was destroying SARS samples after using them for experiments and analysis around Dec. 5.

According to Chen, the patient flew to Singapore with six colleagues Dec. 7. He complained of fatigue and muscle pain Dec. 8 while in Singapore but had no fever until the night of Dec. 10 after he returned to Taipei, according to Chen.

Meanwhile, a China Airlines official urged the public not to worry about contracting SARS from CAL airplanes, as the specific passenger had not developed fever before, during or after he boarded the plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED SARS PATIENT TRANSFERRED TO HOPING HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: A Tri-Service General Hospital patient suspected of having severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has been transferred to Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, the Taipei City Department of Health reported Wednesday.

The patient, a researcher at a Tri-Service Hospital laboratory, will undergo examinations at Hoping Hospital, a SARS designated institution, to determine whether he in fact has SARS, a Tri-Service official said.
The Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health will give a thorough briefing on this latest suspected SARS case at a press conference scheduled for around noon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS TRANSPARENT HANDLING OF LATEST SARS CASE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyh-kun instructed relevant health care agencies and professionals Wednesday to handle Taiwan's first case of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) this winter in a transparent manner to avoid stirring up unnecessary public panic.

Yu said he was informed by Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min about the latest SARS case -- a 44-year-old male researcher with the military-run Institute of Preventive Medicine who tested positive for SARS -- early that morning and immediately relayed the report to President Chen Shui-bian.

Yu instructed relevant health care agencies to spare no efforts to look into contact history of the researcher and crank the SARS prevention and treatment mechanism into high gear, said Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung.
At a press conference held later that day, Health Minister Chen Chien-jen confirmed that the researcher had tested positive for SARS.

The patient -- the first SARS case in Taiwan since the outbreak was contained in late June -- was transferred from the Tri-Service General Hospital to the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, a SARS designated institution, for observation and treatment in a negative-pressure ward, Chen said.

Chen described the latest case as isolated, as the patient was infected with the disease in a closed environment, namely a laboratory. None of the researcher's colleagues or family members have displayed fever or other flu-like symptoms.

In addition to informing the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum about the latest SARS case without wasting time, Chen said, the Department of Health has also instructed the National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) to organize a seven-member SARS investigation ad hoc group, headed by NTUH Infection Department Director Chang Shang-chun, to keep close watch against a possible resurgence of SARS.

Chen said that the latest case, which closely resembles a case in Singapore in September when a 27-year-old researcher with the Singapore Environmental Health Institute laboratory contracted the disease in the lab where he worked, has underlined once again that biological research laboratories are one of the most dangerous places from where SARS could resurface.

However, he added that Taiwan should be spared from being issued a travel advisory or warning by the WHO, given that this is an isolated case with the victim contracting the disease in a closed environment.
The health minister called for the public not to panic, saying that none of the researcher's colleagues or family members have displayed fever or other SARS-like symptoms.
These people, Chen said, are not required to be quarantined and need only monitor their health condition by themselves at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG ACTIVATES SARS ALERT SYSTEM AFTER CASE CONFIRMED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has activated its severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) alert system following the confirmation of a SARS case in Taiwan Wednesday.

The Hong Kong government announced that "alert level A" of the three-level emergency response system relating to SARS has been activated following the confirmation of the SARS case in Taiwan involving a laboratory researcher.

An emergency response command structure involving senior officials from the Health, Welfare and Food Bureau, the Department of Health, and the Hospital Authority has been put in place, the government said, adding that it would monitor developments closely and decide on appropriate action.

According to the government's emergency response system on SARS, "alert level A" is activated when there is a laboratory confirmed SARS case outside Hong Kong, while "alert level B" is activated when there is a SARS alert falling within the World Health Organization definition in Hong Kong.
Officials in Taiwan said a medical researcher has tested positive for SARS -- Taiwan's first case since it was dropped from a global list of SARS-affected areas in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 17, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE PLANNING LIFELONG LEARNING SYSTEM FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Thursday it is crafting a lifelong learning system for foreign and mainland Chinese citizens who have married Taiwan nationals.
At the moment, the ministry said, it is focusing on helping city and county governments open adult learning classes for foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens.

"We have offered financial subsidies for local governments to open 391 Chinese language classes for foreign spouses so far this year, " said Liu Yi-chuan, director of the MOE's Social Education Department.
According to Liu, the MOE is scheduled to publish teaching materials for foreign spouses basic education and a manual for Chinese-Vietnamese language teachers in April 2004.
The ministry will also cooperate with private groups in producing relevant television teaching programs and posting foreign spouses teaching materials on the Internet, Liu said.
With the number of Taiwan citizens married to foreign nationals increasing steadily, the number of schoolchildren from intermarriage families has also risen.

Quoting official tallies, the ratio of first graders from intermarried families has surged from 5.12 percent to 12.46 percent over the past five years, with the number rising from 13,940 to 30,833 in the current school year.

In addition to helping these children adapt to school life, Liu said, the MOE has stepped up adult education for foreign spouses because they play an important role in schoolchildren's care and family life.

Meanwhile, Liu said, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has drawn up a five-year education plan for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses. Under the plan to be carried out from 2004, the government will spend up to NT$700 million on various adult education programs for foreign and mainland spouses.

According to MOI tallies, the number of foreign spouses had reached 71,052 as of June, with Taipei County, Taoyuan County and Taipei City as the top three areas of residence. Vietnam was the top source of foreign spouses with 43,478, followed by Indonesia with 10,52, and Thailand with 5,861. Among the foreign spouses legally residing in Taiwan, a total of 65,466, or 92.14 percent, are women.

However, one unofficial tally showed that the number of foreign and mainland spouses now stands between 250,000 and 280,000, with about 100,000 from Southeast Asian countries and the remaining from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, HONG KONG PURCHASE DELEGATIONS CANCEL PLANNED VISIT

TEXT.P: Purchase delegations from Japan and Hong Kong each have notified the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) that they have canceled their planned visits to an agricultural product exhibition in southern Taiwan, CETRA said Thursday.

Chu Kang-ming, director of CETRA's Kaohsiung office, said that the groups called Thursday to cancel their visits to the exhibition, of which CETRA is a co-sponor, and expressed their hope of being able to come next time if they have the opportunity.

Chu said the purchase delegations did not explain the reason for the cancellation, but he speculated that it may be related to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) case confirmed Wednesday in Taiwan -- the island's first of the winter season.

Chu said it was "regrettable" that Nihon Ryutsu Sangyo Co, a purchase company set up by 19 supermarkets and wholesale stores in Japan with global purchases amounting to US$2.1 billion last year, abruptly canceled its planned visit to Taiwan.
The exhibition will be held in Kaohsiung Dec. 20-21, with more than 200 pavilions to be set up. More than 1,000 agricultural products, including peanuts, wax apples and tea, will be on display.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH AUTHORITIES PUT 34 PERSONS ON SARS WATCHLIST

TEXT.P: The health authorities have informed five more persons who are known to have come into close contact with a confirmed severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) case since Dec. 7 to monitor their health for at least ten days, bringing the number on the watchlist to 34, a health official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, said the new additions include a minibus driver who took the patient home from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport when he returned from Singapore Dec. 10, a Japanese person who occupied a seat near the infected man on a flight from Singapore to Taipei and three patients who were at the clinic the SARS case went to in Hsintien, Taipei County, Dec. 11.
The patient, a researcher at the Institute of Preventive Medicine at the National Defense University in Taipei came into contact with the SARS virus in his laboratory Dec. 5.
He flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five coworkers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day in Singapore but did not develop the fever that is typical of SARS.

The patient returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, where he discovered that he had a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day, but even though his job involved working with the SARS virus, nobody suspected he could be suffering from SARS.
Another full week was allowed to pass until he developed diarrhea and was sent to hospital Dec. 17, where tests confirmed that the SARS virus was present in his system.

The other people who had been told to monitor themselves for signs of fever include the patient's family, medical workers at the clinic in Hsintien and other passengers seated around him on the flights to and from Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DISMISSES SUGGESTIONS ABOUT REPRISAL FOR TAIWAN REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi, Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A State Department official dismissed as "irresponsible rumors" suggestions in Taipei that Washington could downgrade its ties with Taiwan if the country goes ahead with a referendum in spite of U.S. disapproval.
Adam Ereli, deputy spokesman for the State Department said that no downgrading of ties will be contemplated by the State Department even if Taiwan holds an unprecedented referendum in March.

He made the remarks after being asked to comment on reports from Taipei that Washington, which opposes any attempt by Taiwan to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo unilaterally via referendum, might downgrade its ties, perhaps by recalling American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) head Douglas Paal, or by closing the AIT's Kaohsiung office if its warning falls on deaf ears.

In a related development Wednesday, State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher refused to comment on President Chen Shui-bian's statement that he will rescind his promises of not changing the country's status quo if Beijing test fires missiles into the sea near Taiwan.

Instead, the spokesman reiterated the long-standing policy that Washington opposes any unilateral attempts to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and that the use of force to resolve cross-strait differences is unacceptable.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO RAIL STRIKE DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: There will be no rail workers strike during the Lunar New Year holiday, a spokesman for the Taiwan Railway Workers' Union announced Thursday.

The union eventually decided not to go ahead with the planned strike after it reached agreement with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on a number of demands, the spokesman said, adding that the union will officially rescind the strike plan in an interim meeting Friday.

According to the spokesman, the MOTC has officially notified the union of the Executive Yuan's assurance that the government will fully meet their requirements if the union halts its plan to strike during the year's busiest travel period.

Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) head Shu Ta-wen said railway services during the holiday period will be further stepped up, with a 40 percent increase in transport volume, or an additional 500 trains in service, now that the strike has been canceled.
The union decided Sept. 11 to hold a strike over the Lunar New Year holiday as to protest a government privatization plan for the TRA.

The MOTC has been negotiating with the union since then in a bid to persuade its members to cancel the planned strike. With the support of the Executive Yuan, the ministry gave way to the union demands related to the privatization program, including a total government takeover of the TRA's debts and all worker's pensions, among other issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PLANNING TO BUILD SEPARATE TERMINAL FOR BUDGET AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Singapore's Ministry of Transport has plans to build a separate terminal at Changi Airport for budget airline travelers.
The planned low-cost building would have no carpeting, minimal seating, limited services, no air-conditioning, and no aerobridge to connect the terminal to planes for passenger boarding.

Budget airlines have been one of the hottest aviation developments in recent months. "It will be a problem for us if we cannot cater to them, " Minister of Transport Yeo Cheow Tong said, adding that "we do not know if they will be a big factor in the region, but we cannot take the risk."

If the green light is given, the new terminal could be ready within 18 to 20 months, and it would cost only a fraction of Changi Airport's Terminal Three which has a price tag of S$1.75 billion (US$1 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PROMOTE DEMOCRATIC REFORM, REMOVE MISSILES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Francis Kuo and EH)

TEXT.P: The Asian branch of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace issued a joint statement Thursday in Bangkok, urging mainland China to promote democratic reforms and remove all missiles from the Taiwan Strait area.

More than 40 alliance representatives from the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand and Japan issued the joint statement at an alliance conference, which is an organization of overseas Chinese with branches in various parts of the world.

They said in the statement that the mainland should remove all of the missiles aimed at Taiwan and that the deployment of the missiles has seriously threatened the stability and prosperity of the Taiwan Strait area. Only through democracy, freedom and peace can both sides of the Taiwan Strait reach the goal of eternal peace, they added.
The statement also said that the alliance believes Taiwan should be admitted to the World Health Organization as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: 10 die in Baghdad as truck explodes.
A truck exploded in Baghdad when it collided with a bus Wednesday, killing at least 10 people and injuring more than 20. The Iraq police initially said the vehicle was packed with explosives, but U.S. military officialswere later quoted as saying the blast involved a fuel tanker and was accidental.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO RESPOND TO MAINLAND ACTION IN LINE WITH COMBAT RULES: MND

TEXT.P: The ROC armed forces will respond to any mainland Chinese military action in line with relevant combat regulations, Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said Thursday.

Tang was responding to press inquiries about his views on President Chen Shui-bian's statement in a recent interview with the London-based Financial Times that if mainland China test-fires missiles near Taiwan as it did in 1996, the missile tests would be regarded as a provocation, an attack, and therefore contradict the precondition of his "four noes plus one" pledge.
Tang said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) is not in a position to comment on Chen's remarks, as he is the top commander of the armed forces.

Noting that the military consistently monitors mainland China's military activities closely, Tang said the military will take action according to the nation's combat regulations to defend Taiwan in the event of an attack.

Asked whether the president or the defense minister will order the first strike against the mainland in the event of a cross-Taiwan Strait war, Tang said the first strike order should be issued by the chief of the general staff upon the instruction of the defense minister in accordance with two newly passed defense laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXAMINATION YUAN HEAD DESIGNATED ENVOY TO ATTEND HAITI FOUNDING DAY

TEXT.P: Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as his special envoy to take part in the 200th founding anniversary of the Republic of Haiti, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Thursday.
Javier Ho, director-general of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, who made the announcement, said the Foreign Ministry has been arranging the matter.

According to Ho, Yao is slated to depart for Haiti Dec. 29 to take part in the country's Jan. 1 celebrations. Traveling at the head of an official delegation, Yao and the rest of the delegates are scheduled to return to Taiwan Jan. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO INVESTIGATE EMBEZZLED NATIONAL ASSETS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will preside over a meeting of the National Property Management Commission next Wednesday to look into national assets allegedly embezzled by political parties or individuals, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Thursday.

Lin said Yu will ask various government departments, including the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of National Defense, to check and tally assets they believe have been embezzled from their ministries.
If necessary, Lin said, the government will form a supraministerial task force to speed up the probe.

Lin said legislation is the best way to deal with problem regarding political parties' ill-gotten assets. However, he said, the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has dragged its feet on passing a Cabinet-drafted bill that would allow for the disbursement of political parties' improperly obtained assets. Against this backdrop, he said, the Cabinet must take action on its own account.

Lin alleged that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) embezzled a huge amount of the country's assets during its 54-year rule of Taiwan. In recent months alone, he said, the KMT has sold ill-gotten land parcels and securities for nearly NT$240 billion.

Noting that a land dispute between the state-run Central Broadcasting System (CBS) and the KMT-owned Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) highlights the problems of the KMT mixing up state and party coffers while it was in power, Lin said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will assist CBS in filing a misappropriation lawsuit against BCC.

The CBS-BCC dispute started in 1952 when the MOTC bought two parcels of land, totaling 10 hectares, in Minhsiung, Chiayi County for NT$150,000. An additional NT$2 million was spent on radio broadcasting equipment for CBS, originally a BCC subordinate department, to continue its propaganda broadcasting to mainland China.
The land was registered under the BCC but has been used by the CBS branch station in Minhsiung since then. CBS expanded in 1972 and has become a state-financed institution.

Claiming that the land belongs to the company, BCC started demanding that CBS either return or rent the two parcels of land in January 1998, but its requests were met with defiance. Last month the Chiayi District Court ruled in favor of BCC, but CBS has vowed to appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKSHOP PLANNED FOR CHILDREN OF MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is planning to host a workshop next summer for children of Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China, a spokesman for the semi-official organization said Thursday.
The major purpose of the SEF workshop is to help such children gain a better understanding of Taiwan's diversified, multifaceted culture and society, the SEF official said.

The two-week workshop, planned for July 2004 in northern Taiwan, will be available for 130 children ranging from third graders in elementary schools to junior high school students, he noted while welcoming all levels of education institutions and cultural foundations to jointly participate in the program.

The SEF was set up in 1991 to deal with civilian contact with mainland China in the absence of government-to-government ties amid increased exchanges between the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1987, when Taiwan lifted the ban on travel to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFERS MEDAL ON JAPANESE ADVERTISING SPECIALIST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Violet Cordon Thursday on Shuzo Ishikawa, a former senior advisor to Japan's Dentsu Inc., in recognition of his remarkable contributions to technical exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.
Chen said he was very pleased to award the medal to Ishikawa at the Presidential Office on behalf of the Republic of China government in appreciation for his strong support for Taiwan over the years.

Ishikawa, who also served in many key posts at the International Advertising Association (IAA) and the Asian Federation of Advertising Agencies (AFAA), helped a great deal with Taiwan's re-entry into the AFAA and its hosting of an annual conference after the island was forced out of the organization in 1977 by mainland China, Chen said.

The president also praised Ishikawa as the best proof of Taiwan's pursuit of democratization and freedom, saying that the advertising business is just like the Taiwan people's desire for freedom, which must take root and make progress in a democratic society.
He voiced his hope that Ishikawa will continue working to further step up bilateral ties between the two countries.
For his part, Ishikawa said he was deeply honored to receive the medal.
Stating that he believes in "integrity" as his motto, Ishikawa said he follows that path in both his private and professional life.

Ishikawa attributed the international status achieved by Taiwan's advertising industry to the diligence and endurance of the people working in the sector and he also expressed admiration for the efforts made by Hu Jong, president of the Taipei Association of Advertising Agencies.

As to his becoming the first-ever recipient of the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon in the advertising industry, Ishikawa said it is not just an honor for himself but it also represents a jubilant occasion for all advertising companies, both in Taiwan and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE DETAINEE ESCAPES BY SQUEEZING BETWEEN BARS ON WINDOW

TEXT.P: Police said Thursday that they are looking for a Vietnamese detainee who broke out of the detention center for foreigners in Taipei County Tuesday night.

Police said that Nguyen Quang Chinh, 24, was in the detention center awaiting repatriation for overstaying his visa. At around 10 p.m. Tuesday after curfew, Nguyen squeezed through the bars on the window frame, then used a bed sheet he had hidden to let himself down from this third-floor cell.

Mao Chun-chieh, deputy director of the detention center, said that the man is of small build so that he was able to get through the iron bars. Guards later found the white bed sheet and discovered Nguyen was missing.

Mao said the Vietnamese man worked on construction sites during his stay in Taiwan, and knew about building escape routes. Police have stepped up security in and around the old building and are currently trying to find the escapee.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG RESEARCHERS MAY HAVE WAY TO MAKE SARS VACCINE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 18 (CNA) (by C. H. Lu and EH)

TEXT.P: Researchers at the Chinese University of Hong Kong said Thursday that they have discovered a method to produce anti-SARS viral proteins, and that a vaccine for SARS may be available in two or three years, if the vaccine is found applicable for human beings.

A biochemical professor of the university said at a news conference that they could produce a vaccine for severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) from the anti-SARS viral proteins derived from the DNA of silkworm and coliform bacillus.
The vaccine has been found effective in animal experiments, the professor said, adding that it may take two to three years to complete related experiments on human beings.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN STILL WATCHING ATTITUDE OF U.S. TOWARD REFERENDUM: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Japan is still observing how the United States is reacting to the planned referendum by Taiwan and is not expected to express its stance on the issue any time soon, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan said Thursday.
Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, Lo said Japan would not like to see any conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Up to now, Lo said, Japanese authorities have not yet expressed its views on Taiwan's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of the upcoming presidential election on March 20, 2004 to allow its people to voice opposition to mainland China's deployment of hundreds of missiles pointed at the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Unconfirmed reports said mainland China's embassy in Tokyo had asked the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs to publicly oppose Taiwan's planned referendum.

But Lo said Japan has so far not made any comments on the issue. To the best of his understanding, Lo said, Japanese authorities thought that the time was not yet ripe for them to express opinions about the plan.

Lo said Japanese authorities have also not discussed the referendum issue with him. "I think they are still watching the U.S.' attitude toward Taiwan's referendum plan, " he said, adding that the U.S. government will certainly inform Japan of its stance on Taiwan's planned referendum.
Senior U.S. officials have expressed explicit opposition to Taiwan holding a referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move toward independence.

President Chen Shui-bian has said on many occasions that the March 20 referendum is aimed at preserving Taiwan's present status quo and will not touch on the "independence versus unification" subject.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VOWS TO PUSH FOR CROSS-STRAIT ARMAMENT CONTROL TALKS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who is also the "pan-blue alliance's" standard-bearer for the 2004 presidential election, said Thursday that if he wins the presidency, he will push for cross-Taiwan Strait armament control talks.
Lien made the remarks while meeting with U.S. Congressman Dan Burton, who arrived in Taipei last Tuesday for a goodwill visit.

Stressing that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) cannot accept mainland China's deployment of hundreds of ballistic missiles along its southeastern coast pointed at Taiwan, Lien said that if elected, he would demand mainland China publicly renounce the use of force against Taiwan and conduct armament control talks with Taiwan.
Lien said mainland China's missile deployment has hurt Taiwan people's feelings and would never contribute to cross-strait rapprochement.
He further said the top leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should refrain from provocative rhetoric and actions because such moves will only hinder cross-strait detente.
Lien also told Burton that Taiwan treasures its long friendship and relations with the United States, adding that the "pan-blue alliance" does not like to see any setbacks in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 10 points to close at 5,780, with 19,273 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February futures rose 22 points to finish at 5,785, with 52 contract transactions, while March futures gained 10 points to close at 5,780, with 8 contracts traded.
June futures increased 6 points to finish at 5,788, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for September futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,770 for January, 5,763 for February, 5,770 for March, 5,782 for June, and 5,775 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
January TE futures moved down 0.3 points to finish at 239.7, with 2,976 contract transactions, while February TE futures fell 0.9 points to close at 240, with 12 contracts traded.
March TE futures gained 1.35 points to finish at 240, with 6 contract transactions, while June TE futures rose 4.85 points to close at 241.4, with 3 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR COLD FRONT TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN THURSDAY EVENING

TEXT.P: A major cold front will reach the Taiwan area Thursday evening and bring low temperatures to the island, especially from Friday to Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau said Thursday.

A CWB meteorologist said temperatures may drop from 17 degrees Celsius to 13 degrees Celsius on Thursday, and to under 10 degrees Celsius in the coastal and low-laying areas to the north of Tainan on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

The CWB said owners of agricultural and fish farms in those areas should take precautionary measures against the cold front. Ships sailing on the seas near Taiwan should beware of strong winds over the next three days, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 16.75 points to close at 5,768.76.
The bourse opened at 5,743.03 and fluctuated between 5,801.61 and 5,724.94 during trading.

A total of 2.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.6 billion (US$1.75 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.26 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$94.99 billion (US$2.79 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted loses, with foodstuff shares moving down 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.5 percent, pulp and paper issues, construction stocks, and foodstuff shares, all at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 416 to 301, with 218 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANGUAGES ABOUND IN MULTICULTURAL NEW YORK

TEXT.P: A person riding the subway in New York City has a good chance of hearing languages from virtually every corner of the globe being spoken.
With immigrants flocking to the city for well over a hundred years, it is said that as many as 200 different languages are spoken in the Big Apple.

For decades, immigrants of the same background tended to flock together when they first came to the city. Several groups, such as the Chinese and the Italians, preserved their cultures and customs in their new neighborhoods, with Chinatown and Little Italy in Lower Manhattan becoming among New York's most popular tourist attractions.

Over the past 30 years, new immigrants have continued to pour into New York, but many of these have chosen to settle in neighborhoods outside Manhattan because of more affordable housing prices and convenient transportation.
Statistics compiled by the city government indicate that half of the nearly 500,000 Asian people living in New York City reside in Queens.

The multicultural city is very tolerant in terms of language, with the City Council recently initiating a bill that would require city agencies to provide translation in one of six different languages to New Yorkers seeking service. If the bill is enacted, city human services agencies will have to make all documents available in the six languages, including xx, xx....
New York City's Human Resources Administration has estimated that the cost to the government would run to about US$30 million a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 18, or the 25th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.

Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL SARS PATIENT CONTACTS STILL NOT TRACKED DOWN

TEXT.P: Authorities have still not been able to track down several people who are known to have come in close contact from Dec. 7 with the Taiwanese researcher diagnosed Wednesday with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , the Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Friday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the CDC under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, said those who came into close contact with Lt. Col. Chan from the military Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) include passengers seated near him on his flight to Singapore Dec. 7 and his return flight Dec. 10. He added that the passengers include foreign and Taiwanese nationals.
One of the passengers the center has not been able to track down is Taipei County's Hung Chih-ming, 43, who was on the Dec. 10 China Airlines flight to Taipei.

The center has also not been able to get in contact with the minibus driver who took Chan home from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Dec. 10, as well as with three patients who were at the clinic that Chan went to in Hsintien, Taipei County, Dec. 11, according to Shih.
The CDC called for those people who came into close contact with Chan to closely monitor their own health condition for at least 10 days.
Meanwhile, Chan has continued to receive medical attention in a negative-pressure ward at Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital.

According to hospital authorities, the 44-year-old Chan has been placed on artificial respirator since Wednesday. His fever has come down and his diarrhea has been brought under control, but the inflammation in his lungs has continued to increase, doctors said.

The doctors said that they are closely monitoring the condition of Chan's lungs, pointing out that the following three days are extremely critical. The inflammation must be combated to prevent the millions of tiny sacs in his lungs from becoming fluid-filled -- a condition that bars oxygen from entering the lungs, they said.
Chan is believed to have contracted SARS at work Dec. 5 when he touched with his bare hand spilled SARS samples after analysis work in SARS virus research.
He flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five co-workers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day while in Singapore but did not develop a fever which is typical of SARS.

Chan returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, and by that night had developed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day. At that time, nobody suspected him of having SARS, even though his job involved working with the SARS virus.
Another full week was allowed to pass before he was sent to hospital Tuesday after developing diarrhea. At the hospital, Chan underwent tests that confirmed the SARS virus was present in his system.
Others who have been told to closely monitor themselves for signs of fever include the patient's family as well as medical workers at the clinic in Hsintien, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROMISES TO TURN OVER EIGHT MOVIE THEATERS TO GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) promised Friday to turn over eight movie theaters it operates to the government.

The eight theaters were among 19 cinemas the party took over amid the chaos when the island was turned over by Japan to the Republic of China, and when the party ruled the island with an iron fist. They are run by a KMT-owned, loss-making company. The other theaters have already been sold or disposed of by the party.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan also promised to make public the party's assets next Monday after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party began turning the heat on the KMT by pressing it to return its "ill-gotten" assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE REJECTS REQUEST FOR RECONSIDERATION OF REFERENDUM BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan rejected the Executive Yuan's request to reconsider the newly enacted Referendum Bill Friday evening, dealing another blow to the administration of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The two leading opposition parties, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party, which command a narrow majority of 112 seats in the 223-seat legislature, was one vote short of the number of votes they needed to turn down the request because one of the KMT lawmaker was overseas on vacation.
However, they managed to win over the support of seven independents and defeated the request 118 to 95.
Jubilant opposition lawmakers claimed it was a victory for the people because they scuttled the Executive Yuan's attempt to nix the newly created right of referendum.

KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan Lee Chia-chin urged the Executive Yuan to stop its fruitless political struggle with the Legislative Yuan now that it has exhausted all avenues to kill the Referendum Bill and devote its energy to implementing the bill faithfully.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun kept a stiff upper lip after the vote although he said earlier in the day that he will not step down even though the request was rejected. He warned that the ill-thought out bill could hardly be put into practice even the legislature stands by it.

Not surprisingly, the ruling DPP lawmakers were disappointed with the result. Party whip at the Legislative Yuan Chen Chi-mai said the DPP will address the flaws in the bill either by amending the Constitution, revising the Referendum Bill after it takes effect or asking the Council of Grand Justices to determine whether the bill is unconstitutional.

The DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), said the rejection is a setback for the country's democracy. It brought home to the public the need to reform the legislature, which is controlled by the opposition, and which has become the biggest source of disturbance in the country.

The Referendum Bill at the center of the controversy is the brainchild of the DPP, but the opposition at the legislature outmaneuvered the ruling party by packing it with their own ideas and steamrolling it through the legislature on Nov. 27.
The disappointed Executive Yuan decided to ask the legislature to reconsider 12 of the 64 articles of the bill last Thursday, calling them unacceptable.

Notable among them were articles giving the Legislative Yuan the power to initiate referendums while denying the Executive Yuan a similar right, and articles providing for the formation of a referendum review committee which would duplicate the function of the existing Central Election Commission.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said the Executive Yuan's request is unprecedented in that it challenges only part of the bill and in some cases, even only a section of an article. "Usually, we are called upon to deal with a whole article rather than a section of it, " Wang said,

Under the Constitution, the part of a bill returned by the Executive Yuan will be automatically annulled unless the Legislative Yuan rejects the request within 15 days with a majority vote of at least 112 in the 223-seat legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRICTER PENALTIES PLANNED FOR FINANCIAL CRIMES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Legislative Yuan is expected to pass amendments soon to seven financial laws, imposing stricter penalties on those committing financial crimes.

According to sources from the legislature, the ruling and opposition parties finally reached consensus Friday on the amendments to the seven financial laws regarding banking, securities transactions, trust operations, grassroots banking institutions and insurance operations.
The amendments will focus on punishment for computer hacking, ATM fraud and illicit banking businesses, as well as forms of profiteering and breach of trust by heads or employees of banks.

According to the amendments, those who commit crimes related to banks will be put in jail for three to 10 years, plus receive a fine of between NT$10 million to NT$200 million. Those who are convicted of making illegal profits of more than NT$100 million will be jailed for more than seven years and receive a fine of between NT$25 million and NT$500 million.

In addition, lawyers and accountants who make false reports for listed companies on the stock market will face a penalty of up to five years in prison, and if their false reports have influenced the stability of the market, their penalties will be increased by half.
The amendments are expected to clear the legislature next Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCREDITATION OF MAINLAND DIPLOMA NEEDS COMPLEMENTARY MEASURES: MAC

TEXT.P: The accreditation of academic diplomas issued by higher-education institutions based in mainland China needs complementary measures to ward off a negative impact on the domestic higher-learning sector, a government official said Friday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong made the comment at a regular news conference.

The government will have to cautiously assess the pros and cons that such a measure could bring to Taiwan-based colleges and universities because many problems related to Taiwan's economic and educational fronts and to its national security will arise from a policy change, Chen said.

Denying speculation that the government may recognize academic degrees issued by some mainland Chinese colleges and universities, Chen said relevant Taiwan authorities must first fully evaluate the impact on related fields and work out complementary measures before adopting a "proactive opening and effective management" approach to deal with the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES IN CUSTODY BATTLE OF TAIWNESE-BRAZILIAN BOY FAIL TO REACH AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court on Friday called the two parties involved in a custody battle over a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy to discuss ways to have the boy sent back Brazil as ordered by a recent court decision, but the talks fell through.

The Taiwan Supreme Court ruled on Nov. 13 that the grandmother was the sole legal guardian of eight-year-old Iruan Wu Ergui, who is currently living with his Uncle, Wu Huo-yen, in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. The court ruled that the boy should be turned over to the custody of his grandmother in Brazil.

Upon learning of the Nov. 13 ruling, the grandmother, Rosa Leocadia Silva Ergui, said that she would not come to Taiwan to pick up the boy to avoid unnecessary media attention, which she said would be bad for the boy and the families in Taiwan and Brazil. Instead, she entrusted the Brazil Business Center, which represents Brazilian interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, to escort the boy back to Brazil.

The lawyer representing the Brazil Business Center requested Friday that Wu Huo-yen take the boy to the CKS International Airport within one week so that the boy can return to Brazil to be reunited with his grandmother.
But Wu said that if the boy, whose Chinese name is Wu Yi-hua, is unwilling to return to Brazil, he would rather accept punishment, even if that means going to the jail instead of sending him away.

He said that he will talk to the boy, insisting that the boy's "wishes and decisions should be respected, " and he wants the boy to remain in Taiwan. Wu expressed the hope that the grandmother could come to Taiwan and respect the choice of the boy.
The lawyer representing Wu said that Wu will soon again appeal to the court to stop the forceful implementation of the court's ruling.
The lawyer said that even if Wu receives the order of forceful implementation, Wu has said that he just couldn't bring himself to let the boy go.

According to the law, if the quarreling parties refuse to come to a mutually agreeable solution, the court can fine Wu, and if he refuses to pay, the court can take away the boy. The court will make a definite decision very soon.

Iruan was born in Brazil to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and he was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. Since then, the boy has been living with his uncle. He is now a second-grader at a Kaohsiung elementary school.

His grandmother, who became the boy's legal guardian after his mother's death, decided to take legal action to regain custody of the child after his uncle in Taiwan refused to let her take him back to Brazil.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT OF BEING RE-ELECTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is confident that he will be re-elected in the March 20 presidential election.
Chen made the remarks during a ceremony to express gratitude to the voluntary workers and several associations who have contributed significantly to reformatory education of criminals.

The president hailed these people as having carried out a most difficult task, as it needs tremendous patience and selfless love. "Saving a person equals saving a family and a whole society, " Chen said, adding that their devotion deserves respect.
Chen has designated May 20 -- the date of his 2000 inauguration -- as the "Day of Volunteers" for Taiwan and marked it with a campaign of volunteer services led by him every year since then.
Saying that he feels confident he will win re-election, Chen said he hopes he can continue volunteering his services next May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERUM FROM 31 EX-SARS PATIENTS HAS ANTIBODIES AGAINST SARS

TEXT.P: Serum extracted from the blood of 31 former patients of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) have been found to contain antibodies against SARS and could be a valuable weapon in fighting the disease, an official from the Chinese Blood Service Foundation said Friday.

The anonymous official said 36 people who recovered fully from the disease earlier this year and were free of hepatitis and other contagious diseases had donated blood for research and SARS antibodies were found in 31 of the serum samples.

As the antibodies are a valuable weapon in treating the disease, researchers have been eager to test it in clinic trials. However, the disease disappeared in Taiwan after July, making it impossible to find test subjects, said the official.
The latest SARS patient confirmed Wednesday has been treated with the serum, the official added.
SARS flared up in Taiwan in March and claimed the lives of 37 out of 346 cases before it disappeared in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HAS NO COMMENT ON MAINLAND TOURISTS SEEKING POLITICAL ASYLUM

TEXT.P: An official in charge of mainland China policy refused to comment Friday on reports that Taiwan has rejected political asylum requests by four mainland Chinese tourists.

Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) was responding to a report in the mass-circulation United Daily News that a 13-member tour group from the mainland's Guangxi Province arrived in Taiwan Sunday. Four of them requested political asylum, claiming that they were persecuted in the mainland and suspended from their jobs in the court and public security department. The MAC and other government agencies decided that they did not meet the conditions for political asylum, and the four were escorted back to Macau with the nine other members of the tour group.
Chen refused to confirm or deny reports, saying only that Taiwan has no political asylum law.
But he cited the example of Wuer Kaixi, a mainland Chinese political dissenter who married a Taiwan woman and now resides in Taiwan.

He said that because of the Tiananmen massacre of 1989 in Beijing, mainland Chinese people can apply to reside in Taiwan under a regulation governing their settlement in Taiwan, and they can subsequently obtain an ROC ID number.
However, he went on, "individual cases" have to be dealt with by the policy-making authorities in charge of national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO ASK FOR QUICK RESPONSE FROM ARATS ON CHARTER PLANE SERVICES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday that the MAC has demanded that the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) contact its mainland Chinese counterpart regarding the opening of talks on charter plane services during the lunar New Year holiday.

The MAC hopes that the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will respond quickly, Chen said, adding that he strongly believes that the two sides can work out resolutions as long as both are sincere in dealing with the matter.

Chen's remarks came after the local press reported that the MAC was trying to persuade six Taiwan-based carriers to conduct the charter flight services for the coming Chinese New Year holiday that they offered a year ago.

According to the MAC, the six airlines -- China Airlines, EVA Airways Corp., Far Eastern Air Transport Corp., Trans Asia Airways, Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airways Corp., -- have shown a willingness to cooperate with the plan, despite the fact that the historic operation to transport homecoming mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families for the holiday was not profitable last time.

The Taipei Airline Association issued a statement a day earlier in which it stressed that every aviation company is willing to do its best to help carry out the plan, as long as Taiwan businessmen's groups based on the mainland or travel agencies in Taiwan indicate the need for such services during the period from Jan. 9 to Feb. 2.

However, an official of the association said the demand for cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services during the holiday period is not very high, as not a single aviation company has submitted an application to provide the service.

In addition to some extra flights added to normal commercial flight services, newly opened charter plane services between Taiwan and mainland China through a third location such as Japan's Okinawa or South Korea's Cheju would help cope with the busy traffic during the period, as do the existing "mini links " between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and two ports in mainland China's Fujian Province, he added.

The SEF, set up in 1991 to handle cross-strait civilian exchanges in the absence of government-to-government contacts, is under the auspices of the MAC -- Taiwan's highest government agency with regard to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO DEVELOP PRE-EMPTIVE MISSILE ATTACK ABILITY: DPP

TEXT.P: A report said Friday that Taiwan must establish a pre-emptive missile attack ability as the military balance of the Taiwan Strait is gradually tilting toward mainland China.
The report conducted by the Institute for Taiwan Defense and Strategic Studies, a private research institute, also predicted that the next cross-strait war will be between 2005 and 2010.

Chen Chung-shin, director of the Department of China Affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , claimed that the report, drawn up at the commission of his department, is the "most comprehensive" report on mainland Chinese military force by the private sector, which does not include reports by the Ministry of National Defense and national security authorities.

According to the report, Beijing currently deploys 450 short-range ballistic missiles along the coast of Fujian Province, a number that is expected to increase to 650 by 2005. Beijing also deploys cruise missiles that can reach their chosen targets in seven minutes, giving Taiwan only five minutes to respond.

The reports also said that in addition to the development of its own J-10 second-generation fighter planes, Beijing has also purchased advanced fighters such as the Su-27 and the Su-30 from Russia, and is expected to deploy 130 and 150 of these fighters, respectively, by 2005.

This, together with the mainland's H-6 bombers, means that Taiwan will gradually lose its air supremacy, the report claims. It will only take 17 minutes for Beijing fighters to take off from coastal areas of Fujian and reach Taiwan, giving the country only five minutes to 15 minutes to respond.

On the mainland's navy, the report said that Beijing is building its own battleships and has also purchased four modern destroyers fitted with supersonic anti-ship missiles, C-802 anti-ship missiles, as well as Kilo-class submarines which posed a great threat to Taiwan's second-generation battleships.

More importantly, according to the report, Beijing has learned from the U.S.-Iraq wars and has since 1994 gradually established a rapid deployment force that is expected to reach 500,000 strong, which together with its naval and air forces, could pose a major threat to Taiwan.

The report claims that Beijing will launch a seven-minute blitz attack on Taiwan to paralyze its command and control system and obtain air supremacy in 17 minutes. As for how many hours it would take to parachute in military forces and how many days it would take to exclude the intervention of the United States, this would hinge on the military might of Taiwan and the response time of the United States, according to the report.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the DPP noted that growth in mainland China's defense spending has exceeded double digits for the 10th consecutive year. The United States has estimated that mainland military expenditure is US$20 billion annually, but if military budget under other names is also counted it could reach up to US$60 billion. While the annual defense budget of Taiwan is only US$8 billion a year, half of this is in personnel expenditure.

According to Lee, the mainland deploys 496 short-range missiles along its coastal areas, but according to studies by the United States, the number has been increasing by 65 annually, and this does not include the m-missiles and cruise missiles.
In the long-run, Taiwan will be unable to compete with the mainland in the arms race, Lee claimed.
"Faced with the military imbalance in the Taiwan Strait, " Lee said that Taiwan should adopt a two-pronged military and non-military approach.

He said that military approach means that Taiwan should research and develop pre-emptive missiles. The non-military approach will be to demand that Beijing withdraw its missiles aimed at Taiwan through a "defensive referendum, " drawing the attention of the international community so as to put political pressure on Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS ON MACAU TO OPEN OFFICE TO STEP UP TWO-WAY TIES

TEXT.P: The government of the Macau Special Administrative Region should open a special office to provide assistance and services for the many Macau citizens living in Taiwan, in order to strengthen two-way ties, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

Taiwan hopes that the Macau authorities will set up an office in Taiwan to handle stepped-up bilateral relations through institutionalized channels on a mutually beneficial basis amid increased civilian exchanges, the MAC said in a statement. The MAC is Taiwan's highest policy-planning government agency with regard to mainland China.

The MAC hailed the good performance of the Macau government over the past year, evident in that the economy, law and order and the judicial system in the former Portuguese enclave has remained sound and stable.

The role played by Macau as a broker in trade and economics in interrelations with the western part of mainland China's Guangdong Province, as well as with the Portuguese-speaking countries and overseas Chinese businessmen, is increasingly noticeable, the MAC said.

Affected by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the first half of this year, the number of visitors traveling between Taiwan and Macau during the January-November period dropped, according to the MAC.

It said Taiwan people paid a total of more than 768,000 visits to Macau, down by 34.86 percent from the year-earlier level, although Taiwan is still Macau's third-largest source in terms of foreign arrivals.

According to the MAC, the Macau office it opened Feb. 27 this year to handle entry visas and travel permits for local residents, foreigners and mainland Chinese people is operating smoothly and has earned a positive response.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PATIENT TALKS WITH TAIPEI MAYOR VIA TELECONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou talked with the scientist who came down with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) via a teleconference system Friday, sources from Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital said.

Ma talked with Lt. Col. Chan, a SARS virus researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) under the National Defense Medical College, via computer and offered his greetings to the patient, who contracted SARS after handling virus samples with bare hands in blatant disregard of the strict rules of the facility in which he worked.

The 44-year-old Chan, who has been receiving treatment in a negative-pressure ward at Hoping Hospital since Wednesday, told Ma that he feels OK and that he appreciates "all the people for their concern."

Ma conducted the talks with Chan during an inspection tour of Hoping Hospital, now a SARS designated hospital after being the hardest-hit by SARS among all Taiwan's medical institutions in the outbreaks that occurred between March and July this year.

Ma expressed his appreciation to all the health care personnel at the hospital, particularly those who have been working at the A9 Negative-Pressure Ward, raising their spirits while they treat what is described by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) as "an isolated" case that is unlikely to lead to more transmissions of the virus.

According to Hoping Hospital authorities, Chan has been on artificial respirator since Wednesday. His fever has come down and his diarrhea has been brought under control, but the inflammation in his lungs has continued to increase, doctors said.

The doctors said that they are closely monitoring the condition of Chan's lungs, pointing out that the following three days are extremely critical. The inflammation must be combated to prevent the alveoli -- millions of tiny sacs in his lungs -- from becoming fluid-filled, a condition that stops oxygen from entering the bloodstream, they said.

Chan is believed to have contracted SARS at work Dec. 5 when he touched spilled SARS samples with his bare hands after analysis work that was part of SARS virus research at a top-level P4 laboratory in which the use of gowns and gloves is mandatory. It was not clear why Chan had decided to break the rules and not wear gloves.

He then flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five co-workers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day while in Singapore, but did not develop the fever which is typical of SARS.

Chan returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, and by that night, had developed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day. At that time, nobody suspected him of having SARS, even though his job involved working with the SARS virus.
Another full week was allowed to pass before he was sent to hospital Tuesday after developing diarrhea. At the hospital, Chan underwent tests that confirmed the SARS virus was present in his system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 20 points to close at 5,800, with 24,279 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost eight points to finish at 5,777, with 86 contract transactions, while March futures dropped 12 points to close at 5,768, with six contracts traded.
June futures lost three points to finish at 5,789, with three contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,780 for January, 5,785 for February, 5,780 for March, 5,792 for June and 5,785 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.53 points to close at 5,759.23.
The bourse opened at 5,829.02 and fluctuated between 5,829.02 and 5,755.22 during trading.

A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.72 billion (US$1.66 billion), an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 2.57 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$59.6.
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.5 percent and foodstuffs at 0.2 percent.

The other five stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by construction and financial issues, both at 0.4 percent, electrical stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemical issues at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GIVES UP BUILDINGS, THEATERS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Friday that it was relinquishing ownership of two major buildings and seven movie theaters in Taipei City as part of efforts to clear its name in the wake of a spate of criticism of the party for embezzling national assets.

Chang Che-sen, director-general of the KMT Administration Management Committee, claimed that most of the party's assets -- many of which are described by party rivals as "ill-gotten assets" -- were "a historical legacy" that have made significant contributions to the country.
However, despite reluctance, the KMT has since last year continued to give up these assets and return property to their original "donors," Chang said.

According to Chang, KMT Chairman Lien Chan announced in September last year that the party would undertake a sweeping consignment of party assets back to their former owners in an effort to recuperate some of the former ruling party's image and dignity.

Lien said that a total of 120 land lots and 42 buildings would be returned to their former owners, mostly local governments around the island that gave the property to the KMT as donations in the years when the KMT reigned.
The assets consignment, the first of its kind in the KMT's history, is estimated to be worth over NT$900 million (US$26.47 million).

Immediately after making the announcement, Lien told his fellow party members that the KMT would push the Party Law legislation, accelerate measures to put other KMT-owned assets and operations into public trust, and make sure that the party never again owns or engages in any profit-making businesses.
Lien further claimed that the KMT has lost its power but not its self-confidence.
As of the end of August, according to Chang, 120 out of the 165 land lots that the KMT had been using had been returned to their original donors, constituting a completion rate of over 80 percent.
In related news, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party recently rebutted a KMT claim that it had returned all of its ill-gotten assets to the nation.

DPP Legislator Chou Ya-shu accused Lien of lying when he claimed Dec. 1 that his party had returned all of its ill-gotten assets to the nation and had entrusted the party's legal assets to professional trust companies.

"When the KMT was in power, it embezzled vast amounts of national property. Lien should honestly face up to his party's past sins and stop cheating on this issue, " Chou said, adding that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, should support the passage of a bill that would legalize investigations into the assets of major political parties.

Another DPP legislator, Lai Ching-teh, said that the KMT's controversial assets could be divided into four categories -- property taken over from the Japanese colonial government at the end of World War II, such as the building of the Broadcasting Corp. of China; property taken from the government, including 19 theaters, 11 of which were sold secretly by the KMT; 115 pieces of land given by city or county governments; and property that the government sold to the KMT at unreasonably low prices, such as the KMT's present headquarters.
"Among all these assets, the KMT has only returned about half of the 115 pieces of land presented by local-level governments, " Lai claimed.

Legislator Chen Chi-mai, also a DPP legislative whip, said the KMT should explain why it has so far only returned half of the land lots donated by local-level governments and why it has dragged its feet on handling other illegally obtained assets.

TEXT.P: In line with the government's efforts to promote tourism and travel in Taiwan, Chunghwa Post Co. recently issued a series of stamps featuring Suao's unique cold springs in eastern Taiwan and various hot springs around Taiwan.

Those featured also include the Yangmingshan hot springs in Taipei, the Kuantzuling murky hot springs in southern Taiwan, and the seabed hot springs on Green Island. The stamps show people soaking in the springs and enjoying themselves.

The Yangmingshan hot springs stamp sells for NT$5 (US$0.147) , with 2.5 million being issued, while the Suao cold springs stamp sells for NT$5, with 2.3 million being issued.
