DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER APOLOGIZES TO GAYS AND LESBIANS

TEXT.P: Legislator Ho Shui-sheng from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) offered his apologies to Taiwan's homosexual citizens twice Friday for his remarks made the previous day that "same-sex marriages could cause the annihilation of the nation."

At two separate press conferences at the Legislative Yuan, Ho, who represents Tainan County, bowed to express his apologies to the public as well as the nation's gays and lesbians for his "wrongly understood" remarks.

Ho said he didn't mean to hurt gays and lesbians when he made the remarks while speaking to Health Minister Chen Chien-jen about the possible passage of a bill allowing for same-sex marriages. Ho said he simply expressed his opposition to same-sex marriages from the medical point of view.

Ho, a member of the Legislative Yuan Health and Environment Committee, urged the public health officials not to allow marriages between gays and between lesbians, saying that such marriages should be prohibited because they could never produce offspring which are needed for the nation's sustainable development.
On Thursday, the DPP lawmaker had refused to apologize for his remarks as he criticized the media for "wrongly decoding and reporting" his comments made at the Legislative Yuan.
Scores of gays and lesbians staged a protest against Ho Friday morning in front of the Legislative Yuan building.

Meanwhile, Chen Chi-mai, a DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that Ho's remarks will discussed at a DPP caucus meeting next Monday and that it will be decided then whether to discipline Ho under the DPP's regulations.

Commenting on Ho's controversial remarks, Vice President Annette Lu quoted the content of the pending basic human rights draft bill as stipulating that it recognizes, maintains and respects the relationships between people of opposite-sex or same-sex as basic human rights. The rights include the right to marry and the right to adopt children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 19, or the 26th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STRESSES THE IMPORTANCE OF JOINING WHO

TEXT.P: Jumping at the chance to gain some leverage from the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) case in Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian stressed in Taipei Saturday the importance of Taiwan obtaining access to the World Health Organization (WHO).

Speaking at a ceremony to honor senior medical workers, Chen said the reappearance of SARS in Taiwan has reminded the world of the loophole in its anti-epidemic frontline caused by Taiwan's absence from the WHO, which coordinates the global efforts to fight epidemics.

Noting that Taiwan succeeded in overcoming the disease earlier this year on its own, Chen said the episode brought home to both the international community and the country that epidemics know no political boundaries and that the world's attempts to bring epidemics under control are hampered by shutting Taiwan out for political reasons.

Now that the disease has reappeared in Taiwan due to the negligence of a scientist engaged in SARS research that caused him to become infected by the disease Dec. 17, the president said the case serves as a warning to both the world and the country that Taiwan should be included in the WHO as soon as possible.
He vowed to continue the country's seven-year effort to join the WHO as an observer, saying that persistence will eventually lead to success. He also wished the latest SARS patient a speedy recovery.
Taiwan's previous bids to join the WHO have been blocked by mainland China, which claims sovereignty over the nation and goes out of its way to isolate Taiwan at every opportunity.
About 200 senior medical workers were honored in Saturday's ceremony and the president awarded medals to several who boasted careers of more than 60 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE PLEDGES TO INCREASE EDUCATIONAL SPENDING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Lien Chan said Saturday that he will increase educational spending in the public sector to 6 percent of the gross national product (GNP) if he is elected in March.
Lien, who is also the KMT chairman, made the remarks at an electoral campaign rally in Taipei attended by mostly young supporters.
Lien noted that because of the economic recession in the last few years, education spending has decreased to the current rate of 4.39 percent of the GNP.
He pledged to increase education spending to 5 percent of the GNP in the first year of his term if he wins the election, and raise it to 6 percent in the second year.
After the first two years, Lien added, he will keep the rate at a level no less than 6 percent of the GNP.
A 6 percent figure would represent a budget of NT$600 billion (US$17.6 billion) , in comparison with the current level of NT$438 billion, according to Lien.
With the increased budget on education, Lien said he will focus on advanced education in order to elevate the island's competitiveness amid the fierce competition from mainland China.

In addition, Lien said his administration will offer full scholarships to 500 students to pursue advanced studies abroad, and low-interest loans worth NT$10 billion to young people interested in studying abroad.

Referring to the KMT's assets, which many say have been embezzled from the country by the party during its five-decade rule, Lien claimed that he issued instructions for a review of KMT assets immediately after he assumed the party leadership, and ordered a quick return of some land lots to the government.
Furthermore, he claimed, the KMT has put all its assets into trust and has promised that it will no longer manage party-owned business enterprises.
He added that the KMT will announce all its assets to the public starting from next week for public scrutiny.

Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has admitted that his country had been trying to develop a broad arsenal of unconventional weapons, and he promised to dismantle them up and submit to international inspections, President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said Friday.
Libya's actions came after nine months of secret diplomacy, beginning with an overture from Colonel Qaddafi to London and Washington just as the invasion of Iraq was beginning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN NABBED FOR PLANNING TO TAKE FAKE BILLS TO VIETNAM FOR LAUNDERING

TEXT.P: A man was arrested in Taipei Saturday on charges of attempting to take bogus Taiwan currency to Vietnam for laundering, police said.
The man surnamed Lin told police that he intended to take fake New Taiwan dollar bills to Vietnam for laundering because NT dollar trading is brisk in the black market in that country.

As cross-border money laundering will not only disrupt Taiwan's and Vietnam's financial market order but will also undermine Taiwan's international image, police said they will make further investigation into the case and bring Lin's accomplices to justice.

With Taiwan companies making huge investments in mainland China and Southeast Asian countries, the amount of NT dollar circulating in those countries has been increasing. And some criminal rings allegedly have used bogus banknotes for money laundering for illegal profits. POlice said they will step up probes to stave off such illegal practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 130 KGS OF AMPHETAMINE FROM A LARGE FACTORY IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Police seized 130 kilograms of amphetamine Saturday from a large make-shift factory at Chiating Village in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung.

An officer from the Bureau of Investigation in Kaohsiung said that six suspects were arrested, and that the factory is so large that it is capable of producing more than 100 kilograms of amphetamine per day.
In addition to the 130 kilograms of amphetamine, a lot of equipment and tools were also seized from the factory, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO HELP SMES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that he will do his utmost to help small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to upgrade their production and management in order to survive ever-increasing competition in the global market.
Yu made the remarks while attending a seminar on SME development organized by the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises. More than 500 SME representatives attended the meeting.
Noting that Taiwan has 1.1 million SMEs providing 7.36 million jobs, Yu said SMEs have contributed greatly to Taiwan's economic prosperity over the decades.

"Even though we have large enterprises and high-tech companies to serve as a locomotive in driving our economic development, we would have been unable to create an economic miracle if we did not have so many SMEs," Yu said.
Against this backdrop, Yu said, the government has consistently given priority to helping SMEs resolve their difficulties and has adopted various measures to boost their development.

As the ruling Democratic Progressive Party fails to control a majority in the Legislative Yuan, Yu said, the executive branch has encountered many setbacks in carrying out economic and financial reform projects over the past three years.

Nevertheless, he said, the DPP administration has never been daunted by obstacles to its reform agenda. Over the past three years, he said, the government has completed a number of reform projects in the economic and financial fields in order to create a better business and investment environment for local businessmen.

"Our efforts have to some extent paid off. Our economy has bottomed out of a recession. And Taiwan's rankings in all major economic indexes compiled by the world's 10 largest economic rating agencies have all advanced to higher slots this year," Yu said.

Despite pressure from opposition parties and some soical quarters, Yu said, the DPP administration will never stop its reform efforts. Yu also touted the administration's achievements in improving water quality in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and in building the Taichung Science-based Industrial Park in 10 months.

In the early days of the DPP administration, Yu said, the Taiwan economy suffered a downturn because of worldwide economic doldrums and domestic structural transformation. Through concerted efforts of the govenrment and the industrial sector, Yu said, the local economy has returned to the normal track of steady growth.
In the future, Yu assured SME executives that the govenrment will continue crafting measures favorable for business development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO OFFER LATEST SARS MONITORING TECHNOLOGY TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Paul Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Canadian Network for Vaccines and Immunotherapeutics (CANVAC) , an organization subsidized by the Canadian government, will offer Taiwan the latest monitoring technology for severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , CANVAC Director Michel Klein said Friday.
The offer will form part of a bilateral cooperation project between CANVAC and Taiwan's National Health Research Institute (NHRI) aimed at developing vaccines against SARS, Klein noted.

According to an agreement signed by CANVAC and the NHRI, the two institutions will exchange and test blood samples of SARS patients in different phases, a task that will help scientists on both sides understand how the human immune system reacts when attacked by the SARS virus.
In the next few months, CANVAC and the NHRI will experiment with vaccines on animals and will start human trials on a small group of volunteers in 2005.
Klein said Taiwan has found an element that will play an important role in the development of a SARS vaccine.
Noting that although there is little possibility of SARS outbreaks at present, Klein said the threat still exists and he stressed the importance of prevention work.
In addition to the SARS monitoring technology, CANVAC will also offer Taiwan the technology to produce vaccines against other virus-borne diseases.

CANVAC is the only Canadian network comprising public, private and academic partners in the field of vaccine research and development focusing on immune-based prophylaxis and therapy for cancer, viral diseases and emerging viral infections such as HIV, hepatitis C and SARS.
With 79 top researchers in immunology, virology and molecular biology, CANVAC cooperates closely with biopharmaceutical companies around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CHINA TRADE INCREASING SIGNIFICANTLY

TEXT.P: Trade between Taiwan and mainland China amounted to US$44.63 billion in the first 10 months of this year, an increase of 29.4 percent over the same period of last year, according to a report by New China News Agency.

The report quoted an official of China's Ministry of Commerce as saying that the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year had little impact on cross-strait trade, because 80 percent of Taiwan investments in China are in manufacturing industries.

In the first 10 months of this year, Chinese imports from Taiwan totaled US$39.59 billion, an increase of 28.7 percent over the same period of last year. China's exports to Taiwan totaled US$7.04 billion in the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2003 AUSTRONESIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: The 2003 Austronesian Cultural Festival kicked off Saturday in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, focusing on the weaving and knitting skills of Austronesian civilization.

The festival, organized by the Taitung county government and the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung City, is the final large-scale tourist activity that will be held by the government this year. It will run through Dec. 30.
In addition to Taiwan's ten aboriginal groups, the organizers have also invited performance troupes from Canada, Japan, Indonesia, South Korea and Hawaii to take part in the festival.

In addition to the exhibition of weaving and knitting, festival-goers will also be able to get a better understanding of the movements of the Austronesian people and of their marine and terrestrial cultures.
A count-down party will be held late Dec. 31 through early Jan. 1, 2004, featuring various types of music, including jazz and Latin from Cuba and Brazil.

The Austronesian language group probably underwent the widest physical dispersion of a single language family prior to the European colonial expansion following Columbus. From the island of Madagascar, off the east coast of Africa, all the way to the tiny, isolated Easter Island (Rapa Nui) , and extending into Taiwan, Vietnam, Northern Australia, New Zealand and most of the Melanesian and Polynesian islands.
Recent research indicates that Taiwan might be the place from where some of the Austronesian culture originated.
As a result, the organizers plan to invite aboriginal young people from New Zealand or Malaysia to Taiwan next year to conduct cultural exchanges with their counterparts on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, DDP TURN UP HEAT ON KMT FOR ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) continued to pan the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Saturday over its ill-gotten assets, one day after the KMT agreed to hand back eight parcels of real estate to the government.

Speaking at a rally of his supporters from the Chen clan in southern Tainan County, the president cast doubts on KMT Chairman Lien Chan's claims that his party is working hard to divest itself of assets embezzled during nearly five decades of authoritarian rule.

Chen claimed that the KMT sold off most of the property it stole from the country, including the sale of NT$200 billion (US$5.87 billion)-worth of real estate and NT$170 billion (US$4.99 billion)-worth of stocks in 2000 alone when the party lost its grip on power.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun applied another turn to the screw Saturday by pressing the KMT not only to hand back the remaining illegally obtained property but also to repay the government for the ill-gotten assets it has already sold, even if the move brings the KMT to bankruptcy.

DPP Legislator Duan Yi-kan also jumped on the KMT-bashing bandwagon, calling a news conference in front of the KMT headquarters to claim that the site of the eight-story building was purchased by KMT from the government at just one-tenth of the market price in 1980.
He demanded that the KMT stump up the other nine-tenths of the price, which he put at NT$4 billion (US$11.74 million).

Duan's news conference annoyed the KMT workers in the headquarters, who ordered Duan to leave the premises. This led to a quarrel that drew many amused onlookers and snarled traffic outside the headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA INAUGURATES BILINGUAL NGO WEBSITE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) formally inaugurated a bilingual non-government organization (NGO) Website Saturday to signify the determination of the people of Taiwan to take part in global affairs.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the NGO Website and the opening of an exhibition of Taiwan NGO activities and their exchanges with major international NGOs at the Taipei World Trade Center, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said the Website is the first government-financed platform for information exchanges between Taiwan's NGOs and relevant international organizations.

It is also the first government-organized virtual NGO center on the Internet, Chien said, adding that he hopes it will help boost Taiwan NGOs' interchanges with international NGOs and expand Taiwan's external relations.

Citing the story of the 15-year-old African "elephant man" Ahfoo, who recently underwent surgery at a Taiwan hospital to have a gigantic tumor on his face removed with the assistance of the MOFA and several private organizations, Chien said he believes that the establishment of the new NGO Website will help extend Taiwan's love to the world and further boost the nation's diplomatic work.

Ahfoo, a Von Recklinghausen's disease patient whose real name is Vincent Kabore, came to Taiwan from the West African state of Burkina Faso in early November under the auspices of the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, EVA Airways and the MOFA to undergo surgery at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, which is famous for its plastic and craniofacial surgery.

Ahfoo's plight became known here after a Taiwan conscript working with the ROC medical aid mission in Burkina Faso as an alternative to compulsory military service posted a series of reports on the Internet.
"The Ahfoo case marks the best example of pooling the strength of Taiwan's NGOs and information technology to extend its concern and medical service to a needy person," Chien said.
The establishment of the bilingual NGO Website is also a response to a U.N. appeal to narrow the digital divide between rich and poor countries, Chien said.

The Website offers a detailed introduction to Taiwan's NGO development, including information about upcoming conferences, NGO personnel training programs and reports on Taiwan's participation in international NGO activities.

"The Website serves as a gateway for foreign people to get a glimpse into Taiwan's NGO affairs, " Chien said, adding that the Website also bridges exchanges between local NGOs and their international counterparts.
Ahfoo also attended the NGO Website opening ceremony. He struggled to say "thanks" in Chinese to express his heartfelt gratitude for the medical care he has received in Taiwan.
In the company of his father, Ahfoo arrived in Taiwan Nov. 4 and is scheduled to leave for home Dec. 24.

After undergoing two 13-hour operations, Ahfoo can now speak and make facial expressions. Prior to the surgery, most of his face and neck were covered by a giant tumor. Dr. Chen Yu-jui, the convener of the Chang Gung surgical team, said Ahfoo's condition continues to improve and that his protective facial mask can be removed in six months.

Turkish Daily News: [Battle of Cyprus begins]
The anticipated post-poll Turkish pressure on the Northern Cyprus for a negotiated settlement to the 40-year-old Cyprus problem was unveiled Friday with a gale-force wind from Turkey's Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan with a strongly worded message to the Northern Cyprus leader Rauf Denktas of the need to change his mentality.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS FORWARD TO LIFTING PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES AGAINST SARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan was looking forward to lifting precautionary measures against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) by the end of the month Saturday as 32 of the 34 people ordered to stay at home over concerns that they might be suffering from the disease were to come out of quarantine.

The 34 persons were considered to be in the danger of having been infected because they had close contact with a confirmed SARS patient. Twenty of them had already ended their 10-day quarantine time without any signs of SARS and 12 more were to end their quarantine at midnight.
The two others -- the patient's wife and father -- who took care of the patient until he was taken to the hospital Dec. 15 have to stay at home under self-quarantine until Dec. 25.
Unless new cases come to light, the precautionary measure of taking teperatures of visitors to public places will end Jan. 1.
The island was put on a level B alert -- the second-highest of a four-level system -- Dec. 17 after a military researcher exposed himself to the SARS virus in a laboratory and fell ill.

The results of an investigation released Thursday determined that it is an isolated case, as the victim was infected in a maximum-security laboratory with a biosafety level of four and the chance of the virus getting out of the laboratory are virtually nil.

Thirty-four people who had come into close contact with the patient, including members of his family and passengers who sat near him on airplanes to and from Singapore, were told to quarantine themselves at home for ten days.
The patient was reported to be recovering at the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, which is equipped to treat SARS patients.
His doctor said he might be taken off a respirator Saturday if he continues to improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 20, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven-member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPERATURES DROP TO RECORD LOW IN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The temperature dropped to this year's lowest level Sunday morning in Taiwan, but it will begin to get a little warmer in the afternoon, the Central Weather Bureau said.

A CWB meteorologist said that, in early Sunday morning,the temperature dropped to 7.7 degrees Celsius in Chiayi in central Taiwan, 9.7 degrees Celsius in Yungkang in southern Taiwan, and 12.6 degrees Celsius in Tamshui in northern Taiwan.

He said, however, that it will begin to get warmer in the afternoon with temperatures rising to 17 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 22 degrees Celsius in central Taiwan, and 24 degrees Celsius in southern Taiwan.
The meteorologist said the temperature may plunge under 12 degrees Celsius on Thursday due to the arrival of a cold front.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO SPEED UP ANTI-SPAM LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: The authorities were urged Sunday to accelerate the pace of legislation on anti-spam laws to reduce waste in social costs, ward off infringement of privacy and alleviate the other social problems attributed to unsolicited e-mail.

Huang Ching-ning, a lawyer with the non-profit Institute for Information Industry, said that Taiwan should emulate the United States, the European Union and Australia in enacting regulations to govern unsolicited e-mail, or spam to prevent the development of Taiwan's e-industry from being adversely affected.

An opinion poll conducted recently by the non-profit Secure Online Shopping Association (SOSA) shows that some 40 percent of the e-mail received daily by domestic Internet users is unwanted junk mail, causing a tremendous waste of time and energy on the part of consumers, as well as degradation of business efficiency.
According to SOSA, unwanted e-mail cost businesses in the United States US$9 billion in lost productivity in 2002, making it an issue worthy of serious attention.

SOSA officials noted that the governor of California signed into law the toughest ever anti-spam measures in September, calling for a ban on junk e-mail and slapping fines of up to US$1 million on offenders.
Last week, they said, U.S. President George W. Bush signed the "CAN-SPAM Act" aimed at reining in the waves of unwanted e-mail. The act was approved by the U.S. Congress in November.

Liu Chiang-ping, director of the Institute of Intellectual Property Studies of National Chengchi University, said that in addition to the U.S. action, other governments, including those of the United Kingdom and Singapore, have also in recent months enacted legislation to control the tide of spam.

Liu attributed the growing percentage of offensive Internet bulk advertising and pornographic junk e-mail to the fact that sending such mail is relatively cheaper than sending postal "snail" mail or running television advertisements.

The professor said, however, that despite the urgency of the enactment of laws, some critics in Taiwan are opposed to its enactment, saying that such a law would run counter to the spirit of freedom of speech.
According to Liu, in Taiwan, only SOSA provides businesses and advertising firms with non-binding self-disciplinary measures aimed at regulating the content of electronic messages.
He said that so far there have only been "discussions" on the enactment of related laws and that Taiwan "has a long way to go" before it will see an anti-spam bill passed into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACKDOWN ON COMMERCIAL PIRACY SUCCESSFUL: NPA

TEXT.P: Police efforts to crack down on commercial piracy have been successful this year, with the seizure of a record high of 5,743 fake products of famous brand names as of the end of November, a spokesman for the National Police Administration (NPA) reported Sunday.

As the lunar New Year holiday approaches, police authorities islandwide have recently launched a new clampdown, the spokesman said, adding that they nabbed nearly 400 bootlegged products with an estimated value of about NT$1 billion (about US$29.4 million) just over the past three days.

The pirated goods seized by police range from bags, clothes, watches, cellular phone cases and cosmetics, which were all imitations of big-name brands such as Gucci, LV, Nike, Rolex, Montblanc, Nokia and Motorola, as well as many newly published popular music CDs and video games, as well as computer software programs, VCDs and DVDs, the spokesman noted.

Police officers around the island focused their anti-piracy search on traditional markets, night markets, business centers and shopping malls, suspected warehouses and factories and over the Internet, while the immigration authorities and customs officials have stepped up their scrutiny at seaports and airports nationwide.

The results obtained by the police strongly underscore the government's resolve to stamp out violations of intellectual property rights in rapport with Taiwan's commitment and the promises it made to gain entry to the World Trade Organization, he said, noting that the NPA also offers handsome incentives to encourage police officers to carry out their mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SEEK REVISIONS TO REFERENDUM BILL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will seek revisions to the referendum bill after it is promulgated by President Chen Shui-bian, an official of the DPP legislative caucus said Sunday.
Chen Chi-mai, secretary-general of the DPP caucus, claimed that some provisions of the bill are unreasonable and impracticable.
Chen said that the DPP will also address the flaws in the bill by asking the Council of Grand Justices to determine whether the bill is unconstitutional.

He revealed that the DPP plans to eliminate the Legislative Yuan's right to initiate a referendum and screen the referendum subjects, to grant the right to initiate a referendum to the Executive Yuan, and to lower the threshold of the number of signatures needed to initiate a referendum among the general public.
The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan rejected the Executive Yuan's request to reconsider the newly enacted referendum bill Friday, dealing another blow to the DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAUNCHES MECHANISM FOR OFFICIALS IN ELECTION CAMPAIGNS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun met with the heads of government agencies Sunday to exchange views on President Chen Shui-bian's campaign for re-election, formally starting the mechanism for officials campaigning for the presidency.

As the premier had earlier asked government officials to abide by the "administrative neutrality" principle, meaning that they will not use official resources or work hours to engage in campaign activities, the officials did not use their official vehicles to go to the Taipei International Convention Center for the meeting with the premier.

In addition, government heads who have independent terms, such as the minister of National Defense, the chairman of the Central Election Commission, the governor of the Central Bank of China and chairman of the Fair Trade Commission, were not present at the meeting, also as part of the "administrative neutrality" principle.

The premier said before the meeting that in democratic politics, it is only natural for appointed officials to take part in campaign activities, but he criticized the opposition Kuomintang for conducting party affairs in government offices when it was in power, and for allowing government officials to concurrently serve as party officials during its rule, "blurring the ethical line between the party and the government and resulting in a waste of government resources."
This is why, he said, has used his personal name to invite the officials to exchange views on the campaign "over tea."

He said that in democratic politics, officials must do their duty and carry out their campaign obligations, and that the Executive Yuan must establish a "fair and transparent " system for election campaigns.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, then reported on the current situation and public polls on the presidential election. Chiou serves as a key member of the president's re-election campaign team.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR-END BONUSES SLIGHTLY BETTER THIS YEAR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan white-collar workers are expected to receive an average year-end bonus worth 1.46 months of salary for their performance over the past year, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.

According to the results of the poll, carried out by the executive research Website 9999.com.tw, domestic businesses will reward their workers with year-end bonuses worth 1.46 months of salary in appreciation for their efforts over the past year.

The average is slightly up compared to the year-earlier bonus of 1.33 months, reflecting that domestic businesses performed better this year, but it falls slightly short of the workers' general expectation of 1.55 months, the survey shows.

According to the results, employees in financial sector will get the most handsome bonuses worth 2.56 months of their salaries for 2003, followed by workers in the foreign trade sector and by those in service brokerage sector. The ranking for the hi-tech sector fell to ninth from fourth for last year, it discovers.

Workers in the restaurant and entertainment sector, as well as those in the publishing business and tourist agencies are the least fortunate, mainly because of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the first half of this year.

Local tourist agency workers, at the bottom, could receive an average bonus of just 1.07 months for 2003, a fall from the 2002 level of 1.17 months, according to the poll. Many tourist agencies failed to ride out the SARS impact and have folded.

Despite the negative impact of SARS, some 46 percent of domestic companies said their operations have been more profitable this year, ahead of about 27 percent that said they were stable and 25 percent which acknowledged a decline in business.

Around 33 percent said they have met their annual profit target, while about 23 percent said they have outperformed their set objective for the year. At the same time, some 38 percent said they are set to register a lower-than-expected profit, with around 21 percent claiming that they are effectively running in the red, according to the survey.

Out of a total of 85 percent of the business owners surveyed, including those who expect a drop in profit, 55 percent said they will give year-end bonuses this year because it is a "routine practice."

Some 44 percent said they will do so because they made "good profit" and 32 percent cited "workers' good performance" as the major reasons for the bonuses. About 22 percent said their year-end bonus is aimed at encouraging workers to stay, according to the poll.
The survey was conducted Dec. 2-15 among 60,000 companies in 21 business categories and received valid responses from 3,150 business owners, with a margin of error of 2.35 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTECTING RIGHTS OF DISABLED IS GOVERNMENT GOAL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that promotion of the rights of the disabled is one of the government's goals.
Chen said that the government is striving to establish a "fair and just" welfare state and that it will adopt a "pragmatic and creative" approach to promote the welfare and services for the disabled.

He noted that as of the end of September, around 810,000 people in Taiwan are registered as disabled, or around 3.73 percent of the population. This, he said, highlights the fact that their basic needs should be addressed and their rights better protected.
He noted that the government has appropriated a budget of NT$24.99 billion (US$73.5 million) this year to take care of the welfare of the disabled.

In addition, he said that in order to better provide for the disabled in low and middle-income families, the monthly subsidies for them will be raised by NT$1,000 to between NT$3,000 and NT$7,000 starting Jan. 1.

Chen said that to promote "equal opportunities, full participation and independent living in happiness and dignity" for the disabled is the government's goal, but he also pointed out that the government's resources are limited and he appealed for the assistance of the private sector to provide better care for the disabled.
The president made the remarks when he participated an activity for the disabled in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIGER BITES A MAN IN TAIPEI ZOO

TEXT.P: An employee of the Taipei Zoo was bitten by a tiger Sunday afternoon when he was cleaning an outdoor animal display area in the zoo.
Yang tsung-hsian, president of the zoo, said the employee was bitten in the leg. He has been sent to a hospital for treatment.
Yang said that no tiger had bitten people in the zoo before, and that the man was bitten at 2 p.m. by a three-year-old female Bengali tiger, who was born in the zoo on Nov. 20, 2000.

The biggest zoo in Taiwan, Taipei Zoo has more than 2,300 animals in 310 different species.There are eight outdoor display areas and several indoor display areas. The man was bitten in the Asian Tropical Rainforests Animal Area. In the Education Center of the zoo there are special houses displaying nocturnal animals, koalas, penuins, insects, and other animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL COMPETE WITH CHINESE COMMUNISTS IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE: VP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be competing with the Chinese Communist Party in the March 20 presidential election, Vice President Annette Lu claimed Sunday.

Speaking at the inauguration of an association of supporters of the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Lu in Taichung City, central Taiwan, Lu said that the DPP beat the Kuomintang (KMT) in the 2000 presidential election and claimed that that it will be competing with the Chinese communists in the next presidential race.
She did not elaborate on her claim, but said that Chen chose her again as his running mate as he considers her relatively more daring to criticize the Chinese communists.
Also, Lu said, it is better that a president and his vice president belong to the same political party, otherwise it will bring political uncertainty to the country.

Chen and Lu have been named by the DPP to run for re-election in the March presidential election and face a strong challenge by the ticket formed by KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

Chen defeated Lien and Soong in a three-way race in 2000, in which Lien represented the KMT that ruled Taiwan for more than five decades and Soong ran as an independent candidate after quitting the KMT prior to the election.
More than 3,000 people attended the Taichung ceremony to express their support for the Chen-Lu ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES CONTINUED INSISTENCE ON REFORMS, DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his belief Sunday in democracy and reforms when he spoke to the graduates of a school he founded earlier this year.

The president said that compared to the 23 million people of Taiwan, the 600 alumni of the inaugural class of the Ketagalan Academy is not a large number, but he said that as long as they realize and carry out their historic missions, they will "successfully galvanize the dynamism of the Taiwan people."

The president said history clearly indicates that insistence on democracy and reforms is the right direction and he urged the graduates to "believe in themselves and in Taiwan" to help create a splendid chapter in Taiwan's history.
Chen said that although he faces re-election soon, he is most concerned now "not about the results of the election, but about how to continue the ideals of reforms."
He said he would not confront the anti-reform forces, but would rather adopt the approach of dialogue with them because he believes that the flow of democracy cannot be deterred by individuals.

He also said that it requires time to strengthen democracy, which is why he chose to use the most time-consuming, yet most solid way to help democratic reforms -- the founding of the Ketagalan Academy, a school established March 29, 2003 to nurture the nation's future leaders.

Chen said that looking at the history of Taiwan after World War II, one can see that the country has achieved tremendous success with its economy, but he said the opening up of society has been comparably very slow.

He said he believes Taiwan people are born with tenacity and dynamism. They weathered the Kuomintang's white terror following the tragic Feb. 28 incident, and the suppression of martial law, but in the late 1980s, they were able to break free from the shackles of authoritarian rule.

From the lifting of martial law, the comprehensive election of the Legislative Yuan, the popular presidential election of 1996 to the political power transfer of 2000, the dynamism of the Taiwan people was finally able to be released.
Chen said that over the past decade, he has seen the release of this dynamism, but he has also seen the impact of different social forces.

"Even more than three years after political power transfer, Taiwan society today is still trying to build up a new order, " Chen said, adding that "the value and ideals pursued in the past need to be clarified and implemented."
He said that he had hoped that the political power transfer would bring a new start for Taiwan so that the dynamism of the Taiwan people could be pooled and reforms pushed forward.

But he lamented that even though "the Taiwan people have chosen political power transfer and democratic reforms, some political figures, clinging to their past glory and resisting reforms, have tried to drag their feet on the pace of national progress through political bickering without considering the well-being of the nation."
Chen said that the strength of a single individual is small, but pooling the strength of individuals with ideals and the will to implement their ideals can change history.
He said that graduation is the start of responsibility, and he exhorted the alumni to sow the seeds of democracy.
The 600 alumni said they would throw their weight behind Chen's re-election campaign.
Chen Chi-mai, president of the alumni of the Ketagalan Academy, said one should carefully choose the right national leader -- one who can uphold the nation's core values.
Chen Chi-mai said that only if President Chen wins the March presidential election will he be able to "deepen the nation's democracy, insist on reforms and bring a better future to the nation."

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH TYCOON REMEMBERS OLD PAL WHO SHARES HUMANISTIC IDEALS

TEXT.P: Barry Lam, chairman of Quanta Computer, remembered with sobs recently his National Taiwan University classmate Sayling Wen, one of Taiwan's first calculator-makers, who went on to become a pioneer of the island's information technology industry and died of cerebral hemorrhage earlier this month.

Lam, who is camera-shy despite being a successful high-technology tycoon, has been reluctantly in the spotlight recently because of the passing of Wen, who had been Lam's old pal and business partner for decades.
Extremely alike, both Lam and Wen are known as hi-tech giants as well as great men who champion and herald humanistic ideals and put their ideals into practice.

According to Lam, he invested NT$5 billion (US$147 million) to establish the Quanta Research Center, which is not just a research center for "hard and cold" science and technology, but an institution full of humanistic interest, including a concert hall, an art gallery and a library.
Lam and Wen were bunkmates during their university and postgraduate NTU years and as business partners at Kinpo Electronics, which was one of the country's first calculator manufacturers.
Wen, 55, who became president of calculator manufacturer Santron at the age of 24, went into a coma Dec. 5 due to a hemorrhagic stroke and was rushed to hospital. He never awoke from the coma.
His sudden passing caught unprepared his old friends from Santron and the thousands of staff members of Inventec Group, one of the major notebook and IT device manufacturers in Taiwan.
Wen, Lam and Chiang Ying-tsun, former chairman of GVC Electronics, co-founded Santron Electronics in 1972 to manufacture electronic devices and Taiwan's first-generation electronic calculators.
In 1973, at the age of 25, Wen, Lam and some other IT enthusiasts jointly established Kinpo Electronics to expand their manufacture of calculators as well as to research and develop simple computers.

In 1975, Wen and classmate Yeh Kuo-yi co-founded Inventec Group to make computer peripherals and related products. The founding of these companies paved the way for Taiwan's transition into a global hardware manufacturing powerhouse.

By the age of 26, Wen had traveled to 43 countries, most of the time traveling with a suitcase containing calculators and other innovative electronic devices. By the age of 40, he had traveled to 70 countries around the world, spending about 300 days out of every year in hotels or aboard airplanes.
At 50, Wen retired from the electronics business, as he had planned, and became a writer and a philanthropist.

In 2000, he found himself in the rural township of Huangyangchuan in Gansu Province, one of the poorest areas of mainland China. He said at the time that seeing the local residents there living in grinding poverty brought him to the verge of tears.
He spent the entire year of 2002 traveling around 12 provinces in western, southern and northern China, trying to figure out the best ways to help impoverished mainland people.

That same year, he set up the Qian-Xiang-Wan-Cai Co. in Huangyangchuan to establish a computerized network at a cost of US$50 million in western mainland China as a fast track on which the locals' livelihood could be improved.

Meanwhile, he invested US$5 million to build a five-star, 150-room hotel-like conference center in Huangyangchuan, claiming that the hotel would serve as a home away from home for businessmen. "Only by attracting the wealthy to poor areas will the poor be freed from poverty," he said at the time.
Wen was also planning to establish a software development company in Huangyangchuan to turn the backwater into a high-tech hub in western China.
By early 2003, Wen was the talk of the town in western China.
A philanthropist, Wen himself led the simplest life that he possibly could. Being a little bit plump, Wen stopped eating anything after 3 p.m. every day and only drank diet cola after that hour.
Despite the wealth he accumulated over the past three decades, Wen once said that the richness of life derived from his experiences over the years was his only real fortune.

Wen had his first book published at the age of 49 when he and his friends, including renowned cartoonist Tsai Chih-chung, co-founded the Studio for Tomorrow. In the following six years, he authored 20 books on business management and philosophy, English learning, the development potential of western China, and on various other subjects.

In fact, according to Tsai, Wen's greatest ambition was to become a novelist writing exclusively Chinese kung fu novels. Wen began to write kung fu novels as a ghost writer in high school to earn money to help his mother make ends meet, Tsai said.

Tsai used the Chinese word "kuan, " which can mean either "wide" or "magnanimous, " to describe Wen. He said Wen had a wide body and was a "wide-minded" man who always demonstrated magnanimity toward his family and friends.

Wen was impartial politically, giving support to any party that he considered was doing a good thing for the people and the country. He once gave the Democratic Progressive Party NT$500,000 in cash to help out the then-opposition party during its most difficult years.

More recently, he was scheduled to attend a ceremony marking the establishment of the national presidential campaign headquarters of the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Lien Chan and James Soong slated for Dec. 7 to drum up support for the major opposition camp. He never made it.
He left numerous "quotable quotes" in his online chats, such as: "The computer is my office, " "Working is a duty as well as a joy, " and "Flying is a time for writing and sleeping."

He also wrote during one of his online chats that: "Busy is staying for only one day at one hotel and not having time to have your clothes washed. Leisure is staying at the same hotel for three days or more."

More than 10,000 people went to a memorial service held in Huangyangchuan Saturday to pay their last respects to Wen, who, according to the Hong Kong-based Wenweipao daily, came from "all the cities and villages in the western Chinese province of Gansu."

Chen Yun-lin, chief of mainland China's State Council Taiwan Affairs Office, went to a memorial service in Beijing Dec. 17 to pay his respects to Wen for his invaluable contributions in the efforts to speed up intellectual development in western China. The service was sponsored by the Inventec Group's affiliate in Beijing. He also sent his condolences to Wen's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIGER BITES A MAN IN TAIPEI ZOO

TEXT.P: An employee of the Taipei Zoo was bitten by a tiger Sunday afternoon when he was cleaning an outdoor animal display area in the zoo.
Yang tsung-hsian, president of the zoo, said the employee was bitten in the leg. He has been sent to a hospital for treatment.

The biggest zoo in Taiwan, Taipei Zoo has more than 2,300 animals in 310 different species. There are eight outdoor display areas and several indoor display areas. The man was bitten in the Asian Tropical Rainforests Animal Area. In the Education Center of the zoo there are special houses displaying nocturnal animals, koalas, penguins, insects, and other animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ZEN MASTER GIVES BUDDHIST LECTURES IN VANCOUVER

TEXT.P: Zen Buddhist Master Sheng Yen of Taiwan delivered a lecture on Buddha's teachings in Vancouver Saturday, titled "A Peaceful Mind is the Source of all Peace."

In his first speech in Canada in eight years, Sheng Yen said that peace is fortune, that peace derives from the heart and that if one seeks peace, one must first examine the thoughts circulating in one's mind.

Talking about a recent journey he made to the Middle East, Sheng Yen said that he was advised by many people prior to the journey against going there, on the grounds that it would be unsafe to travel in an area rife with military conflicts.

Sheng Yen said he had no fear because his mind was at peace. He said it is his honor to share Buddha's teachings with people and policy makers in the Middle East at a time when peace is keenly needed worldwide.
More than 2,300 people, Chinese as well as foreigners, attended Sheng Yen's Vancouver speech.
Sheng Yen traveled to Israel and Palestine Dec. 9-15 in an effort to help put an end to conflict in the area by means of spiritual enlightenment.

Traveling with some 20 world religious leaders, Sheng Yen, a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, was hoping to use the power of religion to bridge the differences between the two sides, who have been at odds for many years, according to officials of the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Association (DDMBA) in Taipei.

During the week-long "spiritual journey" in the Middle East, Sheng Yen presented two words -- mercy and wisdom -- to the Israeli and Palistinian people and political leaders as the keys to the pursuit of peace, the DDMBA officials said.

Sheng Yen called for the leaderships of both Israel and Palestine to use wisdom to work out solutions to their differences while practicing mercy on all the people in the region regardless of their political affiliation or religion, so as to not let down the people living in the Holy Land.

Sheng Yen and his party met with Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qureia during a symposium held in Jerusalem Dec. 11. After hearing Sheng Yen's preaching, Qureia reportedly applauded enthusiastically and said to his aides that he looks forward to seeing Sheng Yen's suggestions put into practice.

At a colloquium held at the Israeli prime minister's office Dec. 14, Sheng Yen delivered a speech to ranking Israeli officials, including Cabinet officials, parliamentary advisers and government consultants in news and religious affairs, according to the DDMBA officials.

In his speech, Sheng Yen interpreted Islamic doctrine as stipulating that Jihad -- or holy war -- does not mean to strive to defeat others, but instead to defeat one's own evil thoughts. "This is an idea almost the same as the Buddhist concept of conquering the evil in one's mind," Sheng Yen noted.
Sheng Yen said he hopes that all the followers of Islam, Judaism and Christianity will reach out their hands to one another so that world peace will prevail.

Sheng Yen, author of many books on Buddhism both in Chinese and in English, is respected in Taiwan, mainland China and around the world. As a Zen master, his teachings emphasize that practitioners should in their daily lives be constantly aware of the thoughts circulating in their minds.

Such awareness allows people to simplify their minds and to clearly perceive changes in themselves and in their environment, he explained. Wisdom is developed so that people can apply it in their workaday lives to face themselves, grow and dissolve their attachments and enter into a state of "no-self."

Sheng Yen has been actively engaged in inter-faith exchanges that advocate and promote religious understanding. His involvement in such global activities includes being a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders and delivering the keynote address at the 2000 Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders in New York.

In Taiwan, he founded the DDMBA, which now has over one million followers. In the United States, he has been teaching the Buddhadharma since 1975, leading to the founding of two centers, one in New York City and one in Upstate New York.
After concluding his week-long journey in the Middle East, Sheng Yen flew to New York Dec. 15 to continue his preaching in North America, which also took him to Vancouver, Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAL ESTATE MARKET PREDICTED TO BE BULLISH IN 2004

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real estate market will remain bullish for the coming year as the end of a booming 2003 approaches, business sources forecast Sunday.

Thanks to an economic recovery taking place both at home and abroad, business sources said the domestic real estate sector will continue its boom into 2004, despite some uncertainties related to the March presidential election and bank interest rates.

They said they are confident that the ailing market over the past decade will fully regain its momentum in the coming year, evidenced in that consumer confidence and business conditions have been greatly improved.
According to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior, house transfer dealings for the whole of 2003 are expected to total around 334,000, slightly up by 4.4 percent over the 2002 level.
The growth shows that buying has made a noticeable comeback, despite the marked impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on business in the first half of the year, the sources noted.

Chang Hsin-min, an assistant manager of the Sinyi Realty Estate Inc., attributed the good performance to a "three lows" situation -- low house prices, low bank interest rates and a 50-percent cut in land value increment tax, in addition to the preferential loans worth NT$280 million (US$8.24 billion) gradually released by banks since August in line with government policy.

Although some uncertainties remain at home and in the international arena, Chang said an improved economy has anticipated a booming market in 2004, particularly in the aftermath of the March presidential election, even if the preferential loans are used up or the 50-percent discount in land value increment tax is canceled.

The domestic real estate market has managed to gain a new lease on life amid a recession in recent years and a bullish market is expect to set off in 2004, as long as war does not erupt across the Taiwan Strait following the presidential race and as long as the stock market continues to grow, he predicted.

An investigation by Sinyi Realty Estate Inc. shows that the domestic real estate market has the potential to expand by between 5 percent and 10 percent over the next year in terms of transaction numbers and house prices, respectively.
Newly built houses near major traffic networks or prime public space will be good targets for sales, according to the investigation results.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TAKES PART TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL MARATHON

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou took part in the 2003 Taipei International Marathon Sunday, running the 21-kilometer "half marathon" that was one of various races featured in the annual event.
Ma, 54, a devoted amateur runner, finished the marathon with a time of 1:59: 30, ranking 444th among the runners taking part in the category.
The 2003 Taipei International Marathon kicked off at 5 a.m. in front of Taipei City Hall upon Ma firing an inaugural starting pistol. About 7,000 runners from home and abroad took part in the event.

The marathon attracted many long-distance runners from around the world, including Krzysztof Przybyla from Poland, Mark Hutchinson from Australia, Ludek Hudak from the Czech Republic and the youngest foreign marathoner this year, 27-year-old Naoki Hirasawa from Japan. Top Taiwan runners included Wu Wen-chien.

In the same event last year, South African marathoner Mluleki Nobanda won the gold medal in men's 40-kilometer race with a time of 2:30:14, while Russia's Anfissa Kossatcheva finished first among the women, with a time of 2:36:24.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 21, or the 28th day of the 11th month of Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY HELPS OPEN EXPORT OUTLETS FOR TAIWAN FRUITS, VEGETABLES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) has helped open up export outlets for locally grown fruits and vegetables, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.
According to COA tallies, at least 17 kinds of Taiwan-grown fruits and vegetables have been exported to 12 countries or areas since Taiwan's WTO accession Jan. 1, 2002.

COA officials said Taiwan has long produced many high-quality fruits and vegetables. However, these were mainly for domestic consumption in the past. Taiwan's WTO entry has offered easier access for the island's agricultural products into global markets, the officials noted.

Major Taiwan fruit and vegetable export items include pineapples, papayas, lichees, star fruit, oranges, bananas, mangos, bell fruit, grapes, guavas, spinach, carrots, cabbage, parsley, lettuce, great burdock and scallion.
Major export outlets include mainland China, Japan, Hong Kong, the European Union, the United States, Singapore, Canada, Australia, Brunei, Indonesia and Vietnam.

The COA officials said they have collected information on the regulations in these countries and areas regarding pesticide residue limits for reference by local farm produce exporters as well as farmers associations.
"We hope farmers will take precautionary measures to prevent violations of those countries' pesticide residue regulations and protect our business reputation," a COA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD STAY IN OPPOSITION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) should stay in opposition until it gives back its ill-gotten assets to the people, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.
Chatting with journalists at a tea party, the president said the KMT is hardly qualified to be in power again unless it hands back the assets it accumulated illegally in its five decades of rule.

The president, who is engaged in a pitched battle against KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the race for the presidency in 2004, believes the embezzled KMT assets is the opposition's Achilles heel in the campaign and he and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have been focusing their fire on the issue.

Chen said the KMT's ill-gotten assets are a relic of the country's past authoritarian regime and claimed that the party has done nothing to address the issue in the three years since it lost the 2000 presidential election.

The party has never given a full account of his assets, far less giving any back to the people, according to Chen. The DPP has tried more than 30 times in the last three years to press for a law to force the KMT to face up to the problem but has been blocked because of the opposition's legislative majority.
In order to push the party to relinquish its stolen assets, the president said, the KMT should be denied the power to rule in the forthcoming presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIB DENIES TAIWAN SPIES ARRESTED IN MAINLAND CHINA: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Both the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) have denied that any of their spies have been arrested in the mainland since President Chen Shui-bian announced that Beijing has 496 missiles aimed at Taiwan, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Wen-chung said Monday.

As a member of the National Defense Committee at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said he checked with the MND and the MIB about reports that 36 people spying for Taiwan on the mainland were arrested as a result of President Chen's Nov. 30 remarks, and was told that none of their agents has been arrested since Nov. 30.

Displaying satellite photos downloaded from a U.S. Website, Lee told a news conference that the pictures clearly show every one of Beijing's missile launch trucks. Since each truck is equipped with six missiles, it is easy to figure out the total number of missiles targeting Taiwan, he pointed out.

According to the pictures posted on the Website, Lee said, Beijing has deployed 96 missiles in Lepin, Jiangxi Province, 96 missiles in Ganxian, also in Jiangxi Province, 96 missiles in Meizhou, Guangdong Province, 144 missiles in Yongan, Fujian Province, all of which are within range of Taiwan.

Lee said the information about Beijing's missile deployment depends more on satellite photos than intelligence gathered by spies. The Hong Kong newspaper that claimed Chen has exposed the sources of Taiwan's intelligence, thereby risking the lives of Taiwan's spies on the mainland by making public the number of Beijing's missiles, is militarily ignorant, he added.

He disputed a claim made by a retired intelligence official that a local intelligence unit has lost contact with several agents on the mainland since the president revealed the number of Beijing's missiles, saying that it is a politically motivated accusation aimed at smearing the president.
Lee called the news conference in response to a report by Hong Kong's Ming Pao daily that claimed Beijing had arrested 36 Taiwan spies as a result of Chen's Nov. 30 missile remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES KMT CHAIRMAN TO DEAL WITH PARTY ASSETS HONESTLY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday to handle its party assets in an "honest, credible and sincere" manner and said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan should "face history honestly."

The premier made the remarks as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party continued to prioritize the assets of the KMT -- once one of the richest parties in the world -- as one of its campaign themes in the run-up to the March presidential election.
The premier said that the KMT should publish a list of its ill-gotten assets and return them to the national coffers.

On the KMT's stance that former President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui should be held responsible for handling party assets, Yu said that this is an internal party matter and that it should not use such a pretext to drag its feet on the issue.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Lin Chuan said he will check on the status of the KMT's land lots, including the site of the KMT headquarters as well as the Broadcasting Cooperation of China in downtown Taipei.

As for property already relinquished by the KMT, such as seven theaters that the party renounced ownership of last week, Lin said the National Property Bureau has established contact with the KMT and both sides agreed that the transfer will be completed in a simple manner.
KMT officials said Monday that since Lien took over the helm of the party in April 2000, he has dealt with the party assets issue "openly and transparently."

The officials also claimed that April 2000 should be the cut-off point and that the party would be willing to cooperate with investigators to probe any assets obtained in dubious circumstances before that time.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP that claims former President Lee as its "spiritual leader, " decided Monday that it would form an action alliance to reclaim the KMT's assets.
TSU officials said that they will invite private academic and other groups to join the action alliance to push the KMT into giving back the assets that belong rightfully to the Taiwan people.
They also welcomed those that have been used by the KMT as figurehead owners of party assets to make such assets appear to be privately owned to come forward with evidence against the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS, IMPORTS TO REGISTER DOUBLE-DIGIT GROWTH IN 2004: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports will register double-digit growth in 2004, according to a report carried out by the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research and released Monday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

The report said that this will be possible because of the end of the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks earlier this year and the end of the U.S.-led war in Iraq, as well as the economic recovery in the United States.
Taiwan's major competitors will still be Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong, the report said.
The report estimated that exports in 2003 could reach US$142.666 billion, up 9.24 percent, while imports will reach US$123.619 billion, up 9.85 percent.

Riding on the coattails of the strong performance in the third and fourth quarters in 2003, exports in 2004 should reach US$158.2 billion, up 10.89 percent, while imports will reach US$138.322 billion, up 11.89 percent, the report said.

It also said that the factors favorable to Taiwan's exports in 2004 will include the strong economic rebound in the United States, while the leading indicators in other advanced countries such as Japan, Britain, France and Germany have also consistently signalled economic recovery.

Unfavorable factors will include the possible raising of interest rates in early 2004 by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, coupled with the continued sluggishness of the U.S. dollar against the yen and the euro, which will burden the economic recovery in Japan and the European Union and in turn affect the world economy.

The BOFT compared Taiwan's trade performance with nine economies in South Asia -- South Korea, Japan, mainland China, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Hong Kong. Taiwan ranked fifth among the 10 economies, showing that there is room for improvement, as its gross domestic product and per capita product ranked fourth among the 10.
BOFT officials said that Taiwan should make good use of its geographic location to develop the country into a mid-point of the world supply chain.
