DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DENIES ALLEGATION ABOUT LAFAYETTE KICKBACK SETTLEMENT TALKS

TEXT.P: The Navy General Headquarters (NGH) denied any knowledge Monday about negotiations between Taiwan and France over an out-of-court settlement for a kickback scandal involving Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette-class frigates.
NGH Chief of Staff Huang Cheng-yun issued the denial at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Committee.

During the meeting, Legislator Ku Chung-lien of the opposition People First Party, who once served as navy commander-in-chief, claimed that Thales Co. of France sent representatives to Taiwan Dec. 10 to discuss with "high-ranking ROC authorities" whether the Lafayette kickback scandal could be settled out of court.

According to Ku, Thales will send executives to Taiwan again in January to further discuss the issue. Ku demanded that the relevant military and judicial authorities explain their stances on the issue.
In response, Huang said the NGH has no knowledge of the alleged out-of-court settlement negotiations.

Huang said the NGH had already filed an application with a French arbitrary court in August 2001 to demand that Thales repay US$500 million in illegal kickbacks for the Lafayette deal and to compensate the navy to the tune of US$90 million for damage to its reputation.
According to the navy's warship procurement contract, the French contractor was banned from paying any commission or kickbacks for the deal.
Nevertheless, Huang said, Thales filed a countersuit against Taiwan for alleged violations of the procurement contract and demanded that the navy pay US$200 million in damages.

Huang said the suits might take many years to settle through legal procedures. "We at the NGH have never heard of information about the claimed negotiations for an out-of-court settlement, " he added.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice Minister of Justice Hsieh Wen-ting and State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa said the judicial authorities are not in a position to get involved in a civil suit between the navy and Thales.
"Judicial authorities are only responsible for investigating whether any ROC national has illegally taken kickbacks in the Lafayette deal," Lu said.
The ROC Navy purchased six Lafayette frigates built by French defense contractor Thomson-CSF for US$2.8 billion in 1991. Thomson-CSF was taken over by Thales in 2000.

Allegations of kickbacks over the deal emerged after the death of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng, head of the navy's arms acquisition office, whose body was found floating in the sea off the east coast of Taiwan in late 1993.
Since Aug. 1, 2000, a special investigative team headed by Lu has been probing arms procurement scandals allegedly connected with the death of Yin.
It has been alleged that Yin was murdered to prevent him from blowing the whistle on rampant corruption in the military -- including the Lafayette deal.

The investigation team has so far indicted six middle-ranking naval officers on charges of inflating the Lafayette price tag for the benefit of the French contractor. Three other naval officers have also been indicted for irregularities in the procurement of an order of minesweepers.

As for the murder case, no major breakthrough has been achieved because key suspect Andrew Wang, an arms broker who is believed to be deeply involved in the Lafayette kickback scandal, remains at large, reportedly residing in London.
The investigation team has not yet discovered any hard evidence of alleged Lafayette kickbacks paid to Taiwan officials.
To speed up the investigations, the team has recently recruited several prosecutors versed in financial and banking affairs to assist in tracking the money trail.

The Swiss Ministry of Justice announced earlier this month that a federal court has ruled that Taiwan, France and the Principality of Liechtenstein should be given access to Swiss legal files, particularly documents regarding the Andrew Wang family's bank accounts in Switzerland, to facilitate investigations into an alleged kickback scandal in connection with Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette frigates.
Swiss judicial authorities have frozen Wang's Swiss bank accounts, which contain some US$600 million in slush funds suspected of being kickbacks from the Lafayette frigate deal.
Wang fled Taiwan in 1993 and has been wanted since September 2000 for suspected involvement in the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal and the subsequent murder of Yin.

Wang and his son, Wang Chia-hsing, might also have bank accounts with deposits totaling US$100 million in Liechtenstein and the British-administered Cayman Islands in the Caribbean Sea, according to previous press reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGE INCREASES

TEXT.P: Foreign investment in the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) has increased by NT$534.4 billion (US$15.71 billion) so far this year, according to statistics released Monday by the TAIEX.
As of Dec. 19, the statistics show, foreign investors had bought shares with a market value of NT$2.398 trillion and had sold NT$1.863 trillion-worth of stocks listed on the bourse.
The foreign investors held stocks with a combined market value of NT$2.808 trillion as of last Friday, accounting for 23.04 percent of the total, the tallies reveal.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPY RING BUST REPORT DISMISSED AS ILL-MOTIVATED

TEXT.P: Government authorities dismissed as an "ill-motivated rumor" a Hong Kong press report Monday that mainland China had uncovered a huge Taiwan spy ring following the revelation by President Chen Shui-bian of the exact number of mainland Chinese ballistic missiles aimed at locations in Taiwan.
Presidential Office spokesman James Huang said the report was unfounded and a politically motivated attempt to deal a blow to Chen.

The Hong Kong-based Ming Pao daily reported Monday that mainland intelligence authorities had arrested 36 people, including 21 Taiwanese and 15 mainlanders, in mid-December, describing them as one of the biggest Taiwan spy rings Beijing has cracked in recent years.
According to the paper, mainland security authorities were able to track down the spy ring after Chen detailed the Chinese arsenal aimed at the island in a Nov. 30 campaign rally.
"The report is intended to deal a blow to President Chen, " Huang said, adding that some Hong Kong news media often cite unnamed sources to back up their reports for political purposes.
Huang pointed out that Chen had on many occasions mentioned the number and locations of mainland China's missiles pointed at Taiwan long before Nov. 30.
With advanced satellite technology, Huang went on, the mainland's missile deployment can easily be detected and estimated without using traditional intelligence agents.

Meanwhile, officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party noted that the Federation of American Scientists has posted detailed information about mainland China's missile deployment at its Website at www.fas.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE STEP UP PROTECTION OF AMERICANS AFTER U.S. RAISES THREAT LEVEL

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) said Monday that it has stepped up protection of Americans in Taiwan after the United States raised its national threat level to orange the previous day.
On the five-color threat scale, orange means a high risk of terrorist attack. Since May, the level had been at yellow, or an elevated risk and in the middle of the scale.

NPA officials said that in view of the possibility of terrorist attacks, they had stepped up protection of American interests such as the offices of the American Institute in Taiwan in central, southern and northern Taiwan, as well as foreign schools, communities and companies. Police had also stepped up security at harbors and airports.
They said that they had earlier mapped out contingency plans to cope with any possible situation and that police officers at various levels will respond to the world anti-terrorist situation rapidly.

The NPA officials would not disclose how they obtain information from other countries, but high-ranking police officials said that the crackdown on crime is borderless, especially terrorist acts, which should be condemned by all.
Police have obtained first-hand information through various channels and are watching closely the follow-up developments, the officials added.
Saying that they have worked out related protection measures and are keeping abreast of the situation, the officials added that the public have no need to worry.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S., U.K.found Libya had surprisingly advanced arms.
U.S.and British specialists invited into Libya's weapons laboratories and warehouses this fall found an unexpectedly advanced nuclear program and an intensive effort to build more powerful missiles, said senior U.S. officials who had been logging evidence that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi was trying to upgrade his arsenal.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKER MOTIONS TO HOLD REFERENDUM ON NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: Legislator Chiu yi of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Monday that he was collecting signatures from his colleagues for a motion to hold a referendum on whether to continue work on the country's fourth nuclear plant.

In a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Chiu said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has persistently tried to disturb the political water by calling for a referendum on the nuclear plant. In order to forestall them playing the issue against the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and PFP, Chiu said he will seek the sponsorship of other legislators to call for a referendum on the issue and resolve the dispute once and for all.

Citing the newly enacted referendum bill, Chiu said, an issue put to referendum once should be forbidden from being put to referendum again within eight years, which means the DPP would no longer be able to use the plant as an excuse to stir up political disturbances for at least that period of time.
Chiu said he hopes the referendum will be held concurrently with the presidential election of March 20.

Chiu's idea was welcomed by the KMT but frowned upon by his own party. KMT whip at the legislature Lee Chia-chin said the referendum would pre-empt the DPP from using the nuclear plant to pester the government formed after the election.
Noting that KMT Chairman Lien Chan has said his party will neither initiate nor block any referendum on the nuclear plant, Lee said KMT lawmakers will support a motion for referendum on the issue.

However, DPP convener at the legislature Chou Shih-wei said the KMT and the PFP favor the continuation of work on the fourth nuclear plant and will not propose any referendum to the contrary if its purpose is just to pre-empt the DPP from playing up the issue later.

Chou said he will dissuade any PFP lawmaker from calling for a referendum on this issue and will discourage them from sponsoring such a proposal made by the DPP or its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Chou's attitude seemed to reflect the mainstream opinion in the two opposition parties, as a worker for the presidential campaign of Lien Chan, who will pair up with PFP Chairman James Soong on the same ticket, said the two party leaders have agreed to stick to Lien's "neither start nor block" stance on the nuclear plant.

Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan and chief of Lien's campaign, was quoted by an anonymous campaign worker as saying that the KMT-PFP "pan blue alliance, " which succeeded in blocking a DPP attempt to halt the building of the nuclear plant in the early days of President Chen Shui-bian's presidency, need not upstage the DPP by calling for a referendum on the issue.

The two opposition parties will only confuse its supporters if it reopens the debate on an already settled issue, and it is Chen, who ran in 2000 on an anti-nuclear platform, who owes his supporters an explanation as to why he was unable to keep his promise to get rid of the nuclear plant, Wang reportedly said.

Considering that a national referendum will cost the country a fortune, the worker said, the two party leaders are of the opinion that referendum should be used carefully to settle controversies rather than be used as a campaign strategy to boost the profile of the "pan blue alliance."

The construction of the fourth nuclear plant was started by the previous KMT government in 1998 with a price tag of NT$112.5 billion (US$3.3 billion) amid protests from anti-nuclear activists. Chen tried to stop construction after he swept to power in 2000, only to trigger a fierce political struggle with the opposition in the legislature. The opposition, mainly the KMT and PFP, united to force Chen's administration to eat its words and resume construction of the plant in 2001.
Chen, who accepted the defeat with reluctance, vowed in June this year to reopen the issue and put it to referendum before the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE, FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT INCREASES NEARLY 100%

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign direct investments approved in November totaled US$523.99 million, a stunning increase of 94.02 percent from the previous month, according to the latest tallies released Monday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Commission officials said the figure represents the highest monthly increase of the year, showing that a large-scale business conference held in October has successfully solicited foreign direct investment.
The officials said that overseas Chinese and foreign investment in the first 11 months this year amounted to US$2.98 billion, down slightly by 0.62 percent from the same period of last year.

On outbound investment, approved investment in November was US$288.34 million, up 66.53 percent from the previous month. It is estimated that outbound investment in the first 11 months totaled US$2.97 billion, down 5.88 percent from the same period of last year.

In terms of indirect investment in mainland China, the approved investment totaled US$531.42 million in November, up 65.25 percent from the previous month. It is estimated that total investment approved in the first 11 months amounted to US$4.06 billion, up 19.4 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SUSPECTS ARRESTED FOR SMUGGLING HEROIN

TEXT.P: Two suspects were arrested at Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, when they tried to smuggle in 1.34 kilograms of high-purity heroin from Thailand, aviation police said Monday.

Aviation police were tipped off recently that a drug ring had asked Chang Kee-wu, 45, currently unemployed and with prior convictions and reputedly an old drug-smuggling hand, along with his friend Chung Yung-cheng, 43, to bring the drugs to Taiwan.
The ring arranged for Chang and Chung to travel to Thailand Dec. 16, paying them a downpayment of NT$30,000 (US$882.35).
On the night of Dec. 20, the duo were given two pieces of luggage by a ring member known as Ah-yung. The luggage contained carpenters tools as well as the heroin.
They were told that after they arrived at Hsiaokang Airport Ah-yung would contact them to take delivery of the heroin and pay them an additional NT$100,000.
Police turned the two over to the Kaohsiung District Court and are tracing other members of the drug ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Inquiry suggests Pakistanis sold nuclear secrets.
A lengthy investigation of the father of Paki stan's atomic bomb, Abdul Qadeer Khan, by American and European intelligence agencies and international nuclear inspectors has forced Pakistani officials to question his aides and openly confront evidence that the country was the source of crucial technology to enrich uranium for Iran, North Korea and possibly other nations.
The Wall Street Journal: Rules regulating gasoline mileage face an overhaul.
U.S. federal regulators are expected to propose a broad revamping of fuel-economy standards that could pressure auto makers to improve the gas mileage of some of their most lucrative sport-utility vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NEEDS TO EXPAND FIXED INVESTMENT: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Monday that expansion of the government's fixed investment is urgent, as there is already potential pressure for deflation.

Lin, who concurrently serves as the chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan where several legislative committees were reviewing the draft regulations regarding the expansion of public construction projects, which will provide a legal basis for the new 10 major public construction projects recently unveiled by the Cabinet.

Lin noted that government investment in recent years has continued to fall, which he said has not only seriously affected the growth potential of the economy, but has become a major factor in blocking economic growth.

He said that fixed investment accounted for 7.3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) in 1994, compared with only 4.1 percent of the GDP in 2002, adding that fixed investment has shown negative growth since 2000.
He also said that this year, Taiwan's economy has been slowed by the U.S.-led war in Iraq and the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks that occurred between March and June.

Lin said that fixed investment growth in the private sector was minus 11.5 percent, while public construction growth was minus 7.8 percent, so that the economic growth in the second quarter was minus 0.08 percent, or the first negative growth since the fourth quarter of 2001.
He added that it has been estimated that economic growth this year will be between 3.15 percent and 3.2 percent, lower than the targeted 3.52 percent.
Lin also said that consumer prices in 2001 and 2002 dropped by 0.01 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively, with an estimated drop in 2003 of 0.28 percent.
After three consecutive years of drops in consumer prices, there is potential for deflation pressure, which makes an expansion of the government's fixed investment crucial, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED ECONOMIST TO SPEAK AT TAIWAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Noted economist Richard C. Koo will deliver a speech at an economic forum Wednesday, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), sponsor of the forum, said Monday.

Koo, chief economist of Nomura Research Institute as well as economic adviser to the Japanese Cabinet, has on several occasions offered suggestion to Taiwan, becoming a valuable aid to Taiwan's economic and financial agencies in making policies.
Koo, who arrived in Taiwan over the weekend at the invitation of the TIER, will speak on the "World Economy's Fight Against Balance Sheet Recession," at the economic summit.

Chen Po-chih, Presidential Office adviser and a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will also speak on the impact of globalization and the exchange rate of the mainland Chinese currency, the renminbi.

Both of them will then have dialogues on the new challenges faced by the world economy, hoping to provide more suggestions on substantive policy through brainstorming as Taiwan's economy is gradually shifting toward the path of recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO FURTHER PROMOTE TIES WITH CHAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the ROC government will continue promoting cooperation with the Central African ally of Chad for mutual benefits.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Chadian Prime Minister Moussa Faki Mahamat, who is currently on an official visit to Taiwan.

Chen said he is pleased to see Taiwan-Chadian cooperative programs proceed smoothly and successfully. The two infrastructure projects -- the Taiwan Boulevard and the Unity Bridge -- completed in Chad late last year epitomize the success in bilateral cooperation, he added.

At the moment, Chen said, Taiwan-financed projects are been carried out in 26 of Chad's 28 provinces. All of Taiwan's financial aid to Chad has been used to help improve Chadian people's livelihood, Chen said.
In addition, the president went on, Taiwan has posted medical and technical missions in Chad to offer health care services and assist in the African ally's agricultural development.
Chen congratulated Faki on Chad's becoming an oil exporting country in July this year. "Oil exports will definitely contribute to your country's overall development," Chen said.

He also expressed his gratitude for Chad's staunch support for Taiwan's cause in the international arena. Top Chadian leaders, including President Idriss Deby and Prime Minister Faki, have on many international occasions spoken for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOLF PRODIGY RETURNS FOR VACATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born golf prodigy Candie Kung, who won three victories on the LPGA tour this year, has returned to Taiwan for a brief winter break.

Kung, 22, won her first LPGA title at the 54-hole 2003 Takefuji Classic held in Las Vegas April 19 with a 12-under-par 204 (67, 67, 70) , two strokes ahead of Annika Sorenstam -- the world's top woman player -- and two others. Kung held a news conference Monday under the auspice of the Golf Association of the Republic of China (GAROC).

GAROC Chairman Wang Yung-tsai, who is one of the executives of Taiwan's petrochemical giant, the Formosa Group, offered Kung a scholarship of NT$10 million (US$294,118) as a "homecoming gift" to be used to assist her training in the United States.

Prior to the news conference, Kung teed-off with Wang and other Taiwan entrepreneurs at a local golf club. According to Wang, Kung is polite but serious and concentrates when playing golf. "The sky's the limit for this young lady," he said.
Taking home US$165,000 from the Takefuji Classic, Kung now ranks sixth on the LPGA's top-10 earnings list, with more than US$186,000. She joined the LPGA tour last year.

Kung moved from Taiwan to the United States with her parents when she was 15. She is a three-time American Junior Golf Association All-American and was named 1999 AJGA Player of the Year. She won the 2001 U.S. Public Links Championship.
At the news conference, Kung said she is proud to be Taiwanese, adding that the first words she said upon winning the LPGA title were, "I'm from Taiwan."

Kung said that she had missed out a lot during her high school years because she had to practice golf. Her dislike for golf turned into a sense of responsibility after she entered university, she said, adding that she understood that golf would be her career.

She said during her years as a professional golfer, her parents and brother have been her greatest supporters. She said she owes a lot, particularly to her father, who always fixes her a big meal he cooks at home after a tournament.

She said she has lots to learn besides honing her skills, including learning to concentrate and learning to persevere to the last minute. "Annika Sorenstam is my idol and the person that I hope to outperform," she said.

Kung will have a tight schedule in Taiwan. She met with former President Lee Teng-hui, who likes to play golf, Monday afternoon, and will meet with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office Tuesday.

In addition to a meeting with Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation Wednesday, she is also scheduled to lecture at a workshop for young golfers in Taiwan and their parents on Saturday, among other activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SURVEY SHOWS CHEN AND LIEN RUNNING EVEN IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Incumbent President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is in a dead heat for reelection against his opponent, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, according to a new poll conducted by the ruling party, a DPP spokesman said Monday.
Spokesman Wu Nai-jen also said that the DPP's latest move to target KMT's allegedly ill-gotten assets is "positive" to the campaign.

A China Times newspaper poll Monday showed support for Lien and his running mate People First Party Chairman James Soong at 36 percent, compared with Chen and his partner, Annette Lu, at 31. When asked about the newspaper poll, Wu said he had no comment.

Wu said that the DPP won a few elections over the past years, but the party had never led in any polls conducted by the media, adding that he doubted the credibility of the media based on his past experience.

He also said that the campaign to force the KMT to deal with its illegally obtained assets is a good strategy, since the KMT has tried to deal with the matter in a misleading way, such as with KMT headquarters in downtown Taipei.

President Chen said Sunday that he did in fact approve and issue the licence for the KMT headquarters building during his stint as Taipei mayor, but this does not mean that the land was legally obtained by the KMT.

Wu said that the DPP is now producing campaign literature on the KMT's ill-gotten assets, and the party will strive to let others know that the licence for the building and how the land was acquired are two different issues.
He claimed that the DPP has tracked down all of the KMT's assets, and that it will continue to push for the party to return them to the rightful owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE DEFENSE MINISTER WRAPS UP U.S. VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Minister of National Defense Lin Chon-pin left Washington, D.C. for home Sunday after wrapping up a visit to the U.S. capital.
Unlike a similar visit six months ago, Lin did not meet with U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz because he was on vacation in California.

A U.S. official denied that bilateral military exchanges have been hindered by disputes over Taiwan's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of its next presidential election March 20, 2004. The referendum seeks to give the people of Taiwan a venue to voice their opposition to the deployment by mainland China of nearly 500 ballistic missiles targeting locations in Taiwan.

The official cited the convening of a seminar on the Taiwan Strait situation in Hawaii on Dec. 15 to back his claim that Taiwan-U.S. military exchanges have not been affected by the referendum dispute.

Previous media reports said the United States had canceled the seminar to express its displeasure at Taiwan's referendum plan. Some reports mistakenly described the seminar as a Taiwan-U.S. joint computer war simulation and alleged that Lin had been barred from attending the event because of the referendum issue.
All those reports were untrue, the U.S. official said, adding that the seminar was held as originally scheduled and that Lin was not supposed to take part in the seminar from the very beginning.

An American China hand said Taiwan-U.S. military exchanges are not expected to be adversely affected by political relations between the two countries at least for the time being. It is not easy to suddenly put the brakes on the increasingly closer Taiwan-U.S. military cooperation, the expert noted.
Some U.S. officials in charge of relevant affairs said bilateral military cooperation not only benefits Taiwan's national defense but also U.S. interests.
However, some other U.S. scholars pointed out that military cooperation could be the first target if the Bush administration really intends to cool its relations with Taiwan.

During his just-concluded visit, Lin headed a delegation of military officials to attend a meeting on bilateral military exchanges. Lin briefed U.S. officials on Taiwan's national defense reforms, military restructuring and progress in its arms procurement plans.

In addition, Lin met with James Moriarity, outgoing senior director for Asian affairs at the U.S. National Security Council, and Michael Green, who will take over Moriarity's current post in January, as well as State Department officials.

Lin also exchanged views with scholars at major U.S. think tanks. Sources said U.S. officials and academics had all expressed much concern about Taiwan's referendum plan. Some scholars were quoted as having said the planned referendum could cause tension in the Taiwan Strait.

During a news conference held after his meeting with mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at the White House earlier this month, U.S. President George W. Bush said the United States is opposed to Taiwan taking any unilateral action to change the status quo in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 38 points to close at 5,838, with 28,628 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February rose 63 points to finish at 5,840, with 103 contract transactions, while March futures gained 92 points to close at 5,860, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,800 for January, 5,777 for February, 5,768 for March, 5,767 for June, and 5,805 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
January TE futures moved up 1.4 points to finish at 242.4, with 3,493 contract transactions, while February TE futures rose 1.3 points to close at 242.35, with 13 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 75.88 points to close at 5,835.11.
The bourse opened at 5,782.09 and fluctuated between 5,850.74 and 5,773.64 during trading.

All of the eight major stock categories categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by cement stocks and pulp and paper issues, both at 2.1 percent, construction stocks at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent, electrical stocks at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PATIENT STEADILY RECOVERING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only confirmed severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) patient this winter, Lt. Col. Chan, has been steadily recovering from the killer disease, Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital officials said Monday.

The 44-year-old Chan, who has been receiving treatment in a negative-pressure ward at Hoping Hospital since last Wednesday, has seen a remarkable increase in his blood's oxygen content, and his lung inflammation has stopped increasing, the officials said.

Hoping Hospital President Chu Ta-cheng said Sunday that Chan was recovering satisfactorily, with his fever coming down several days earlier and his diarrhea being brought under control. He has been able to breathe without the use of a respirator since early Sunday morning.
The 15 people who had come into close contact with Chan were removed from the watch list Sunday after not displaying any SARS symptoms over the 10 previous days, Chu said.
The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health labeled Chan's case as "an isolated" case that is unlikely to lead to more transmissions.

Chan, a SARS virus researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) under the National Defense Medical College, is believed to have contracted SARS at work Dec. 5 when he touched spilled SARS samples with his bare hands after analysis work that was part of SARS virus research at a top-level P4 laboratory in which the use of gowns and gloves is mandatory.
He then flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five co-workers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day while in Singapore, but did not develop fever which is typical of SARS.

Chan returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, and by that night, had developed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day. At that time, nobody suspected him of having SARS, even though his job involved working with the SARS virus.
Another full week was allowed to pass before he was sent to hospital Dec. 16 after developing diarrhea. At the hospital, Chan underwent tests that confirmed the SARS virus was present in his system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 22, or the 29th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty with Japan in Peking regarding Manchurian affairs, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways and appoints Liang Shih-yu as the director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Xian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: U.S. heavy bomber planes bomb Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as U.S. President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement began in the Southeast Asian country.
1965: President Chiang Kai-shek issues a decree convoking an extraordinary session of the National Assembly in Taipei on Feb. 1, 1966.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the U.S. intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes the secretary-general of the United Nations.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Australia and New Zealand.
1976: Adm. Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, presents citations to outstanding cadres and political warfare personnel.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1990: Lech Walesa becomes Poland's first popularly elected president.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
1999: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest (236.2 cm) person by the Guinness Book of World Records, meets with the local press as he starts his four-month visit to Taiwan.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) says the Republic of China will fully open its livestock products market in 2005.
2001: The Alishan forest railway in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, which was seriously damaged when Typhoon Nari swept the island in mid-September, resumes service.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER MORI TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By C.N. Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day private visit, a Japanese daily reported Tuesday.

Mori, who was prime minister between April 2000 and April 2001, told reporters in Tokyo Monday that his upcoming Taiwan visit would be purely private in nature. The itinerary will include a visit to an old friend of his late father and rendezvous with people in Taiwan's sports and economics circles, the Asahi Shimbun quoted Mori as saying.

According to the report, some Beijing officials have expressed concern over the nature of Mori's upcoming visit to Taiwan on the grounds that the former Japanese prime minister has just recently visited Beijing. Mori was in the mainland capital Dec. 14-16.
Mori, 66, was elected prime minister by the two houses of the Japanese Diet in early April 2000, succeeding Keizo Obuchi who was in a coma at the time after suffering a stroke.

In the vote, Mori, who had served as secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), was supported by the LDP, the Komei Party and the Conservative Party. He retained all the Cabinet ministers of the Obuchi administration.

Mori, who had also served as Japan's minister for international trade and industry in the past, has been very friendly toward Taiwan. Taiwan-Japanese relations improved during the Mori administration.
Mori has visited Taiwan on a number of occasions over the past years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRAMEWORK PROPOSED FOR TAIWAN TO JOIN REGIONAL ECONOMIC INTEGRATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan could join in regional economic integration under a closer economic operation framework (CEOF) , a renowned economist suggested Tuesday.

Addressing a luncheon party of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that Taiwan could avoid political interference and maintain its competitiveness by joining the regional economic integration under the name of CEOF instead of a closer economic partnership agreement (CEPA) or a free trade agreement(FTA).

Siew, who also serves as chief of an economic advisory panel to President Chen Shui-bian, said Asia has apparently entered a heated regional economic integration season since October, with a series of economic meetings by leaders of the countries in the region, including a summit of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , a Japan-ASEAN summit in Tokyo, an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Forum leaders' meeting in Bangkok, and a Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, mainland China.

Faced with this new trend, the former premier suggested that Taiwan should become a free trade zone where all enterprises and economies around the world would be willing to operate their businesses, in addition to actively participating in World Trade Organization (WTO) activities and seeking to sign free trade agreements with other countries.
At present, Siew said, Taiwan should focus its efforts on FTA talks with the United States, Japan and its diplomatic allies in Latin America.
The country should also seek to sign an agreement with mainland China similar to an FTA that would be mutually beneficial, although it would be difficult under the existing situation, Siew added.
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should first establish mutual trust in order to achieve this goal, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PATIENT RECOVERING WELL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only SARS patient, identified only as Lt. Col. Chan, has got through the most dangerous period of the infection and is recovering well, Hoping Municipal Hospital officials said Tuesday.

It is believed that the patient, a researcher at the Institute of Preventive Medicine of the National Defense University in Taipei, inadvertently infected himself with the SARS virus in his research laboratory earlier this month.

Since Chan was confirmed as having contracted the disease Dec 17, the health authorities have put 34 people known to have come into close contact with Chan since Dec. 7 on a watchlist to monitor their health for at least ten days.
Hoping Hospital Vice President Huang Lien-chi said Tuesday that Chan no longer requires additional oxygen but is still partially on a respirator.
Huang added that Chan will have to remain under observation at the hospital for one or two more days.

Chan had suggested that the medical team use the medicine he had developed in the lab, but the team did not adopt the idea, pointing out that there is a big gap between lab experiments and human testing, according to Huang.
Meanwhile, Hoping Hospital executives decided to downgrade the guard level in its emergency room from degree 2 to degree 1.

In addition to the self-health management and home quarantine, the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health has also implemented a series of control measures for those who came into contact with Chan, which means they are not allowed to travel abroad during the quarantine period.

Travelers with fever are only allowed to depart from Taiwan if they get a health certificate to prove they are not infected with SARS, while airline companies have been asked to conduct strict fever screening on their crew members.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS PANEL FORMED TO DEAL WITH ASSETS RELINQUISHED BY KMT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered the formation of an ad hoc panel Tuesday to deal with assets relinquished to the government by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
The panel will consist of representatives from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of National Defense, Yu said.
It will study procedures through which to take delivery of eight property lots the KMT has promised to turn back to the government.
Most of the properties are loss-making movie theaters around the island.

In a related development Tuesday, Huang Chu-wen, chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, announced the establishment of a group aimed at pressing the KMT to hand back assets it accumulated illegally during its five-decade rule of the island.

Huang noted that he served in the KMT before and claimed that he knows that the value of the stocks owned by the party peaked at NT$600 billion when the stock market was booming, all of which were illegally accumulated by the party and should be returned to the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPL RATIO OF LESS THAN 5 PERCENT TO BE REACHED BEFORE YEAR END: MOF

TEXT.P: The average ratio of non-performing loans (NPLs) of domestic banks had dropped to 5.01 percent as of November, and the government's target of keeping the ratio below 5 percent is expected to be reached before the end of this year, an official of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Tuesday.

Tseng Kuo-lie, director of the MOF Bureau of Monetary Affairs, said the target forms part of President Chen Shui-bian's plan to cut the NPL ratio of domestic banks to under 5 percent and to raise the capital adequacy ratio to above 8 percent within two years.

MOF statistics show that NPLs accumulated by 51 domestic banks had reached NT$716.9 billion (US$21.08 billion) as of November, registering an NPL ratio of 5.01 percent, a drop of 3.03 percentage points from the 8.04 percent registered in the first quarter of last year, a record high.

Among the 51 banks, 34 banks registered NPL ratios below 5 percent, while nine banks had NPL ratios of between 5 percent and 10 percent. Eight banks suffered NPL ratios of more than 10 percent in November.

The statistics also show that during the January-November period, domestic banks sold bad loans worth NT$1.168 trillion, which demonstrates the efforts made by these banks to decrease their NPL ratios.

Tseng expressed gratitude to the financial institutions for their efforts to improve their financial structures. However, to those that have not yet reached the target, the bureau said these banks might face some degree of punishment according to a financial reform ad-hoc group's suggestion, such as reshuffles of boards of directors and supervisors and general managers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSISTS ON CONTINUED REFORM FOR WORKERS, UNDERPRIVILEGED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Tuesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will continue with reforms in order to build a society in which justice and fairness are fully served for workers and the underprivileged.
Chen made the remarks at the weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee in his capacity as party chairman.

Citing statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Chen reported that Taiwan's jobless rate in November fell to 4.71 percent, down 0.21 percentage points from the October level and the lowest monthly record since July, 2001.

The president hailed the outstanding performance and attributed the result to the all-out efforts made by the government and people of Taiwan. He said Taiwan's November unemployment rate is lower than Germany's 10 percent, France's 9.7 percent, Hong Kong's and Canada's 7.5 percent and Singapore's and the United States' 5.9 percent.

Chen said he is confident of increasing the country's budgets for research and development programs to account for more than 3 percent of its gross domestic product by 2006, reducing the unemployment rate to less than 4 percent by 2005 and lifting its economic growth rate to over 5 percent in 2004, if he wins a second term in the March presidential election.
However, he lamented that the many grassroots workers -- the behind-the-scene heroes of Taiwan's economic miracle -- have not been fairly treated with dignity over the past few decades.

In an effort to live up to the promises made to the workers, the DPP-led government has tried to resolve the problems by making adjustments to the existing systems, including establishing and amending the Gender Equality Employment Law and the Labor Standards Law, among others, he noted.

Stressing that Taiwan will become a harmonious and progressive society only when the workers are fairly treated, he vowed to face the many challenges ahead with a firmer stance by seeking to create a "win-win" situation for labor and management.
The fruits obtained at the moment are just transitional and the DPP will firmly stick to reform and justice as a means of throwing its support behind the workers and the underprivileged, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DOING UTMOST TO KEEP INAUGURAL PROMISES: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is doing his utmost to keep his inaugural promises to not attempt to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, although he is no longer obliged to do so, his chief of staff Chiou I-jen claimed Tuesday.

Elaborating on the president's remarks the previous day that his "five noes" inaugural promises "no longer" exist, Chiou said that Chen made his promises in 2000 "as long as Beijing has no intention of using force against Taiwan. " Beijing has never given up its threat of force against Taiwan and accordingly, the president was not bound by his promises.
The president's patience is limited and Beijing should not expect him to recede endlessly, Chiou warned.
The president's remarks made headlines Tuesday, although their political ramifications had not yet fully sunk in.

Believing that the status quo is the basis of stability across the Taiwan Strait, the United States has repeatedly said it takes the president at his word and will disapprove of any attempt on either side of the strait to change the status quo unilaterally.

In a suggestion that a report in Monday's Ming Pao daily in Hong Kong could be a political plot devised by Beijing, Chiou said Beijing has been trying to influence the island's presidential election by putting Chen out of favor.

The Ming Pao said the previous day that Chen's revelation of the number of Beijing's missiles targeting Taiwan Nov. 30 irritated Beijing, which nabbed 36 Taiwanese spies already under its surveillance in reprisal. The allegations have been denied by the Taiwan authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DENIES SPY NETWORK CRACKED BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied Tuesday that its spy network in mainland China had been cracked by Beijing.
MND spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said the report, first broken by the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao daily on Monday, is not true and that the domestic media should be careful about how they relay the story.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun dismissed as unsubstantiated the paper's report that Beijing had arrested 21 Taiwanese and 15 mainland Chinese for spying for Taiwan since Nov. 30, when President Chen Shui-bian said that Beijing has 496 missiles targeting Taiwan.
Yu said Chen's information comes from satellite photos rather than Taiwan spies and that the Ming Pao report is groundless.

However, the report was supported by retired intelligence official Chen Hu-men who claimed that the Military Intelligence Bureau under the MND has lost contact with at least three of its secret agents on the mainland.

It was all grist to the mill for the opposition lawmakers in their war of words with Chen in the lead up to the 2004 presidential campaign. They claimed that the president has risked the lives of the country's spies on the mainland by revealing the number of missiles pointed at Taiwan.

In a rebuttal of the opposition lawmakers' criticism, several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers Tuesday dismissed the report as a political ploy hatched by the opposition with the intention of tarnishing the president.

DPP lawmaker Lai Ching-teh said Chang Rong-gong, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs, visited the mainland five times in the last two months as an emissary of KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who is running against Chen in the 2004 presidential election.
Lai suggested that Chang concocted the scheme with his Beijing host during his mainland trips with the purpose of undermining Chen's credibility.

Another DPP lawmaker, Lin Chung-cheng, questioned the truth of Chen Hu-men's claims, asking how someone who has been retired for many years could know that the Military Intelligence Bureau had lost contact with three agents.
DPP lawmaker Chiang Chao-yi said the whole thing is a scheme cooked up by Beijing in the hope of boosting Lien's presidential campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Student loan programme / Secondary education loans axed.
The government will change conditions for the debt-burdened education loan programme, making university students the only group eligible to apply. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Hague wants Saddam capture to inspire search for its outlaws.
In the corridors of the international war crimes tribunal here, the capture of Saddam Hussein this month was a source of joy and frustration.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS TAIWAN YOUTH MOST LIKES FREE-WHEELING LIFESTYLE

TEXT.P: Many young Taiwan people most prefer a free-wheeling lifestyle, according to the results of an opinion poll released Tuesday.
Sinorama magazine surveyed young people aged between 19 and 30 from late November through early December about their expectations. A total of 1,009 valid samples were collected.

Asked about their life dreams, the respondents cited the following expectations -- leading a free-wheeling lifestyle (47 percent) ; having a happy family life (30 percent) ; having a stable job (26.7 percent) ; joining the ranks of the rich and famous (17.9 percent) ; traveling around the world (9.7 percent) ; winning the lottery (9 percent) ; working as a volunteer (7.4 percent) ; becoming an influential person (4.6 percent) ; and seeking religious enlightenment (3.3 percent) . The respondents were allowed to give multiple choices.
The poll also found that local young people are generally satisfied with their lives, with 75.1 percent giving a positive reply and only 17.4 percent saying they are dissatisfied.

As to their major concerns, 28.4 percent cited work or career; 22.7 percent cited their own financial status; 13.3 percent were most concerned about their health; 11.1 percent mentioned family life as their number one concern; 9.5 percent were most concerned about their academic performance; and only 6.8 percent said they were concerned about Taiwan's political and economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY BUSES TO PASS INTO HISTORY BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Municipal buses running on Taipei streets will soon become history, as the Taipei City Bus Administration will have to transform into a privately run company at the beginning of next year, the administration head said Tuesday.

The company will operate under the name of "Metropolitan Bus Company" when it starts operations, and will aim at achieving a monthly business target of at least of NT$160 million (US$4.7 million), Hui Chao-hung said.

According to Hui, the municipal buses run by the administration have so far served passengers on more than 2 billion trips over the past 53 years since the start of its operations as an independent unit in 1952 under the Taipei city government.
The administration employed more than 5,000 workers in its prime, but began to streamline its workforce in 1997 to reduce its large annual deficit.
Hui, who will serve as the first chairman of the newly consolidated bus company, promised that the company will do its best to offer first-class services to passengers.
The bus company has selected a logo featuring the English letter "E" and a yellow phoenix.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said municipal agencies such as the Taipei Water Department and the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation will also have to be privatalized amid fierce competition to provide high quality services to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR SPEEDY PASSAGE OF BUDGET BILL FOR 10 NEW PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pass a special budget bill for the government's 10 new major construction projects to boost Taiwan's sustainable development.

Yu made the call while presiding over a groundbreaking ceremony for the Pali-Wuku section of a new expressway in Taipei County, which is an integral part of the ambitious 10 new major construction projects.

"The groundbreaking ceremony marks the kickoff of the 10 new major construction projects," Yu said, adding that the legislature should pass the budget plan for the new infrastructure projects as early as possible.

The new expressway will link the Taipei Port on the northern Taiwan coast to Taipei County's urban districts. Yu said the expressway, scheduled for completion in March 2008, will help boost Taipei Port's traffic volume and regional development.

Noting that infrastructure construction is critical to economic development and upgrading of national competitiveness, Yu said the legislature should not stonewall the passage of the special budget bill for the 10 new major construction projects which call for capital investment of NT$500 billion over the next five years.
Yu said the government must increase capital investment as Taiwan faces potential pressure of deflation.

According to a report delivered by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i to the legislature a day earlier, Taiwan's fixed investment has shown negative growth since 2000. Fixed investment accounted for 7.3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) in 1994, compared with only 4.1 percent of the GDP in 2002.

Government investment in recent years has continued to fall, which Lin said has not only seriously affected the growth potential of the economy, but has become a major factor in blocking economic growth. With a view to sustaining Taiwan's economic development, Lin told lawmakers that expansion of government's capital investment is urgent and crucial and that the 10 new major construction projects are part of the administration's efforts to resolve the plight.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING BOATS SEIZED FOR POACHING

TEXT.P: Three mainland Chinese fishing boats were seized Tuesday for poaching in waters near the Penghu island group, according to coast guard authorities.
The three vessels from the southeastern mainland coastal province of Fujian were intercepted some 11 nautical miles northeast of Penghu's Mutouyu islet.
Coast guard patrol ships escorted the boats along with their 11 crew members back to Penghu's Makung port for investigation. Their catch and fishing gear were confiscated.

As the fishing gear used by mainland fishermen tends to wreak havoc on seabed fishery resources, coast guard authorities have stepped up their crackdown on poaching by mainland boats. To prevent seized boats from returning to Penghu waters in the near future, coast guard officers also removed fixed fishing net winding mechanisms installed on the three boats. The 11 mainland crew members and their boats were then dispersed to waters 24 miles off the Penghu coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES GOLFING ACE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that Taiwan sporting talent is shining in the international sports arena, showing that although the country is small, it has big ambitions.
The president made the remarks when he received Taiwan-born golfer Candie Kung, a three-time winner on the LPGA tour this year.
The president lauded Kung for her courage and confidence in "always having Taiwan on her mind and making it visible to the world."
He noted that Kung emigrated with her parents to California when she was 14 and that she still holds a Republic of China passport.
Kung carries an ROC national flag with her in every game and shows it to the media at post-tournament press conferences, proudly proclaiming that "I come from Taiwan."
The president noted that the LPGA was founded in 1950 and that although six Taiwan players have tried to make their marks on the tour, only Kung and Cheng Mei-chi have made it to the top.
Kung took three wins in a period of five months, setting a historic record for Taiwan golfers, the president said.
The president said that not only has Taiwan excelled in the production of golf equipment, but also a "Taiwan female Tiger" is emerging, referring to top golfer Tiger Woods.
"Kung is the pride of the 23 million people of Taiwan, " the president said.

Citing the examples of sprinter Chi Cheng and decathlete Yang Chuang-kuang and more recently the baseball players Chen Chin-feng and Tsao Chin-hui, the president said that "Taiwan-made" is indeed good quality.
He also noted that there are many other sportsmen and women waiting for their chance to shine and that they need more business support and government assistance.

He said that he was gratified to learn that Formosa Plastics Chairman Wang Yung-ching and the Golf Association of the Republic of China Chairman Wang Yung-tsai will contribute generously to set up a Candie Kung development fund.

The president said that the government will continue to encourage top players and will provide assistance and training programs, hoping for a development of golf through the efforts of the government and private sectors.

Kung, 22, won her first LPGA title at the 54-hole 2003 Takefuji Classic held in Las Vega April 19 with a 12-under-par 204 (67, 67, 70) , two strokes ahead of Annika Sorenstam -- the world's top woman player.
Pocketing US$165,000 from the Takefuji Classic, Kung now ranks sixth on the LPGA's top-10 earnings list. She joined the LPGA tour last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES URGED TO USE OFFSHORE CROSS-STRAIT TRANSSHIPMENT HUB

TEXT.P: Domestic companies should use the offshore cross-Taiwan Strait transshipment hub located at Kaohsiung Port more frequently for value-added processing and direct sailing to and from mainland China to upgrade their industrial levels and global competitive edge, government authorities said Tuesday.

According to a spokesman for the Economic Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan-based businesses should take more advantage of the center located at the southern Taiwan port to process their semi-finished products from mainland China.

Taiwan investors can assemble, test, pack and label their parts and components as well as complete their semi-finished products manufactured on the mainland at the hub and then re-export them to third countries or areas, the spokesman explained, adding that greater value will be added to their goods, allowing them to chalk up greater profits on lowered production costs and a more efficient cross-strait labor division model.

Currently, more than 40 businesses based at various export processing zones in Kaohsiung are using the hub to process their parts and components produced in Fuzhou and Xiamen of the mainland's Fujian Province, and they have thus achieved greater earnings by re-exporting their fully finished goods from the center to the rest of the world, the spokesman noted.

The spokesman strongly suggested that Taiwan businesses use the hub's facilities for sea, air or air-sea and sea-sea transport to reduce the travel time of their merchandise made on the mainland on the grounds that this would help them save between 17 percent and 24 percent on transport costs and further strengthen their international competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINTER SARS CASE COULD AFFECT JAPANESE TRAVEL TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A recent case of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan might affect the willingness of Japanese tourists to visit Taiwan, sources from local travel agencies said Tuesday.

Taiwan's tourism industry took a historic dive in April this year, when the potentially deadly disease broke out in Taiwan, the sources said, adding that the number of foreign tourists to Taiwan did not rise until July, when the situation improved markedly.

They pointed out, however, that the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has rebounded to only about 40 percent of normal levels of the past. The target set by the government -- to attract 2.1 million tourists for the whole of 2003 -- remains some way off, they said.

Under the current circumstances, a possible resurgence in the number of Japanese tourists might take place within the next six months later, even though it had been expected to happen in April 2004, the start of Japan's fiscal year, the sources predicted.

Although the recent SARS case in a researcher at a military-run institute has been proven to be an isolated one, the sources expressed the hope that no more new infections will surface. Otherwise, they warned, the government's campaign to double the number of tourist arrivals to Taiwan by 2008 will suffer a fresh setback.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION STEPS UP CAMPAIGN AGAINST VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: The State Public Prosecutor-General's Office of the Supreme Court formed a special task force Tuesday to supervise the campaign against vote-buying and violence in the upcoming presidential election.

Addressing the inauguration ceremony, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said he hopes the public will join forces with law enforcement authorities in fighting vote-buying and violence in the presidential election to be held March 20, 2004.

With less than 100 days to go before the vote, both the ruling and opposition camps have stepped up their campaign activities and Chen said he has already received reports about suspected vote-buying in both northern and southern Taiwan.
"I have forwarded the relevant information to the relevant prosecution authorities for further investigation," Chen said, but he declined to elaborate.

Chen said all local citizens are welcome to provide leads to vote-buying practices. The government is offering cash rewards ranging between NT$500,000 and NT$15 million for those whose information leads to convictions for vote-buying by the presidential candidates themselves or their campaign aides. In the 2001 legislative elections, Chen said, one citizen received NT$10 million in reward for offering leads that led to the conviction of a lawmaker for vote-buying.

The new supervisory team will be headed by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa. Public Prosecutor-General Wu Kuo-i, Taipei Prosecutor's Office chief Shih Mao-lin, National Police Administration Director Chang Shih-liang and Yeh Mao-sheng, director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau attended the inaugural ceremony to signify their determination to root out election vote-buying and violence.

Meanwhile, the Taichung Prosecutor's Office in central Taian also formed an action team Tuesday to investigate suspected election vote-buying and violence. Twelve senior prosecutors have been assigned to join the team.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
TOKYO, DEC.23 (CNATYO) The Japan Times: Expressway plans get green light, Scheme to privatize operators favors LDP vested interests.
The government and ruling coalition on Monday endorsed a privatization scheme for semigovernm- ental expressway operators that effectively fai- ls to put the brakes on the completion of unfin- ished sections of the planned 9,342-km thruway network.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS FOR TAIWAN PRODUCTS EXCEED US$15 BILLION IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers received orders for US$15.18 billion of products from foreign buyers in November, an increase of 13.14 percent over the same month of 2002, according to statistics compiled by the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The statistics released by the department Tuesday showed that the amount of November export orders for electronics and precision instruments were US$560 million and US$470 million respectively more than the same month of last year. The export orders for information and communication products were US$370 million more than a year earlier.
Most of the orders were placed by buyers from the United States, Hong Kong, Japan, and Europe.
Officials of the department also said the production of Taiwan's manufacturing industries is expected to grow 4.8 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST FEMALE COMPANY LEADER HEADS ENGINEERING TROOPS IN TRAINING DRILL

TEXT.P: The ROC military publicly displayed its highly advanced German-made M3 amphibious floating bridges for the first time Tuesday in a training drill headed by a young woman officer.

Army Captain Lee Ya-ting commanded a company of engineering troops under the Sixth Army Group in erecting and connecting three 50-meter floating bridges in the training exercise at the Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

Sixth Army Group Commander Lt. Gen. Hu Chen-fu said it usually takes 15 minutes to erect a 50-meter floating bridge. Thanks to Lee's skillful training and efficient leadership, the company completed the bridge in just eight minutes. Hu said Lee deserved credit for her company's selection as model company of the year.

In the training drill, the engineering company used the three-unit floating bridges to ferry an 11-ton CM21A1 armored vehicle, a Hammer vehicle and a 15-ton truck as well as a group of journalists and military officials through the Shihmen Reservoir.

Lee, 27, is the first female company leader since the ROC Army formed an engineering corps decades ago. A graduate of the Civil Engineering Department of the Chinese Military Academy (CMA) in southern Taiwan, Lee once traveled to Germany to receive 46 days of professional training in erecting M3 amphibious floating bridges.
The ROC Army purchased 22 M3 floating bridges in 1999. Taiwan is the only Asian country to have acquired the amphibious equipment, known as the most advanced of its kind in the world.
In addition to transporting various kinds of military vehicles, M3 floating bridges can also be used in emergency disaster relief operations.
The deputy commander of the floating bridge company is also a woman officer, Lt. Kang Hsiao-lan. Kang, 24, is also a graduate of the CMA's Civil Engineering Department.

Lee and Kang are two of the few female officers to have assumed commanding posts in regular combat units in the ROC military. Their professionalism and dedicated working style have won them much recognition and respect in the army, Hu said.

Lee said she has not encountered special difficulties in commanding the engineering company. "Gender is not a problem so long as I give clear and definite orders, they can always be fulfilled smoothly," she said.
Kang echoed Lee's view, saying that most engineering troops are obedient. "Gender has never hindered my leadership or work, " Kang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANHUA UNIVERSITY DONATE COMPUTERS TO NICARAGUA

TEXT.P: Nanhua University, in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, donated 10 computers to schools in remote areas of Nicaragua Tuesday to promote learning in the region.
The donation ceremony was held in the Legislative Yuan, with Nicaraguan Ambassador Luis A. Wong accepting the gifts.
Nanhua University, established by Master Hsing Yun of Fukuangshan Foundation for Buddhist Culture and Education, has been involving in charity work in recent years.

Officials of the university said they made the donation as Nicaragua is one of the most important diplomatic allies of Taiwan and both the president and vice president of this Central American country are recipients of honorary doctoral degrees of the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAY GROUPS CALLS FOR TIMETABLE FOR HUMAN RIGHTS LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: Members of several homosexual groups and human rights activists organizations urged the government Tuesday to come up with a timetable for the enactment of a basic human rights law, which will also protect the rights of gays and lesbians.

The groups lodged their appeal in front of the headquarters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , calling for concrete and effective measures to be taken by the government to facilitate legislation of a basic human rights law.

Ashley Wu, publicity director of the Gay and Lesbian Hotline Association, Taiwan, also appealed to the government for an inclusion of gays and lesbians into the category of people entitled to the benefits stipulated in the Statute Governing Artificial Aid Reproduction, to allow them to have children of their own produced artificially.
Wu said President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions advocated a basic human rights law which legitimizes same-sex marriages and other rights for the nation's homosexual citizens.
The president's promises, however, have remained empty words, with no sign of concrete actions, said Wu.
Wu said if the government is indeed working on drafting the law, it should let the people know the law's articles and stipulations and allow the people concerned to provide their opinions.

In related news, DPP Legislator Ho Shui-sheng offered his apologies to Taiwan's homosexual citizens twice last Friday for his remarks made the previous day that "same-sex marriages could cause the annihilation of the nation."

At two separate press conferences at the Legislative Yuan, Ho, who represents Tainan County, bowed to express his apologies to the public as well as the nation's gays and lesbians for his "wrongly understood" remarks.

Ho said he didn't mean to hurt gays and lesbians when he made the remarks while speaking to Health Minister Chen Chien-jen about the possible passage of a bill allowing for same-sex marriages. Ho said he simply expressed his opposition to same-sex marriages from the medical point of view.

Ho, a member of the Legislative Yuan Health and Environment Committee, urged public health officials not to allow marriages between gays and between lesbians, saying that such marriages should be prohibited because they could never produce offspring which are needed for the nation's sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.008 to close at NT$34.050.
A total of US$405 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.062 and was traded between NT$34.036 and NT$34.062.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES REMAIN UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market remained unchanged on Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January closed at 5,838 on Tuesday, with 14,754 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost four points to finish at 5,836, with 66 contract transactions, while March futures remained unchanged to close at 5,840, with four contracts traded.
June futures rose 31 points to close at 5,836, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,838 for January, 5,840 for February, 5,840 for March, 5,805 for June, and 5,843 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
January TE futures moved up 0.45 points to finish at 242.85, with 2,347 contract transactions, while February TE futures lost 0.95 points to close at 242.60, with 12 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January TF futures lost one point to finish at 880, with 3,303 contract transactions, while February TF futures lost 3.2 points to close at 880, with 15 contracts traded.
March TF futures lost four points to finish at 876, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR SAYS CENTRAL GOVERNMENT DEBT TO REACH NT$4 TRILLION SOON

TEXT.P: Legislator Lee Tung-hao of the People First Party said Tuesday that he and eight other legislators have jointly introduced a bill governing public debt and budgets because the central government's debt is increasing at an alarming rate.

Lee said at a news conference that the central government's debt has already increased to NT$3.98 trillion (US$116.6 billion), and is increasing at a speed of NT$1.2 billion per day. It will break the NT$4 trillion mark early next year. The total debt of central and local governments has reached NT$4.7 trillion.

He said it is necessary to control government debt by legislation because high government debt can dampen economic development and blunt the nation's competitive edge in world markets. More than 70 legislators have endorsed the bill, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices rose slightly on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 10.4 points to close at 5,845.51.
The bourse opened at 5,858.11 and fluctuated between 5,858.34 and 5,827.94 during trading.

A total of 2.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.36 billion (US$1.48 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 3.12 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$60.08.

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.6 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other four stock categories lost ground, with construction and textile stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent respectively, followed by plastics and chemical, as well as financial issues, both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 392 to 323, with 223 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINES NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
President Chen says he will give up his 'five noes' pledge if Beijing steps up military threats.
The United Daily News:
Defense experts say Hong Kong spy-ring report a political trick.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen vows to hold 'peaceful referendum.'
The Taiwan Daily:
Chen reminds Beijing his 'five noes' pledge not applicable should PRC conduct military exercise against Taiwan again.
