DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NEEDS FURTHER EXPLANATION ON REFERENDUM: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien reiterated Tuesday that Taiwan and the United States have very smooth communication channels but admitted that there are difficulties getting the message across regarding referendum issues.
The minister made the remarks while meeting the media at a year-end news conference.

In response to Washington's concerns over Taiwan's initiative to hold what it calls a "defensive referendum, " Chien emphasized that the communication channels between the two countries are very smooth.
However, he said that differences exist between Taiwan and the United States regarding the referendum, admitting that there are some "communication difficulties."

Noting that Taiwan considers that holding the referendum would better the island's democratization, the minister said that the United States on the other hand sees the referendum with a consideration of regional security, peace and stability, and this difference has caused "a discrepancy of opinion."
Chien further said that his ministry will continue to communicate with the United States and that he believes that Washington will eventually understand Taiwan's referendum position in the future.

Indicating that the U.S. State Department has divided Taiwan's referendum into three categories -- independence and unification, public policy and political meaning but without substantial results -- and has expressed clearly its positions on such referendums, the minister said that what the ministry should do is to better communicate with the United States on the goal of Taiwan's "defensive referendum" and the actions the island will take in the future.

As to the names of the referendum that have been raised by President Chen Shui-bian in the past few weeks -- from "defensive referendum" to "peace referendum, , Chien said that the goal of changing referendum names is to tell the international community and the United States that Taiwan's referendum is to strengthen regional stability and not to change the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MOTOR TO COOPERATE WITH DAIMLER-CHRYSLER TO TAP MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: China Motor Corp., one of the leading automobile manufacturers in Taiwan, is cooperating with German company Daimler-Chrysler AG and a mainland Chinese automaker to build Mercedes-Benz vans targeting the growing Chinese market, a corporate source said Tuesday.

A China Motor official said that the joint venture, approved by the mainland Chinese authority recently, marks the first business operation overseas launched by Daimler-Chrysler that will not be completely owned by the German automaker.

Daimler-Chrysler and China Motor have already established a company in Hong Kong to facilitate the joint venture between them -- Daimler-Chrysler Vans Hong Kong -- and have worked out a formula to enable the cooperation with the Chinese partner -- Fujian Automotive Industry Corp., the official said.

Under the three-way joint venture project, dubbed Daimler-Chrysler Vans China, China Motor will hold about 17 percent of the new venture, Fujian Automotive will hold 50 percent, and Daimler- Chrysler Vans Hong Kong will hold the remaining share.

Officials and technical advisers of Daimler-Chrysler recently traveled to Taipei to meet their China Motor partners and have entrusted China Motor with the entire responsibility for building the new plant, which will be located in the southern mainland Chinese city of Fuzhou, according to the official.

Initially, Daimler-Chrysler Vans China is expected to make 20,000 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter, Vito and Viano vans at the plant. The company hopes to roll out 40,000 vans a year in the future, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MAINLAND CHINESE WORKING ILLEGALLY IN JAPAN INCREASING

TEXT.P: Japan will not consider granting mainland Chinese citizens the privilege of visa-free entry because the number of mainland Chinese overstaying their visas and working illegally in Japan is increasing, Hong Kong's Sun Daily reported Tuesday.

The Sun Daily quoted Japanese Consul Sado Shimashiro as saying in an interview with the newspaper that, due to this reason, Japan is tightening the rules regarding the issuance of visas to mainland Chinese applicants.

He said the number of illegal workers caught in Japan totaled 34,746 last year, of which 36 per cent were mainland Chinese citizens. Last year, 220,000 foreigners overstayed their visas in Japan, with some 30,000 of these being mainland Chinese, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LAUNCH SPACE EXPLORATION ROCKET: NSC

TEXT.P: A scientific space exploration rocket will be launched from a base in southern Taiwan Tuesday evening as part of the work of Taiwan's space program, according to an official from the National Science Council (NSC).

The space exploration rocket, the third of its kind to be built by the military Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), will be launched in the evening from a CIST base located in Chiupeng, Pingtung County, NSC Vice Chairman Hsieh Ching-chih said.
The launching of the horizontal rocket, whose range is not in excess of 300 kilometers, is mainly aimed at gaining better observation capabilities of the earth's ionosphere, Hsieh said.

Noting that objects placed in orbit under 300 km from the earth's surface are highly prone to falling back to earth, Hsieh said that no satellites fly in the region between 60 km and 400 km above the earth's surface. This part of the ionosphere has long been referred to in jest as an "uncharted zone," he said.

The rocket will be carrying scientific instruments to explore and measure the ionosphere. According to Hsieh, the first such rocket was successfully launched about three years ago, but it did not carry any research gear. The second rocket of its kind did carry such equipment, but its launch two years ago failed, he said.

Taiwan's space program, under the charge of the NSC Space Program Development Preparatory Office, is aimed at carrying out the research, development and launch of basic space exploration rockets before 2009 and of multi-functional space exploration rockets by 2018, he noted.
The CIST builds and launches the rockets under a contract signed with the NSC Space Program Development Preparatory Office at a cost of NT$25 million (US$735,294) per unit, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bush Gets Year-End Boost in Approval; Poll Shows Dean Surging Among Democratic Rivals.
Growing optimism about the economy and a spike in support for going to war in Iraq have given President Bush a sharp year-end boost in his approval ratings, according to a new Washington Post-ABC News poll, suggesting that the president is in a strong position politically as he looks toward his reelection campaign next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICE IN TAIPEI TO MOVE TO NEW LOCATION

TEXT.P: The United States will pay more than NT$330 million (US$9.7 million) to rent a new site for the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) for 99 years, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
The AIT is the U.S. top representative office in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
The MOFA said in a report that the lease on the AIT's current office on Hsinyi Road will expire soon.

Taipei City Council decided earlier that the present site of the AIT office will be turned into a junior high school in June 30, 2004. The United States then asked the MOFA to locate a new site for the AIT office, with the former eventually selecting an empty lot of land in Neihu, suburban Taipei.

The MOFA carried out the task of obtaining ownership of the land, which had been partially owned by the central government, the city government and private individuals. It was purchased at an estimated cost of more than NT$230 million.
The United States will pay a lump sum of more than NT$330 million to rent the land for 99 years, and it will also spend NT$160 million on constructing a building on the site.

Under the principle of reciprocity, the Republic of China government has asked to rent the present Coordination Council for North American Affairs, which is the counterpart of the AIT, in downtown Taipei for 99 years at a price of more than NT$88 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO BEGIN RECYCLING KITCHEN WASTE FROM FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presided over a rally of municipal environmental workers and volunteers Tuesday in preparation for the kick-off of the city's kitchen waste recycling program Friday.
Addressing the rally of more than 1,000 city street cleaners and environmental volunteers, Ma said the kitchen leftover recycling program will be the city's "second garbage disposal revolution."
"The new measure will mark a step forward in achieving the city government's ambitious goal of 'recycling all garbage and leaving no landfills' by 2010," the mayor said.

Ma added proudly that Taipei's first garbage revolution -- the pay-by-bag garbage fee collection system launched in 2000 -- has been very successful as the city's waste has since declined by 50 percent.
At the moment, Ma said, kitchen leftovers account for about 30 percent of total waste. With the launch of kitchen waste recycling, he said, the city's garbage will decrease further.

Besides kitchen leftover recycling, Ma said, the most effective way to reduce waste is to cut the source of garbage. "We should cultivate the habit of ordering only exactly what we want to eat when we eat out. When we eat at home, we should only prepare exactly what we need, " he explained.

Taipei will be Taiwan's first city to recycle kitchen waste. The municipal Environmental Protection Bureau (EPB) urged city residents to work in tune with the new recycling program and divide their kitchen waste into two categories -- namely cooked food scraps which can be used to feed hogs, and material that can be used as compost, such as vegetable leaves and fruit peels.

Cooked food scraps should be put into the special blue container installed on each garbage truck, while compost material should be thrown into the red container. In the initial stage, the EPB will post environmental volunteers to garbage collection locations to instruct residents on how to divide their waste.

The EPB said it will launch a three-month publicity campaign from Dec. 26 to rally public support for the kitchen waste recycling program. After Feb. 26, those who mix their kitchen leftovers with regular garbage will be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 23, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1948: Japanese war criminal Eiki Tojo is executed.

1958: The construction of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower is complete.

1986: Soviet human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov is released from exile and he returns to Moscow.
1989: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF VOTERS WANT CANDIDATES TO DEBATE EDUCATION ISSUES: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan voters want the presidential candidates to debate education issues during the campaign, according to the results of an opinion poll released Wednesday.

The poll, conducted by the Education Policy Research Center of National Taiwan Normal University in early December, found that 61.2 percent of respondents said they support the notion that the presidential candidates debate education issues to let voters know their ideas and positions on the nation's education development.
The survey of over 1,000 randomly selected adults around Taiwan also showed that 49.3 percent said that education issues will be an important factor in determining who they will vote for.

In related news, the results of a public opinion poll conducted by Commonwealth Magazine three months ago of parents of elementary school, junior high and high school students islandwide found that half of the respondents do not support the current education reforms engineered by the Ministry of Education.

While a majority of the respondents said they consider the on-going reforms a failure, 43 percent said the last four education ministers are to blame for the failure, compared with 34 percent who said the president or other political leaders should take responsibility, according to the poll results.

THE SANDIGANBAYAN anti-graft court Tuesday gave deposed president Joseph Estrada an early Christmas gift, after the special division conducting his plunder trial granted his motion to undergo knee surgery in the United States.
The Philippine Star: Court OKs Erap trip to US.
Overturning its previous ruling, the Sandiganbayan Special Division on Tuesday gave deposed President Joseph Estrada three months within which to seek medical treatment in the United States for his knee problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TRANSPORTATION WITH MAINLAND IS IMPORTANT: LEGISLATURE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Direct transportation links with the mainland are vital for the country if it doesn't want to be marginalized in the region, said Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Wednesday.

In a news release issued by his office, Wang was quoted as saying in a recent interview with an unidentified media outlet that without direct transportation links with the mainland, there is no way for the country to join the free trade zone consisting of the member states of the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN).

While the country is divided over the issue of whether the island should unite with or separate from mainland China, neighboring states are undertaking an economic and political integration which has heretofore not been seen in the past.

The integration process, with ASEAN at the center, has included mainland China, Japan, South Korea and India. It is transforming ASEAN into an economic bloc rivaling the United States and the European Union in size, Wang was quoted as saying in the interview.
Countries which will not or cannot join the bloc will certainly be squeezed out of the international market to the detriment of their economic development, he said.

Being shut out of the integration process in the region, Taiwan will not only be shunned by foreign investors but also see the flight of its own capital. Unless it improves its ties with the mainland, Taiwan's economic development will slow and the country will be marginalized, he said.

The absence of direct transportation with the mainland has become the biggest concern of many foreign businesses in Taiwan, according to Wang. Multinational businesses are relocating their operations hubs from Taiwan to other places, and add the pressure of competition brought about by bilateral free trade pacts concluded between other countries and a situation develops whereby Taiwan is slowly hemmed in and unable to grow, he said.

Both experience and logic tells us that Taiwan can accelerate its economic development by riding on the economic coattails of mainland China. If not, the country will risk having to sit on the sidelines of the international community and could become a state of little account, Wang warned.

Noting that good relations with the mainland is an easy way for Taiwan to play an active role in the international community, the Wang said Taiwan should shelve its political differences with the mainland and create an environment favorable to economic development for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT EXPLAINS REASON FOR OPPOSING WAFER INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Wednesday that integrated circuits can been used for numerous purposes, and this was why he was opposed to the investment by local 8-inch silicon wafer makers in mainland China when he was in power before 2000.

In a speech at Fu Jen Catholic University in Taipei on Taiwan's economic development in the age of globalization, Lee stressed that he would not want to find that the missiles Beijing point at Taiwan contained integrated circuits manufactured by Taiwan companies.

Lee noted that Taiwan is facing fierce competition from mainland China, especially the challenge brought by Beijing's economic opening policy. People cannot ignore mainland China's ambition to become the world's largest factory, and then the world's biggest market, Lee added.

Referring to his "no haste, be patient" policy in limiting mainland-bound investment when he was president, Lee said it was to prevent the "magnetic effect" of mainland China and to ensure Taiwan's leadership in certain industries.

According to Lee, reports by many globally well-known organizations, such as the Economist Intelligence Unit, Brown University, the Heritage Foundation and the Wall Street Journal, have shown that Taiwan's e-government, business environment, as well as economic liberty evaluations have been among the bests in the world in recent years, reflecting Taiwan's sound economic structure.
Lee said Taiwan's economic structure is quite fine and there is still much space for Taiwan to get loans to support its economic development.

On questions about the high unemployment rate since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party took the helm of the country in 2000, Lee noted that the inactive economy was affected by the global economic recession.
Noting that Taiwan's economic structure is sound, Lee predicted that the domestic economy will improve gradually.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANIMAL RIGHTS GROUP CALLS FOR MORE HUMANE POLICY ON STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: An animal rights group said Wednesday the government should give priority to sterilization to resolve the stray dog issue.
The Life Conservationists Association said Taiwan has some 1.7 million dogs, but more than 1.4 million of them have not been sterilized.
"It is regrettable that the Council of Agriculture (COA) has never listed dog sterilization on its work agenda, " said a spokesman for the association.
Quoting COA tallies, the spokesman said government offices in charge of stray animal affairs euthanized more than 41,900 stray dogs in 2002, while only sterilizing 7,750 strays.

Asserting that killing animals is detrimental to human conscience and civilization, the spokesman said the COA should modify its policy toward stray dogs by replacing "catch and kill" with sterilization.

"We need a more humane policy on stray animals and sterilization is the best way to resolve the issue," he said, adding that local pet lovers should also replace "purchasing dogs" with "adopting strays" to help contain the growth of stray dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLAIM THAT PRESIDENT BLEW COVER OF SPIES IN MAINLAND UNTRUE: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian's remark on the number of ballistic missiles in mainland China targeting Taiwan had not tipped off the mainland to the whereabouts of Taiwan spies; rather, it was a successful stroke of " defensive diplomacy."

Lu made the remarks while visiting a hospital in northern Taiwan. The vice president said the president's comments, made on Nov. 30 in an interview with the London-based Financial Times newspaper, has drawn worldwide attention to Beijing's military threat against Taiwan, and prompted the European Parliament to forbid its member states from selling arms to Beijing.

The president has achieved a diplomatic breakthrough by changing the EU's view of mainland China, a feat which is almost impossible through regular diplomatic channels because of the absence of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and European states, Lu said.
Beijing's military threat will become more serious because the number of its missiles targeting Taiwan will increase to 650 next year, Lu added.

President Chen's critics had argued that the disclosure of the number of Beijing's missiles jeopardized the country's intelligence gathering operations in the mainland by alerting Beijing to what Taiwan had learned about the missile deployment.

Their accusations were boosted by a report in Monday's Ming Pao Daily in Hong Kong that said Beijing has arrested 36 people for allegedly spying for Taiwan in the mainland as a response to Chen's remarks.

However, government officials as well as Chen's supporters have spoken out against the accusations, dismissing them as groundless or as a political trick concocted by Beijing and its sympathizers in Taiwan.

While inspecting the Taoyuan Hospital, Lu also criticized Beijing for shamelessly claiming earlier this year that it had taken care of Taiwan's medical needs when in fact it had done little to halt the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and had not even bothered to apologize to the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: A general voices new confidence on Iraq. British officer says capture of Saddam has changed outlook.
A British general commanding an area of southern Iraq with five million inhabitants said Tuesday that Saddam Hussei's capture and other changes including progress in restoring oil installations, power stations and running water, had fostered a new confidence that the U.S.-led occupation force can achieve its objective of building a stable Iraq and handing the country back to its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY ECONOMIC ADVISOR SUGGESTS ALLOWING MAINLAND TOURISTS INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan should allow mainland Chinese tourists to enter if the government hopes to inject a new lease on life in the domestic tourism industry, a key economic advisor at a presidential panel said Wednesday.

Vincent Siew, a veteran economist and a vice chairman of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , who served as premier in the previous KMT-led government from 1997-2000, said he will make the suggestion to President Chen Shui-bian in a meeting slated for Friday at which panel members will give advice to help promote Taiwan's tourism and related education and training at domestic higher learning institutes.

Stating that the government must adopt adequate and concrete measures to bolster Taiwan's tourism and resort industry, Siew said that relevant government authorities should work out a clear-cut policy and businesses in the sector must devise their own approaches to target their clients.

Siew added that he will suggest in the Friday meeting to help the tourism businesses operating domestically and to have outbound travel and inbound travel verify their markets and make programs to attract potential customers.

In line with the government's goal of doubling the number of foreign tourist arrivals to Taiwan by 2008, Siew said that opening the domestic market to tourists from mainland China will give a major boost to the domestic tourism industry.

As to a recent proposal he made regarding the signing of a closer economic partnership arrangement between Taiwan and mainland China, Siew said that such an accord will be in place only when politically sensitive elements have been wiped out between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Malvo is spared death penalty; Jury gives teen life sentence for his role in sniper slaying.
A jury spared the life of Lee Boyd Malvo on Tuesday, deciding that his crimes were vile and that he posed a future danger to the community, but still choosing to impose a life sentence rather than death for his role in the sniper attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER URGES KMT TO RETURN ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS SOON

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan on Wednesday urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return as soon as possible the assets it obtained illegally during its previous five-decade rule on the island.
Lin stressed that the most important element in handling the ill-gotten assets will be "moral power, " which Lin described as a better way than the "power of law."

Since the KMT has many assets, he said, while the government has very little information about them, he urged the KMT authorities to take the initiative and use its moral strength to hand over detailed reports about the properties in question.

On the same day, Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked Lin to set up an ad hoc group to handle the return of ill-gotten assets by political parties and visit KMT authorities within a week to talk about the issue.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan claimed recently that he had issued instructions for a review of KMT assets immediately after he assumed the party leadership, and ordered a quick return of some land to the government.
Furthermore, Lien added, the KMT has put all its assets into trust and has promised that it will no longer manage party-owned business enterprises.
KMT officials said they will make public soon all the party's assets for public scrutiny.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATROL INSPECTIONS OFF MATSU ISLANDS INCREASED: COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: Inspections off the outlying Matsu Islands have been stepped up and advanced radar equipment utilized to prevent mainland Chinese fishing boats from poaching in nearby waters, a spokesman for the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Wednesday.
According to the CGA official, the administration has eight patrol boats stationed around the island group, which lies 114 nautical miles northwest of the northern port city of Keelung.

Apart from one vessel for repairs and maintenance and two based on Tungyin Island and one based on Chukuang Island, the official explained that the remaining four are fully devoted to carrying out routine patrol missions every day off the main island of Nankan, commonly known as Matsu, as well as other islets such as Peikan and Tungyin, among others.

The official, however, also acknowledged that four patrol boats are not enough to deal with serious situations or major incidents in which additional patrol vessels and helicopters must be sent from Taiwan proper to help intensify inspections.

For instance, he said, Taiwan-based patrol ships took part in a program in July and August last year off the Matsu Islands to help fend off intruding fishing boats from the mainland and help protect a special zone designated for an endangered bird.

In addition, he said, new types of monitoring radars have recently been installed on the Nankan, Peikan, Chukuang and Tungyin islands as part of the government's efforts to strengthen inspection along the coast.

As to a recent letter-to-the-editor printed by a local newspaper saying that a mainland fishing boat entered port on Peikan Island, he dismissed the incident as purely a "fishery dispute" and added that the mainland boat was escorted by CGA vessels to leave Taiwan-controlled waters after both sides reached a settlement following an investigation by coast guard authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEAK SEASON FOR FLU BEGINNING

TEXT.P: The number of people coming down with the flu is expected to increase in the next eight weeks, unless this winter is unseasonably warm, an official of Center for Disease Control (CDC) said Wednesday.

Yen Tse-chie, a section chief of the CDC under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, said that the peak season for flu comes each year around the time of the first cold snaps and the beginning of the Christmas season. Moreover, the gathering of people for the new year and Chinese Lunar New Year increases contacts and the possible spread of flu, Yen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN EARLY JANUARY

TEXT.P: Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique De Menezes is scheduled to visit Taiwan Jan. 5 for five days at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
MOFA officials said Menezes' entourage will include Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Minister Mateus Meira Rita, as well as his advisers.

During his stay in Taiwan, Menezes will meet with Chen to exchange views on bilateral relations and bilateral cooperation projects. The two leaders will also sign a joint communique, the officials said.

The officials said that since Taiwan established diplomatic relations with the African country in 1997, it has helped the nation develop international and bilateral cooperation projects, covering agriculture, medical care, vocational training, technical assistance, transportation and road and water infrastructure, as well as sending medical and technical missions to the country.
Menezes will also call on Taiwan businesses during his stay to solicit their investment in his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ANNOUNCES SUSPENSION OF U.S. BEEF IMPORTS, RELATED PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced the suspension Wednesday of imports of U.S. beef, cattle carcasses, organs, tissue and derived products such as placenta extract, in response to the first suspected case of mad cow disease reported in the United States a day earlier.
But Chen Lu-hung, director-general of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, said U.S. milk and milk products will not be included for the time being.
A single Holstein cow on a Washington State farm has tested positive for mad cow disease, marking the first appearance of the disease in the United States.

On whether U.S. beef products will be removed from Taiwan shelves, Chen said that as very little beef is imported from Washington State and the suspected case is a dairy cow, beef already on the domestic market should be safe.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) has also suspended imports of U.S. live goats and feed made of goat parts. But Chen pointed out that very little goat meat and mutton is imported from the United States, so that U.S. goat meat and mutton are not included in the suspension.
Asked whether the beef suspension will affect beef supplies, Chen pointed out that Taiwan still can import from Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Paraguay.
Chen said that according to general practice, U.S. beef shipped before Wednesday will not be affected by the ban and can be imported to Taiwan.

According to COA tallies, Australia and New Zealand are Taiwan's two largest sources of beef. Taiwan imported more than 35,000 tons of beef and related products from Australia in 2002, 15,400 tons from New Zealand and 13,900 tons from the United States. Canada was the fourth-largest supplier, with 3,800 tons. Other beef sources include Panama and Paraguay.

Mad cow disease, also known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, eats holes in the brains of cattle. It first sprang up in Britain in 1986 and spread through countries in Europe, prompting massive slaughter of herds and decimating the European beef industry.

A form of mad cow disease can be contracted by humans through eating infected beef or nerve tissue, and possibly through blood transfusions. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease -- the human form of mad cow disease -- has so far killed 143 people in Britain and 10 elsewhere. No one in the United States has died from the disease. People who are possibly at risk for the disease are banned from donating blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK BANS IMPORTS OF U.S. BEEF

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has taken the lead from most Asian countries and has banned the import of U.S. beef.
According to report, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and Australia have already banned the import of U.S. beef after mad-cow disease was discovered in the United States.
Hong Kong is said to be the world's fifth-largest importer of U.S. beef. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: HK POLICE SMASH ARMED ROBBERY SYNDICATE

TEXT.P: Hong Kong police have smashed an armed robbery syndicate and made the largest seizure of weapons in 30 years.

After an investigation of several weeks, police officers broke into an apartment in the former British colony, arrested two men and seized seven grenades, one AK 47 rifle, two shotguns, seven pistols and more than 800 bullets.

"The seizure was the biggest in the past 20 to 30 years and we believe that this successful operation has prevented serious armed crimes, " the chief superintendent of the organized crime and triad bureau said.
About 120 officers were deployed during the operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Pakistani scientists aided Iran; Nuclear scandal grows as Libya set for inspections.
Pakistan comfirmed Tuesday that Iran has named Pakistani scientists who have alledgedly helped The country develop its uranium enrichment program.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWER SUPPLY TO A TAOYUAN INDUSTRIAL ZONE DISRUPTED TWICE

TEXT.P: Power supply to Kuanying Taiyuan Industrial Zone in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan was disrupted twice Tuesday night and early Wednesday morning.

A spokesman for the Association of Manufacturers in the industrial zone said power supply to the zone was disrupted without warning twice between 7 p.m. Tuesday and 4.30 a.m. Wednesday, affecting the operations of several dozen manufacturing companies.

The power disruptions have caused at least US$10 million of loss to the producers of chemicals, textile materials, plastics, optoelectronics, heavy electrical machinery, and other products in the industrial zone, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN MISSING ON MAINLAND NOT MND WORKERS: MND

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said Wednesday none of several people allegedly nabbed by mainland Chinese intelligence authorities recently are staff members of the Ministry of National Defense (MND).
Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung quoted Tang as having issued a three-point statement at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
First of all, Tang said, after undergoing verification, the list of Taiwanese businessmen alleged by local media as having gone missing on the mainland recently does not include any MND employees.

For the sake of protecting intelligence agents' safety, Tang said, government authorities around the world traditionally do not publicly discuss issues concerning intelligence personnel. In the future, Tang said, the MND will consistently give a "no comment" reply to all intelligence-related inquiries.

Moreover, Tang stressed that the MND has adopted appropriate measures to protect intelligence staff's safety, rights and interests as providing care and protection for intelligence agents is the government's duty.
Meanwhile, Lin urged local media and opposition lawmakers to refrain from describing the missing of certain mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen as a case concerning espionage.
Lin said the government will look into reports about the missing Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland and will assist their families in dealing with relevant affairs.

Commenting on a report by Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency earlier in the day that mainland security authorities have arrested 24 Taiwanese and 19 mainland Chinese on charges of spying for Taiwan, Lin said the report was just a mainland ploy to undermine President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid.
Lin reminded local people that the mainland authorities will make every possible effort to sway Taiwan voters ahead of the island's March 20 presidential election.

He also urged Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland to exercise caution and prudence in their daily lives and business operations, as it is all too common in a repressive country like mainland China for security authorities to make arrests without legitimate reasons.
In a related development, Vice President Annette Lu also dismissed the Xinhua report as an attempt to embarrass Chen ahead of the election.

"Let's not believe in rumors, " Lu said during a campaign appearance. "We all know that the Beijing authorities have all kinds of strategies for dealing with Taiwan and interfering with our elections."

On Monday, Hong Kong's Ming Pao daily claimed that Chen exposed 36 of the island's spies on the mainland in a speech last month that listed the locations of 496 mainland Chinese missiles pointed at Taiwan.
The newspaper reported that the mainland authorities had arrested 21 Taiwanese and 15 Chinese nationals since mid-December on espionage charges. It reported partial names for five of the Taiwanese.

On Tuesday, Taiwan's secretive Military Intelligence Bureau took the unusual step of issuing a denial, saying: "To date, after undergoing verification, we can say that none of our personnel have been arrested by the Chinese communists."
Chen's aides say the missile information came from satellites, not intelligence personnel. They also say the mainland authorities could not possibly have broken up a spy ring with such speed.
Espionage accusations are frequently intertwined with Taiwan's domestic politics.

Four years ago, Beijing reportedly executed a mainland army general and a colonel for selling secrets to Taiwan during military exercises meant to intimidate the island ahead of its first-ever direct presidential election in 1996.

In that case, then-President Lee Teng-hui was accused of blowing the Chinese officers' cover by claiming in a campaign speech that Chinese missiles being launched into the Taiwan Strait were carrying dummy warheads.
In the latest allegations, opposition politicians have accused Chen of endangering the military intelligence service by disclosing the number and locations of mainland missiles targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR FACING FIERCE COMPETITION FROM RIVALS

TEXT.P: The authorities of southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor are observing closely the operations of rival harbors, as its former position as the world's third-largest container port has been squeezed to No. 6.
Kaohsiung Harbor was squeezed out by Busan in South Korea, and Shanghai and Shenzhen in mainland China, according to statistics from the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.
Hong Kong is still the largest container port in the world, followed by Singapore.
In addition to the pressure from these harbors, Kaohsiung Harbor has also encountered strong competition from domestic ports such as Keelung, Taichung, Mailiao and Taipei.
The government has been planning and trying to develop Taiwan into an Asia Pacific Operations Center, with Kaohsiung Harbor as its marine transportation center.

In accordance with government policy, Kaohsiung Harbor has been working to improve service quality and operational efficiency, including strengthening on-line information, reducing operational fees and constructing an international container center that can accommodate super-large container ships.

The number of containers handled at Kaohsiung Harbor last year reached 8.49 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units), an increase of 12.6 percent over the previous year, and the port plans to reach a target of 9 million this year, according to bureau officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAFETY OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN OPERATING IN MAINLAND SERIOUS PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that more than 1,000 Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China have been arrested over the past three years and that the personal safety of Taiwan businessmen there has become a serious problem.

Chai and his colleagues Lin Chin-hsin, Chiang Chao-yi, Wang Shu-huei and Lan Mei-chin also rebutted in a press release allegations that Taiwan's spy network on the mainland was jeopardized after President Chen Shui-bian's remarks on mainland Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan.

A day earlier, Premier Yu Shyi-kun dismissed as unsubstantiated a Hong Kong-based paper's report that Beijing had arrested 21 Taiwanese and 15 mainland Chinese for spying for Taiwan since Nov. 30, when President Chen said that Beijing has 496 missiles targeting Taiwan.

However, the Ming Pao daily report was supported by retired intelligence official Chen Hu-men, who claimed that the Military Intelligence Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense has lost contact with at least three of its secret agents on the mainland.

Chai pointed out the unlikelihood that a former intelligence officer who has been retired for 10 years would have up-to-date knowledge of the latest developments in Taiwan's spy network on the mainland.
Instead, he said that more than 1,000 Taiwan businessmen have been arrested over the past three years, not because they were spies but because they were evading taxes.

The legislators said that statistics released by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation show that cases involving the personal safety of Taiwan businessmen over the past two years have also increased.

They noted that there were 67 cases involving murder, accidental death, accidental injury, robbery, extortion, blackmail, kidnapping and restricting the freedom of movement of Taiwan businessmen in 2001, and 91 cases in 2002. The number of cases so far this year has reached 80, showing the seriousness of the issue, the legislators added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF GRAVEL FROM HUALIEN MIGHT AFFECT NORTHERN REGIONS

TEXT.P: A reduction in the amount of gravel extraction from eastern Hualien County could affect major public works construction plans in the northern Taipei and Taoyuan regions, informed sources reported Wednesday.

As a result of an environmental impact assessment being conducted in the Hualien area, the number of ships transporting gravel from the eastern county to Taipei Harbor in November dropped to 46 from October's 61, a reduction of 66,000 tons of gravel, according to Lin Hsin-chuan, a secretary at Taipei Harbor.
According to Lin, gravel shipped from Hualien to Taipei is mainly used for public work construction projects in the Greater Taipei and Taoyuan areas.

Statistics compiled by Taipei Harbor show that ships transported gravel from Hualien to Taipei on 499 trips during the first 11 months of this year. However, the volume of gravel shipped from Hualien to Taipei fell by 66,000 tons in November alone.
The major purpose of the building of Taipei Harbor is to handle gravel shipped from eastern Taiwan to Taipei.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Ready-Mixed Concrete Industry Association has decided to temporarily halt supplies for construction projects being carried out in the Taoyuan area for four days from Jan. 1.

The health implications of the finding are minimal, experts say, but the economic implications are substantial for the U.S. cattle industry, which is the single largest part of the American agriculture sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PATIENT EXPECTED TO BE DISCHARGED IN FEW DAYS: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only confirmed severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) patient this winter, identified only as Lt. Col. Chan, is making a steady recovery from the disease, Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said Wednesday.

The 44-year-old Chan, who has been receiving treatment in a negative-pressure ward at Hoping Municipal Hospital since Dec. 17, has been declared out of critical condition, Chen quoted Hoping officials as saying.
If everything goes smoothly, Chan is expected to be discharged from the hospital before the end of December, said Hoping Hospital President Chu Ta-cheng.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, Chen said that the country has learned a lesson from Chan's case, particularly that P3 and top-level P4 laboratories should have more efficient management and implementation of security and safety measures.

Chan, a SARS virus researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) under the National Defense Medical College, is believed to have contracted SARS at work Dec. 5 when he touched spilled SARS samples with his bare hands after analysis work that was part of SARS virus research at an IPM top-level P4 laboratory in which the use of gowns and gloves is mandatory.

The IPM P4 lab, the only one of its kind in Taiwan, was closed down temporarily Dec. 17 after Chan was confirmed positive for SARS. With the closure of the lab, all public and private laboratories conducting SARS research in Taiwan were also ordered to shelve their operations with immediate effect.

Chen said the P4 lab has been conducting an overall sterilization job in the wake of the infection, while the Department of Health (DOH) invited specialists from the United States to Taiwan to provide lessons for Taiwan researchers working at SARS laboratories on security, safety and related policies.
The P4 lab, as well as other SARS research labs, are not expected to resume their operations until March, Chen added.

According to Center for Disease Control (CDC) officials, 15 of the people who had come into close contact with Chan prior to his hospitalization were removed from a SARS watchlist earlier this week after not displaying any SARS symptoms over the 10 previous days.
The CDC has from the beginning labeled Chan's case as "an isolated" one that is unlikely to lead to more transmissions.
Chan flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five co-workers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day while in Singapore, but did not develop the fever that is typical of SARS.

He returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, and by that night, had developed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day. At that time, nobody suspected him of having SARS, even though his job involved working with the SARS virus.
Another full week was allowed to pass before he was sent to hospital Dec. 16 after developing diarrhea. At the hospital, Chan underwent tests that confirmed the SARS virus was present in his system.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAUNCH OF SPACE EXPLORATION ROCKET POSTPONED: NSC

TEXT.P: A scientific space exploration rocket will be launched from a base in southern Taiwan Wednesday evening, one day later than its original schedule, officials from the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) said Wednesday.
The launch was postponed when an unidentified vessel intruded unexpectedly into the restricted sea area that was zoned for the launch, coupled with bad weather, NSC officials said.

The space exploration rocket, the third of its kind to be built by the military Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), will be launched from a CIST base located in Chiupeng, Pingtung County, NSC officials went on.

The launch of the rocket, whose range is not in excess of 300 kilometers, is mainly aimed at gaining a better observation of the earth's ionosphere, NSC Vice Chairman Hsieh Ching-chih said a day earlier.

Noting that objects placed into orbit less than 300 km from the earth's surface are highly prone to falling back to earth, Hsieh said that no satellites are orbiting in the region between 60 km and 400 km from the earth's surface. This part of the ionosphere has long been referred to in jest as an "uncharted zone," he said.

The rocket will be carrying scientific instruments to explore and measure the ionosphere. According to Hsieh, the first such rocket was successfully launched about three years ago, but it did not carry any research gear. The second rocket did carry such equipment, but its launch two years ago failed, he said.

Taiwan's space program, under the charge of the NSC Space Program Development Preparatory Office, is aimed at carrying out the research, development and launch of basic space exploration rockets before 2009 and of multi-functional space exploration rockets by 2018, he noted.
The CIST builds and launches the rockets under a contract signed with the NSC Space Program Development Preparatory Office at a cost of NT$25 million (US$735,294) per unit, he said.

Mainland Chinese maritime research vessels have been discovered operating in areas very close to Taiwan's economic waters on more than 12 occasions over the past year and an official Website of the mainland Chinese authorities has been found to have closely monitored Taiwan's space development program and reported every relevant activity in detail on its Website, including the rocket launches.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN STUDIED FEASIBILITY OF TWO-CHINA POLICY IN 1960S: DOCUMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By C.N. Chieh and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Japan paid much attention to the cross-Taiwan Strait question in the 1960s and looked into the possibility of adopting a "two-China" policy, according to a confidential document released Wednesday by the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The document said that although the Japanese government insisted on its "one-China" policy on the surface at that time, it also studied the feasibility of adopting a "two-China" policy.

In December 1964, then Japanese Prime Minister Eisaku Sato said while receiving a British envoy to Japan that officially, his government only recognizes one China and sticks to the policy only because both mainland China and Taiwan insist there is only one China, according to the document.
Sato stressed that he himself knows clearly there are two regimes that coexist in China, the document said.

Meanwhile, then Japanese Foreign Affairs Minister Ohira Masayoshi said at a Japan-U.K. meeting held in May, 1964 that Japan hopes that Taiwan will be able to keep its seat in the United Nations if mainland China joins the organization, according to the document.

Furthermore, the document revealed that around the same time, the then British minister of foreign and commonwealth affairs indicated that London believes that in dealing with the China question, Taiwan and mainland China should be handled separately. He even suggested that Taiwan's Nationalist government should abandon its unrealistic mentality of still being the ruler of all of China, according to the document.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUSPENDS U.S. BEEF PRODUCT IMPORTS OVER MAD COW FEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan suspended imports of U.S. beef and related products Wednesday after the first suspected case of cattle infected with mad cow disease was reported in the United States a day earlier.
A single Holstein on a Washington State farm has tested positive for mad cow disease, marking the disease's first suspected appearance in the United States.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) said the government has decided to suspend U.S. beef and goat product imports for the time being now that Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Malaysia have indefinitely banned such U.S. imports.

Chiang Yi-nan, director of the COA's Animal and Plant Inspection and Quarantine Bureau, said U.S. beef and goat products, including powdered bones, that may spread mad cow disease will all be banned from entering Taiwan for the time being.

Chiang said it will take a few more days to determine whether the United States will be declared a mad cow disease-affected area. Inspection of contaminated samples takes three to five days to complete.
According to the World Organization for Animal Health, a mad cow disease-affected country is prohibited from exporting beef and related products for at least seven years.
Britain has not resumed beef exports since a mad cow disease outbreak several years ago.

The United States has been the third largest beef import source. The import ban is expected to push up local beef prices. But Chiang said the price hike should not be too drastic because local importers can import more beef from Australia and New Zealand to meet the market demand.

Australia and New Zealand have been Taiwan's two largest beef import sources. According to COA tallies, Taiwan imported more than 35,000 tons of beef and related products from Australia in 2002; 15,400 tons from New Zealand; and 13,900 tons from the United States. Canada was the fourth largest supplier, with 3,800 tons. Other beef import sources included Panama and Paraguay.

Mad cow disease, known also as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, eats holes in the brains of cattle. It sprang up in Britain in 1986 and spread through countries in Europe, prompting massive destruction of herds and decimating the European beef industry.

A form of mad cow disease can be contracted by humans by eating infected beef or nerve tissue, and possibly through blood transfusions. The human form of mad cow disease has so far killed 143 people in Britain and 10 elsewhere. No one in the United States has died from the disease. People who are possibly at risk for the disease are banned from donating blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 24, or the second day of the 12th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies at the age of 90.
1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.
1999: Taipei's fifth rapid transit line -- the Pangnan Line -- is inaugurated, completing the foundation of the city's rapid transit network.
2000: About 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas take part in a peaceful street march in Taipei to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
2000: Thai Rangsit University confers an honorary doctoral degree on former ROC Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN PARLIAMENTARIANS TO VISIT DEC. 28

TEXT.P: At the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , foreign parliamentarians from Colombia, Germany and the United Kingdom will arrive in Taipei Dec. 28 for goodwill visits, MOFA officials said Friday.

Jairo Raul Clopatofsky, president of a pro-Taiwan group in the Colombian Parliament and chairman of the Senate's Foreign Relations, National Defense and Trade Committee, will be at the head of a nine-member parliamentary delegation during the six-day visit, the officials said.
German lawmakers Heidi Wright and Harald Schneider will also arrive in Taipei Dec. 28 for an eight-day visit.
Meanwhile, British parliamentarian Lord Faulkner of Worcester, who is deputy chief of a pro-Taiwan group in the Parliament, will head a five-member delegation to visit Taiwan from Dec. 28 to Jan. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS FILM FESTIVAL OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An international human rights film festival opened Friday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan with eight films from six countries being screened.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Kuan Pi-ling, director of the Kaohsiung City Government's cultural center, said that she hopes the festival will inspire the general public to join efforts to protect human rights and to offer better care to the underprivileged.
The festival is part of a series of activities marking this year's International Human Rights Day, she added.
The eight films from France, Brazil, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong, Iran and the host Taiwan will be screened at the festival that will run through Dec. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF BAD CHECKS DOWN IN NOVEMBER: CBC

TEXT.P: The number and value of bad checks in November dropped from the October levels as a result of an improved domestic economy, a spokesman for Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) said Friday.

More than 10.21 million checks with a total value of about NT$2.801 trillion (US$82.38 billion) were drawn in November, 43,247 checks of which, or 0.42 percent of the total, were bad checks with a value of some NT$8.4 billion, according to the spokesman.

Compared with the October levels, checks issued in November were down by 26.3 percent and 15.69 percent in terms of total number and value, respectively, while bad checks also fell by 0.01 percentage points and 0.02 percentage points in number and value, the CBC official elaborated.

The official attributed the decreases to a better economic situation at home over the past few months on the grounds that a four-color economic gauge published by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development has continued to flash green uninterrupted since July.
It is an indication that the improved economic situation has helped individuals and companies better manage their money and capital, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA OUTLINES 2004 WORK AGENDA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Friday 2004 will be a year to promote garbage classification and recycling.
According to the EPA's plan, all garbage will be divided into four categories -- recyclable garbage, kitchen leftovers, large waste and unrecyclable waste.

"We have worked out a comprehensive resourceful management plan to promote garbage reduction, classification and recycling with an ultimate goal of zero disposal," EPA Administrator Chang Tsu-en said.

Noting that many counties and cities have either launched or are experimenting kitchen waste recycling, Chang said the program will be implemented in all of the nation's 25 cities and counties in the coming years.
Chang said the EPA is planning to set up large waste recycling plants in selected cities and counties to repair and remodel discarded large articles, such as furniture and other household items.
