DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO FUEL ACROSS-THE-BOARD ECONOMIC RECOVERY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday relevant government agencies should adopt more effective measures to fuel an across-the-board economic recovery in order to further lower the unemployment rate.

Chen made the directives at a meeting of the president's economic advisory panel headed by Vincent Siew, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang who once served as a premier in the previous KMT administration.
Chen said even though the nation's unemployment rate has continued its downward streak in November, the number of jobless people remains large.

"Relevant government agencies should continue its current job-creation programs and work out even more effective measures to enhance the intensity of domestic economic recovery and create more job," Chen said.

During the meeting, Chen also said he hopes the nation's overall investment in research and development can be raised to 3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) by 2006. All responsible government agencies should formulate detailed measures to realize this goal.

To cope with a steady decline in the population growth rate, Chen said, tertiary education institutions should formulate an academic mechanism and courses that are suitable for lifelong learning to meet the high demand for trained professionals under the current knowledge-based economy.
The government should also encourage and promote transformation of government-funded universities into independent institutions to allow for more flexibility and access to more resources, Chen said.

Noting that the government has set 2004 as the year for tourism promotion, Chen said responsible government agencies should pool resources with the private sector in promoting domestic travel and attracting foreign tourists.
Chen also called on Beijing to respond to Taiwan's goodwill in opening its door to mainland Chinese tourists.

"We hope mainland China can lift its ban on its people's leisure trips to Taiwan," Chen said, adding that Taiwan's responsible agencies should step up negotiations with mainland authorities to pay the way for ordinary mainland citizens to make sightseeing trips to this island.

Meanwhile, Chen stressed the importance of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection. "IPR protection is our obligations following our entry to the World Trade Organization and will also benefit our industrial upgrading. We must further revise our copyrights law and institutionalize the IPR investigative police team and mete out harsher punishment to copyrights violators," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS OPEN FORUM TO PROMOTE REGIONAL SECURITY, WORLD PEACE

TEXT.P: Various lawmakers, including Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , attended the opening ceremony Friday of a parliamentary forum to promote security in the Asia-Pacific region and peace in the world.

Chai was elected the first chairman of the institutionalized International Inter-Parliamentary Conference on Asia-Pacific Security during the gathering and he declared that the organization will hold its annual conference Jan. 13 in Taipei. Parliamentary members from Japan and the United States, among other countries, will be invited to take part in the meeting, he added.

Chai expressed the hope that the forum will help strengthen Taiwan's security and international status, as well as peace in the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world by stepping up exchanges among parliamentarians from nations in the region and other parts of the world.

According to Chai, a group of parliamentarians from around the world agreed in mid-January this year to set up a systematic mechanism to help promote these causes while participating in a meeting on Asia-Pacific security in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KENTING NATIONAL PARK RELEASES MORE SIKA DEER INTO THE WILD

TEXT.P: Kenting National Park, Taiwan's southernmost national park, released 25 Formosan sika deer into the wild Friday to mark the park's 20th founding anniversary.
Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien presided over a ceremony marking the deer release -- part of the park's sika deer replenishment project which began in 1984.

Addressing the ceremony, Yu said that Kenting National Park is a unique national park where protection of natural scenery and deposits of natural resources as well as wildlife conservation receive equal attention.
This was the fifth time since the park's inception in 1984 that park officials have released a group of the protected animals which are bred in the park.

Beginning with a herd of 22 pure-bred Formosan sika deer -- or Cervus nippon taiwanus -- donated by the Taipei Yuanshan Zoo in 1984, Kenting park authorities have raised nearly 300 offspring of the core herd.

The park released a total of 98 of the indigenous deer in 1994, 1995, 1997 and 2002 into a forested area in the coastal county of Pingtung. These animals have bred and now number around 300, according to zoologists.

The released deer are monitored by the zoologists with electronic detectors planted under the skin of the animals. The raising of some of the sika deer are also financially supported by rural township governments in Pingtung County, zoo officials said.

Deer skin from the Formosa sika deer was one of the most important economic resources of the indigenous Taiwan people in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. The wild animal, however, came close to extinction six decades ago due to excessive hunting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Deadly earthquake strikes historic city in southern Iran.
A severe earthquake devastated the historic city of Bam in southeast Iran at about 5: 30 a.m. Friday, and apreliminary estimate said the the death toll could reach 10,000.
The Wall Street Journal: After years behind the scenes, Chinese join the name game.
Chinese manufacturing companies are starting to buy brand names of products that they formerly only produced. In some cases, they acquire the company, as with Nakamichi stereo gear, in others they get an exclusive licensing deal, as with Benetton eyeglass frames.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CITIZENS WELCOME TO MAKE SIGHTSEEING TRIPS TO TAIWAN: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that Taiwan is willing to open its door wider for mainland Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to the island.
Speaking at a meeting of the president's economic advisory panel, Chen said his administration has lifted a ban on mainland citizens' leisure trips to Taiwan.

"However, mainland China has so far been unwilling to ease its stringent restrictions on its people's leisure trips to Taiwan. We hope Beijing authorities can make a goodwill response to our 'open-door' appeal," Chen said.
He also directed relevant government agencies to continue consulting with mainland authorities on the issue based on the principle of "openness."
"I hope the policy initiative of allowing mainland people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan can be put into force as soon as possible," Chen said.
Chiou I-jen, President Chen's chief of staff, said after the meeting that mainland China still lists Taiwan as an off-limits area for its people intending to make overseas leisure trips.

"So long as China lifts its ban, Taiwan will have its door wide open for mainland tourists, " Chiou said, adding that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has worked out many complementary measures in preparation for mainland China's deregulation.

Taiwan has opened its door for mainland citizens residing in foreign countries with "permanent residency" status as well as those in Hong Kong and Macau and mainland students pursuing advanced studies abroad to make leisure trips to Taiwan under the principle of "groups in, groups out." Mainland people who make overseas visits are also allowed to make leisure trips to the island on their way back to the mainland.
What local travel agents would most like to see is the government open the door for ordinary mainland citizens to travel to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau for sightseeing purposes.

Chiou said if mainland China includes Taiwan on its list of countries that its people can visit for sightseeing purposes, the MAC will further ease regulations governing mainland people's leisure trips, with only a few exceptions.

"Except for several categories of mainland citizens such as those in the military, most other mainland people will be allowed to make leisure trips to Taiwan once the mainland lifts its ban, " Chiou said.

Travel agents said they welcome the government's "open door" policy. Even if the government sets an annual quota of 365,000 ordinary mainland citizens to be allowed to make leisure trips here, travel sources said, the move will contribute much to the recession-hit local tourist industry. And the government's goal of doubling the number of tourist arrivals in five years will then be realized easier, the sources said.

Nevertheless, local news media quoted mainland travel officials as saying that mainland China is unlikely to allow its people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan before the two sides sign an agreement on issues regarding travel insurance, visa processing, travel accidents, travel disputes and the return of overstaying visitors. Mainland officials said Taiwan should commission private travel agencies to negotiate with the mainland as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORERS REDUCED TO BELOW 300,000 UNDER DPP WATCH: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has reduced the number of foreign laborers to 297,000 -- down 32,000 from the peak -- over the past three years, DPP legislators said Friday.

The legislators made the remarks in response to criticism by Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . Ho faulted the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for easing the foreign laborer policy at the expense of domestic workers.

Ho said that the CLA announced Wednesday that it will once again allow imports of foreign laborers in the construction sector after freezing them for two years. Formosa Plastics Group's sixth naphtha cracker project will be able to introduce 5,800 foreign laborers, which Ho said will affect the employment opportunities of domestic laborers, citing the jobless rate in November as 4.7 percent.
But DPP Legislator Lai Chin-teh said that it was the KMT who increased the number of foreign laborers every year during its reign, adding that the number reached more than 330,000 at its peak.

Lai stressed that the DPP introduced two kinds of foreign laborers, those in industry and those in social welfare. The number of foreign laborers in industry has been cut by more than 40,000 since the DPP came to power, he said.

He said that the DPP's adjustment of its foreign laborer policy is mainly based on the considerations of national dignity, protecting job opportunities of nationals, basic human rights of foreign laborers and cutting the total number of foreign laborers. The purpose is to control the number of foreign laborers to below 300,000, he added.

He said that his colleague, Ho, may have a "misunderstanding" about foreign laborers, saying that for major construction projects over NT$200 million (US$5.88 million) , the government sill bans the import of foreign laborers, but he said that for those major investment projects on strategic industries, it will allow the introduction of foreign laborers based on several conditions.
These include the investment amount, the number of jobs created, the help to the development of peripheral industries and the aid given to underprivileged groups.
"Only those projects that meet these criteria will be able to apply to introduce foreign laborers, and there will not be any misgivings about benefiting specific groups," he said.
In addition, the employment will follow a one-two ratio, meaning that when two local workers are employed, then one foreign laborer will be allowed to enter Taiwan.
Lai noted that the Formosa Plastics Group will invest NT$120 billion into its project, which he said will create 270,000 jobs, including those for more than 5,000 foreign laborers.
Lai said that this is a good thing, asking, "Do we want the Formosa Plastics Group to remain in Taiwan or invest overseas?"

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES SLIM FOR CROSS-STRATI CHARTER PLANE SERVICE FOR HOLIDAY: MAC

TEXT.P: The chance that Taiwan and mainland China will agree on indirect charter flights for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to return home for the Lunar New Year holiday is slim, since negotiations have yet to start, a government official said Friday.

Speaking at a regular news briefing, Chen Ming-tung, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said the cross-Taiwan Strait charter plane service might not be available for the many Taiwan businessmen and their families who wish to return home for the coming Chinese New Year holiday, since without bilateral talks, it would be difficult for the plane to get off the ground.

Clarifying a recent media report that attributed the inability of the two sides to begin talks on the service to Taiwan's failure to honor its promise to allow mainland-based airlines to participate in the program in this, the second time the routes have been used, Chen made it clear that the "MAC never made such a pledge."

According to the report, the mainland side agreed last Chinese New Year to allow Taiwan-based aviation companies to unilaterally fly Taiwan businessmen back home from mainland China in exchange for Taiwan's permission this time to allow mainland-based carriers to join in. The report also said that mainland China favors the idea of commissioning private groups to conduct relevant talks.
The MAC vice chairman criticized the report as untrue and insisted that the private sector cannot represent government authorities to negotiate matters pertaining to law enforcement.

Chen also accused the mainland side of lacking sincerity in pushing for the charter flight service, since the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait has so far failed to respond to the invitation issued by the MAC-affiliated Straits Exchange Foundation to begin talks on the issue.

If mainland China is sincere in cooperating with Taiwan to start the service in the interest of Taiwan businessmen, it should do something concrete to make it happen, such as following the year-earlier mode of having stopovers in Hong Kong or Macau, Chen said.
The main stumbling block between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lies in the fact that the Beijing regime is reluctant to face the reality that the Republic of China exists, he stressed.

Chen Chung-hsin, head of the mainland affairs department under the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , also criticized mainland China for passing the responsibility to Taiwan by not efficiently responding to Taiwan's initiatives to start talks.

According to the DPP official, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen has demonstrated her willingness to allow mainland Chinese airlines to join in the charter flight plan as Beijing has requested. But the mainland side has still failed to reply on a date to beginning talks, he added.
Beijing is simply trying to pass the buck to Taiwan by stalling on the talks, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUREAU OF CONSULAR AFFAIRS PASSES ISO9001 QUALITY TEST

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Consular Affairs (BCA) has received certification from the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) for its service quality, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Friday.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien received the ISO9001 certificate in recognition of the BCA's upgraded service quality at a ceremony held at the MOFA convention hall.

A senior executive of the Taiwan branch of the London-based Energy and Environment Accredited Quality Assessments (EAQA) , which is authorized by the ISO to handle ISO9001 quality certifications, presented the certificate to Chien during the ceremony.

Chien said the MOFA has decided to standardize BCA operations and upgrade its service quality because it maintains frequent contacts with local citizens and is an important showcase of MOFA operations.

The BCA put forth its operations regarding passport issuing, visa processing, document certification and emergency relief aid for ROC expatriates for ISO9001 quality control certification. After eight months of efforts, the BCA passed the EAQA certification Sept. 15.

"The ISO9001 certificate indicates that the BCA operations have all been documented and standardized and live up to stringent international standards, " Chien said, adding that from now on, local citizens can receive world-class consular services from the BCA.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO TAKE ACTION TO CONTRIBUTE TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: The government is happy to see that both sides of the Taiwan Strait think highly of Taiwan businessmen, but hopes that mainland China will take substantive action to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said Friday.

Chiou was responding to mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao's remarks the previous day when he received the presidents of Taiwan businessmen's associations in mainland China and told them he will make every effort to achieve the peaceful unification of China.

"Our cross-strait policy remains steady," Chiou said, adding that President Chen Shui-bian has said repeatedly that his advocacy of "one country on each side of Taiwan Strait, " and "defensive referendum" are not attempts to change the status quo and have nothing to do with Taiwan independence, nor are they provocations. They are intended to strengthen Taiwan's democracy and maintain peace in the region, Chiou said, which is "our basic stance," although mainland China might have a different interpretation.
"We don't want to change the status quo," Chiou said.

The government has released more than 20 substantive polices over the past three years to improve cross-strait relations, averaging almost one policy every two months, he went on, citing the direct trade, postal and transportation links between the Republic of China-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu and various mainland ports, allowing mainland journalists to be stationed in Taiwan and allowing mainland spouses of Taiwan nationals to obtain work permits.

Chiou said that "we have displayed substantive efforts to improve cross-strait relations" and "we hope that Hu, after his statement, can really do something along the lines of the more-than 20 policies we have implemented."
"Both sides should work toward improving cross-strait relations," Chiou said, adding that "Taiwan's unilateral efforts cannot ensure peace in the Taiwan Strait."

He expressed hope that Beijing will take substantive action and that recent reports about the mainland authorities rounding up Taiwan spies and clamping down on tax-evading Taiwan businessmen, which has caused uneasiness among Taiwan businessmen, are only rumors.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HAS NO RIGHT TO TALK ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: DPP

TEXT.P: If mainland China refuses to remove the missiles it has aimed at Taiwan, it has no right to speak of cross-strait peace and reconciliation, Chen Chi-mai, secretary general of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday.

The DPP legislative party whip was responding to an apparent attempt the previous day by the mainland authorities to woo Taiwan when mainland leaders received the presidents of Taiwan businessmen's associations in mainland China.

Mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao said he would do his utmost to seek the peaceful unification of China and put forward "three ifs" in his first meeting with the leaders of the Taiwan businessmen's associations. These were described as "if things are favorable toward Taiwanese businessmen investing in the mainland, if things are favorable toward cross-strait economic, technology and cultural exchange and cooperation, and if things are favorable toward the development of cross-strait relations and national unification," mainland China will do its utmost to promote them.

Chen said that if the mainland authorities do not remove the missiles aimed at Taiwan and renounce the threat of force against Taiwan, it has no right to talk about cross-strait peace or reconciliation.

"Even if they talk about '100 ifs, ' the Taiwan people will not believe them, " Chen said. "Only if they make substantive moves to show concern and goodwill by removing the missiles will they be qualified to talk about cross-strait issues," he added.

Chen noted that Hu, together with Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of State Council, and his deputies Li Bingcai and Wang Zaixi are the highest-level mainland officials to have received Taiwan businessmen.
"This is obviously because of the March presidential election in Taiwan and because they want to woo Taiwan businessmen to affect the election," he observed.
Chen Chung-hsin, director of the DPP's Department of China Affairs, echoed his words and noted that there are two factions on the mainland concerning policy toward Taiwan.
He said Hu's words might be aimed at improving cross-strait ties in the short term, hoping to woo the Taiwan people so as to dampen the sentiment of Taiwan independence

But he also urged Beijing to be pragmatic, saying that President Chen Shui-bian's cross-strait policy has always been to keep Taiwan's status quo and peace in the Taiwan Strait. He added that the president said in his New Year's message this year that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should establish stable, peaceful exchanges.
But the DPP official also said that because there is a lack of basis for mutual trust, there are great hurdles in the way of achieving the goal.
The mainland says that the hurdle lies on the Taiwan side, but the Taiwan side disagrees. He cited as an example the direct cross-strait postal, trade and transportation links touted by Taiwan.
He said that the government has already issued an assessment report on direct transportation links, but has so far failed to get any response from the mainland.
"That is because Beijing doesn't want the DPP to continue to rule, so that it is unwilling to give a chance to both sides to improve relations before the March 20 presidential election, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WATCHING U.S. MAD COW CASE CLOSELY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is watching closely the developments following the announcement of the first case of mad cow disease in the United States that was confirmed by a British veterinary laboratory Thursday, government sources said Friday.
Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said they will make a decision shortly on whether a long-term ban on U.S. beef and related products will be implemented.

In the wake of the confirmation of the case, discovered in the state of Washington, the world organization for animal health, known by the acronym OIE, is expected to make a decision shortly on whether to declare the United States a mad cow disease-affected area, the COA officials said.

If the United States is declared a mad cow disease-affected area, it will have to suspend exports of beef and related products for seven years. Taiwan, consequently, is also expected to announce a ban on imports of U.S. beef and related products for seven years, said Chen Yu-hsin, a section chief of the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine.

The Department of Health (DOH) announced Wednesday a temporary suspension of imports of U.S. beef, cattle carcasses, organs, tissue and derived products such as placenta extract, in response to the first case of mad cow disease reported in the United States a day earlier.

The beef import suspension is not expected to affect beef supplies in Taiwan very much, as Taiwan still can import beef and related products from Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Paraguay, in addition to domestic supplies, Chen noted.
He added that Taiwan consumers can turn choose domestic beef, as the product is safe and supplies are strictly controlled in terms of safety inspections.

Chen said Taiwan has adopted stricter inspection measures on beef products and cattle than the criteria mandated by the OIE. For example, he said, the OIE rules that for mad cow disease checks, 50 head of cattle out of each 500,000 must be examined by vets to make sure the herd is not infected.
Taiwan's criteria are 20 times more strict than the OIE standard, Chen said.

Currently, Taiwan rancher are raising some 160,000 head of cattle islandwide. Some 600 head of cattle have been randomly selected for mad cow disease inspection annually since 2002. This year, 984 head had been examined as of the end of November.

According to COA tallies, Australia and New Zealand are Taiwan's two largest sources of beef. Taiwan imported more than 35,000 tons of beef and related products from Australia in 2002, 15,400 tons from New Zealand and 13,900 tons from the United States. Canada was the fourth-largest supplier, with 3,800 tons. Other beef sources include Panama and Paraguay.

Mad cow disease, also known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, eats holes in the brains of cattle. It first sprang up in Britain in 1986 and spread through countries in Europe, prompting massive slaughter of herds and decimating the European beef industry.

A form of mad cow disease can be contracted by humans through eating infected beef or nerve tissue, and possibly through blood transfusions. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease -- the human form of mad cow disease -- has so far killed 143 people in Britain and 10 elsewhere. No one in the United States has died from the disease. People who are possibly at risk for the disease are banned from donating blood.
Chen Lu-hung, director-general of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, said U.S. milk and milk products will not be included for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS EX-JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui hosted a luncheon Friday in honor of former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, who arrived in Taipei a day earlier for a three-day private visit.
Lee said he welcomes Mori's goodwill visit to Taiwan, which he said would help boost friendship between the two countries. Lee refrained from elaborating further on his talks with Mori.

Sources close to Lee said the former president took advantage of the lunch meeting to thank Mori for granting him a visa to visit Japan in April 2001 to receive medical treatment. At that time, Mori was still prime minister. As to whether Lee is likely to visit Japan again for medical treatment, the sources said, the issue was not discussed.
Earlier in the day, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said President Chen Shui-bian met with Mori at the Presidential Office a day earlier for wide-ranging talks.
As Mori is on a private visit, Chien said he was not in a position to comment further on the visit.
To the best of his understanding, Chien said, Chen and Mori are "old friends." Chen once met with Mori during a trip to Japan before he assumed the presidency, Chien noted.
Diplomatic sources said Chen exchanged views with Mori on measures to further boost Taiwan-Japanese ties as well as Asia-Pacific regional affairs.

Meanwhile, reports from Japan said Mori had advised Chen to have second thoughts on his plan to hold a "defensive referendum" on the day of Taiwan's next presidential election to provide a venue for local people to express their feelings about mainland China's deployment of nearly 500 ballistic missiles pointed at Taiwan. The U.S. government has expressed concern about the referendum plan as it is afraid that the move may provoke Beijing.

Mori is one of the few Japanese political heavyweights to have visited Taiwan and Beijing has expressed "deep regret" and "strong dissatisfaction" with Mori's visit. Japanese news media have given prominent coverage to Mori's itinerary.

The main purpose of Mori's current trip is to attend the funeral of a friend of his father. He will also dine with a group of Taiwan alumni of his alma mater, Waseda University, before wrapping up his visit Saturday.

Legislator Tang Pi-o of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Mori ranks among the three most influential Japanese politicians at the moment. In the face of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Tang said, Mori's visit is an encouragement to Taiwan.
"We hope other Japanese political heavyweights can follow suit and make frequent visits to Taiwan help boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation," Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETAIL BOOKING SYSTEM HOPES TO INCLUDE TAIWAN BUDGET HOTELS

TEXT.P: The popular Retail Booking System (RBS) called a news conference Friday in Taipei to express its hope of attracting domestic economy and budget hotels to enter its worldwide Internet service.

The system hopes to include Taiwan's small hotels and youth hostels as part of its international service on the Internet to provide backpackers with greater access to more economic options for online hotel booking, an RBS executive said.

Currently, almost all five-star hotels in Taiwan are part of the RBS, and the system now is hoping to seek small and medium-sized hotels to offer foreign individual customers more short-term accommodation on the Internet, the RBS official said.

Lai Seh-jen, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said the RBS offers an effective channel for Taiwan's economy hotels and youth hostels to sharpen their international distribution, particularly among the many young and individual backpackers who are the prevailing force in the global tourism market.
The RBS drive comes at a good time, as the government has set a target of doubling the number of tourist arrivals to Taiwan by 2008.

The multilingual RBS is widely used by 15,000 hotels in 112 countries around the world, including Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Hong Kong, Singapore, Sydney, Indonesia, the United States and Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.007 to close at NT$34.052.
A total of US$413 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.063 and hit a low of NT$34.045.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLY SEE DONATES US$500,000 TO CATHOLIC DIOCESE OF KAOHSIUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By P.C. Fann and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Holy See has donated US$500,000 to the Catholic Diocese of Kaohsiung to show its concern over the Catholic community's development in Taiwan and to demonstrate Pope John Paul II's friendship toward the people of Taiwan.

Well-placed sources in the Vatican said Friday that the donation has already been given by the Holy See's envoy in Taipei to His Eminence Paul Cardinal S.J. Shan, who is also bishop of the Diocese of Kaohsiung. The money will be used for charity work in the diocese.

Saying that the pope has always been concerned about poor people, refugees and minority groups around the world, the sources said that the donation illustrates that the head of the Holy See has not forgotten such people in Taiwan.
The Republic of China government donated US$500,000 to the Vatican in October in celebration of the 25th inauguration anniversary of the pope and in support of his benevolent work for world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,500 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS DETAINED IN 2003

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have detained 3,500 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants by the end of this year, the head of the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Friday.
CGA Minister Wang Chun made the remarks in the first meeting as part of a project to crack down on illegal immigrant crime syndicates. The meeting was presided over by Premier Yu Shyi-kun.
Wang noted that the detention of illegal mainland immigrants reached its highest figure of 6,130 in 1993. The number began to decrease after 1995, but started to increase dramatically again in 2002.

The number of illegal mainland immigrants in the first 10 months of this year reached 3,055, Wang said, adding that more than 300 have been arrested since October and predicting that the number will reach 3,500 by the end of the year.

But he said that mainland China has also begun to crack down on illegal immigrants, and has arrested 200 so far. With both sides taking action, he estimated that the number of illegal mainland immigrants detained could drop to below 2,000 next year.

Wang also said that after the recent revision of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, those who broker illegal immigrants to come to Taiwan -- known as snakeheads -- will receive stiffer punishment.

Human smuggling ringleaders will face prison terms of over five years, and could also be fined up to NT$10 million (US$294,117). The fishing vessels commonly used to smuggle illegal immigrants will also be confiscated.
Ring members will be turned over to prosecutors' offices. Other measures will include raising the cash rewards for informers to between NT$3,000 and NT$60,000.

National Police Administration Director-General Chang Su-liang said that the police will step up a crackdown on fronts for prostitution such as KTVs and barber shops and that when illegal immigrants are found to be working there, the water and power supplies to such businesses will be cut and they might be ordered to close.
Chang also said that new detention centers will be built on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, as most illegal immigrants are detained there so as to facilitate their repatriation.

An inter-government agency project to crack down on illegal mainland immigrants was established Nov. 1 and the project organizers hope to arrest 1,000 and 1,200 people and bust between 15 and 25 cases of syndicate crime during a six-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were generally higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 7 points to close at 5,867, with 17,939 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February futures rose 4 points to finish at 5,870, with 218 contract transactions, while March futures gained 7 points to close at 5,867, with 4 contracts traded.
June futures increased 12 points to finish at 5,852, with 7 contract transactions, while September futures moved down 41 points to close at 5,845, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,860 for January, 5,866 for February, 5,860 for March, 5,840 for June, and 5,886 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
January TE futures rose 0.75 points to finish at 244.85, with 1,857 contract transactions, while February TE futures gained 1.5 points to close at 245, with 2 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January TF futures lost one point to finish at 884.6, with 2,950 contract transactions, while February TF futures fell one point to close at 885, with 8 contracts traded.
March TF futures decreased 7 points to finish at 878, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL RESPECTS JAPANESE COURT DECISION OVER COMPENSATION: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) respects the ruling by a Japanese court Thursday that CAL must pay 5.02 billion yen (US$46.6 million) in compensation to the families of 111 people who perished in a 1994 plane crash, a CAL spokesman said Friday.

Responding to the ruling made by a Nagoya court, the spokesman said that CAL will see to it that the families of the victims -- including 100 Japanese passengers and 11 Taiwanese passengers -- receive due compensation in accordance with the requests made by a committee formed by the victims' families.
All such payments will be made by CAL's insurance company and will not have any impact on CAL's finances, the spokesman said.
The ruling by the Japanese court marks a new high in Japanese air traffic history in terms of the amount of compensation awarded and the number of plaintiffs.
However, another suit filed by the same committee against Airbus Co. for compensation for the same tragedy was rejected by a French court.

According to an investigation report released by the Japanese Ministry of Transport in July 1996, the 1994 CAL Airbus crash was caused mainly by pilot error and the fact that there were no warning systems in the aircraft exclusively for abnormalities.
The families of the victims who filed the suits had asked that CAL and Air Bus Co. jointly pay 19 billion yen in compensation for the deaths of the 111 people.

CAL has settled compensation and related matters separately with families of 153 other victims, who included Taiwanese nationals and citizens of various other countries, over the past nine years, the spokesman added.

The CAL Air Bus 300-600R passenger jet was flying from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to the central Japanese city of Nagoya the night of April 26, 1994, when it crashed at the Nagoya Airport, killing 264 of the 271 people aboard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 26, or the fourth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG REMAINS ON HIGH ALERT FOR SARS

TEXT.P: Hong Kong authorities are on high alert for severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) following news of a suspected case in Guangdong province.
The Ministry of Health has despatched several specialists to determine if the patient in a Guangzhou hospital actually has SARS.
The Nanfang Dushi Bao newspaper in Guangzhou first reported on the suspected case and gave the patient's surname as Luo.
The patient was reportedly hospitalized on December 20.
The Department of Health in Hong Kong has ordered all public hospitals to implement the existed three-tier warning system against SARS.

TEXT.P: The New York Times: Quake in Iran kills thousands and ravages an ancient city.

A powerful earthquake rocked Bam, an ancient Iranian city 610 miles southeast of Tehran, in southeastern Iran, early Friday morning. killing thousands and destroying 70 to 90 percent of the residential areas.

The provincial governor general, Muhammad Ali Karimi, put the initial number of dead at 5,000 to 6,000, but said the toll was expected to rise as high as 20,000. Some 30,000 were reported to be injured, many in critical condition.

"The reason for concern with these calves is that even though it is an unlikely means of spreading the disease, there is the potential that the infected cow could pass the disease onto its calves," according to Dr. Ronald DeHaven, the Agriculture Department's chief veterinarian.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDECIDED VOTERS ON THE RISE: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: The ratio of undecided voters has risen while the support ratings for presidential candidates from both ruling and opposition camps declined, according to the results of an opinion poll released Saturday.

The telephone survey of 1,205 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) from Dec. 22-25, found that the team of President Chen shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu has a support rating of 24.9 percent, down 0.4 percent from the level recorded in a similar poll conducted a week ago.
The support rating of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong also declined 1.1 percent to 33.1 percent.

Meanwhile, 6.1 percent said they would not go to polls or would cast spoiled votes if the presidential election were to take place the following day; and 35.9 percent said they have not yet decided for whom they would vote, up 4.2 percent from the week-earlier survey.

Huang Teh-fu, director of the "pan-blue alliance's" polling center, attributed the increase in the undecided voters to a combination of factors, including the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) attack on the KMT's allegedly ill-gotten party assets and the controversy over President Chen's alleged disclosure of information about mainland China's missile deployment that opposition parties claimed had led to Beijing's arrest of scores of alleged Taiwan spies.
Commenting on the KMT poll results, DPP officials claimed that the survey underestimated the Chen-Lu ticket's support rating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STAYS ON HIGH ALERT OVER SUSPECTED SARS CASE IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Health authorities said Saturday they will step up fever-screening of passengers from mainland China and neighboring Hong Kong and Macau after a suspected case of SARS was detected in the southern mainland city of Guangzhou.

Those detected with fever -- an early symptom of the severe acute respiratory syndrome or SARS -- would be sent directly to a hospital for tests on arrival at the airport, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said.

"Patients will only be discharged after they are confirmed safe. The other passengers (checked with no suspicious symptoms) would be asked to monitor their own health conditions for 10 days," said CDC director Su Ih-jen.
Su also urged local people to avoid visiting hospitals or eating wild animal meat while traveling in mainland China to reduce the risk of infection.
Once the mainland patient is confirmed to have come down with SARS, Su said, quarantine and other precautionary measures will be further reinforced.
Mainland China's Ministry of Health confirmed Saturday that a man in Guangzhou was being treated as a suspected SARS case.
The communicable disease triggered a worldwide health crisis after emerging in China's southern Guangdong province in November last year, causing more than 700 deaths from some 8,000 infections.
The World Health Organization declared the disease contained worldwide on July 5.
In Taiwan, a military medical researcher was confirmed on Dec. 17 to have contract the deadly virus while at work, raising fears that an outbreak might return.

The case was later determined an isolated one, with the CDC announcing the island cleared of SARS infections after the last two people who had contact with the patient were removed from a watchlist at midnight Friday. The military researcher will be discharged from the hospital next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60-MEMBER TAIWAN RESCUE TEAM LEAVES FOR IRAN

TEXT.P: A 60-member Taiwan rescue team left for Iran Saturday evening to join search and rescue operations in the southeastern Iranian city of Bam which was hit by a deadly earthquake a day earlier.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien presented a national flag to Huang Po-tsun, a senior official from the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior who is heading the rescue team on the Iranian rescue mission.

Chien said at the flag-presentation ceremony held at Chaing Kai-shek International Airport that Taiwan received assistance from many countries when it was rattled by a magnitude 7.3 earthquake in 1999.
"Now is time for us to feed back what we have received in the past. We hope our rescue team will contribute to post-quake search and relief operations," Chien added.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced earlier in the day that Taiwan will donate US$100,000 in emergency relief aid to help Iranian quake victims.

MOFA officials said the ministry has joined forces with Taiwan's overseas offices in the Middle East to arrange for the rescue team to reach Bam, which is located about 1,000 kilometers southeast of the Iranian capital of Tehran.

The Taiwan rescue team is scheduled to arrive in Iran Sunday via a flight through Bangkok and Dubai. Iranian authorities will send staff to assist professional Taiwan rescuers in carrying out their work, MOFA officials said.
The officials said MOFA has offered condolences and regards to the Iranian government and earthquake refugees on behalf of the ROC government and people.

According to MOFA officials, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity -- has also organized an emergency relief team to assist in post-disaster relief operations in Iran. The Tzu Chi team is scheduled to leave for Tehran Sunday evening.
Taiwan has sent rescue experts and first-aid medical professionals to join disaster relief operations in Indonesia and El Salvador in the past few years.

Iran's official news agency reported Saturday that the Iranian government has decided to offer visa-free entry privileges to foreign rescue specialists and other emergency relief workers for the time being.

Meanwhile, the ROC Red Cross Society said it has sent messages to Iran's Red Crescent Society and the Geneva-based International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, offering to send rescue and medical professionals as well as relief goods to help Iranian earthquake victims. The Red Cross Society said it plans to send 30 trained rescuers to Iran initially.
Major local Buddhist groups said they are also planning humanitarian aid programs to assist Iranian refugees.
The Tzu Chi Foundation said it will take concrete actions after receiving reports from its volunteers in Iran's neighboring countries, such as Jordan and Turkey.
The Dhram Drum Mountain Culture and Education Foundation said it has set up a special task force to work out feasible relief programs.

The Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society said it has maintained close contacts with major Islamic groups in Iran as they have been jointly planning a seminar on Buddhist-Islam exchanges to be held in Iran in 2004. "We'll announce concrete post-quake aid programs after discussing with Iranian Islamic groups," said a spokesman.

The Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps said it has expressed its concerns about Iranian refugees through an Iranian non-government organization known as ODBVV. "We'll evaluate the feaibility of offering medical aid after receiving a report from ODBVV about the medical demand in the quake-affected region," said the group's founder Liu Chi-chun in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR UNITY AGAINST BEIJING MEDDLING IN 2004 ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday the nation's upcoming presidential election will be a battle between Taiwan voters and the Communist Party of China (CPC) on the mainland.

Addressing a rally marking the inauguration of a campaign office for the "Chen-Lu" ticket in the southern county of Chiayi, Chen said the CPC's Taiwan Affairs Panel and its Central Military Commission held a joint meeting Dec. 2 to discuss various measures aimed at undermining his re-election bid.

"Beijing authorities have decided to launch an all-out campaign through news media, the Internet and Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China to prevent me from winning the presidency again, " Chen told a large crowd of his supporters present at the rally.

Chen, who will team up with Vice President Annette Lu to run in next presidential election scheduled for March 20, 2004, said the upcoming election will not be a battle for him and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to remain in power, but rather a battle against mainland China's interference with Taiwan's electoral affairs.
Stressing that Taiwan has come a long way to achieve democracy, Chen said local people should stand united to fight against Beijing's meddling in the upcoming presidential election.
"We should not be daunted by China's intimidation and saber-rattling, " Chen said, adding that the people of Taiwan should be free of fear.

Chen said Taiwan is like an international outcast because of mainland China's diplomatic embargo. "Worse still, it has deployed hundreds of ballistic missiles pointed at Taiwan. And now it has stepped up efforts to sway local voters ahead of our presidential election. We should stand firm and united to stave off Beijing's interference in our electoral affairs," he urged.
Speaking at another supporters rally in neighboring Yunlin County in the afternoon, Chen said the upcomign election is for the people of Taiwan to choose their future national leader.
"China has no say in deciding who should be Taiwan's president," Chen said. "Let our people use ballots to protect our young democracy amd decide our own destiny."
Chen also urged local voters to support his re-election to complete his ambitious reform initiatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU RESIDENTS SUPPORT SETTING UP CASINOS DESPITE LOW TURNOUT

TEXT.P: The turnout rate for a consultative referendum on setting up casinos on the outlying Penghu Island was only around 21 percent, but those who are supportive of setting up casinos outnumbered those who are opposed to the idea.

There are 68,086 eligible voters in Penghu, and out of the 13,814 effective votes cast, 7,830 votes were supportive of the establishment of casinos, outnumbering the 5,984 votes who were against the proposal.

The outlying island, because of its geographical location and windy weather conditions, has difficulty in developing a local industry, and the job market is limited. As it is distant from Taiwan proper, it has not attracted much attention from the central government, resulting in stalled local construction and the outflow of the local population.

For this reason, Penghu has for the last 20 years tried to set up casinos to help local development, but those who are opposed to the idea said casinos could make social order worse and corrupt local residents.

The referendum promotion committee said that judging from the referendum result, those who are in the more remote villages cast more supportive votes, while those in Makung, the capital city, votes between the yes and noes were 282 votes apart, showing those who are civil servants, teachers or have higher educational backgrounds tend to worry more about the possible adverse impacts of the casinos.
Meanwhile, independent Legislator Lin Ping-kun expressed the hope that the government would attach importance to the result of the referendum.
As for the low turnout rate, Lin said that this was because the choices of the referendum were too simplified with only two options.

Lin stressed that Penghu residents have misgivings about whether the government can effectively manage the casinos, and that if the referendum had a third option -- meaning a conditional approval of the setting up of casinos -- he is sure that a majority of the residents would give their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HAPPY WITH RESULTS OF NEW KITCHEN WASTE COLLECTION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Officials of the Environmental Protection Bureau under Taipei City Government said Saturday that they are satisfied with the results of the new kitchen leftover recycling program one day after the system was put into practice.
Environmental officials said that around 80 tons of kitchen waste was collected Friday, or about half of their targeted collection goal of 150 tons daily, which they said was a "good start."

The officials said that they observed a great majority of people supporting the kitchen leftover recycling effort, and they know how to divide two different kinds of kitchen waste, although around 50 percent of the people still used plastic bags for kitchen waste.
The Environmental Protection Bureau provides containers to collect kitchen waste, and the public can also use their own containers to collect it.

The officials urged the public to heed the regulations and not mix non-kitchen waste with kitchen waste, saying that those who violate the regulations will be advised for the time being, and will later be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000 (US$35.29 to US$176.45).

The kitchen waste is divided into two categories under the new system: food leftovers or spoiled food will be used to feed pigs, while fruit peelings, egg shells, fruit seeds, tea and coffee grounds are to be used as compost.

Meanwhile, the Environmental Protection Administration also announced that the kitchen waste collection system will be expanded from Taipei to all cities and counties in Taiwan next year, hoping to recycle 900 tons of kitchen waste a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXHIBITION OF HIGH-QUALITY AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS HELD IN TAINAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A two-day exhibition of Taiwan's high-quality agricultural products was inaugurated Saturday in Tainan, with domestic and overseas buyers attending.

The exhibition, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) at the commission of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, is aimed at promoting the sale of Taiwan's agricultural products both in local and foreign markets.
According to CETRA, foreign buyers attending the exhibition came mainly from South Korea, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Macau.

As the government has attached much importance to such product-promotion activities, President Chen Shui-bian will be invited Sunday to attend the exhibition, where more than 1,000 farm, livestock and marine products with local characteristics will be exhibited.
Facing strong competition from foreign products after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, CETRA has formed an ad-hoc group to exclusively promote Taiwan's agricultural exports.
With Taiwan's high-quality agricultural products, CETRA officials said they have great confidence that these products will be popular in world markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG ALERTS MEDICAL FACILITIES OF SUSPECTED SARS CASE

TEXT.P: Hong Kong is closely watching the suspected case of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Guangdong, and has activated preventative measures.

At a media briefing today, Health Director P.Y. Lam said that following notification by Guangdong authorities, the Department of Health has been closely watching developments and taking the following precautionary measures:
- Maintaining mandatory health declarations and temperature screening checks for passengers arriving from Guangdong.
- Stepping up broadcasts at border check points.
- Deploying medical staff to distribute health alert cards to passengers arriving by plane from Guangzhou.
"Although there are no cases in Hong Kong yet, we are mindful of the large volume of people flowing between Guangdong and Hong Kong, " Lam said.
The Department of Health has established communication channels and dialogue with Guangdong authorities and will contact them daily for updates, he said.
The Department of Health has also alerted the Hospital Authority and is informing private hospitals, all doctors and laboratory personnel in Hong Kong about the incident.
"They have been reminded to maintain vigilance in infection control and disease reporting," Lam said.

"We will also send letters to all Chinese medicine practitioners to advise them to be vigilant. Even though Hong Kong has been free from SARS since early June, members of the public are reminded to remain vigilant and observe good personal hygiene," Lam added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE US$100,000 IN QUAKE RELIEF AID TO IRAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate US$100,000 in emergency relief aid to Iran to help victims of a deadly earthquake that devastated the southeastern Iranian city of Bam early Friday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.

More than 50 rescue staff members from the National Fire Administration and the Taipei municipal rescue team are waiting at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan and can leave for rescue missions in Iran anytime, the officials said. The Red Cross Society said it plans to send 30 trained rescuers to Iran initially.

The Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps said it has expressed its concerns about Iranian refugees through an Iranian non-government organization known as ODBVV. DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PATIENT EXPECTED TO BE RELEASED FROM HOSPITAL BY END OF MONTH

TEXT.P: The scientist who came down with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is expected to be released from Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital by the end of this month, a hospital official said Saturday.

Huang Lien-chi, deputy superintendent of the hospital, said that Lt. Col. Chan, a SARS researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine under the National Defense Medical College, who contracted the atypical pneumonia while handling the virus, is recuperating well at the hospital.
"Except for a very small amount of virus in his body, Lt. Col. Chan is just like a normal, healthy person," Huang said.

Huang said the hospital has sent a specimen of Chan's saliva to the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health, and if all examinations are negative, then he can be discharged from the hospital.

Chan checked into Hoping Hospital Dec. 17, and his fever subsided the next day and his conditions greatly improved. He has not needed a nose tube over the past two days, and his breathing is smooth without signs of shortness of breath.
The more significant development is that antibodies have appeared in his system, showing that the amount of viral infection is slowly being reduced, Huang said.

Chan, the first SARS case this winter, is believed to have contracted the disease at work Dec. 5 when he touched spilled SARS samples with his bare hands after work that was part of SARS virus research at a top-level P4 laboratory in which the use of gowns and gloves is mandatory. It was not clear why Chan had decided to break the rules and not wear gloves.

He then flew to Singapore for an academic conference along with five co-workers Dec. 7 and began to feel fatigue the next day while in Singapore, but did not develop the fever which is typical of SARS.

Chan returned to Taiwan Dec. 10, and by that night, had developed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. His wife took him to see a doctor near their house in Hsintien the next day. At that time, nobody suspected him of having SARS, even though his job involved working with the SARS virus. Another full week passed before he was sent to Hoping hospital after developing diarrhea. At the hospital, Chan underwent tests that confirmed the SARS virus was present in his system.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP GOVERNMENT IS DETERMINED ON AGRICULTURAL REFORM: PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, southern Taiwan, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that a series of agricultural reform projects have reflected President Chen Shui-bian's determination in protecting farmers' interests.

In an inspection tour to cooperative societies in Yunlin County to better understand their marketing operations, Yu noted that the Council of Agriculture and the China External Trade Development Council have been cooperating actively in promoting the sales of Taiwan's agricultural products abroad.
He went on that the country needs a comprehensive plan for the production and marketing of agricultural products.

According to Yu, other measures aimed at protecting farmers interests are also high on the agenda of the government, such as increasing elderly farmers' pensions, offering low-interest farmers' loans and disaster relief loans, as well as increasing import relief funds.

Yu added that the government plans to inject NT$67.5 billion (US$1.98 billion) into the import relief fund next year to better protect the interests of farmers, and the target for the fund in 2005 will be NT$100 billion.
Later in the day, in a visit to an association of president Chen's supporters, Yu stressed that the DPP government has presented numerous policies and reform plans since it came to power in 2000.

As a result, the island's economy has been recovering, and share prices, the real estate market, as well as foreign reserves are rising, Yu noted and added that the DPP government has the capability to lead the country efficiently. Therefore, he said that it would be unwise to remove the architects of the vibrant, new country.
Yu urged the people to continue their support for Chen in next year's presidential election for the welfare of the country.
Meanwhile, Yu criticized the opposition Kuomintang's reluctance to return the assets it has embezzled from the country during its previous five-decade rule on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER MORI WRAPS UP VISIT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori left Taiwan Saturday afternoon after wrapping up a three-day private visit.

Although no longer in power, Mori is still considered as one of the few influential political heavyweights in Japan. He was the Japanese prime minister who granted a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui in 2001 allowing him to receive medical treatment in spite of strong opposition from Beijing.
Political analysts said Mori's visit is expected to strengthen Taiwan-Japan ties in the lack of official relations.
During Mori's stay in Taipei, he met with several important political figures, including President Chen Shui-bian and former president Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEEF IMPORTERS URGED TO DISPLAY COUNTRY OF ORIGIN CERTIFICATES

TEXT.P: Relevant government agencies should demand that beef importers produce official country of origin certificates because of concern over mad cow disease, the ROC Consumers Foundation said Saturday.
Beef retailers or supermarket operators should also be required to display country of origin certificates on their beef shelves, the non-profit foundation said.

The foundation made the call after conducting spot checks on supermarket shelves in 10 noted department stores in metropolitan Taipei Dec. 25-26 amid concern about beef safety in the wake of the announcement of the first case of mad cow disease in the United States.
The foundation said only Tayeh Takashimaya Department Store has clearly displayed country of origin certificates where it sells beef products.

The remaining stores have either not displayed the origin certificates or have offered confusing information, the foundation said. For instance, a supermarket displayed a "beef imported from Australia" signboard near a shelf even though the labels on the packages indicated that the products were from the United States.

Nearly all supermarkets surveyed displayed posters claiming that their beef came from Australia or New Zealand, but none of them have produced country of origin certificates or copies of the documents, the foundation said.

Department of Health (DOH) officials said they will intensify their spot checks of markets. Supermarket operators or retailers who offer confusing or false information to mislead consumers will be penalized in accordance with existing food regulations, the officials said.

The Consumers Foundation advised consumers to ascertain product origin and check relevant certificates whenever they purchase beef at supermarkets or other retail shops. Amid the mad cow disease scare, the foundation said consumers should for the time being avoid eating beef offal.

The foundation also urged food hygiene authorities to step up inspections of markets and trace distribution networks. While beef importers should be required to produce country of origin certificates, the foundation said, retailers should display those certificates at distribution points.

Health authorities should also inspect dairy products and cosmetics to determine whether they contain contaminated substances, the foundation said, adding that the government should establish an imported meat certification system.
More important, the foundation said, the government should make every possible effort to prevent beef smuggling, particularly cattle offal from mainland China.
Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said it is closely watching the developments following the announcement of the first U.S. mad cow disease case.
As of Saturday, the COA said, the world organization for animal health, known by the acronym OIE, has not yet declared the United States a mad cow disease-affected area.
If the United States is declared a mad cow disease-affected area, it will have to suspend exports of beef and related products for seven years.

Like many other countries, Taiwan announced a temporary ban on beef imports from the United States immediately after the announcement of the discovery of a mad cow disease-infected cow on a farm in Washington State Wednesday.

According to OIE regulations, the COA said, member countries can determine the scope and duration of the import ban in terms of the contamination risks of different products after a specific country is declared a mad cow disease-infected area.

"This means in case the United States is declared a mad cow disease-affected area, Taiwan may still import selected beef products under certain conditions, " said Chiang Yi-nan, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine.

The United States is Taiwan's third-largest beef supplier, after Australia and New Zealand. In 2002, Taiwan imported more than 35,000 tons of beef and related products from Australia, 15,400 tons from New Zealand and 13,900 tons from the United States.

Mad cow disease, also known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, eats holes in the brains of cattle. It first sprang up in Britain in 1986 and spread through countries in Europe, prompting the massive slaughter of herds and decimating the European beef industry.

A form of mad cow disease can be contracted by humans by eating infected beef or nerve tissue, and possibly through blood transfusions. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease -- the human form of mad cow disease -- has so far killed 143 people in Britain and 10 elsewhere. No one in the United States has died from the disease. People who are possibly at risk from the disease are banned from donating blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 27, or the fifth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES TAIWAN WOMEN TO DEMAND BEIJING REMOVE MISSILES

TEXT.P: The women of Taiwan, particularly the more than 1 million mothers, should stand up and demand that Beijing remove its deployed missiles aimed at Taiwan, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday.
Lu made the remarks while giving a speech during a re-election campaign rally in northern Taoyuan County.

Claiming that Taiwan's more than 8.15 million women should rally behind the government to urge Beijing to remove the missiles, Lu said spouses of the many Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland should ask their husbands to return home if the Chinese Communist regime refuses to abandon the option of the use of force against Taiwan.
Lu lashed out at Beijing's rhetoric that its missiles are only aimed at a small group of Taiwan independence advocates.

She called on Taiwan's women voters to support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the March presidential election because it will be a fierce competition against the Kuomintang, the People First Party, the New Party and the Chinese Communist Party.

The DPP attaches great importance to gender equality and women's welfare and interests, she said, adding that Taiwan's female citizens should open their eyes wide when casting their ballots to help the DPP continue with its reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WELCOME TO TAKE PART IN FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is welcome to take part in the New Year national flag-raising ceremony to be held at the Presidential Office Building plaza in the early morning of Jan. 1, a Presidential Office spokesman said Sunday.
All citizens of the country are welcomed by the Presidential Office to attend the ceremony, said James Huang, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office.

Huang, nevertheless, questioned the timing of Lien's decision to take part in this flag-raising ceremony in the run-up to the March 20 presidential election, asking why Lien did not attend similar ceremonies over the past three years. Huang said Lien owes the general public an explanation in the matter.

According to Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also campaign manager of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate ticket of Lien and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, arrangements have been made for Lien and Soong to take part in the ceremony.
It will be the first time for Lien or Soong to take part in a national flag-raising ceremony since the power transition in May 2000.
It has been learned that the "pan-blue alliance" is expected to mobilize some 10,000 supporters to take part in the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPERATURE CHECKS AT AIRPORTS COULD BECOME NORM: HEALTH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Temperature checks may become the norm at Taiwan's international airports in the wake of a possible resurgence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Guangdong Province, mainland China, a Center for Disease Control (CDC) official said Sunday.

While closely monitoring the situation regarding the suspected SARS case in Guangdong, Taiwan authorities implemented the temperature taking policy at the country's two international airports Saturday as part of efforts to keep SARS at bay, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said at a joint press conference.

Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport began on Saturday taking the temperature of passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau after a suspected SARS case was reported in Panyu City, Guangdong.
Passengers found to have a fever -- an early symptom of SARS -- will be sent directly to hospital upon arrival, Shih said.

Speaking at the press conference that he jointly called with Chang Shang-chun, director of the Infectious Disease Department at National Taiwan University Hospital, and Ho Mei-shang, an associate research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences, Shih said the CDC is worried that SARS may already have become an endemic disease in some areas in Asia which will occur seasonally in these regions.

Commenting on the possible SARS case in Guangdong, Chang said that "one can never be too careful, " adding that employing a higher standard of preventive measures is essential for Taiwan at a time when the Guangdong health authorities are delaying in verifying the latest case.
For her part, Ho, a virologist, said some SARS cases take longer to verify due to the nature of the disease.

Shih said he believes that Guangdong's latest suspected SARS case will not be an isolated case. In June of this year, mainland China was declared safe for travel after a spate of SARS outbreaks in southern and northern parts of the country.

He said that if Guangdong's suspected SARS case is confirmed to indeed be a SARS case and the patient is found not to have come into close contact with any wild animals recently, this will indicate that SARS has become endemic in the region.

Meanwhile, Shih said that the temperature taking policy implemented at Taiwan's international airports Saturday is not only helping in the battle against SARS, pointing out that several cases of malaria, dengue fever and shigella dysentery have also been discovered.

In addition to the temperature checks at the airports, other measures, such as vaccination against SARS as well as the development of relevant medicines, are crucial for Taiwan in its fight against SARS, he said.
The CDC urged local people to avoid visiting hospitals or eating wild animal meat while traveling in mainland China in order to reduce the risk of contracting SARS.
