DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORERS DEMONSTRATE FOR BASIC HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Some 600 foreign workers in Taiwan took to the streets Sunday to appeal to the government to protect their basic human rights in a demonstration which began from the 228 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei.

The foreign workers, expatriates from Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam, came from their work places in Taipei, Chungli, Taoyuan and southern Taiwan to take part in the demonstration, a spokesperson for the Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA) said.

During the rally, the foreign workers made known their four-point appeal to the government, asking the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to carry out a comprehensive review of the foreign worker introduction policy aimed at protecting the foreign expatriates' rights to choose and change employers.

The TIWA wants the CLA to establish a "foreign worker affairs bureau" under the CLA hierarchy to directly handle labor affairs between the government of Taiwan and those of the expatriates' countries so as to prevent exploitation by labor brokers, the spokesperson said.

The TIWA also wants the Legislative Yuan to enact a statute governing household services and related affairs so as to protect the foreign workers' rights to rest and free time. It further wants the CLA to repeal the existing regulation in which meal and accommodation costs are calculated as part of the foreign workers' wages, the spokesperson said.

The spokesperson pointed out that some 3 million foreign workers have been sacrificing their time and energy working as laborers in Taiwan over the past decade, contributing significantly to Taiwan's development in various sectors.

The foreign workers should not be blamed for Taiwan's rising unemployment, the spokesperson said. Instead, the Taiwan authorities should review and overhaul their labor affairs policy to find out what has gone wrong and what has caused the foreign workers' plight and rising unemployment, the spokesperson added.

The rally, the first of its kind in Taiwan's history, kicked off from the 228 Memorial Park at 2 p.m., with the foreign workers walking with banners along Guanqian Road, Zhongxiao East Road, Gongyuan Road, Qingdao West Road and Zhongshan South Road to Ketagalan Road in front of the Presidential Office.

In related news, lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said last Friday that the DPP has reduced the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan to 297,000 -- down 32,000 from the peak figure -- over the past three years.

The legislators made the remarks in response to remarks by Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticizing the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for relaxing the foreign laborer policy at the expense of domestic workers.

Ho said that the CLA announced recently that it will once again allow imports of foreign laborers in the construction sector after having suspended them for two years. Formosa Plastics Group's sixth naphtha cracker project will be able to introduce 5,800 foreign laborers, which Ho said will affect the employment opportunities of domestic laborers. Ho noted that the jobless rate in November was 4.7 percent.
DPP Legislator Lai Chin-teh retorted that the number of foreign laborers in the industrial sector has been cut by more than 40,000 since the DPP came to power.

Lai said that the DPP's adjustment of its foreign laborer policy is mainly based on considerations of national dignity, the protection of job opportunities for Taiwan citizens, the basic human rights of foreign laborers, and the goal of reducing the total number of foreign laborers in Taiwan. The purpose is to control the number of foreign laborers at below 300,000, he added.

TEXT.P: The Supreme Prosecutors Office has established a task force to curb vote-buying and violence in the run-up of the next March 20 presidential election, officials of the Ministry of Justice said Sunday.

The officials said that the task force will pool together efforts of all law enforcement agencies around the nation to deter vote-buying and violence from happening in the election. No vote-buying and violence will be tolerated, they claimed.
The officials also encouraged the general public to report vote-buying and other illegal practices to the authorities in order to help make a clean election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM MIGHT BE AFFECTED BY NEW SARS CASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourism industry might be dealt a fresh blow by the recent re-emergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan and mainland China, a business source said on Sunday.

Tseng Chien-shun, secretary-general of the Taiwan Tourism Association, said both inbound and outbound travel will be affected by the new SARS cases in Taiwan and mainland China as many cautious Japanese and Taiwanese tourists will decide to stay away from Taiwan and the mainland, respectively, out of a fear of a possible new SARS outbreak.

Tseng based his argument on the fact that a large number of Japanese tourists immediately canceled their trips to Taiwan in the wake of the outbreaks of the potentially deadly epidemic in spring this year. The last time they did so was in 1999, when the Sept. 21 earthquake -- the worst in Taiwan's history -- rocked the island, he noted.

Despite an intensified government effort to attract foreign tourists with the goal of doubling the number of tourists to Taiwan by 2008, a drop in the number of Japanese tourists will undoubtedly have a negative impact on the domestic tourism industry since Japan has long been a leading source of tourists to the island.

The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications plans to send officials to Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the United States and Europe from the beginning of next year to promote Taiwan as a tourist destination, with the goal of attracting 3.2 million tourist arrivals for the whole of 2004.

At the same time, the island's outbound travel to mainland China, the most popular overseas destination among Taiwan tourists, will also be affected by the new suspected SARS case in the southern mainland province of Guangdong, said business sources from Taiwan-based tourist agencies.

According to the sources, the number of mainland-bound Taiwan tourists has steadily increased by an annual rate of more than 10 percent over the past decade. However, the SARS outbreaks earlier this year in mainland China had an unprecedented negative impact on Taiwan's tourist industry, they added.

With the new suspected SARS case in Guangdong, many Taiwan travelers will cancel or put off their trips to the mainland until the situation is adequately dealt with, the sources predicted, expressing worry that Taiwan travel agencies may face tougher times ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUP DONATES US$100,000 TO HELP IRANIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan religious group on Sunday announced a donation of US$100,000 to help Iranian earthquake victims and at the same time launched a fund raising campaign for the same cause.

Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Dhram Drum Mountain Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, said that his group will remit the donated money as soon as possible to international relief organizations for the purchase of needed materials for the quake victims.
Sheng Yen also led some 2,500 followers at a gathering to pray for the quake victims and urged the general public to join the fund raising campaign.
A strong quake hit the southeastern Iranian city of Bam on Dec. 26, claiming more than 20,000 lives and injuring another 10,000.

The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced a day earlier a donation of US$100,000 in emergency relief aid for the quake victims, while a 60-member Taiwan rescue team left for Iran to join rescue operations.

In addition to the Dhram Drum Mountain Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, various charity groups in Taiwan, including the ROC Red Cross Society and the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, are planning humanitarian aid programs to assist the quake victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONSIDERING INITIATING REFERENDUM ON EDUCATION, HEALTH INSURANCE

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is mulling over putting the controversial education reform and national health insurance premiums increase to a referendum now that the referendum bill has gone through the legislative process and is set to be promulgated into law by the president next week.

Lee Chia-chin, KMT whip at the Legislature, told CNA that the president is supposed to promulgate the bill ten days after being informed by the Legislative Yuan of its decision to reject a request by the Executive Yuan to reconsider the bill. The bill is supposed to take effect three days after being promulgated.

As the bill empowers the Legislature to initiate referendums on policies laid down by the Executive Yuan, the KMT is considering putting to a referendum the government's education reform which features the abolishment of the joint university entrance examination and its replacement with an admissions system patterned on the U.S. university system.

The changes have prompted complaints from teachers and parents of students, especially those whose children are applying for admission to universities under the new system. They have criticized the new system as expensive, troublesome, and giving universities the power to arbitrarily turn down applicants.
The KMT is also contemplating putting to a referendum the increase in national health insurance premiums and the amount paid by patients per visit to doctor.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" candidate for the presidential election set for Mar. 20, 2004, has promised during the campaign to modify the education reform by reinstating the joint university entrance examination and re-introducing uniform text books.

The increase in national health insurance premiums and doctor-visit fees was implemented by Chen Shui-bian's administration Sept. 1, 2000, without first consulting the Legislature. Lee Min-liang, the health minister at the time, claimed his office was empowered to do so at its own discretion.

The angry opposition lawmakers asked the Control Yuan -- the executive branch's top watchdog -- to intervene, which it did on July 2 by ordering the Executive Yuan to seek the Legislative Yuan's approval within two months. However, the Control Yuan later agreed to the Executive Yuan's request in September to extend the two-month deadline indefinitely.

Lee Chia-chin said the KMT is assessing the public response to the two proposals before deciding whether to flex the Legislature's muscle by calling for a referendum on the two issues. He added that hopefully, the referendum will be held simultaneously with the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS MODELS OF FILIAL PIETY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian recalled his own father while honoring seven models of "dutiful sons" in a ceremony held in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

The president said that his father helped his wife Wu Shu-chen run for a legislative seat in 1985 when he himself was at the nadir of his political career. At the time, Chen had just been defeated in the Tainan County magistrate election and had been sentenced to jail for eight months for libel, and his wife Wu Shu-chen was paralyzed from the waist down in a traffic accident.

Wu succeeded in the election, but Chen's father was diagnosed with terminal liver cancer and died four months after the election. Chen said his father didn't live long enough to see his son elected president.

The president lauded the establishment of the prize to honor the models of filial piety, saying that filial piety can improve harmony in society. He pointed out that the founder of the prize, business tycoon Wu Hsiou-chi, is himself a well-known dutiful son.
The 91-year-old Wu attended the ceremony in a wheelchair despite not feeling well. The president expressed his respect to Wu and wished him to get well soon.
After the ceremony, the president attended a trade fair for agricultural products, in Tainan City.

Speaking at the trade fair organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) , Chen touted his administration's contribution to helping the country's farmers through such measures as lowering the interest rate for loans to farmers, raising the price of purchasing rice from farmers and increasing monthly allowances to senior farmers to NT$4,000 (US$117).

Chen also claimed credit for Sunday's trade fair, saying that he ordered the CETRA to promote sales of Taiwan's agricultural products overseas in addition to exploring markets for the country's information products to cushion the impact brought about by the country's entry into the World Trade Organization.
The president tasted the fruits displayed at the fair and drew lots to select the winner of a television set prize offered by the organizer to visitors.
CETRA Chairman Hsu Chih-ren said this is the ninth trade fair of its kind organized and held this year in Taiwan by the council.
Employing the method used to promote sales of Taiwan's computers, CETRA has succeeded in helping Taiwan's agricultural products sell in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADBAND PREVAILS AMONG INTERNET HOUSEHOLDS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Some 73 percent of Taiwan households that have access to the Internet are broadband users, according to the results of a survey released by the Institute for Information Industry Sunday.

The survey, commissioned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, showed that 57 percent of households in Taiwan have access to the Internet, or up 15 percentage points from the level seen in a similar survey in 2002. Of these households, 73 percent are broadband users, up 33 percentage points from the 2001 ratio.
Of the broadband household users, some 66 percent go online via xDSL, while only 4 percent do so via regular phone line, a fall from 10 percent in 2002, according to the survey.

Among the broadband Internet households, 20 percent of the respondents said they have broadband mainly to meet their children's Internet surfing needs, while 19 percent cited their own information search needs, and 16 percent mentioned the need to download large amounts of data.
According to the survey, broadband Internet households go online 22.6 days per month, spending an average of 16.9 hours per week online. Their average monthly bill is NT$1,083 (US$31.85).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUPS RUSH AID TO QUAKE STRICKEN IRAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tehran, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 19-member group from the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation of Tzu Chi, Taiwan's largest charity organization, arrived in Tehran, Iran at around 2 a.m. Monday to aid in relief work for Iranian earthquake victims.

The southeastern Iranian city of Bam was hit by a deadly earthquake in the early morning of last Friday. The death toll stood at about 25,000 as of Monday, and Iranian officials have said that it could eventually rise to as high as 30,000. Bam is located about 1,000 kilometers southeast of the Iranian capital Tehran.

The members of the Tzu Chi relief group, who came from Taiwan, Jordan and Turkey, separately, are preparing to depart for Bam Monday morning, bringing the foundation's first batch of relief supplies, including 100 medical supply kits, 11,000 blankets, as well as food supplies and bottled water, to those injured or made homeless by the earthquake.

As temperatures in Bam have dropped to as low as minus 6 degrees Celsius in recent nights, the Tzu Chi group is taking tents and sleeping bags for themselves in order to be able to remain in the disaster area for a longer period of time.
Meanwhile, a 60-member Taiwan rescue team left for Iran Saturday evening to join search and rescue operations in the ancient Iranian city of Bam.

The team, comprised of professional rescue workers from the National Fire Administration and Taipei City Government, has had experience in search and rescue work in post-disaster areas in Indonesia and El Salvador.

A relief group from World Vision Taiwan is scheduled to arrive in Tehran Tuesday morning, bringing its first batch of relief supplies, including blankets, bottled water and medicine. The relief supplies total about US$25,000 in value, according to a spokesman for the charity organization.

The ROC Red Cross Society said Saturday that it has sent messages to Iran's Red Crescent Society and the Geneva-based International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, offering to send rescue and medical professionals as well as relief supplies to help the Iranian earthquake victims. The Red Cross Society said it will initially send 30 trained rescue workers to Iran.
The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs also announced Saturday that the government will donate US$100,000 in emergency relief aid to help the Iranian quake victims.

Another Taiwan religious and philanthropic group, the Dhram Drum Mountain Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, announced on Sunday a donation of US$100,000 to help the quake victims and at the same time launched a fund raising campaign for the same cause.

Foundation founder, Master Sheng Yen, who visited the Middle East earlier this month to spread the message of peace, said that his group will remit the donated money as soon as possible to international relief organizations for the purchase of needed materials for the quake victims.

The Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society said Saturday that it has maintained close contact with major Islamic groups in Iran as they have been jointly planning a seminar on Buddhist-Islam exchanges to be held in Iran in 2004. "We'll announce concrete post-quake aid programs after discussing the matter with Iranian Islamic groups, " a spokesman for the organization said.

The Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps said it has expressed its concerns about the Iranian disaster victims through an Iranian non-government organization known as the ODBVV. "We'll evaluate the feasibility of offering medical aid after receiving a report from the ODBVV about the medical needs in the quake-affected region, " the group's founder Liu Chi-chun said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 29, or the seventh day of the 12th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."
